na-ba-sa6 simug| Nabasa, the smith(?), 
u3 ur-szu-ga-lam-ma| and Ur-šugalama, 
i3-gal2| are here.

pisan-dub-ba| Basket-of-tablets:  
e2-usz-bar| weaving house, 
i3-gal2| are here; 
2(disz) udu abul bara2 {d}utu| 1 sheep, city gate, dais of Utu; 
2(disz) udu abul {d}ba-ba6| 2 sheep, city gate of Baba; 
2(disz) udu abul e2-gal| 2 sheep, city gate, palace; 
2(disz) udu abul {d}nansze| 2 sheep, city gate of Nanše; 
1(disz) udu e2-unu{ki}-sze3| 1 sheep, House-of-Uruk; 
1(disz) udu ga2 ma2-gur8-ra {d}nin-gesz-zi-da| 1 sheep, cabin of the barge of Ningešzida; 
1(disz) udu {d}gu3-de2-a| 1 sheep, Gudea; 
1(disz) udu ur-{d}lamma ensi2| 1 sheep, Ur-Lamma, the governor; 
siskur2 ga gu7-sze3| offering for milk-feeding; 
giri3 a-kal-la lu2-inim-ma| via Akalla, man of testimony; 
zi-ga ki lugal-nam2-mah| booked out of the place of Lugal-nammaḫ; 
iti ezem-{d}dumu-zi u4 1(u) 6(disz)-kam| month: “Festival of Dumuzi,” day 16,
mu ma2-gur8-mah ba-dim2| year: “Great-barge was fashioned.” 
3(gesz2) la2 1/2(disz) geme2| 180 less 1/2 female laborers, 
iti mu-szu-du7-ta| from month: “musudu,” 
iti sze-il2-la-sze3| to month: “Grain-carried,” 
mu {d}i-bi2-{d}suen lugal| year: “Ibbi-Suen (is) king,” 
2(gesz2) 5(u) 1(disz) geme2| 171 female laborers, 
iti GAN2-masz-ta| from month: “GANmaš,” 
iti ezem-{d}ba-ba6-sze3| to month: “Festival of Baba,” 
mu en {d}inanna unu{ki} masz2-e i3-pa3| year: “The high-priest of Inanna with extispicy was named,” 
a2-bi 1(szar'u) 7(szar2) 2(gesz'u) 3(gesz2) geme2 u4 1(disz)-sze3| the labor: 62,580 workdays, female laborers;
lu2-{d}nin-gir2-su dumu ur-{d}nansze| Lu-Ningirsu, son of Ur-Nanše; 
iti 1(u) 2(disz)-kam| (period) of 12 months, 
mu en {d}inanna unu{ki}-ga masz2-e i3-pa3| year: “The high-priest of Inanna with extispicy was named.”

kiszib3 ur-sa6-ga nu-banda3 su-su-dam| under seal of Ur-saga, manager, to be repaid; 
dam-gar3-ne-bi gi-ne2-dam| the trade agents will confirm; 
mu {d}amar-{d}suen lugal| year: “Amar-Suen (is) king.” 
ur-sa6-ga| Ur-saga 
nu-banda3| manager 
gu-za-la2| of throne bearers.

2(disz) gin2 ku3-babbar| 2 shekels of silver, 
sze-bi 2(asz) 2(barig) gur| its barley 2 gur 2 barig; 
buru14 ama-bi gi4-gi4 su3-su3-da| the harvest will remit this debt, should (it) be inundated; 
ba-a-mu| Ba’amu 
mu lugal-bi in-pa3| by the royal name has sworn; 
ki {d}nanna-i3-gi-ta| from Nanna-igi 
ba-a-mu| did Ba’amu 
szu ba-ti| receive; 
iti me-gi8-gal2| month “Mekigal,” 
mu en {d}nanna masz2-e i3-pa3| year: “The en priestess of Nanna by omens was chosen.” 
2(disz) gin2 ku3-babbar| 2 shekels of silver, 
sze-bi 2(asz) 2(barig) gur| its barley 2 gur 2 barig; 
buru14 ama-bi gi4-gi4 su3-su3-da| the harvest will remit this debt, should (it) be inundated; 
mu lugal-bi in-pa3| by the royal name he has sworn; 
ki {d}nanna-i3-gi-ta| from Nanna-igi 
ba-a-mu szu ba-ti| did Ba’amu receive;

1(disz) gu-u2-gu| 1 Gu’ugu, 
ARAD2 ur-{d}nun-gal-ka| slave of Ur-Nungal, 
ba-an-da-zah3| fled; 
mu-dab5| he was captured 
igi-ni in-gar| and presented. 
mu lugal u4 a-ra2 2(disz)-ka| [By] the royal name, “When a 2nd time 
i3-zah3-de3-na| I flee, 
ga-hul bi2-in-du11| may I be destroyed,” he said. 
1(disz) lugal-a2-zi-da| 1 Lugal-azida, 
1(disz) a-ba-{d}en-lil2-gin7| 1 Aba-Enlil-gin, 
1(disz) i-di3| 1 Iddi, 
di-ku5-bi-me| are the judges, 
dumu nibru{ki}| son(s) of Nippur; 
mu {d}amar-{d}suen lugal| year: “Amar Suen is king.” 
3(asz) sze gur| 3 gur barley, 
sze ur5-ra {d}en-lil2-la2| barley loan (of the temple household) of Enlil, 
ki amar-szuba2-ta| from Amar-šuba 
lugal-pa-e3 gu-za-la2| did Lugal-pa’e, the throne bearer, 
szu ba-ti| receive; 
buru14 ama-bi gi4-gi4| the harvest the obligation will discharge; 
iti sig4-ka i3-ib2-gi4-gi4| in the month “Brick” it will be remitted; 
a-sza3-mu a-e3 ba-rex(HU)| “My field by flooding was ruined!,” or 
a-sza3-mu u3-de3 ba-rex(HU)| “My field by the storm was ruined!” 
ba-ra-ab-be2-en3| you will not say!; 
iti udru{duru5}| month “udru,” 
mu hu-hu-nu-ri ba-hul| year “Ḫuḫnuri was destroyed.”

u3 sze u4-de3 de6-a ri-ri-ga|  and barley to the day delivered, fallen; 
a-sza3 ka-ma-ri2{ki}|  (in the) field of Kamari, 
a-sza3 {d}szara2|  field of Šara, 
u3 a-sza3 la2-mah|  and field of Lamaḫ; 
ki a-du-ta|  from Adu, 
kiszib3 a-du-mu|  under seal of Adumu; 
mu ma2 {d}en-ki ba-ab-du8|  year: “The boat of Enki was caulked.” 
ur-{d}suen|  Ur-Suen, 
dub-sar|  scribe, 
dumu ur-{gesz}gigir sza3-tam|  son of Ur-gigir; official (seal). 
1(disz) szah2-gesz-gi| 1 reed thicket pig, 
sza3-gal-bi 1(disz) sila3-ta| the fodder 1 sila3 each (day), 
iti szu-numun-ta u4 1(u) 5(disz) ba-zal-la| from month “Sowing,” completed 15th day, 
iti {d}dumu-zi-sze3| to month “Dumuzi,” 
ki ur-{d}szul-pa-e3-ta| from Ur-Šulpa’e, 
kiszib3 ensi2-ka| under seal of the governor, 
mu hu-uh2-nu-ri{ki} ba-hul| year: “Ḫuḫnuri was destroyed.” 
{d}amar-{d}suen| Amar-Suen,
nita kal-ga| strong man,
lugal uri5{ki}-ma| king of Ur,
lugal an-ub-da limmu2-ba| king of heaven with its four corners:
ur-{d}li9-si4| Ur-Lisi,
ensi2| governor
umma{ki}| of Umma,
ARAD2-zu| is your servant. 
enuru{+e2-nu-ru}| enuru: 
lu2-ra musz mu-ra gir2 mu-ra ur mu2-da mu-ra| A man a snake struck, a scorpion struck, a rabid dog struck, 
usz-bi mu-na-ab-szum2| their spittle gave. 
{d}asar:lu2-hi-e| Asarluḫi 
a-ni {d}en-ki-sze3 lu2 mu-szi-gi4-gi4| to his father Enki a messenger sends: 
a-mu lu2-ra musz mu-ra gir2 mu-ra ur mu2-da mu-ra| “My father, a man a snake struck, a scorpion struck, a rabid dog struck,
usz-bi mu-na-ab-szum2| their spittle gave; 
a-na ib2-ak-na-bi nu-zu| what to do about it, I don't know.” 
dumu-mu a-na nu-zu| “My son, what don't you know? 
a-na na-ab-dah-e| What can I add? 
a-la2-ku3-ga na-ba-ni-zalag| His silver ala is purified; 
a-be2 nam-szub u3-ma-szum2| once to the water the incantation is given, 
a-bi lu2 kur2-ra u3-mu-ni-nag| the water the ‘foreigner’ made to drink, 
usz-bi ni2-ba ha-mu-ta-e3-de2| may the spittle on its own go out!” 
lu2 musz zu2 ba-du3 a-bi lu2 kur2-ra na8-na8-da-kam| A man by a snake bitten: the water the ‘foreigner’ is to be given to drink. 
2(disz) 1/2(disz) ma-na 4(disz) gin2 la2 1(u) 5(disz) sze ku3-babbar| 2 1/2 mana 4 shekels less 15 grains silver, 
si-i3-tum nig2-ka9-ak-a| remainder of the account, 
hu-bi2-dam dam-gar3| against Ḫubidam, the trade agent, 
in-da-gal2| exists; 
su-su-dam| it is to be repaid; 
giri3 ki-tusz-lu2 dub-sar| via Ki-tuš-lu, the scribe, 
u3 sipa-inim-gi-na| and Sipa-inim-gina; 
mu us2-sa a-ra2 3(disz)-kam si-mu-ru-um{ki} ba-hul| year following: “For the 3rd time Simurrum was destroyed.”

gurusz 6(disz)-am3 a2 buru14 mu 2(disz)-kam| The male laborers are 6: labor of harvest, of two years, 
ku3-bi 1(disz) 1/2(disz) gin2| ist silver: 1 1/2 shekels; 
gurusz 1(u) 2(disz)-am3 a2 en-te-na| The male laborers are 12: labor of wintertime, 
ku3-bi 2(disz) gin2| its silver: 2 shekels; 
ku3-bi n 1/3(disz) gin2| the silver: n + 1/3 shekel 
lu2-nin-nu-musz-da-ka-ra| of Lu-Ninnumušda 
in-na-la2-e| he will weigh out; 
iti szu-numun-ta u4 1(u)-am3 ba-ra-zal| from month: Sowing, day 10 completed; 
1(disz) da-ti dumu lugal-sa6| 1 Dati, son of Lugal-sa, 
1(disz) me-a-a ha-za-num2| 1 Me-aya, the mayor, 
1(disz) inim-ma-dingir dam-gar3| 1 Inima-dingir, the trade agent, 
1(disz) ur-{d}nu-musz-da| 1 Ur-Numušda, 
lu2 ki-ba gub-ba-me| are men at the place stationed; 
di til-la dumu umma{ki}| complete legal matter, son of Umma; 
mu {d}amar-{d}suen lugal-e ur-bi2-lum{ki} mu-hul| year: “Amar-Suen, the king, Urbilum destroyed.” 
1(disz) gurusz  u4 4(disz)-sze3 kar umma{ki}-ta| 1(?) male laborer for 4 workdays, from Umma-harbor 
iri-sa12-rig7{ki}-sze3 ma2 gid2-da| to Irisagrig barge punted, 
u4 1(disz)-sze3 sze bala-a u3 sze ma2-a si-ga| for 1 workday barley transferred and barley in the barge loaded, 
iri-sa12-rig7{ki}-ta| from Irisagrig 
u4 2(disz)-sze3 kun-zi-da {gesz}kiri6 gesztin-sze3 ma2 gid2-da| two workdays to reservoir of Vineyard barge punted, 
u4 1(disz)-sze3 e2-duru5 uri3-ru2-a-ka sze bala-a| for 1 workday at Uriru-village barley transferred, 
u4 7(disz)-sze3 e2-duru5 szesz du3-a-ta kun-zi-da i7 {d}amar-{d}suen-ni-tum-sze3| for 7 workdays from Uriru-village to reservoir of Amar-Suenītum canal 
sze ga6-ga2| barley carried, 
kun-zi-da i7 {d}amar-{d}suen-ni-tum-ta| from reservoir of Amar-Suenītum canal 
u4 2(disz)-sze3 iri-sa12-rig7-sze3| for 2 workdays to Irisagrig 
ma2 gid2-da u3 bala ak| barge punted and transfer done; 
u4 2(disz)-sze3 iri-sa12-rig7{ki}-ta| for 2 workdays from Irisagrig 
ka da-mi-ma-ma-sze3 ma2 gid2-da| to mouth of Damimama barge punted,

u4 1(disz)-sze3 ma2 ba-al-la| for 1 workday barge unloaded; 
u4 1(disz)-sze3 sze bala-a| for 1 workday barley transferred;

kiszib3 a-du-mu| under seal of Adumu; 
mu ma2 {d}en-ki ba-ab-du8| year: “The boat of Enki was caulked.”

1(disz) dumu-munus da-da nu-zah3-am3| It was (the case) that the daughter of Dada did not escape. 
ensi2-ke4| The governor 
i7-pa-e3 en3 in-na-an-tar| (about this) Ipa’e asked. 
i3-zah3 in-na-an-du11| “She escaped,” (Ipa’e) told him. 
ki-bi-ta nu-tuku4 mu-gub| (But) from that place she did not move, she stayed there. 
ensi2-ra| (With) the governor 
du11-ga-ni si nu-un-na-an-sa2| his statement did (Ipa’e) not put in order;
iti sze-kar-ra-gal2-la| month “Barley brought to the harbor,” 
mu {d}szu-{d}suen lugal uri5{ki}-ma-ke4 ma-da za-ab-sza-li{ki} mu-hul| year: “Šū-Suen, king of Ur, the lands of Zabšali destroyed.” 
i7-pa-e3| Ipa’e, 
dub-sar| scribe, 
dumu lu2-{d}szara2| son of Lu-Šara, 
sa12-du5| the field registrar.

zi3 ma2-ta ba-al| flour unloaded from the barge,

sanga-ne-sze3| for the temple administrators,

dub-sar| scribe, 
dumu lugal-ma2-gur8-re| son of Lugal-magure.

ki-la2-bi 9(disz) ma-na 1(u) 5(disz) gin2| their weight: 9 ma-na and 15 shekels,

ur-{d}nin-gesz-zi-da| Ur-Ningešzida
szu ba-ti| received. 
giri3 gu3-de2-a sza13-dub-ba| Conveyor: Gudea the chief accountant;

mu hu-uh2-nu-ri{ki} ba-hul| Year: “Ḫuḫnuri was destroyed.” 
3(u) 5(disz) {uruda}ha-bu3-da| 35 copper hoes, 
ki-la2-bi 9(disz) ma-na 1(u) 5(disz) gin2| their weight: 9 ma-na and 15 shekels, 
ba-zi-ir| (they) were smelted down. 
ki lugal-im-ru-a-ta| From Lugal-imrua 
ur-{d}nin-gesz-zi-da szu ba-ti| Ur-Ningešzida received. 
giri3 gu3-de2-a sza13-dub-ba| Conveyor: Gudea the chief accountant; 
giri3 lu2-{d}nin-gir2-su szabra-e2| Conveyor: Lu-Ningirsu the chief household administrator. 
iti ezem-{d}dumu-zi| Month: “Festival of Dumuzi.” 
mu hu-uh2-nu-ri{ki} ba-hul| Year: “Ḫuḫnuri was destroyed.” 
lu2-{d}nin-gir2-su| Lu-Ningirsu,
dub-sar| scribe, 
dumu ARAD2-mu| child of ARADmu.

1(disz) gin2 ku3-babbar| 1 shekel silver, 
a2 ur-{d}iszkur| labor of Ur-Iškur, 
ki lugal-a2-zi-da-ta| from Lugal-azida 
geme2-{d}nun-gal-ke4| did Geme-Nungal 
u3 szu-dur-ul3 dumu-ni| and Šu-durul, her son, 
szu ba-ti-esz2| receive; 
igi ur-{d}iszkur| before Ur-Iškur, 
igi dumu ur-{d}suen| before the son of Ur-Suen, 
igi lu2-{d}iszkur| before Lu-Iškur, 
igi tul2-ta dumu lugal-he2-gal2| before Tulta, son of Lugal-ḫegal 
tukum-bi| if 
ga2-la ba-dag| there is a work loss, 
sze 6(disz) sila3-ta a-ag2-dam| barley, 6 sila3 per (day) will be measured out, 
mu lugal-bi in-pa3| did he the royal name invoke; 
iti sze-sag11-ku5| month: “Harvest,” 
mu ma2-gur8-mah {d}en-lil2-la2 ba-ab-du8| year: “The Big-Barge of Enlil was caulked.” 
szu-tu-ul| Šutul, 
dumu geme2-{d}nun-gal| son of Geme-Nungal. 
geme2-{d}nin-gal| Geme-Ningal, 
dumu ba-gi-na| son of Bagina. 
sze {d}en-lil2-la2| barley for (the temple household) of Enlil, 
ki-ba se-ge-de3| to be stored in that place, 
ki lugal-nam-tar-re-ta| from Lugal-namtare 
ur-{d}ha-ia3-ke4| did Ur-Ḫaya 
szu ba-ti| receive; 
iti diri sze-sag11-ku5| the extra month “Harvest,” 
mu en-mah-gal-an-na en {d}inanna ba-hun| year: “En-maḫgal-ana as en priestess of Innana was installed.” 
sze-bi buru14 ama-bi gi4-gi4| the harvest will remit this barley (debt) 
e2 {d}en-lil2-la2-ka| into the household of Enlil 
i3-ni-kux(KWU636)-kux(KWU636)-a| which he is entering; 
a-sza3-mu u4-de3 ba-ab-de3| That “My field by the storm was ruined!”, or 
a-e ba-ab-de3| “by flood water was ruined!” 
lugal-ra u3 sanga nu-un-na-be2-a| to the king or to the chief administrator he will not say, 
mu lugal-bi in-pa3| by the royal name he swore. 
ur-{d}ha-ia3| Ur-Ḫaya, 
dub-sar| scribe, 
dumu engar-du10| son of Engar-du, 
sagi| cupbearer. 
ur-{d}nusku| Ur-Nusku:
igi-4(disz)-gal2| 1/4,
ur-{d}utu| Ur-Utu,
igi-4(disz)-gal2| 1/4,
lu-lu dumu x-alim| Lullu, the son of x-alim:
igi 8(disz)-gal2| 1/8,
ur-e-kur2-ra| Ur-ekura:
igi 8(disz)-gal2| 1/8,
ARAD2-du10| ARADdu:
igi 8(disz)-gal2| 1/8,
ur-{d}szu-mah| Ur-Šumaḫ:
igi 1(u)-gal2| 1/10,
ur-{d}en-lil2-la2| Ur-Enlila:
igi 2(u)-gal2| 1/20,
dam-gar3-me| they are trade agents.
6. iti sig4-ga-ta| In the month ‘of the bricks’
u4 6(disz) zal-la-a| (3rd month) from the end of the 6th day,

1(disz) gurusz u4 4(disz)-sze3| 1(?) male laborer, for 4 workdays, 
kar umma{ki}-ta iri-sa12-rigx(PA.MUNUS.HUB2.DU){ki}-sze3 ma2 gid2-da| from Umma-harbor to Irisagrig barge punted, 
u4 1(disz)-sze3 sze ma2-a si-ga| for 1 workday barley into the barge loaded, 
iri-sa12-rigx(PA.MUNUS.HUB2.DU){ki}-ta| from Irisagrig  
u4 2(disz)-sze3 kun-zi-da {gesz}kiri6 gesztin-sze3 ma2 gid2-da| two workdays to reservoir of Vineyard barge punted, 
u4 8(disz)-sze3 e2-duru5 uri3-ru2-a-ka sze bala-a| for 8 workday at Uriru-village barley transferred, 
kun-zi-da i7 {d}amar-{d}suen-ni-tum-sze3 sze ga6-ga2| to reservoir of Amar-Suenītum canal barley carried, 
kun-zi-da i7 {d}amar-{d}suen-ni-tum-ta| from reservoir of Amar-Suenītum canal

na-ni| (To) Nanni 
u3-na-a-du11| speak: 
masz-gu-la-ra| "To Mašgula 
1(gesz2) sze gur| 60 gur barley 
szum2-mu-da| to give 
he2-na-du11| I did tell him.
a-na-asz-am3| Why 
nu-u3-na-szum2| did he not give it to him? 
he2-na-ab-szum2-mu| He must give it to him! 
inim-bi na-ba-ab-gur-re| He should not bring up this issue again!". 
ba-zi| To Bazi
u3-na-a-du11| speak:

u3-na-du11| say

1(asz) {gesz}gigir e2-UMBINxLU 2(disz)| “1 2-wheeled transport wagon

1(asz) {gesz}gigir e2-UMBINxLU 2(disz)| 1 2-wheeled transport wagon 
al-gal2| is available;

lu2 kin-gi4-a-ka-ni| After his (my lord’s) messenger 
u3-mu-gi4| has returned, 
ha-ma-ab-szum2-mu| may he (my lord) have him (Bazizi) give it to me! 
ARAD2 kal-ga-ni-me-en6| His (my lord’s) strong servant am I; 
ga-na sza3-mu he2-eb2-hul2-le| come now, may my gut be happy! 
im sar-ra-bi| The written document of this case 
igi-ni-sze3 he2-gal2| should be before him (Bazizi)! 
ur5-e gesztu2-ga-na| In this way to his mind 
he2-na-ni-ib2-ru-gu2| it should this be made clear! 
u3 ga2-e sza3-ga-ni ab-hul2-le-en6| Then I will myself make his (my lord’s) gut happy!

a-na {d}na3 en-mah a-szib e2-zi-da| To Nabu, exalted lord, who dwells in Ezida,
sza2 sza3 nina{ki} en-szu2 {disz}{d}aszszur-du3-ibila man kur aszszur| which is in Nineve, his lord: (I) Assurnasirpal, king of Assyria
i-risz-ti hi-szah-ti dingir-ti-szu2 gal-ti| the one who is longed for and destined by his great divinity,
sza2 ina gar i-ku-szu2 u in ur-ti-szu2 dugud-ti| who, at the issuing of his order and the giving of his solemn decree
ina mit-hu-s,i bad5-bad5 ku5-su sag-du {disz}te-um-man| (after) defeating (him) in battle, cut off the head of Teumman,
man {kur}elam{ki} u {disz}um-man-i-gasz {disz}tam-ma-ri-tu| king of Elam. And Ummanigash, Tammaritu,
{disz}pa-a'-e {disz}um-man-al-dasz sza2 egir {disz}te-um-man| Pa'e, Ummanaldash, who before Teumman
du3-szu2 man-ut {kur}elam{ki} ina qi2-bi-ti-szu2 gal-ti| exercised kingship over Elam, by his great command
qa-ti kur-su-nu-ti-ma ina {gesz}sza2 sza2-da-di| he captured them. To my sedan chair,
ru-kub pirig3-ti-ia la2-su-nu-ti| my royal conveyance, I yoked them.
u ina tukul-ti-szu2 gal-ti ina kul-lat nigin kur kur| with his great help in all the lands,
gar gar-nu si-mat ina u4-me-szu kisal e2 {d}na3| I established order. At that time, the court of the house of Nabu,
en-ia2 ina pi-i-li esz-qi2 szi-kit-ta-szu2| my lord, with massive limestone, its construction,
u2-rab-bi ana szat-ti {d}na3 ha-disz igi-bar-ma| I enlarged. May Nabu look joyfully upon it.
lim-ma-hir igi-uk-ka ina ti-kip santak4-ki-ka| May he find it acceptable in the impression of its wedges.
ki-e-ni tin u4-mesz egir-mesz li-s,a-a| May the order for a life of long days come forth
szap-tuk-ka du-du-ku e2-zi-da| from your lips. Walking in Ezida
ina igi dingir-ti-ka li-lab-bi-ra giri3-a-a| in your divine presence, may my path grow old.

bala im-ma su-ga-ta| From the bala(-obligation) of the last year that was repaid 
gi-zi ze2-de3| to cut fresh reeds 
usz-mu| Ušĝu 
ensi2-ke4| the governor 
a2 in-da-ag2| ordered, 
gi-zi-bi| (but) these fresh reeds 
nu-un-ze2| he did not cut. 
1(szar'u) sa gi-zi| 36,000 bundles of fresh reed: 
im ba-a-sze-en6 ba-hul| rain fell (and) they were destroyed. 
usz-mu en3-bi nu-un-tar| Ušĝu did not make an inquiry, 
ga2-la bi2-in-dag| he neglected that.

gesz la-ba-an-tuku-am3| he did not obey;

igi musz-husz igi lu2-ulu3 musz-husz| The dragon-face (is) the dragon-face of a man, 
igi lu2 nig2-hul-dim2-ma musz-husz| the dragon-face of a man causing evil 
an-ne2 ba-te im szeg3-szeg3| approached heaven (and) the clouds bring (no) rain. 
ki-a ba-te {u2}szim nu-mu2-mu2| He approached the earth, and the plants do not grow. 
gu4-e ba-te {gesz}szudul5-bi im-du8| He approached the ox, and its yoke does not open.
e2-tur3-e ba-te ga-ra-bi im-ta-kum-kum| He approached the stall and smashes its cheese-pot. 
inim gar-ra ha-ba-an-dib-dib| Utterances have passed by.
gurusz-ra mu-na-te ib2-la2 mu-da-an-gaz| He approached the lad and sapped his (sexual) energies, 
sikil-ra mu-na-te tug2 mu-da-an-szub| he approached the maiden and tossed away her towel. 
um-me-da dumu-da mu-na-te lirum-bi mu-e-du8| He approached the nurse with the child - her arms were torn apart.
SAR.SAR-e ba-te i-iz za3-hi-li im-hul| He approached the vegetables - lettuce and cress became bad.
pu2 {gesz}kiri6 ba-te gurun im-hul| He approached the garden, the fruit became bad.
igi kur-ra kur-ta nam-ta-an-e3| The eye of the mountain came out from the mountain,
szeg9-bar-re si-musz-bi nam-ta-an-e3| The wild ram let its shining horns come out.
igi hul igi gig-ga he2-tar| May the evil eye (like?) the sick eye be cut off.
{kusz}a-ga2-la2-gin7 he2-dar| May it split open like a leather bag.
{dug}sila3-bur-zi bahar2-ka tilla2-a he2-gaz-gaz| May it go to pieces (like) the potter's bur-zi-pot on the market place.
gub-bu-da-ba gub-bu-da-ba| While standing, while standing,
ka e-sir2-ra-ka gub-bu-da-ba| while standing at the mouth? of the street,
szul dingir nu-tuku gaba im-ma-an-ri| it opposes the young man who has no personal god.
igi lil2-am3 he2-sig3-ge| Let the eye turn into a wind.
{d}asar-e abzu-a| Asar in Abzu,
nam-mu-un-da-bur2-e| may he not undo it!

i3-ne-esz2 u4-da nig2-ki-szar2-ra-ke4| Now, today(?) that of the horizon/entire earth (everything?), 
lugal kalam-ma en {d}nin-urta-ra su3-u4-bi mu-un-hul2-e-esz| The kings of the homeland profoundly rejoiced for Ninurta 
GAN2-ne2 sze gu-nu-a mi-ni-in-si| The field ripened with/placed barley 
pu2 {gesz}kiri6-ke4 szu im-mi-in-il2| The harvest of the irrigated orchard yielded (fruit) 
guru7 du6-de3 gu2 im-mi-in-gur-gur| He heaped up the grain piles 
en-e kalam-x kar im-ta-an-e11| The lord brought up harbors/trading colonies from within the land 
dingir-re-e-ne ur5-bi mu-un-sa6| He made the mood of the gods pleasant 
{d}nin-urta a-a-ni {d}en-lil2-le me-tesz2 me-i-i-ne| And they were praising Ninurta and his father Enlil(?) 
u4-bi-a munus-ra arhusz-a sa2 nam-ga-mu-ni-ib2-du11| At that time he also reached (a) compassion(ate state) for the woman 
siki u8 dugud-gin7 bar-ra bi2-in-dul| She made her hair cover her back like a heavy (i.e. unshorn?) ewe(?) 
i-lu kur giri3 nu-gal2-la-ba gal-gal-bi mi-ni-ib2-be2| She was greatly intoning a lament in the mountain that had not been stepped on/had no trails 
ur-sag gal an-gin7| The hero who, like An in his anger, his might no one approaches 
u4 sur2 ki-a gen usz11| The furious storm that moves upon the earth, depositing(?) poison on its “chest” 
en szi {d}mu-ul-lil2-la2| Lord, the “life”(?) of Enlil, of whom the crown is appropriate upon his head 
dingir-mah inim diri-ga hul gig| Digirmah, who hates excessive speech 
munus zi nin-hur-sag ki-sikil| The true lady, Ninhursag, the young woman 
te-mu-da nin me mah ma-ra-an-szum2 za-e he2-em-il2-e| Draw near(?), lady, I(!) have given you supreme cosmic powers so that you shall be exalted/shall wield them 
munus zi me-ni me diri-ga nin nagar-sza3-ga| True lady(!?), her cosmic powers surpass (other) cosmic powers, lady, “carpenter of the womb” 
{d}a-ru-ru nin gal {d}en-lil2-la2 gaba-na ba-e-gub| Aruru, the elder sister of Enlil, stood at his front 
ur-sag gal ur-sag ug5-ga-za| "Great hero, when you killed the hero 
u3-mu-un a-a-ni-gin7 du11-ga-ni nu-kur2-ru na-ag2 nu-um-mi-tar| Lord, who like his father his utterance cannot be changed, you have not (yet) decreed a fate” 
en ib2-ba kalam-ma inim mu-na-ni-ib-be2| In the homeland, the angry lord(?) spoke a word to him 
{d}nin-urta en dumu {d}en-lil2-la2-ke4 asz2 im-mi-ib2-sar-re| Ninurta, lord, son of Enlil was cursing him 
{na4}u2 kur-ra ma-an-zi-ge-en-na-gin7| Emery stone, you who (the Asag) mustered against me in the mountain 
nam ug5-ge-gu10 ba-e-ku5-da-gin7| As one who swore to commit(?) my murder 
en {d}nin-urta-me-en ki-tusz mah-ga2 ba-e-hu-luh-en-na-gin7| As one who terrified me, lord Ninurta, in my own supreme dwelling 
kal-ga sul e2-gar8 tuku diri-ga-zu alan-zu he2-em-ta-be4| Mighty one, youth possessed of form, your surpassing(ness) and you stature shall be diminished 
nemur usu-bi-ta nir gal2-la-am3 he2-me-zi-ir-zi-re-ne| Leopards that rely on their strength shall tear you up

a-zu gal u2 nam-ti-la me-zu nag nam-ti-la me-zu| "Great physician, you know the plant of life, [you know] the potion (?) [of life],
iri-bi dili-dili bir-bir szu-bi {d}utu di-ku5 u3 an ku3 x KA na-ah-he2-esz| To scatter their cities one by one, Utu, the judge (?), and pure An ordered (?).
an-ku3-ga gal-bi inim ka-na nu-mu-un-{ti-il}til-le-e-de3 = %a {d}a-nu el-lu zi-kir pi-i-szu2 la ga-ma-ru| Holy An, the great words of his mouth are not to be abrogated. 
dingir gal-gal-e-ne ul-la a-ra-zu-ga2 {zu}zub-bi-gin7 ba-an-gur2-ru-usz = %a dingir-mesz gal-mesz ina an-nim tas-li-tu4 gam-li-isz ik-tan-szu2-usz| The great gods bow down to him, like a curved staff, in approval of and in prayer to him.  
ba-e-du11-ga zi-da nun en ka-ba-a-ni ba-a-{du}du11-ga-zu e-sze = %a taq-bi-ma ki-na-at ru-bu-u2 be-lu4 e-pisz pi-i-szu2 taq-bi ma-ag-rat| What you command is just. (Like) what a prince or lord has uttered, what you have commanded is obeyed. 
an du11-ga mah-zu sag ba-du ul-la mu-lu im-me = %a {d}a-nu qi2-bit-ka s,ir-tu4 ina mah-ri il-lak ul-la man-nu i-qab-bi| An, your lofty command takes precedence, who would say No to you? 
a-a dim3-me-er-e-ne-ke4 {en}inim-zu an-ki-a te-me-en-bi dingir na-me nu-sze = %a a-bi dingir-mesz a-mat-ka te-me-en an-e u ki-tim a-a-u2 dingir le-em-ma| Father of the gods, your word, the foundation of heaven and earth, no god fails to heed it.  
en mas-su3 usz gar ni2-te-na-me-en {sa}sa2-gar{ga-ar}-me te-am3 = %a be-el mas-su-u2 ma-lik ra-ma-ni-sza2 at-ta mi-lik-ni mi-i-nu| Lord, you are the leader who takes only his own counsel, what should be our counsel? 
ki-sikil {d}inanna hi-li-bi mu-un-szi-in-kar-ra {a}a2-zu a-ri-a-an-szi-ib = %a ana ar-da-tu4 {d}isz-tar sza2 te-em-nu-szi id-ka i-din-szi| Grant your strength to the maiden Ištar, whom you have loved.   
na-nam gi-na-zu an-gin7 ze2-eb-be2-da da-gan-me-a zu-zu-ab-ta = %a an-na-ka ki-na sza2 ki-ma an-e kab-tu4 ina pu-uh-ri-ni ud-di-szi| Your reliable approval, weighty as heaven, make known (to her) in our assembly.  
{d}in-nin dim3-me-er hi-li-bi mu-un-szi-in-kar-ra me-tesz2-zu szum2-mu-un-na-ab = %a ana {d}min i-lat te-em-nu-szi hi-im-mat par-s,i-ka szu-ut-{li}lim-szi| Give to the mistress, whom you have loved, your combined divine powers.   
{d}ki-szar2 {ni-id-la-am}gidlam e-da-sa2 he2-na-nam mu-zu-a nir he2-{ga}galam-galam{ga-la-ma} = %a lu-u2 an-tum hi-ir-tu4 szin-na-at-ka szi-ma ana szu-me-ka li-te-et-li| Let Kišar truly be the spouse equal with you, may she rise to the (equivalent) authority of your name.  
ug3-{gu}ga2 u3-bi2-tab a2-ag2 {d}en-lil2 {d}en-ki-ke4 szu-na he2-en-da-ab-tum2-tum2-mu{x-(x)-x-x} = %a li-is,-s,ib ap-pu-na te-ret {d}en-lil2 u {d}e2-a qa-at-sa lit-bal| Moreover, in addition let her carry out herself the decrees of Enlil and Enki.    
{gi-ir}esz2-giri17 an-ki{DI}-a asz-a-ne2 a-ba-ni-in-tab a2-{ga}gar-me ur he2-me-a e-sze = %a lit-mu-uh e-disz-szi-sza2 s,er-ret an-e u ki-tim szi-i lu-u lit-ni| When she alone has taken hold of the nose-rope of heaven and earth, she shall be our strength! 
an-na-ra inim-bal bar ze2-eb-ba-ke4 hul2-le-esz nam-mi-in-gar = %a ana {d}a-nu na-pa-le-e t,u-ub ka-bat-ti ha-disz isz-sza2-kin-szum-ma| For An, the pleasant conversation produced happiness.
ku3 {d}inanna-ke4 sza3 {si3-ga}sig6-ga-na {mi}mi2 zi mu-ni-in-du11 = %a el-le-tu4 {d}isz-tar ina t,u-ub lib3-bi-szu ki-nisz u2-kan-ni| He in his goodness of heart treated holy Inanna well.   
a2-ag2-ga2 nam-an-na-mu ul-he2 en-na nig2 se3-se3-ke-da-na = %a ur-ti {d}a-nu-ti-ia an-e nak-lu-ti sza2 la um-dasz-sza2-lu| The commands of my Anu-ship are the complex fundament(?) of heaven which cannot be equaled.  
{bu-lu-ug}bulug ki-us2-sa-mu bar-be2 ab-hul-e ku-nu-de3 nu-ub-zu-a = %a pu-lu-uk-ki szur-szu-du sza2 i-ta-tu-szu szuk-lu-ta-ma ana t,a-he-e la na-t,u-u| My fixed boundaries whose exteriors are fearsome and know no approaching, 
an-szar2 lugal-la sag-en3-tar-bi-me-en ud5-sag-be2 szu u-me-ti = %a {d}a-nu be-el a-szir3-KU-nu ana-ku ri-kis-KU-nu ah-zi-ma| I am Anšar/Anu, the king's helper, do take hold of their band.   
zu2-keszda ki-sur-bi za3-zu u3-bi2-gi a-ga-zu nam-en-bi ak-ab = %a kip-pat ki-sur-ri-szu2-nu ana i-di-ka ter-ri-ma e-disz-szi-ka be-el| Do take for yourself the entire extent of their territory, exercise alone the ruling of them!
bara2 nam-lugal-la-mu-sze3 ga2-na u3-bi2-galam-galam{ga-ga-la-am} an-ta-szar2 he2-gal2 ti = %a ana pa-rak-ku szar-ru-ti-ia ga-na ut-li-li-ma ina e-la-a-tu2 tisz2-bi| Come, rise up to my dais of kingship and dwell in the heights!
gaba-ra mu pa3-da-mu-sze3 {d}ki-szar2 mah-a mu sa4-zu he2-em = %a ana mi-hi-ir zi-kir szu-me-ia an-tum2 s,ir-tu4 lu-u2 ni-bit szu-me-ki-ma| Corresponding to my called name, may Exalted Kišar/Antu be your called name! 
li-bi-ir zi-da-mu szu-um-du-um kal-kal-la-ki ka-dib-ba-mu mu-un-zu-a = %a suk-kal-lu4 ki-nu szap-tan szu-qu-ra-a-tusz mu-du-u2 pi-risz-ti-ia| My faithful vizier, whose lips are prized, who is aware of my secrets, 
{d}nin-szubur sukkal me-te-mu za-e-da nam-ab-ba ak-a he2-na-nam = %a {d}i3-li2-ab-rat suk-kal-lu4 si-ma-ti-ia lu-u2 e-pesz a-bu-tu2 it-ti-ka| Ninšubur, my fitting vizier, shall exercise the status of father with you. 
i-bi2-zu e-ne-eg3-mar dim3-me-er amalu-bi sag-us2 nam-sza6-ga he2-bi2-ak = %a ina mah-ri-ki e-gir-e dingir u {d}isz-ta-ri li-dam-me-eq sa-an-tak-x| May he (standing) before you constantly present auspicious words from (every) god and goddess. 
te-me-en da-ri2 an-ki-ke4 gesz-hur gi-na dim3-me-er-e-ne-ka-ta = %a ina da-ru-ti te-me-en an-e u ki-tim u2-s,u-rat dingir-mesz ki-na-a-ti| At the eternal foundation of heaven and earth and by the enduring designs of the gods,  
sag-tab an {d}en-lil2 {d}en-ki-ke4 nig2 hal-hal-la ba-an-ba-esz-a-ta = %a szur-ru-u2 {d}a-nu {d}en-lil2 u {d}e2-a u2-za-'i(IM)-i-zu zi-za-a-tim| when, in the beginning, Anu, Enlil and Ea allotted the shares, 
dingir min3-na-bi en-nu-ug3 an-ki-a {gesz}ig an-na gal2-la-ar = %a ana dingir-mesz ki-lal-la-an ma-as,-s,ar an-e u ki-tim pe-tu-u2 da-lat {d}a-nu| for the two gods, the watchmen of heaven and netherworld, the ones who open the door of Anu,
{d}nanna {d}utu-ra gi6{gi} u4-da szu-ta-ta an-ni-szi-ib2-si = %a ana {d}sin u {d}szamasz u4-mu u mu-szi ma-al-ma-lisz ba-szim-ma| for moon-god and sun-god the night and day were made in equal parts, 
an-ur2-ta an-pa-{szu2}sze3 a2-du3-a-bi im-ta-an-zu-zu-ne = %a isz-tu i-szid an-e ana e-lat an-e a-da-szu2-nu u2-ta-ad-du-nu| and from the bottom of heaven to the top of heaven they assign them their tasks: 
ab-{si}sin2-gin7 {i}i3-dur2-dur2-re-esz-am3 mul an za3 til-bi = %a ki-ma szi-ir-'i su-un-nu-qu kak-kab an-e gi-mir-szu2-un| to keep all the stars of heaven on course as in a furrow, 
gu4-gin7 us2 ba-ab-se3-se3-ga-esz-am3 dim3-me-er dub-sag-ga2-ar = %a ki-ma al-pi u2-sa szu-hu-zu dingir-mesz szu-ut mah-ri| to make the leading gods keep to their paths like oxen. 
ki-bi-a {d}inanna nam-nin gu2-sa-bi sag an-sze3 u6-mi-ni-in-il2-la = %a a-sza-risz {d}isz-tar a-na szar-ru-tu nap-har-szu2-nu ru-tab-bi-ma| Up into that place, Inanna, rise to the rulership of them all! 
{d}in-nin za-e dili-bad-bi he2-na-nam an-ti-mu2-a he2-ri-in-e-sze = %a {d}min at-ti lu-u2 na-bit-su-nu-ma {d}isz-tar mul-an liq-bu-ki| Lady, you be the brightest of them, so may they call you Ištar of the Stars!  
{a}a2 min-na-bi-sze3 an-ti-bal diri-ga-zu sun5-na-bi he2-en-bal-bal-e = %a i-da-as-su-nu szal-t,isz lit-tak-kir sza2-qu-u2 na-an-za-az-ki| May your high position (relative to them) alternate between the two sides (east and west) triumphantly!
ki en-nu-ug3 {d}suen-na {d}utu-bi-da-ta si-zu(SU) gu2 he2-en-me-er-me-re = %a it-ti ma-as,-s,ar-ti sza2 {d}sin u {d}szamasz sza2-ru-ur-ka li-ih-nu-ub| May your splendor be as abundant as that of the moon and sun in (their) watches. 
{i-zi-ga-ri}izi-gar su-lim du9-du9-a-zu an-sza3-ga szi-im-da-kar2-kar2-ra AB = %a sza2-lum-mat di-pa-ri-ki szit-pu-tu4 ina qi2-rib an-e lit-tan-pah| May the flaring glow of your torch shine high in the sky!  
dingir-re-e-ne-gin7 lu2 ki-la2-zu nu-gal2-la-ar sag u6 he2-ri-in-e-sze = %a ki-ma ina dingir-mesz sa-ni-qa la te-szi-i ug3-mesz lib-ra-ki| May the people marvel at you as one for whom among the gods there is none to check up on her.
en dumu {d}suen-na-ra nig2 gal-gal-la un-da-an-{ga}gar-ra-ta = %a isz-tu be-lu ana ma-rat {d}sin nar-ba-a i-szi-mu-szi| After the lord had bestowed (these) great powers upon the daughter of Sîn, 
esz3 e2-an-na-ra {i-di}itima ku3-ga-na ba-ra-an-na-an-kesz2 = %a bi-it e2-an-na el-lu ki-is,-s,a-szu2 la ik-lu-szi| he did not keep her away from the shrine Eanna, her sacred chamber.
an lugal-la {d}in-nin nig2 gal-gal-la un-da-an-ga-ra-ta = %a isz-tu {d}a-nu-um szar-ri ana {d}min nar-ba-a i-szi-mu-szi| After king Anu had bestowed the great powers upon her, 
esz3 e2-an-na-ra itima ku3-ga-na sag-gesz mu-un-rig7-esz = %a bi-it e2-an-na el-lu ki-is,-s,a-szu2 ana szi-rik-tu4 isz-ru-ku-szi| they presented to her the shrine Eanna, her sacred chamber. 
{pa-al-na-mu}pala2 nam-ur-a-sa zalag2 {d}suen-na-ke4 {al-bi}alan-bi mi-ni-ib2-su3-su3 = %a te-di-iq {d}a-nu-ti sza2-ru-ur dingir-mesz na-mi-ri x-szu2 u2-tal-lih| He covered her figure with the ceremonial garment of Anu-hood, the brilliant splendor of Sîn.
{su-ki-isz}suh-kesz2 mah-a ag2-tag-ga na-ag2-dingir-ra u4-gin7 ba-ni-in-e3 = %a {ti-iq}ti5-iq-ni s,i-ru-ti su-du-ur i-lu-ti ki-ma u4-mu usz-te-pi-szi| He made her appear like the day with superb ornaments, the ornaments of divinity. 
{u2-lu-hu nam-lugal-la}{gesz}u3-luh nam-lugal-la gesz husz il2-la-na sag-bi-sze3 nam-szul-sze3 ba-an-ak = %a u2-luh szar-ru-ti is,-s,i ez-za ka-ak la pi-di ana i-di-sza2 usz-t,ib| He enhanced her arm with the scepter of kingship, the fierce wood (staff), the unsparing weapon.   
sag-zi ka-silim-ma gu2 ma2-gur8{ma-qu-ru}-ra-ke4 sag(ZAG)-ga2-na ba-ni-in-gar = %a a-ge-e tasz-ri-ih-tu4 sza2 ki-ma re-esz {d}nanna-ri ina qaq-qa-di-sza2 uk-tin| A glorious crown which is like (that on) the head of Nanna he set (firmly) upon her head.  
nu-gig-an-na ag2 ze2-eb-be2-da-mu me al nu-di-di nig2-mu mu-ra-an-gar = %a isz-ta-ri-tu4 ur-ti ka-bit-ti pa-ra-as, la e-re-szi mim-me-e-a a-szim-ki| O Hierodule, my important decisions, divine powers which could not be asked for (by anyone else) I have assigned to you.

im (disz)21-35-26-44 a (disz)21-11-20-42| Tablet of {m}21-35-35-26-44, son of {m}21-11-20-42.

dingir gal-gal-e-ne ul-la a-ra-zu-ga2 {zu}zub-bi-gin7 ba-an-gur2-ru-usz = %a dingir-mesz gal-mesz ina an-nim tas-li-tu4 gam-li-isz ik-tan-szu2-usz| The great gods bown down to him, like a curved staff, in approval of and in prayer to him.  
ba-e-du11-ga zi-da nun en ka-ba-a-ni ba-a-{du}du11-ga-zu e-sze = %a taq-bi-ma ki-na-at ru-bu-u be-lu4 e-pisz pi-i-szu2 taq-bi ma-ag-rat| What you command is just. (Like) what a prince or lord has uttered, what you have commanded is obeyed. 
an du11-ga mah-zu sag ba-du ul-la mu-lu im-me = %a {d}a-nu qi2-bit-ka s,ir-tu4 ina mah-ri il-lak ul-la man-nu i-qab-bi| An, your lofty command takes precedence, who would say No to you? 
a-a dim3-me-er-e-ne-ke4 {en}inim-zu an-ki-a te-me-en-bi dingir na-me nu-sze = %a a-bi dingir-mesz a-mat-ka te-me-en an-e u ki-tim a-a-u2 dingir-mesz le-e'-mu| Father of the gods, your word, the foundation of heaven and earth, no god fails to heed it.  
en mas-su3 usz gar ni2-te-na-me-en {sa}sa2-gar{ga-ar}-me te-am3 = %a be-el mas-su-u2 ma-lik ra-ma-ni-sza2 at-ta mi-lik-ni mi-i-nu| Lord, you are the leader who takes only his own counsel, what should be our counsel? 
ki-sikil {d}inanna hi-li-bi mu-un-szi-in-kar-ra a2-zu a-ri-a-an-szi-ib = %a ana ar-da-tu4 {d}isz-tar sza2 te-em-nu-szi id-ka i-din-szi| Grant your strength to the maiden Ištar, whom you have loved.

{d}ki-szar2 gidlam e-da-sa2 he2-na-nam mu-zu-a nir he2-galam-galam = %a lu-u an-tu4 hi-ir-tu4 szin-na-at-ka szi-ma ana szu-me-ka li-te-et-li| Let Kišar/Antu truly be the spouse equal with you, may she rise to the (equivalent) authority of your name.

{d}inanna ti-sah4 gesz-la2 eszemen2-gin7 u3-mi-ib2-SAR-SAR = &a {d}isz-tar a-na-an-ti u tu-qu-um-ta ki-ma kip-pe-e szu-tak-pi-ma| Inanna, after you have made fighting and battle flip about(?) like a skip-rope,

amalu a-da-min3{me-en}-na bi-za szu(SU) tag-ga-gin7 szen-szen-na{a} us2-sa-ab = %a i-lat te-s,e-e-ti ki-ma me-lul-tu2 pa-as-si re-de-e qab-lu| Goddess of contention, make battle be pursued like puppets=dolls being manipulated.

{il-lu-ru}illar {kusz}gur21{ur3}-me3 szu si sa2-da-zu ulu3 ha-ra-an-{du}du9-{du}du9-de3 = %a til-pa-nu u ka-ba-bu ina szu-te-szu-ri-ki me-hu-u li-su-ru-ki| When you make ready your bow/throw-stick(?) and shield of battle, may the storms whirl about for you. 
szu ur4-ur4 zi-ga-zu {d}er3-ra-gin7 lu2-gi16-gi16 {gi-ir}gir2-{gi-ir}gir2 he2-en-ak = %a ka-szu-usz-ki na-ad-ru ki-ma {d}er3-ra qar-da-mu li-szab-ri-iq| May your raging divine weapon strike the evil person with lightning like (the plague god) Erra. 
{d}in-nin ki {gesz}tukul sag3-ga szu-nir gub-bu a2(NE) gal2-zu lu2 na-me nu-mu-un-da-ab-gi4-gi4 = %a {d}min ina ti-is,-bu-ut kak-ku u szu-rin-ni ina pe-te-e i-di-ki mam-ma-an a-a ip-par-szid(SZU)| Lady, at the place of clashing of weapons and planting of standards, no one can get away from the opening of your arms. 
dumu-mu ki za-ra du10-ga an-sze3 la2 ki-sze3 la2 tu-lu gid2-da-bi = %a mar-ti ana e-ma t,a-bu-ki szu-usz-qu-u2 szu-usz-pu-la sza2-da-da u ni-i'-u| My daughter, wherever it is pleasing to you to extend upwards, to extend downwards, to pull taut or to loosen, 
{i-zi-in}ezem siskur2 ul du3-a-ta ni2 tur-tur-ra szu giri17- du3 mu-pa3-da-(x)-bi-da-asz = %a ina i-sin-nu ni-qi2-i qe2-re-e-tu4 ut-nin{ni-in} la-ba-an ap-pi u za-kar szu-mu| At festivals, offerings, banquets, prostration(?), making obeisance, and invoking the name (of the god), 
lu2-u18-lu nig2 dingir-ra-a-ne2 sza3-dab ga2-ga2-bi mu-un-da-ak amalu-bi za3-sze3 ba-an-di-ni-ib2-gar-ra = %a a-me-lu sza2 dingir-szu2 szab-sisz ik-tam-lu-sza2 u {d}isz-tar-szu2 iq-t,i-nu-szu2| a human being whose god has gotten very angry with him, whose goddess has become soured/jealous towards him, 
za3 ki-a inim du10 nam-amalu-zu li-bi2-in-kin-kin dingir na-me(A) du10-du10(UD) ak-ak-bi nu-sze = %a a-di asz-rat sa-lim dingir-u2-ti-ka la isz-te-e'-u2 dingir ma-am-man te-es-pi-su le-em-ma| as long as he does not seek out the place of reconciliation with your divinity, no god will be agreeable to his petition. 
uru2-mu hur-sag ki-in-gi uri an-dul2 ub-da-ke4 = %a a-lu sza-ad(S,I) ma-a-ti szu-me-ri  u ak-ka-di-i s,u-lul kib-ra-a-tu4| At my city, the mountain of Sumer and Akkad, the shade of the world quarters,

bara2 nam-lugal-la-mu szu giri17-du3 dingir-re-e-ne-ke4 am-si-gin7 ba-nu2 = %a pa-rak szar-ru-ti-ia sza2 ana la-ban ap-pi dingir-mesz ki-ma ri-i-mu rab-s,u| at my royal dais reposing like a horned bull (or elephant?) at the obeisances of the gods, 
esz3 nibru{ki}-mu ki-szu-pesz5 nam-{d}en-lil2-la2 bad3-gal kalam-ma-ke4 = %a bi-tu4 ni-ip-pu-ru ma-haz {d}en-lil2-u2-tu2 tu-kul-ti ma-a-ti| at my sanctuary Nippur, the shrine of Enlil-ship, the mainstay/great wall of the nation,

gidim sag10-ga dingir inim-ma-mu sag an-na gub-bu-de3 = %a sze-e-du dam-qa dingir mu-ta-mu-u2 na-an-za-za mah-ri-ia| The good protective spirit, (my) eloquent god who is standing in front of me,

ib2-du11-ga mah-zu u3-ma-zu sa2 ib2-du11-ga-ke4 sag-tuku-zu he2-na-nam = %a ana sza2 ug-gat-ki ra-bat ir-nit-ta-ki kasz-da-at lu-u ra-bi-is,-ka szu-u2| let be your guardian be he against whom your wrath was great and whom your divine fury has overcome. 
{d}nin-imma3-imma3 gal-an-zu un-gi bar ze2-eb-be2-ba-ke4 ur5-zu he2-en-ib2-sze4-de3 = %a {d}min er-szi ina na-pa-le-e t,u-ub ka-bat-ti ka-bat-ta-ka li-szap-szih| May wise Nin-imma'imma cool your heart with pleasant conversations. 
{d}in-nin ag2 ze2-eb-be2-da-mu me al nu-di-di nig2-mu mu-ra-an-gar = %a {d}min ur-tu4 ka-bit-tu4 pa-ra-as, la e-re-szi mim-me-e-a a-szim-ki| Lady, I have established for you my weighty commands, divine powers that should not be demanded by anyone;

nun {d}nu-dim2-mud-da nam-bi-sze3 i3-hul2 bar-bi ul-la am3(AN)-mi-ib2-zi| Because of this, the prince Nudimmud became happy, his liver rose with joy.
im-gid2-da {disz}ba{sza2}-a bu12-kur2 {disz}{d}inanna-mu-mu sza3-bal-bal {disz}e2-kur-za-kir lu2-masz-masz qat3 {disz}{d}inanna-mu-mu| Long tablet of Iqīša, heir of Ištar-šūma-ēreš, descendent of Ekur-zakir the incantation priest. Hand of Ištar-šūma-ēreš 
%a dumu-a-ni pa-lih {d}a-nu  {d}en-lil2 u {d}be nu-tum3-szu2 ina me-resz-ti-szu2 la u2-szam2-kisz-szu2| his son. One who reveres Anu, Enlil, and Ea will not take it away, (or) who borrows it must not intentionally allow it to become lost. 
%a ina te-szu2 ana e2 umun-szu2 he2-gur-szu2 sza2 i-tum3-szu2 {d}iszkur u {d}sza-la lit-bal-szu2| At its proper time he shall return it to the house of its owner. He who does take it may Adad and Šala take HIM away!

sila-ta kur2-ra| from the street rescued:

ri-ri-ga| fallen;

ur-am3-ma| Uramma; 
mu en eridu{ki} ba-hun| year: “the en-priest of Eridu was installed.” 
ur-am3-ma| Uramma, 
dub-sar| scribe, 
dumu na-silim| son of Nasilim. 
3(u) 6(asz) gu2 3(u) 6(disz) 5/6(disz) ma-na 7(disz) gin2 siki| 36 talents, 36 5/6 mina, 7 shekels of wool

gu-da-da| Gudada 
szu ba-ti| received. 
mu {d}szu-{d}suen lugal uri{ki}-ma ma2-gur8-mah {d}en-lil2 {d}nin-lil2-ra mu-ne2-dim2| year: “Šu-Suen, king of Ur, had the great-barge built for Enlil and Ninlil.”

sza-at-i3-li2| by Šat-ilī;

lugal-gu10 gu4 gal a2 gu2-nu musz-husz igi pirig-ga2| My king, big bull with colorful horns, dragon with lion eyes! 
sipa szul-gi gu4-gal a2 gu2-nu musz-husz igi pirig-ga2| Shepherd Šulgi, big bull with colorful horns, dragon with lion eyes! 
amar szilam2 he2-gal2-la tu-da gu2 mar-mar-re di-de3| Wildcowcalf, born in plenty, made to thrive! 
kal-ga nam-ur-sag-ga2 tum2-ma he2-du7 kalam-ma-na| Strong, courageous, ornament of his land! 
nita zi {d}utu-u3 nig2-si-sa2 sa12-e-esz2 rig7-ga| Good man, endowed with the laws by Utu! 
nemurx(PIRIG.TUR) banda3{da} ga zi gu7-a gu4 a2-gur8 pirig gal-sze3 tu-da| Young leopard fed good milk! Bull with curved horns, born to (match) a big lion! 
su6 za-gin3 gaba ku3-ga u6 di| With lapis-lazuli beard, breast with silver to marvel! 
lugal sag men-na hi-li-bi| King with a head (being) the allure of the headband! 
szul-gi aga zi-da he2-du7-bi| Šulgi, ornament of the good crown, 
suh-kesz2 nam-dingir-ra tum2-tum2| wearing the pectoral of divinity, 
lu2 an-ne2 mu du10-ga sa4-a| one named by An with a good name! 
sipa zi a2 szum2-ma {d}en-lil2-la2| Right shepherd, given strength by Enlil, 
szul-gi {d}nin-lil2-la2 ki-ag2 sza3-ga-na| Šulgi, beloved of Ninlil’s stomach! 
lugal-gu10 za-gin7 a-ba an-ga-kal a-ba an-ga-a-da-sa2| My king, who is as strong as you, and who rivals you? 
a-ba za-gin7 sza3-ta gesztu2-ga szu-dagal mu-ni-in-du11| Who, like you, from womb is so richly endowed with understanding? 
nam-ur-sag-zu-u3 pa he2-e3-e3| May your heroism shine forth, 
nam-kal-ga-zu mu10 du10 he2-e| may your strength be caressed! 
kur gu2-erim2-gal2-la iri gul-gul-me-en3| You are such a one, destroying cities in the hostile foreign lands; 
kur gu2-erim2-gal2 {d}nanna-a-ka ug3-ba gu3 mi-ri2-a ra-ra-me-en3| You are such a one as strikes in raging voice against the people of the foreign lands hostile to Nanna. 
am zi am-gal-sze3 tu-da-gin7 si-musz gu2-nu-me-en3| You are such a one as, like a right wild bull born to a great wild bull, colors curved horns. 
nig2-szu {gesz}gigir2 har-ra-an-na si-ga-me-en3| You are such a one whose possession is a chariot set on the byway. 
{ansze}ni-is-ku-gin7 kas4 ne-gal2-la-zu-u2 {d}en-lil2 hul2-le-me-en3| You are such a one as, like a select donkey, your running of force brings joy to Enlil. 
{gesz}ildag4 ki-en-du za3-ga du3-a-gin7 usu-a-me-en3| You are such a one as, like an ildag planted by the side of a watercourse, is strong. 
mes zi kurun3-na gun3-a-gin7 u6 di du10-ga-me-en3| You are such a one as, like a right mes tree in colorful fruit, is sweet marvel. 
{gesz}geszimmar dilmun ku3-gin7 {d}nin-e2-gal-ke4 mu10 zi du11-ga-me-en3| You are such a one as, like a date palm of silver Dilmun, is caressed by Ninegal. 
{gesz}erin duru5 ha-szu-ur2-re mu2-a-gin7 gissu du10-ga-me-en3| You are such a one as, like a moist cedar growing amid the cypresses, is sweet shade.

sipa szul-gi a-zu sza3 ku3-ga u4 ba-an-ri-a| Shepherd Šulgi, when your seed was dropped in the silver womb, 
ama ugu4-zu {d}nin-sun2-ke4 mu-u3-tu-e-en3| your birth-mother Ninsun bore you; 
dingir-zu ku3 {d}lugal-banda3{da} mu-u3-dim2-e-en3| your god, silver Lugalbanda, fashioned you;

{d}nin-lil2-le ki mu-ra-an-ag2| Ninlil loved you.

{gesz}mes {gesz}geszimmar-gin7 mu10 zi mu-ni-in-du11| like a mes tree or a palm-tree he caressed you. 
{d}nin-lil2-la2 siskur a-ra-zu-a sza3 im-ma-an-sed4| Ninlil was soothed with offerings and prayers. 
dingir ki nam tar-tar-ra-ka na-nam na-nam dingir an-na ba-su8-su8-ge-esz| The gods of the place of decrees stepped up with “Indeed, indeed”. 
sig-ta igi-nim-sze3 kalam-ma {d}en-lil2 lugal kur-kur-ra-ke4 nam-sipa-bi ma-ra-an-szum2| From below to above, Enlil, the king of all the lands, gave you shepherdship of the homeland.

kur gu2-erim2-gal2 {d}nanna-a-ka x szeg12 i3-ni-gi4| you roared at the foreign land hostile to Nanna. 
ki-bala-e {d}en-lil2-la2-ka x za-pa-ag2 dub2-i3| Thump your battle-cry at the insurgent region against Enlil! 
gu2 kur-ra-ke4 giri3 u3-mi-us2| After setting foot on the neck of the foreign lands, 
ki-bala-e szu si-ig-ga ga-am3-du11| I shall bring down a heavy hand on the insurgent region. 
sag-ga2-ni giri3 u3-mi-ni-us2| and placing foot on his head, 
mitum-gu10-u3 ur zu2 ses-a-gin7 gug hu-mu-u3-ra-ra-ra| May my battle-axe forever hit its teeth like a bitter-toothed dog. 
im-du8-a lu2-lu2-bi-ir| Against their men on the pisé walls, 
musz ki-ur3-ra-gin7 ka-a-gu10-u3 ir he2-e-tum2-de3| like a roof-snake, may my mouth bring forth venom. 
a2-tuku a2-na mu-szi-in-gen-na| The strong one who went in his strength. 
du10-tuku-bi-ir sa-par4 u3-mu-na-ab-dim2| Against their runners, after I fashioned sapar nets, 
masz-da3-gin7 {gesz}tir-re gi4-bi-in-dab5| I shall catch them like gazelles in the woods. 
kas4 du11-ga ni2 nu-te-na-bi-ir| Against their runners without rest, 
ansze-edin-na-gin7 pu2 sa-a ak-a me-er-bi gi4-ni-in-szu2| like steppe asses I trap them violently in a hole outfitted with a net. 
{gesz}tukul husz-gu10 uszum gurusz3 bur2-ra-gin7 usz ha-mu-na-ab-szum2-mu| May my fierce weapons give him venom like a gnawing serpent. 
di4-di4-la2 zi-bi-da kar-ra-ba| The little ones who escaped with their lives, 
zi-bi-a bir5 szu2-szu2-a-gin7 sahar ses-ses gi4-bi2-ib2-gu7| as long as they live, like the all-covering locust, I shall make eat bitter soil.” 
{gesz}szu-nir-gu10 kur-ra za3-ba ga-am3-du3| my standards at the border of the foreign lands I shall plant. 
e2-mar-uru5-gu10-u3 nig2 ga-am3-ta-si| I fill my quiver to overflowing. 
{gesz}pan-gu10-u3 musz-husz-gin7 gurusz3 ha-ma-bur2-bur2-re| May my bow, like a raging snake, ever gnash for me;

ki-bala-a ug3 tar-tar-ra-bi| The separated peoples of the insurgent region

{uruda}mitum-gu10-u3 kurinx(DUG){in} nam-lu2-ulu3 a-gin7 he2-em-bala-e| “May my battle-axe cross over the blood of the people like water. 
{gesz}tukul ha-zi-in da tab-ba-gu10-u3| May my double-edged axe weapon 
nag dug gesztin gaz za-gin7 hur-sag-e i3-bi2-i3-su3| Like the contents of a broken wine jug, having poured it on the mountains, 
kur-ra ur3-ra nu2-a-bi ur3-ra ga-am3-mi-ag2| “Those who lie on the roofs of the foreign lands, on the roofs I shall kill; 
bad3-da nu2-a-bi bad3-da ga-am3-mi-gaz| those who lie on the city walls I shall grind up on the city walls. 
mu-u3-da-gub-a-bi giri3-na ga-am3-mi-gub| Whoever stood with me, I shall let stand on his feet; 
nu-mu-u3-da-gub-a-bi ki-ba ga-am3-mi-gaz| whoever did not stand with me, I shall grind up on the spot. 
kur-ra tur-tur-bi ma2-a ga-am3-mi-ib2-u5| The young ones of the foreign lands I shall let ride off on ships, 
gal-gal-bi szu-gi4-ta ga-am3-gi4| the big ones I shall “send back from old age”. 
nu-mu-u3-gi4-esz2 nu-mu-u3-dagal-e-sza-a u4 la-ba-da-ab-su3-ra2-asz| To those who did not return and spread out, the days will not be long!” 
lugal-me-en3 szu iri-ga2 ga-am3-gi4| “I, the king, shall avenge my city. 
nig2 ki-en-gi-ra ba-a-gu-la kur-ra ga-am3-mi-ib2-gu-ul| Whatever was destroyed in Sumer, in the foreign lands I shall destroy. 
iri-ba dingir-bi giri3-ba ga-am3-mi-si| The gods of their cities I shall cause to “get into shoes”; 
u2-du11 igi-sa6 {d}lamma igi-sa6-bi bar-sze3 ga-am3-ta-an-gub| their pretty-face udug and lamma protective deities I shall let step out. 
GAN2 zi sze dadag-ga-be2-e u2 gid2-da gi4-bi2-i3-mu2| In their fertile fields of shining barley I shall let long grass grow; 
gesz tur-tur-bi ur2-ba ga-mu-bu3-bu3| their small trees I shall uproot; 
gesz dagal gal-be2-e tun3 gul ga-am3-du11| their thick and tall trees with the axe I shall bring to destruction; 
gesz nig2-tuku-bi suhur-ba gi4-ni-ib2-bala-bala| their trees of wealth I shall “cross over” at the crown. 
pu2 {gesz}kiri6 lal3 {gesz}pesz3 mu2-a-bi a-ri2-na{sar} gi4-bi2-i3-mu2| In their well-orchards, where date syrup and fig trees grew, I shall make weeds grow; 
lugal-me-en3 iri mu-gul-la-ta bad3 mu-se3-ga-ta| “After I, the king, have destroyed the cities and laid flat the city walls, 
kur kum2-ma a-ge6 i3-huluh-ha-ta| with floodwater caused the torched foreign lands to shake, 
numun gu-ti-um-ma sze sahar-ra-gin7 mu-bi-bi-re-a-ta| have scattered the seed of the Guti like seed-grain, 
u3-ma-gub {d}en-lil2-la2 sa2 mu-du11-ga-ta| have achieved Enlil’s triumph, 
ku3 za-gin3 kur-ra {kusz}PA5.(SZIR.LU.SU)%(SZIR.LU.SU) ga-am3-mi-ak| then the silver and lapis lazuli of the foreign lands into leather pouches I shall put. 
iri {d}en-lil2-le nam-bi ba-an-ku5| The city Enlil cursed; 
{d}inanna nin me3-ke4 sag-ki im-ma-da-an-gid2| Inanna, the lady of battle, frowned on it. 
an-za-gar3 dingir ma-mu-da-ke4| Anzagar, the god of dreams, 
musz-sag-kal-gin7 gu3 nun am3-me-e| like a strong-head snake he roars. 
lugal a e3-a ki-bala-sze3 gu3 nun-bi di-da| The king, roaring like a rising flood against the insurgent region, 
szul-gi a e3-a ki-bala-sze3 gu3 nun-bi di-da| Šulgi, roaring like a rising flood against the insurgent region, 
szesz ku-li-ni en {d}gilgames2| his brother and friend, lord Gilgameš, 
szul-gi sipa zi ki-en-gi-ra-da giri3-a ba-da-an-gen| together with Šulgi, the right shepherd of Sumer, he walked along the path. 
lugal an ku3-ga men dagal su3-su3| The king of the silver heavens, spreading out a wide crown, 
en u4 sze-er-zi dingir-re-e-ne| the lord, the bright sun of the gods, 
szul-gi sipa zi ki-en-gi-ra-da giri3-a ba-da-gen| together with Šulgi, the right shepherd of Sumer, he walked along the path. 
am-gal-sze3 tu-da pirig ne3-ba gub-ba| Born to a great wild bull, a lion standing in his strength, 
ibila kal-ga szul {d}suen-na| mighty heir of youthful Suen, 
dumu ur-sag {d}asz-im2-babbar-ra| son and hero of Ašimbabbar, 
szul-gi sipa zi ki-en-gi-ra giri3-a ba-da-gen| together with Šulgi, the right shepherd of Sumer, he walked along the path. 
szul-gi sipa zi ki-en-gi-ra-da giri3-a ba-da-gen| together with Šulgi, the right shepherd of Sumer, he walked along the path. 
enegir3{ki} x du10 du11-ga x x im-ma-ti-a-ta| When he arrived at Enegir, 
szul-gi sipa zi ki-en-gi-ra-da giri3-a ba-da-gen| together with Šulgi, the right shepherd of Sumer, he walked along the path. 
u4-ba abzu-ta ib2-ta-e3| At the same time, from the abzu emerged, 
lugal {d}en-ki-ke4 abzu-ta igi-asz mu-il2| King Enki lifted one eye out of the abzu, 
ki-gub-ba-ni kur mu-na-gul-e| from where he stands destroying for him the foreign lands, 
ki-tusz-a-ni-ta iri mu-na-gul-e| from where he sits destroying for him the cities. 
du11-ga zi-da inim ki-bi-sze3 gar| He of rightful speech, whose utterances are firmly established, 
nu-dim2-mud en gal eridu{ki}-ga| Nudimmud, great lord of Eridu; 
szul-gi sipa zi ki-en-gi-ra-da giri3-a ba-da-gen| together with Šulgi, the right shepherd of Sumer, he walked along the path. 
e2-babbar e2 {d}utu-ke4 im-ma-ti-a-ta| When he arrived at the E-babbar, the house of Utu, 
kur-ra tur-tur-bi ma2-a i3-mi-ib2-u5| The young ones of the foreign lands he let ride off on ships, 
gal-gal-bi szu-gi4-ta mu-gi4| the big ones he “sent back from old age”. 
nu-mu-gi4-esz2 nu-mu-dagal-le-e-sza-a u4 la-ba-da-ab-su3-ra2-asz| To those who did not return and spread out, the days were not long! 
ur-sag-e szu iri-na mu-gi4| The hero avenged his city. 
nig2 ki-en-gi-ra ba-a-gu-ul-la kur-ra i3-mi-in-gu-ul| Whatever was destroyed in Sumer, in the foreign lands he destroyed. 
iri-ba dingir-bi giri3-ba i3-mi-si| The gods of their cities he caused to “get into shoes”; 
u2-du11 igi-sa6 {d}lamma igi-sa6-bi bar-sze3 im-ta-an-gub| their pretty-face udug and lamma protective deities he let step out. 
GAN2 zi sze dadag-ga-a-be2-e u2 gid2-da bi2-i3-mu2| In their fertile fields of shining barley he let long grass grow; 
gesz dagal gal-be2-e tun3 gul bi2-in-du11| their thick and tall trees with the axe he brought to destruction; 
gesz nig2-tuku-bi suhur-ba mi-ni-in-bala-bala| their trees of wealth he “crossed over” at the crown. 
gesz tur-tur-bi ur2-ba mi-ni-in-bu3-bu3-u2| their small trees he uprooted. 
pu2 {gesz}kiri6 lal3 {gesz}pesz3 mu2-a-be2-e a-ri2-na{sar} bi2-i3-mu2| In their well-orchards, where date syrup and fig trees grew, he made weeds grow; 
lugal-e iri mu-gul-la-ta bad3 mu-se3-ga-ta| After the king had destroyed the cities and laid flat the city walls, 
kur kum2-ma a-ge6 i3-huluh-ha-ta| with floodwater had caused the torched foreign lands to shake, 
numun gu-ti-um-ma sze sahar-ra-gin7 mu-bi-bi-re-a-ta| the seed of the Guti like seed-grain had scattered, 
ku3 za-gin3 kur-ra {kusz}PA5.(SZIR.LU.SU)%(SZIR.LU.SU) im-mi-ak| then the silver and lapis lazuli of the foreign lands into leather pouches he put. 
gi16-sa-bi tesz2-e bi2-in-tag-tag| All their treasures he gathered together 
nig2-gur11 kur-ra-ke4 gu2-asz im-mi-szid| and all the goods of the foreign lands counted to one load. 
gu4 gi4-a udu gi4-a-bi-a| On their delivered cattle and delivered sheep. 
mu {d}en-lil2-la2 i3-mi-ib2-pa3-de3| the name of Enlil invoking, 
mu {d}nin-lil2-la2 im-mi-ib2-pa3-de3| the name of Ninlil invoking. 
ur-sag-e kur-ta szu-mah gi4-a-ni| The hero, after achieving an august revenge in the foreign lands, 
ma2-gur8 za-gin3 nam-lugal-la ba-ni-in-du8-a-ni| had his blue barge of royalty caulked. 
si ku3 su3-su3 udu-utua2 ku3-sig17-bi an-sza3-ga hud-hud| adorned with expansive silver horns, its ram of gold gleaming in the middle of heaven. 
abzu-ta mu10 zi du11-ga-am3| was caressed from the abzu; 
gesz-hum-bi e2-gal i7-mah-ha me-lam2 gur3-ru-am3| its cabin was a palace, carrying a terrible splendor on August River, 
an-gin7 mul-a sze-er-ka-an mi-ni-ib2-du11| like the sky with stars it was decorated. 
si-im a2-la2-e szeg12 mu-na-ab-gi4| The sim and ala (drums) resounded for him, 
e2-balag szer3-re-esz2 mu-na-ab-du11| and the balag-house drums played music for him. 
nar-re en3-du-am3 mu-na-ni-ib2-e-ne| the cantors for him were signing in a song. 
addir-ni a2 nu-kusz2-u3| His tireless boatmen 
u5 du3-du3-me-esz2 u5 la2-la2-me-esz2| —hoisting and hanging (sail)— 
a-ne-ne dumu enegir3{ki} dumu uri2{ki}-ma-me-esz2| these—sons of Enegir and sons of Ur— 
esz3 nibru{ki} esz3 dur-an-ki-sze3| At the temples of Nippur, the temples Dur-an-ki, 
kar-gesztin-na {d}en-lil2-la2-ke4| at the Kar-geština of Enlil 
ma2 na-ga-am3-mi-in-us2| did he not moor the boat? 
ku3 za-gin3 kur-ra {kusz}PA5.(SZIR.LU.SU)%(SZIR.LU.SU) ak-da| With the silver and lapis lazuli of the foreign lands put into leather pouches, 
gi16-sa tesz2-e tag-tag-ga-da| all their treasures gathered together, 
nig2-gur11 kur-ra-ke4 gu2-asz szid-da| with all the goods of the foreign lands counted to one load, 
{d}en-lil2-ra mu-na-da-an-ku4-ku4| he enters before Enlil. 
szul-gi-ra nam mu-ni-ib2-tar-re| a destiny for Šulgi he decrees: 
lugal nam gi4-ri2-ib2-tar{ar} nam du10 gu2-mu-ri2-ib2-tar{ar}| “King, a destiny for you I shall decree, a good destiny for you I shall decree! 
szul-gi nam gi4-ri2-ib2-tar{ar} nam du10 gu2-mu-ri2-ib2-tar{ar}| Šulgi, a destiny for you I shall decree, a good destiny for you I shall decree! 
nam-ur-sag nam-sze3 gu2-mu-ri2-ib2-tar{ar}| heroism as your destiny I shall decree! 
nam-en nam-lugal-la u4 su3-da nam-sze3 gu2-mu-ri2-ib2-tar{ar}| Long-lasting lordship and kingship as your destiny I shall decree! 
ni2 me-lam2-ma gu2 hu-mu-ni-us2| In terrifying splendor may you lean your neck! 
igi husz-zu lu2 nam-ba-gub| Before your fierce face may no one stand! 
aga nam-lugal-la2-zu-u3 dalla he2-em-e3| May your crown of royalty shine radiantly! 
gidri-zu nig2 nam-nun-na he2-em| May your sceptre be a thing of princes, 
pa mul-bi an-dul3-le-esz2 hu-mu-u3-ak| and may its shining branches provide you with shade! 
sza3-za sza3 hul2-la he2-en-gal2 nam-ba-kusz2-u-de3-en| May there be joy in your stomach, and may you never grow weary! 
lugal zi-sza3-gal2 ukken-za he2-me-en| May you be a breath-of-life king in your assembly! 
nam-ti-la-zu gu-gin7 he2-mu2-mu2 sze-gin7 he2-mu2-mu2| May your life flourish like herbs, may it flourish like grain! 
mes zi-gin7 ki dagal-e he2-mu2-mu2| May it flourish like a right mes tree in a broad plot!” 
{d}nin-gir2-su| For Ningirsu, 
ur-sag kal-ga| the mighty warrior 
{d}en-lil2-la2-ra| of Enlil, 
gu3-de2-a| Gudea, 
ensi2| ruler  
lagasz{ki}-ke4| of Lagaš, 
nig2-du7-e pa mu-na-e3| made a fitting thing resplendent for him, (namely)  
e2-ninnu anzu2{muszen}-babbar2-ra-ni| his Eninnu-With-the-White-Thunderbird 
mu-na-du3| he built  
ki-be2 mu-na-gi4| and restored for him. 
lugal ma2 na-mu-u5| At the king sailing 
ki unu{ki}-ge me nam-nun-na-sze3| to Uruk towards the princely divine powers 
ki-en-gi ki-uri u6 mu-e| Sumer and Akkad marvel. 
kar kul-aba4{ki}-ba-ke4 ma2 na-ga-am3-mi-in-us2| Did he not he moor the boat at the quay of Kulaba? 
am-gal hur-sag-ga2 a2 il2-il2-la-da| With a big wild bull of the mountains with uplifted horns 
udu en zi-de3 szu-a la2-a-da| with a sheep led by the hand of an en priest at his right side, 
masz2 su4 masz2 za-la2 gaba-a tab-ba-da| with a reddish kid and a bearded kid doubled up on the breast, 
{d}inanna-ra esz3 e2-an-na-ka mu-na-da-an-ku4-ku4-u3| before Inanna in the shrine of E-anna he enters. 
sipa zi szul-gi-re sza3 ki-ag2 {tug2}ma6 tug2 mu-mu4| Good shepherd Šulgi, loving heart, dressed himself in a ma garment, 
hi-li men-sze3 sag-ga2 mi-ni-gal2| put a ḫili wig as a crown on his head. 
{d}inanna-ke4 u6 mu-ni-du11| Inanna marveled, 
ni2-te-ni-sze3 szer3 ba-szi-ni-ra| and spontaneously struck up a song, 
en3-du-sze3 im-e| singing the lyrics: 
lugal-ra u3-mu-un-ra| “When for the king, for the lord, 
a mu-na-tu17-a-gin7| I have bathed, 
su-ba du5-mu-zi-ra a mu-na-tu17-a-gin7| when for the shepherd Dumuzi I have bathed, 
im da-mu szu tag-ge4 du11-ga-gin7| when I have adorned my sides with clay, 
u3 szembulug3-ga giri17-mu gun5-gun5-na-gin7| when with resin I have colored my nose, 
szembi2-zi i3-bi2-ga2 mi-ni-mar-mar-ra-gin7| when with kohl I have covered my face, 
szu na-am3-sa6-ga-na-ka| when with hands of his fairness, 
ib2-ib2-mu mi-ni-dim2-dim2-ma3-gin7| he has covered my hips, 
u3-mu-un i3-nu2 ku3 {d}inanna{na}-sze3| when the lord who lies down beside silver Inanna, 
su-ba du5-mu-zi-de3| the shepherd Dumuzi, 
ur2-ra ga-ni-du8-a-na-gin7| (has said) ‘I would loosen that of the lap’, 
x IM a2 gi-rin-ga2 GI4 in-tenx(GUR8)-tenx(GUR8)-na-gin7| when in my radiant arms he has grown calm, 
siki-pa-mu a-ne in-da-an-du11-ga-gin7| my pa-wool he has played, 
gal4 ku3-ga2 szu bi2-in-ma-ra-gin7| when he has put hand to my vulva, 
sza3 ze2-ba-ga2 u3 x x-bi i3-x-nu2-a-gin7| when on my sweet stomach he has lain, 
ma2 sal-la-ni-gin7 mu-un-til-til-la-gin7| like his thin boat he has finished, 
ki-nu2-a mu10 ma3-ni-du11-ga-a-gin7| when on the bed he has caressed me, 
u3-mu-un-ra mu10 da-an-du11| then the lord I shall caress, 
na-am3 ze2-eb2 du10-mu-ni-ib2-tar{ar}| I shall decree him a good destiny; 
sipa zi szul-gi-ra mu10 da-an-du11| the good shepherd Šulgi I shall caress, 
na-am3-ze2-eb2 du10-mu-ni-ib2-tar{ar}| decree him a good destiny. 
a2-gu2-ra-na mu10-sze3 da-an-du11| his thick arms I shall caress, 
na-am3-sipa kur-kur-ra| shepherdship of all lands 
na-am3-sze3 du10-mu-ni-ib2-tar{ar}| as his destiny I shall decree.” 
nin su3-ra2-ag2 an-na| The lady, the mountain-crystal of heaven, 
hi-li sag-ge6-ga| delight of the black-headed, 
munus szul-la ama-ni-ra diri-ga| youthful woman who excels her mother, 
a-a-ne2 me ba-a| by her father granted divine powers, 
{d}inanna dumu {d}suen-na-ke4| Inanna, daughter of Suen, 
szul-gi dumu {d}nin-sun2-ka-ra| for Šulgi, son of Ninsun, 
nam mu-ni-ib2-tar-re| decrees a destiny: 
me3-a igi-sze3 du-zu ge26-me-en3| “Your ‘walking to the fore in battle’ am I! 
szen-szen-na sahar-gin7 tukul la2-zu-me-en3| Your ‘weapon carrier in combat like an attendant’ am I! 
ukken-na inim-mud-gal2-zu-me-en3| Your ‘advocate in the assembly’ am I! 
har-ra-an-na zi-sza3-gal2-zu ge26-me-en| Your ‘breath-giver in the campaign’ am I! 
lugal u2-a zi e2-an-na-me-en3| King, good provider of Eanna are you. 
szuba3 iri12-gal an-na-me-en3| carneol of An’s Irigal are you! 
du-du-e ba-ab-du7-u3| fir for running, 
bara2 mah-ha sag il2-la-a ba-ab-du7-me-en3| fit to lift head in the august dais are you! 
{gesz}gu-za za-gin3-na dur2 gar-ra-a ba-ab-du7-u3| fit to take a seat on the lapis throne, 
sag-zu men gun3-a ba-ab-du7-u3| your head fit to wear a colorful, 
bar-zu-sze3 {tug2}suluhu su3-de3 ba-ab-du7-u3| as to your body, fit to spread out a the fleece-garment, 
tug2 nam-lugal-la2-ka sza3 la2-a ba-ab-du7-u3| fit for stomach-hanging of the garment of royalty, 
{gesz}mitum-ma a2 il2-de3 ba-ab-du7-u3| fit to lift to the side the mitum-weapon, 
{gesz}tukul-a du10 bad-bad-de3 ba-ab-du7-u3| fit to open knees with mace, 
ti su3 {gesz}pan si sa2-e-de3 ba-ab-du7-u3| fit to send off straight the broad arrows, 
{gesz}ilar {kusz}eb2-ur3-ra za3 kesz2-ra2-a ba-ab-du7-u3| fit for throwing stick and shield bound to the hips, 
szu-zu-sze3 gidri ku3-ge ba-ab-du7-u3| as to your hands, fit for silver staff, 
giri3-zu-sze3 {kusz}e-sir2 ku3-ge ba-ab-du7-u3| as to your feet, fit for silver sandals, 
du10-tuku-me-en3 har-ra-an-na kas4 di-de3 ba-ab-du7-u3| You have knees! On the campaign, fit for running, 
amar za-gin3-na-gin7 gaba ku3-ga2 a-ne di-de3 ba-ab-du7-u3| fit for playing, like a calf of lapis, on my silver breast; 
sza3 ki-ag2-zu-u3 u4 he2-em-su3-re6-e| May your loving stomach be lasting! 
an-ne2 mi-ri-in-ak na-da-ab-kur2-re| An has doned this for you, may he never alter it! 
{d}en-lil2 lu2 nam tar-tar-re-de3 szu na-an-ni-ib-bala-e| May Enlil, the decreer of fates, never change it!” 
{d}inanna-ke4 mu10 mu-ni-in-du11| So did Inanna caress him. 
sza3 hul2-la {d}nin-e2-gal-ka zu| He who knows the joyful heart of Ninegal 
masz2 ge6 umbin ba-an-kin| sheared a black kid 
masz2 babbar2 a ba-an-tu17-tu17| bathed a white kid; 
am hur-sag-ga2 giri17-sze3 ba-an-la2-la2| wild bulls of the mountains by their noses tied up 
e2 ninda2-mah gu3 nun di-dam| —house of the august breeding bull roars— 
szul {d}utu-u3 esz3 e2-babbar2-ra mu-na-ni-ib2-ku4-ku4| up to the young man Utu into the temple E-babbar brings, 
szul {d}utu-u3 sag-ki zalag-ga-ni mu-szi-ib2-zi-zi| up to the young man Utu raising his radiant forehead, 
szul-gi sipa zi ki-en-gi-ra-ra nam mu-ni-ib2-tar-re| For Šulgi, good shepherd of Sumer, he decress a fate: 
lugal inim gun3-gun3 igi sa6-sa6| “King, colorful words, sweet face, 
ur-sag kal-ga pirig-sze3 tu-da| mighty hero, born to be a lion, 
sun2 tur nam-szul-ba gub-ba| young cow standing firm in its vigor, 
lipisz-tuku ne3-ni-e nu-kesz2-ra2| valiant, unbound in his strength, 
hur-sag gal-gal-la giri3-ni gar| whose feet trample great mountains: 
ur-sag kur-ra mu-ri-ri-ge-esz| the heroes of the foreign lands you have brought down, 
bara2-bara2-ge giri3 sa-ga i3-mi-du11| you have trampled upon all the thrones, 
mu-zu za3 an-na-sze3 mu-u3-gar| your name to the edge of heaven you have established. 
lugal-zu {d}asz-im2-babbar2-ra silim-ma gen-na| Your king—to Ašimbabbar go in peace.” 
enegir3{ki} iri me-lam2-ma du3-a| And so at Enegir, city built in splendor, 
ma2 nam-ga-am3-mi-in-us2| did he not moor the boat? 
a nun-ne2 sza3 ku3-ga ru-a kur szubax(MUSZ.SZA) tu-da-a| “Seed placed by the prince in the silver womb, born on the bright mountain, 
{d}nin-a-zu gu4-sun2 nag-a ad-ba gu3 di-gin7| Ninazu, like a wild bull lowing in drink, 
lugal en inim szu12-da ra2-zu-ke4 sza3 mu-ni-pa3-pa3-de3| King, the lord of prayers and supplications chooses you by heart; 
sipa szul-gi en szu12-da ra2-zu-ke4 sza3 mu-ni-pa3-pa3-de3| shepherd Šulgi, the lord of prayers and supplications chooses you by heart; 
lugal {d}en-lil2-le a2 szum2-ma a-ba mu-da-ga2-ga2| Who sets a king given strength by Enlil? 
a2 su3-su3-da-zu a-na ba-ta-an-e3-e3| what escapes your outstretched arms? 
anzu{muszen}-gin7 gu3 dub2-da-zu-ne igi-zu-u3 a-ba ba-gub| When like the thunder bird you shriek, who stands before you? 
u4-gin7 sze17 gi4-gi4-da-zu-ne| When like the storm you howl, 
kur gi bad-ra2 izi-da hur-sag gi-gin7 sag im-mi-sag3-sag3| the foreign lands, open reeds ablaze, mountains trembling like reeds, 
kur-ra e2-bi-a igi mu-ni-bar-bar| in the houses of the foreign lands watching, 
tidnum-e u6 du10 i3-mi-du11| Tidnum well marveled. 
{d}utu-gin7 ni2-zu-u3 me3-a dalla im-ma-ni-e3| Like Utu, your terror radiates in battle. 
{d}nergal-gin7 {gesz}tukul-zu-u3 usz2-a ka im-ma-ni-ba| Like Nergal, your mace drools in death 
gesz-gid2-da-zu-u3 u3-mun kalam-ma-ka szu ba-ni-gid2-gid2| your lance reaches into the blood of the Land. 
ig gal iri-a-me-en3 bad3 gal kalam-ma-me-en3| The great door of the city are you, the great wall of the Land are you! 
sa-par4 an ki-e dub-ba-me-en3 {gesz}ud5-sag ki-en-gi-da si-ga-me-en3| A net piled up over heaven and earth are you, lead-jenny positioned with Sumer are you, 
inim {d}en-lil2-la2 nig2 gu-la-am3 sag-za an-dul3-esz2 he2-em-ak| May the words of Enlil, enormous things, create shade on your head! 
sza3 ki-ag2 {d}inanna-ke4 szu na-ri2-bar-re| May the loving heart Inanna never abandon you!” 
u8 zi-da sila4 mu-ni-in-szar2-szar2{ar}| he let ewes goodly produce endless lambs, 
ud5 zi-da masz2 mu-ni-in-szar2-szar2{ar}| let jennies goodly produce endless kids, 
ab2 babbar2-ra amar bi2-in-du3-du3| let white cows set up calves, 
{d}nanna e2-temen-ni2-guru3-na mu-na-da-an-ku4-ku4-u3| then before Nanna in his E-temen-ni-guru he enters with them, 
e2 nam-lugal e2 he2-du7-ba ki-lugal-gub ki ku3-ba sag bi2-in-il2| head held high in the most fitting house of the the royal household, in its royal offering place, the silver place. 
lugal-a-ni {d}asz-im2-babbar2-re igi hul2-hul2-la-ni mu-szi-bar-ba-re| His king Ašimbabbar casts a joyous glance at him, 
szul-gi sipa zi ki-en-gi-ra-ra nam mu-ni-ib2-tar-re| for Šulgi, the good shepherd of Sumer, decreed a fate: 
ur-sag en gaba-gal2 kur-kur-ra a2 zi-da kalam-ma| “Hero, lord, mighty one of the foreign lands, right arm of the Land, 
u3-ma gub-ba-mu-u3 sa2 bi2-du11 inim mu-du11-ga im-ma-ni-gar| you have achieved victory for me, have carried out the commandeds. 
ki-bala nam ba-da-ku5-ra2-ga2 e2-bi du6-du6-ra2 mi-ni-gar-gar| The houses of the rebel lands that I have cursed you have reduced to ruin mounds. 
iti u4-sakar me szu du7-du7-ga2 na-ba-an-kusz2-u3-de3-e| May you never grow weary of perfecting the divine powers for me every month at new moon! 
{d}asznan2-gin7 mu-zu ka kalam-ma-ka ka kur-kur-ra-ka du10-ge-esz2 he2-eb-gal2| Like Ašnan, may your name be as sweet in the mouth of the Land and in the mouths of all the countries! 
ku3 {d}nin-gal nin e2-nun-na-ke4 gesz-{kusz}ummu3-da-gin7 ur2 hu-mu-ri2-in-PI-PI| May silver Ningal, lady of the Enunna, like the wooden frame of a waterskin spread out her lap for you! 
{d}suen-e nam du10 mu-ni-in-tar{ar}| Thus did Suen decree a good fate. 
e2-gal-mah {d}nin-e2-gal-la-kam bara2 ku3-ga-a dur2 ba-a-gar| In the Egal-maḫ of Ninegal, he took his seat on the silver throne. 
{d}isztaran ki-en-gi-ra sza3-ta nig2-nam zu-u3| The Ištaran of Sumer, omniscient from the womb, 
di kalam-ma ki-bi-sze3 i3-ku5-re6| renders the judgments of the Land in due order, 
ga-esz8 kalam-ma ki-bi-sze3 i3-ba-re| makes decisions for the Land in due order 
a2-tuku si-ga sza-ga2-asz-sze3 la-ba-an-gur4-e| lets no strong man wrong the weak, 
ama dumu-ni-ir sa6-ga mu-na-ab-be2| lets mother speak sweetly to her child 
dumu a-a-ni-ir nig2-gi-na mu-na-ni-ib2-gi4-gi4| lets child answer truthfully to his father. 
ki-en-gi-re he2-gal2 mu-da-ab-si| Sumer is filled with abundance, 
uri2{ki}-e giri17-zal mu-da-ab-su13| Ur prolonged in splendor, 
lugal-e kur silim-e-esz2 du11-ga-a nam-kal-ga-ne-e dalla bi2-in-e3-a| Because the king exulted in his triumph and let his might radiate, 
nam-ur-sag-ga2-ni szu zi bi2-in-ga2-ra| his heroism set well, 
ki-bala-e gu2 ki-sze3 bi2-in-la2-a| made the rebellious lands bow, 
iri-me uri2{ki}-e he2-gal2-la gu2-bi mi-ni-ib2-zi-ga-a| made our city Ur raise neck in prosperity; 
lugal suhx(MUSZ) za-gin3-na gun3-a dumu {d}en-lil2-la2| king, adorned with a face of colorful lapis, son of Enlil; 
men dagal-la sag an-sze3 il2-il2| lifting up head to heaven in broad crown, 
an-da ki mah-ha-na sza3 kusz2-u3 ur5-ra-asz-da bara2 gal-e si-a| with An in his lofty place taking counsel, sitting with Uraš on a big throne, 
i3-ti u4 zal-la kalam-e kur-kur-re a-ne hul2-la du11-du11| manth and passing days making the Land of Sumer and all the foreign lands play joyously— 
en {d}asz-im2-babbar2 za3-mu10| praise be to Lord Ašimbabbar! 
{d}nisaba za3-mu10| praise be to Nisaba!

lugal kal-ga| strong king,

u3 {d}be-la-at-te-ra-ba-an| and Belat-teraban,

tukum-bi| If
lu2-u3| a man
ma2 in-hun| hired a boat,

in-na-an-gar| one had established for him,
e-ne kaskal-bi| but he himself that route
in-kur2| did change,

sa-gaz-sze3 ba-ak| was subjected to a robbery,
lu2 ma2 in-hun-ga2| the man who hired the boat
ma2 ib2-su-su| shall replace the boat.
nig2-ba-ni-sze3| as(?) his gift
ib2-ba-an-szum2-e| he shall give(?) to it.

mi-iq-tum| a miqtum(-person)
nig2-ba lugal-kam| is a gift of the king,

tukum-bi| If

ni2-te-a-ni-ta| of his own accord
lu2-u3 un-szi-gen| has gone to (serve?) another man,
lu2-bi| that man
nu-un-tag-tag| shall not be touched;
ki sza3-ga-na-sze3| wherever he wishes
ha-ba-du| he may go.
tukum-bi| If
lu2 lu2-u3| a man by another man
a2 nu-gar-ra-ta| heedlessly(?)

in-da-la2| has been accused,
lu2-bi| and that other man
nu-un-ge-en| has not proved it,
inim in-da-la2-a| in the matter of which he accused him
nam i-ni-tag-ba ib2-il2-e| its assessed penalty he shall bear.
lugal e2-a| the master of an estate
u3 nin e2-a-ke4| or mistress of an estate
gu2-un e2-a| on the taxes of the estate
in-szub-bu-usz| has defaulted,
lu2-kur2-e in-il2| and another person has borne them,
mu 3(disz)-kam-ma-ka| until the 3rd year
nu-ub-ta-e3-e| he shall not be evicted;

in-il2-la| has borne
e2-bi ba-an-tum3| shall take the estate,
lugal e2-a-ke4| and the owner of the estate
inim nu-um-ga2-ga2-a| may make no claims.

lugal e2-a-ka| the owner of the house
tukum-bi| If
lu2-u3| a man
dumu tul2-ta| a child from a well
szu ba-ra-an-kar| has pulled out,
tukum-bi lu2-u3| If a man
dumu a2-e3-a usu-ni-gin7 nu-bulug3-e-de3| cannot raise a foster-child according to his abilities(?),
igi di-ku5-ne-sze3 un-ge-en| when this has been confirmed before the judges
ama tu-da-na ba-an-szi-gur-ru| he shall be returned to his birth-mother.
tukum-bi lu2-u3| If a man
nig2-ba e2-ad-da-na-ka| (regarding) the gift of her father’s house
ba-an-na-ba-a| which was presented to her
ibila-ni-im| as his heir
ba-an-tum3| she may take it away.
nig2-ba e2 ad-da-na-ka| the gift of her father’s house
ba-an-na-ba-a| which was presented to her
szesz-a-ne-ne| by the brothers
nu-un-da-ba-e-ne| shall not be divided,
tukum-bi| If
ad-da ti-la| while the father is still living
dumu-munus-a-ni| if his daughter,
erisz-dingir lukur| be she an ugbabtu priestess, a cloistered nadītu
u3 nu-gig he2-a| or a qadištu woman,
ibila-gin7-nam| considering her as an (equal) heir
e2 i3-ba-e-ne| they (all) shall distribute the estate.
tukum-bi| If
dumu-munus e2 ad-da-ka ti-la| a daughter, when she was still living in her father’s house,
dam-ra la-ba-an-szum2| he did not give to a husband,
szesz-a-ne-ne| her brothers
dam-ra in-na-an-szum2-mu| shall give her to a husband.
tukum-bi| If
nam-ARAD2 in-tuku| he took a slave,
tukum-bi| If
lu2-u3| a man
tukum-bi| If
dam egir-ra| a later wife
ba-an-tuku-a| whom he married
dumu in-szi-in-tu-u4| has born him children,
sag-rig7| the (marriage) gifts
e2 ad-da-na-ta| which from her father’s house
mu-un-tum2-ma| she had brought
dumu-na-kam| belong to her children;
dumu dam gidlam| the children of the equal-ranking wife
u3 dumu dam egir-ra| and the children of the later wife
nig2-gur11 ad-da-ne-ne| the property of their father
tesz2-a se3-ga-bi| equally
i3-ba-e-ne| they shall divide.
tukum-bi lu2-u3| If a man
dam in-tuku| married a wife,
dumu in-szi-in-tu-u4| and she bore him a child,
dumu-bi i3-ti| and that child lived,
u3 geme2 lugal-a-ni-ir| and a slave woman for her master
dumu in-szi-in-tu-u4| also bore him a child,
ad-da-a geme2| the father the slave woman
u3 dumu-ne-ne| and her children
ama-ar-gi4-bi in-gar| shall bring about their freedom;
dumu geme2-ke4| the children of the slave woman
dumu lugal-a-na-ra| with the children of the master
e2 nu-un-da-ba-e| shall not share the estate.
tukum-bi| If
dam gidlam-a-ni| his equal-ranking wife
ba-usz2| has died,
egir dam-a-na-ta| and after (the death of) his wife
geme2-ni nam-dam-sze3| his slave woman into the status of wife
ba-an-tuku-tuku| he shall take,
dumu dam gidlam-a-na| the children of his equal-ranking wife
ibila-ni i3-me-en| are his heirs;
dumu geme2| a child of the slave woman
lugal-a-ni-ir| whom to her master
in-szi-in-tu-u4| she has born,
dumu dumu-gi7-gin7-nam| will be a child equal to a free child;
e2-a-ni ib2-du10-ge| his (share of the) estate shall be made good.
tukum-bi| If
lu2-u2| a man
dam-a-ne2| whose wife
dumu nu-un-szi-in-tu-u4| has not born him a child,
kar-ke4-da| but a prostitute
tilla2-a| from the town square
dumu in-szi-in-tu-u4| has born him a child,
kar-ke4-ba| that prostitute’s
sze-ba i3-ba| grain ration, oil ration,
siki-ba-ni| and wool ration
in-na-ab-szum2-mu| he shall provide to her;
dumu kar-ke4-de3| the child
in-szi-in-tu-u4-da| that she has born to him
ibila-ni i3-me-en| shall be his heir;
u4 dam-a-ni| however long his wife
a-na ti-la-a-asz| is alive,
kar-ke4| the prostitute
dam gidlam-ra| with the equal-ranking wife
e2-a nu-mu-un-da-an-tusz| shall not reside in the house.
tukum-bi| If
lu-u3| a man’s
dam gidlam-a-ni| equal-ranking wife
igi-ni ba-ab-gi4| her eyes have changed(?),
u3 szu ba-an-la2-la2| or she has become paralyzed,
e2-ta nu-ub-ta-e3| she shall not be evicted from the house;
dam-a-ne2| her husband
dam 2(disz)-kam-ma| a 2nd wife
ba-an-tuku-tuku| may marry;
dam egir-ra-ke4| the later wife must
dam gidlam| the equal-ranking wife
in-il2-il2-e| support.
tukum-bi| If
mu10-us2-sa2-tur| a son-in-law
e2 uszbar-ra-na-ka| the house of his father-in-law
i3-in-ku4| has entered,
nig2-mu10-us2-sa2 in-ak| and he has made the betrothal gift,
egir-bi-ta| and afterward
im-ta-an-e3-esz| they have evicted him
dam-a-ni ku-li-ni-ir| and his wife to his friend
ba-na-an-szum2-mu-usz| they have given,
nig2-mu10-us2-sa2| his bethroval gift
in-tum2-a-ni| which he brought
in-na-ab-tab-e-ne| they shall double for him;
dam-bi ku-li-ne2| that wife his friend
nu-un-tuku-tuku| shall not marry.
tukum-bi| If
gurusz dam tuku| a young man having a wife
kar-ke4-de3 tilla2-a| a prostitute in the town square
in-tuku-am3| has had,
kar-ke4-bi-ir| and that to that prostitute
nu-un-szi-gur-ru-da| he should not return
di-ku5-e-ne in-na-an-esz| the judges have told him,
egir-bi-ta dam gidlam-a-ni| and afterwards his equal-ranking wife
ba-an-tak4| he has divorced,
ku3 dam tak4-a-ni u3-na-la2| when he has paid her his divorce money,
kar-ke4-bi nu-un-tuku-tuku| he may not marry that prostitute.
tukum-bi| If
ad-da ti-la| a father while living
dumu igi-na sa6-ga| to a son favored in his eyes
nig2-ba in-na-an-ba| has presented a gift
kiszib3 in-na-an-sar| and has written him a sealed document,
egir ad-da ba-usz2-a-ta| after the father has died,
ibila-e-ne| the heirs
e2 ad-da i3-ba-e-ne| shall divide the father’s estate,
ha-la ba-a nu-un-ba-e-ne| but they shall not divide the (already) allotted share;
inim ad-da-ne-ne| the word of their father
tukum-bi| If
ad-da ti-la| a father who is still living
dumu szesz-gal-a-ni-ir| to his eldest son
nig2-mu10-us2-sa2 in-na-an-szum2| has given a betrothal gift,
igi ad-da ti-la-sze3| and while the father is alive
dam ba-an-tuku| he has married a wife,
egir ad-da ba-usz2-a-ta| after the father has died
ibila-e-ne| the heirs
e2 ad-da-ta| from the estate of the father
nig2-mu10-us2-sa2| the betrothal gift
tukum-bi| If
dumu-munus lu2| about a man’s daughter,
e2 nu-un-gi4-a gesz3 i3-zu| who was unmarried, ‘You had sexual relations,’
lu2 ba-ab-du11| another man has said,
gesz3 nu-un-zu-a| when that she had not had sexual relations
un-ge-en| she has proved,
1(u) gin2 ku3-babbar i3-la2-e| he shall pay 10 shekels of silver.
tukum-bi| If
lu2-u3| a man
gu4 in-hun| rented an ox
sa-sal KU-a bi2-in-sil2| and cut the hoof tendon on it,
igi 3(disz)-gal2 sa10-ma-kam i3-la2-e| 1/3 of its value he shall pay.
tukum-bi| If
lu2-u3| a man
gu4 in-hun igi-bi in-hul| rented an ox and damaged its eye,
szu-ri-a sa10-ma-kam i3-la2-e| one-half its value he shall pay.
tukum-bi| If
lu2-u3| a man
gu4 in-hun si-bi ib2-ta-an-ku5| rented an ox amd cut off its horn,
igi 4(disz)-gal2 sa10-ma-kam i3-la2-e| 1/4 of its value he shall pay.
tukum-bi| If
lu2-u3| a man
gu4 in-hun| rented an ox
kun-bi ib2-ta-an-hul| and damaged its tail,
igi 4(disz)-gal2 sa10-ma-kam i3-la2-e| 1/4 of its value he shall pay.
inim gi-na {d}utu-ta| By the true command of Utu,
ki-en-gi ki-uri| Sumer and Akkad
di gi-na he2-bi2-dab5| I made hold to fair judical procedures.
ka-ta e3-a {d}en-lil2-ta| By the utterance of Enlil
{d}li-pi2-it-esz18-dar| I, Lipit-Ištar
dumu {d}en-lil2-la2-me-en| the son of Enlil,
nig2-erim2 nig2-a2-zi| evil and violence
ka-ge he2-em-mi-gi4| I sent back to the source.
er2 a-nir i-{d}utu di-bi| Weeping, wailing, and making cries for justice
nig2-gig-ga he2-ni-ku4| I made taboo.
nig2-zi nig2-gi-na pa-e3 he2-mi-ak| Righteousness and truth I made appear resplendently.
su ki-en-gi ki-uri hu-mu-du10| I made pleasant the substance of Sumer and Akkad.
u4 nig2-si-sa2 ki-en-gi ki-uri| When justice in Sumer and Akkad
i-ni-in-gar-ra-a| I established,
na4-bi ki he2-em-ma-ni-tag| this stela I planted out upon the ground.
lu2 a2 nig2 hul-dim2-ma| A man who a command of evildoing
nu-ub-szi-ag2-ge26-a| does not issue regarding this,
nig2-dim2-ma-mu nu-ub-zi-re-a| and does not efface my creation,
mu-sar-ra-ba szu li-bi2-ib2-ur3-a| who does not erase my inscription
mu-ni li-bi2-ib2-sar-re-a| and does not write his name upon it,
nam-ti zi-u4-su3 gal2| may a life of long existence
sag-e-esz he2-rig7-ga| be granted (to him).
e2-kur-ra gu2 an-sze3 he2-ni-in-zi| May he lift his neck up high in the Ekur,
sag-ki zalag-ga {d}en-lil2-la2-ka| and may the shining brow of Enlil
an-ta he2-eb-gi4| turn down from heaven.
lu2 a2 nig2-hul-dim2-ma ib2-szi-ag2-ge26-a| But a person who issues an order of evil-doing,
nig2-dim2-ma-mu ib2-zi-re-a| who effaces my creation,
e2-nig2-gur11-ra i-ni-ku4-ku4-a| or who has it taken into a storehouse,
ki-gub-ba-bi ib2-kur2-ru-a| or who changes its standing place,
mu-sar-ra-ba szu bi2-ib2-ur3-ru-a| or who erases its inscription
mu-ni bi2-ib2-sar-re-a| and writes his own name upon it,
asz2-bala-ke4-esz lu2-kur2 szu ba-an-zi-zi-a| or because of the curse incites a stranger to do it,
lu2-bi lugal he2-a| that man, be he a king,
en he2-a ensi2 he2-a| be he an en, or be he a governor,
dumu-sag {d}en-lil2-la2-ke4| the firstborn son of Enlil,
e2-a-na u3-mu-na-ni-in-ku4| After he has been allowed to enter his house,
ibila-a-ni nam-me| may there be no heirs for him.
en he2-gal2-la-ke4-ne| the lords of abundance,
an-ki-a ba-an-da-an-kar-re-esz| shall strip it away from him in sky and on earth.
nig2 ba-a e2-kur-ra il2-la-na| his allotments carried to the Ekur
inim he2-em-mi-ib-gi4-gi4| may he revoke.
{d}utu di-ku5 an-ki-ke4| May Utu, the judge of heaven and earth,
ka-inim mah-da| with exalted testimony
ha-ba-an-da-an-kar| make it be taken away from him.
he2-ni-in-sar| let him write(?) there.
iri{ki}-bi du6-du6-ra| Its cities as ruined mounds
he2-en-szid| may he reckon.
ma-da-na suhusz-bi na-an-ge-ne| The foundation of his land may he not keep secure.
lugal-bi nam-me| May there not be a king of it.
{d}nin-urta| May Ninurta,
ur-sag kal-ga| the mighty warrior
{d}en-lil2-la2| of Enlil,
maszkim nu-kur2-ru-bi he2-a| be the unalterable bailiff of this,
u4 da-ri2-isz| for time eternal.
{d}szul-gi| Šulgi, 
nita kal-ga| mighty man, 
lugal uri5{ki}-ma| king of Ur, 
lugal an-ub-da limmu2-ba| king of the four quarters: 
{d}szul-gi-si-im-tum| Šulgi-simtum 
lukur kaskal-la-ka-ni-ir| (is) his travelling companion: 
masz-gu-la| Maš-gula, 
sukkal ARAD2-zu| the vizier, (is) your servant.

lugal kal-ga| strong king,

ma-szum| Mašum,
sukkal ARAD2-zu| courrier, is your servant.

a2 umma{ki}-sze3| under the control of Umma 
mu-tak4| he left, 
GAN2 lugal nu-tuku| and into a field with no owner 
i3-kux(DU)| he made it.

e-me-sar-sar| he inscribed, 
na-ru2-a| and the stele 
me-silim-ma| of Mesilim 
ki-be2 bi2-gi4| he returned to its (former) place. 
edin umma{ki}-sze3| Into the plain of Umma 
nu-dib2| he did not pass.

{d}nin-gir2-su-ka| of Ningirsu 
nam-nun-da-ki-gar-ra| (named) Namnunda-kigara, 
bara2 {d}en-lil2-la2| a dais of Enlil,
