bara2 {d}nin-gir2-su-ka| a dais of Ningirsu, 
bara2 {d}utu| and a dais of Utu 
bi2-du3| he constructed. 
sze {d}nansze| Of the barley of Nanše 
sze {d}nin-gir2-su-ka| and the barley of Ningirsu, 
1(asz) guru7-am6| one grain-heap measure
lu2 umma{ki}-ke4| the Man of Umma 
ur5-sze3 i3-gu7| consumed as an interest-bearing loan. 
ku5-ra2 ba-us2| The ‛cut’ was imposed, 
4(szar'ugal){gal} guru7| and 144,000 (gur measured in) grain-heaps 
ba-kux(KWU147)| were to be brought in.

ensi2| governor 
umma{ki}-ke4| of Umma,

izi ba-szum2| he set fire,

i3-gul-gul| he demolished. 
kur-kur e-ma-hun| Foreign countries he hired,

ugula-ne| foremen, 
gala-e-ne| lamentation singers, 
engar-re2-ne| farmers, 
lu2 lungax(BIxNIG2)-ke4-ne| or brewers 
udu siki u3-mu-tum2| brought in a wool sheep,

e-ga2-ga2-ne| they would pay.

a-ba-dab5| was taken,

addirx(PAD.DUG.GISZ.SI) en-na ak| (no matter) how much the work(?) being performed, 
a na8-na8| drinking water 
nu-na-szum2-mu| he would not give him, 
ansze a na8-na8| and drinking water to the donkeys 
nu-ba-szum2-mu| he would (also) not give.

tukumx(SZU.TUR)| If 
{d}en-lil2| Enlil, 
lugal kur-kur-ra-ke4| king of all the lands, 
an a-a ki-ag2-ni| to An, his beloved father, 
nam-szita-mu| a prayer on my behalf 
he2-na-be2| should say, 
nam-ti-mu| to my life 
nam-ti| (additional) life 
ha-ba-dah-he| may he add! 
kur u2-sal-la| May the land in riverine meadows 
ha-mu-da-nu2| rest (contentedly) under me, 
nam-lu2-u18| may the people 
u2-szim-gin7| like sweet-smelling grasses 
szu dagal ha-mu-dab6-du11| spread out widely under me, 
ubur an-na-ke4| may the breast of heaven 
si ha-mu-dab6-sa2| function properly under me, 
kalam-e| and the nation 
ki sa6-ga| a pleasant place 
igi ha-mu-da-du8| may it behold under me. 
nam sa6-ga| The favorable destiny 
mu-tar-re-esz2-a| which they (An and Enlil) have determined 
szu na-mu-da-ni-bala-e-ne| may they never alter for me! 
sipa sag-gu4-gal2| A proud shepherd 
da-ri2 he2-me| may I be forever!

{d}en-lil2| to Enlil,

u4 an ki-a nam tar-tar-re-da| It was time to decide destinies in heaven and on earth, 
lagasz{ki}-e me gal-la sag an-sze3 mi-ni-ib2-il2| Lagash had raised the head towards heaven in large ‘me’, 
{d}en-lil2-e en {d}nin-gir2-su-sze3 igi zi mu-szi-bar| Enlil looked righteously upon lord Ningirsu. 
iri-me-a nig2-ul pa nam-e3| Did the ‘nig2-ul’ not emerge in our city? 
sza3 gu2-be2 nam-gi4| The ‘heart’, did it not return to its banks? 
sza3 {d}en-lil2-la2 gu2-be2 nam-gi4| The ‘heart’ of Enlil, did it not return to its banks? 
sza3 gu2-be2 nam-gi4| The ‘heart’, did it not return to its banks? 
a-mi-ru12 nam-mul ni2 il2-il2| The flood, did it not twinkle? Frightening (all). 
sza3 {d}en-lil2-la2-ke4 i7 idigna-am3 a du10-ga nam-de6| The ‘heart’ of Enlil, it is the river Tigris, did it not bring sweet water? 
e2-e lugal-be2 gu3 ba-de2| To the house its king spoke: 
e2-ninnu me-be2 an ki-a pa e3 mu-ak-ke4| “I will make the ‘me’ of Eninnu emerge in heaven and on earth. 
ensi2 lu2 gesztu2 dagal-kam gesztu2 i3-ga2-ga2| The governor is wise, he shall pay attention. 
nig2 gal-gal-la szu mi-ni-mu2-mu2| He shall enlarge big things. 
gu4 du7 masz2 du7-re6 si im-sa2-sa2-e| He shall straighten the horns of perfect oxen, perfect goats.” 
sig4 nam tar-ra sag mu-szi-ib2-il2| The brick of deciding destinies lifted the head towards him, 
e2 ku3 du3-de3 gu2-bi mu-szi-ib2-zi| to build the shiny house it raised its neck towards him. 
lugal-ni-ir u4-ne masz-ge6-ka| It was then, in a ‘dark goat’, that towards his king, 
gu3-de2-a en {d}nin-gir2-su2-ra igi mu-ni-du8-am3| on the lord Ningirsu, Gudea looked. 
e2-a-ni du3-ba mu-na-du11| “Build his house!,” he ordered him. 
e2-ninnu me-bi gal-gal-la-am3| On Eninnu, whose ‘me’ is very large, 
igi mu-na-ni-gar| he (Ningirsu) directed his (Gudea’s) eye there. 
gu3-de2-a sza3-ga-ni su3-ra2-am3| Gudea, his ‘heart’ is distant, 
inim-e mi-ni-kusz2-u3| counseled about the message: 
ga-na ga-na-ab-du11 ga-na ga-na-ab-du11| “Let me, let me tell it to her, let me, let me tell it to her, 
inim-ba ha-mu-da-gub| may she stand by me in this case. 
sipa-me nam-nun-ne2 sag ma-ab-szum2-szum2| I am the shepherd, princeliness was given to me. 
nig2 masz ge6-ke4 ma-ab-de6-a-ga2| Of what my ‘dark goat’ has revealed to me, 
sza3-be2 nu-zu| its ‘heart’ I did not know. 
ama-mu ma-mu-mu ga-na-de6| Let me bring my dream to her, to my mother. 
ensi ku3 zu me-te-na-mu| My dream-interpreter, knowing ‘ku3’ on her own, 
{d}nansze nin9 dingir sirara6-ta-mu| Nanše, my divine sister from Siraran, 
sza3-bi ha-ma-pa3-de3| may she make its meaning visible for me.” 
ma2-gur8-ra-na giri3 nam-mi-gub| Did he not set foot on his barge? 
iri-ni nina{ki}-sze3 i7-nina{ki}-du-a ma2 mu-ni-ri| Towards Nina, her city, on Ininadua, he directed the barge, 
i7-de3-hul2-la-e kur-kux(KWU147) i3-si-il-e| he is breaking the waves of Ideḫula. 
ba-gara2 e2 i7-de3 la2-a-e im-ma-ti-a-ta| After reaching Bagara—house hanging over the river, 
ninda gesz bi2-tag a sze23 i3-de2| he sacrificed bread, he poured out cold water, 
lugal ba-gara2-ra mu-na-gen szu12 mu-na-de6| he went to the king of Bagara, and prayed to him: 
ur-sag pirig zi-ga gaba-szu-gar nu-tuku| “Hero, charging lion, having no rival, 
{d}nin-gir2-su2 abzu-a gal di| Ningirsu, boisterous in the Apsû, 
nibru{ki}-a nir-gal2| being noble in Nippur.

{d}nin-gir2-su e2-zu ga-mu-ra-du3| Ningirsu, let me build your house for you,

gu3 de2-a-ni gesz ba-tuku-am3| His (Gudea’s) prayer was being heard.

ensi2 e2 {d}ga2-tum3-du10-sze3 ki-nu2-a-ni ba-re6| The governor set up his bed in the house of Gatumdu.

ku3 {d}ga2-tum3-du10-ra mu-na-gen| He went to Shiny-Gatumdu, 
siskur2 mu-na-be2| (and then) he is saying an offering(!) to her: 
nin-mu dumu an ku3-ge du2-da| “My lady, child born by shiny An, 
nir-gal2 me-te-na dingir sag zi| princely in her own right, god with the raised head, 
kalam-ma ti-la| living in the land, 
nu-du zu iri-na| knowing ‘nig2-du7’ in her city. 
nin ama lagasz{ki} ki gar-ra-me| You are the lady, the mother, founder of Lagash. 
igi ug3-sze3 u3-szi-bar-ra-zu szegx(IM.A) he2-gal2-la-am3| (With) your looking at the people: it is a bountiful wind. 
szul zi lu2 igi mu-bar-ra-zu nam-ti mu-na-su3| (With) your looking at the righteous hero, the man: for him life is prolonged. 
ama nu-tuku-me ama-mu ze2-me| I am a no-mother-haver, you are my mother. 
a nu-tuku-me a-mu ze2-me| I am a no-father-haver, you are my father. 
a-mu sza3-ga szu ba-ni-du11 unu6-a i3-tu-e| You have placed my semen in the inside: you bore me in the cella. 
{d}ga2-tum3-du10 mu ku3-zu du10-ga-am3| Gatumdu, your shiny name is sweet. 
ge6-a ma-ni-nu2| I will lay me down here this night, 
{gesz}kiszi17 gal-mu-me za3-mu mu-us2| you are my big dagger, following my side. 
gi:li9-bar a gal-la du3-a-me| You are a reed, planted in the big water, 
zi-sza3 mu-szi-i3-gal2| you have placed life in me. 
an-dul3 dagal-me gissu-zu-sze3| You are a broad parasol, under your shade 
ni2 ga-ma-szi-ib2-te| let me cool myself there. 
szu mah-za sa-ga a2 zi-da-bi| With the index finger? of your right hand, 
nin-mu {d}ga2-tum3-du10 ga2-ra ha-mu-u3-ru| ‘stroke’ me with it my lady Gatumdu. 
iri-sze3 i3-du-e geszkim-mu he2-sa6| I will go to the city, may my sign be good.

gu3 de2-a-ni gesz ba-tuku-am3| His cry was heard.

iri-ni nina{ki}-sze3 kar nina{ki}-na-ke4 ma2 bi2-us2| To her city, Nina, he moored at the port of Nina.

ninda gesz bi2-tag a sze23 i3-de2| he sacrificed bread, he poured out cold water. 
{d}nansze mu-na-gen szu12 mu-na-sza4| He went to Nanše, he prayed to her: 
{d}nansze nin uru16 nin me an-kal an-kal-la| “Nanše, large lady, lady of precious, precious, ‘me’. 
nin {d}en-lil2-gin7 nam tar-tar-re| Lady, like Enlil deciding destinies. 
{d}nansze-mu du11-ga-zu zi-dam| My Nanše, your word is righteous, 
sag-bi-sze3 e3-a-am3| it goes to the top. 
ensi dingir-re-ne-me| You are the dream interpreter of the gods. 
nin kur-kur-ra-me ama inim-mu u4-da ma-mu-da| You are the lady of all the lands. Mother, my words, in the day, in the dream. 
sza3 ma-mu-da-ka lu2 1(asz)-am3 an-gin7 ri-ba-ni| Inside the dream there was one man, his greatness was like heaven, 
ki-gin7 ri-ba-ni| his greatness was like the earth. 
a-ne sag-ga2-ni-sze3 dingir-ra-am3| He, according to his head he was a god, 
a2-ni-sze3 anzu2{muszen}-dam| according to his arm he was the Anzu, 
se11-ba-a-ni-sze3 a-ma-ru-kam| according to his lower body he was the flood. 
zi-da gub3-na pirig i3-nu2-nu2| Lions lay by his right and left. 
e2-a-ni du3-da ma-an-du11| He spoke to me about the building of his house. 
sza3-ga-ni nu-mu-zu| His ‘heart’ I did not understand. 
u4 ki-szar2-ra ma-ta-e3| A light went up on the horizon for me. 
munus disz-am3 a-ba me-a nu a-ba me-a ni| There was one woman. Who was it, who was it not? 
sag-ga2 e3 ki karadinx(U.SZUR) mu-ak| going up to the top she made a haystack on the earth. 
gi-dub-ba ku3 NE-a szu im-mi-du8| She held a stylus of purified silver in the hand. 
dub mul-an du10-ga im-mi-gal2| She had the tablet of the stars on her lap. 
ad im-dab6-gi4-gi4| She counseled it. 
2(asz)-kam ur-sag-ga2-am3| Secondly, it was a hero, 
a2 mu-gur le-um za-gin3 szu im-mi-du8| he bent the arm, he held a lapis writing board in the hand, 
e2-a gesz-hur-bi im-ga2-ga2| he drew the plan of the house. 
igi-mu-sze3 dusu ku3 i3-gub| In front of me stood a shiny basket, 
{gesz}u3-szub ku3 si ib2-sa2| a shiny mold was made ready, 
sig4 nam tar-ra {gesz}u3-szub-ba ma-an-gal2| the brick of deciding destinies was placed in the mold for me. 
ildag2 zi-da igi-mu gub-ba| In a just poplar standing in front of me, 
ti-bu{muszen} lu2-a u4 mi-ni-ib2-zal-zal-e| a ‘tibu’-bird passed the time tweeting. 
dur3 a2 zi-da lugal-ga2-ke4 ki ma-hur-hur-e| A donkey stallion, on the right side of my king, scratched the earth for me.” 
ensi2-ra ama-ni {d}nansze mu-na-ni-ib2-gi4-gi4| His mother, Nanše, answered the governor: 
sipa-mu ma-mu-zu ge26 ga-mu-ra-bur2-bur2| “My shepherd, let me, me interpret your dream for you. 
lu2 an-gin7 ri-ba ki-gin7 ri-ba-sze3| The man (who was) great like the heaven, (who was) great like the earth, 
sag-ga2-ni-sze3 dingir a2-ni-sze3| (who) according to his head (he was a) god, according to his arm

zi-da gub3-na pirig i3-sze21-sze21-a| at (whose) right and left lions were lying, 
szesz-mu {d}nin-gir2-su ga-nam-me-am3| it is surely my brother Ningirsu. 
esz3 e2-ninnu-na du3-ba za-ra ma-ra-an-du11| ‘Build his shrine, the Eninnu!’ He ordered you. 
u4 ki-szar2-ra ma-ra-ta-e3-a| The light that went up for you on the horizon, 
dingir-zu {d}nin-gesz-zi-da u4-gin7 ki-sza-ra ma-ra-da-ra-ta-e3| it is your god Ningešzida, who like the light went up for you on the horizon.

nin9-mu {d}nisaba ga-nam-me-am3| That is surely Nisaba, my sister. 
e2-a du3-ba mul ku3-ba| (About) the shiny star of the building of the house, 
gu3 ma-ra-a-de2| she poured out her voice for you. 
2(asz)-kam-ma ur-sag-am3 a2 mu-gur8| The second (one), it was a hero, with bent arm,

{d}nin-dub-kam e2 e2-a gesz-hur-ba im-mi-se3-se3-ge| it is Nindubba, placing the house on the plan of the house.

sig4 zi e2-ninnu ga-nam-me-am3| that is surely the righteous brick of Eninnu. 
ildag2 zi-da igi-zu gub-ba| In the righteous poplar standing in front of you,

e2 du3-de3 igi-zu u3 du10-ga nu-szi-kux(KWU147)-kux(KWU147)| in order not to let sweet sleep come to your eyes, (so) that the house is build.

na ga-ri na-ri-mu he2-dab5| Let me give give you instructions, let my instructions be heeded. 
gir2-su{ki} e2 sag ki lagasz{ki}-sze3 giri3-zu ki i3-bi2-us2| (When) you have reached Girsu, the chief house of Lagash: 
e2 nig2-gur11-ra-za kiszib3 u3-mi-kur2 gesz u3-ma-ta-gar| after you broke the seal of your treasure house, after your brought out wood, 
lugal-zu {gesz}gigir u3-mu-DI| after your have prepared a chariot for your king,

{gesz}gigir-bi ku3 NE za-gin3-na szu u3-ma-ni-tag| after you decorated this chariot with purified silver and lapis, 
ti mar-uru5-a u4-gin7 i3-e3| (called) ‘quick as light the arrow go out from the quiver’,

gesz-gu3-di mu tuku nig2 ad gi4-gi4-ni| the famous roaring wood, with which he counsels, 
ur-sag nig2-ba-e ki-ag2-ra| to the hero who loves gifts,

tur du11-ga-zu mah du11-ga-am3 szu ba-a-szi-ib2-ti| he will receive your small word, as if it was a mighty word. 
en-na sza3 an-gin7 su3-ra2-ni| The ‘heart’ of the lord, distant like the heavens, 
{d}nin-gir2-su dumu {d}en-lil2-la2-ka za-ra ma-ra-hun-ge26-e| of Ningirsu, son of Enlil, he will calm for you.

ur-sag-e me-ni gal-gal-la-am3| The hero, his ‘me’ are the greatest, 
szu ma-ra-ni-ib2-mu2-mu2| he shall let it grow for you.” 
sipa zi gu3-de2-a| The righteous shepherd Gudea 
gal mu-zu gal i3-ga-tum3-mu| learnt big, and now he will perform big. 
inim {d}nansze-e mu-na-du11-ga-asz| To the word Nanše spoke to him, 
sag sig ba-szi-gar| he bowed his head. 
e2 nig2-gur11-ra-na kiszib3 bi2-kur2| He broke the seal of his treasure house, 
gesz im-ma-ta-gar| he brought out wood. 
gu3-de2-a gesz-a mu-gub-gub| Gudea stood by the wood, 
gesz-e mu10 im-e| he is caring for the wood. 
{gesz}mes-e sag bi2-sa6| He made the top of the ‘mes’ wood good. 
{gesz}ha-lu-ub2-ba tun3 bi2-bar| He put the oak wood to the axe.

dur9{ur3}-bi pirig-kas4-e-pa3-da| The donkey stallion, ‘lion called for running’, 
im-ma-szi-la2-la2| he harnesses for it. 
szu-nir ki-ag2-ni mu-na-dim2| He fashioned his beloved emblem for him, 
mu-ni im-mi-sar| he wrote his name on it. 
balag ki-ag2-e uszumgal kalam-ma| With his beloved harp, ‘dragon of the land’, 
gesz-gu3-di mu tuku nig2 ad gi4-gi4-ni| the famous roaring wood, with which he councels, 
ur-sag nig2-ba-e ki-ag2-ra| to the hero loving gifts,

e2-ninnu anzu2{muszen}-babbar2-ra| in Eninnu, the white Anzu, 
mu-na-da-kux(KWU147)-kux(KWU147)| he enters. 
e2-a hul2-la i3-na-ni-kux(KWU147)| Joyfully he entered to him in the house. 
gu3-de2-a esz3 e2-ninnu-ta zalag-ga nam-ta-e3| Didn’t Gudea go out, brilliantly, from the shrine Eninnu? 
2(asz)-kam-ma e2-sze3 u4-u3-de3 bi2-dab| For the second (time), in(?) the house he passed the days, 
ge6-ge6 ba-an-dab| he passed the nights. 
du6-du6 mu-si-ig i5-gar mu-gi4| He flattened the hills, he returned accusations. 
ah-du11-ga gir2-ta im-ta-gar| He removed the spittle from the dagger. 
szu-ga-lam ki husz ki di-ku5-ne| To Šugalam, the terrible place, the place of rendering justice, 
ki {d}nin-gir2-su-ke4 kur-kur-ra igi mi-ni-gal2-la-sze3| the place of Ningirsu’s looking on all the lands, 
udu i3 gukkal masz2 niga ensi2-ke4| the governor, fattened(?) sheep, fat-tail sheep, fattened goats, 
asz2-gar3 gesz nu-zu kusz-ba mi-ni-dab5-dab5| un-fertilized sheep, in their hides, he brought in. 
li {gesz}u2-sikil kur-ra-kam izi-a bi2-si-si| Juniper, the pure tree of the mountain he placed on the fire, 
szim erin ir-szim dingir-ra-kam| cedar incense, the incense of the gods, 
i3-bi2-bi mu-du3| its smoke he made. 
lugal-ni-ir ug3-ga2 mu-na-zi szu12 mu-na-de6| He rose for his king in public, he prayed to him, 
ub-szu-kin-na-ka mu-na-gen giri17 szu mu-na-gal2| he went to him in ‘ubšu-ukkina’, he greeted him: 
lugal-mu {d}nin-gir2-su en a husz gi4-a| “My king, Ningirsu, lord holding back the terrible water, 
en zi a kur gal-e ri-a| righteous lord, semen poured out by the ‘great mountain’. 
szul ka-tar nu-tuku| I am the youth not possessing guilt (?). 
{d}nin-gir2-su e2-zu ma-ra-du3-e| Ningirsu, I will build your house for you, 
geszkim-mu nu-mu| (but) my sign is my not. 
ur-sag nig2-du7-e gu3 ba-a-de2| Hero you poured out the voice to me about the old order, 
dumu {d}en-lil2-la2 en {d}nin-gir2-su| son of Enlil, lord Ningirsu, 
sza3-bi nu-mu-u3-da-zu| I don’t understand its ‘heart’, 
sza3 ab-gin7 zi-zi-zu| your ‘heart’, surging, like the ocean, 
{gesz}esi-gin7 ga2-ga2-zu| your, receding, like the wave, 
a e3-a-gin7 gu3 nun di-zu| your roaring, like cascading water, 
a-ma-ru12-gin7 u2-ru14 gul-gul-zu| like a flood, your crushing of cities, 
u4-gin7 ki-bala-sze3 du7-du7-zu| like the storm, your smashing of rebel lands, 
lugal-mu sza3-zu a e3-a u2 nu-la2-zu| my king, your whirling water which cannot be held back, your ‘heart’. 
ur-sag sza3 an-gin7 su3-ra2-zu| Hero, your remote, like the heaven, ‘heart’, 
dumu {d}en-lil2-la2 en {d}nin-gir2-su| son of Enlil, lord Ningirsu, 
ge26 a-na mu-u3-da-zu| I, what can I learn from you?” 
2(asz)-kam-ma-sze3 nu2-a-ra nu2-a-ra| For the second (time), to the sleeping, to the sleeping, 
sag-ga2 mu-na-gub ul4(GIR2) mu-da6-da6-e| he stood by his head, he is touching his dagger: 
ma-du3-na ma-du3-na| “(That which) you are building for me, (that which) you are building for me, 
ensi2 e2-mu ma-du3-na| Governor, the house you are building for me, 
gu3-de2-a e2-mu du3-da geszkim-bi ga-ra-ab-szum2| Gudea, I will surely give you the sign of the building of my house. 
garza-ga2 mul-an ku3-ba gu3 ga-mu-ra-a-de2| The shiny star of my ‘garza’ I will certainly proclaim for you. 
e2-mu e2-ninnu an-ne2 ki gar-ra| My house, Eninnu, founded by An, 
me-bi me gal-gal me-me-a diri-ga| its ‘me’ is bigger than all the other enormous ‘me’ 
e2 lugal-bi igi su3 il2-il2| The king of the house gazes far. 
anzu2{muszen}-gin7 szeg12 gi4-a-bi-sze3| Like the Anzu, its shriek, 
an im-szi-dub2-dub2| makes the heaven tremble. 
me-lam2 husz-bi an-ne2 im-us2| Its terrible radiance reaches the heaven. 
e2-ga2 ni2 gal-bi kur-kur-ra mu-ri| The big fear of my house is spread on all the lands. 
mu-bi-e an-za3-ta kur-kur-re gu2 im-ma-si-si| At its name all the lands gather at the horizon. 
ma2-gan me-luh-ha kur-bi-ta im-ma-ta-e11-de3| Magan (and) Meluhha will descend from their land. 
ge26 {d}nin-gir2-su a husz gi4-a| I Ningirsu, holding back the terrible water, 
ur-sag gal ki {d}en-lil2-la2-ka| the big hero in the place of Enlil, 
en gaba-ri nu-tuku| having no rival, 
e2-mu e2-ninnu-ga2 en kur-ra ab-si-a| I, the lord, have made my house, the Eninnu, bigger than a mountain. 
tukul-mu szar2-ur3 kur szu-sze3 gar-gar| My weapon, ‘multitude-eraser’, which places the mountain in the hand, 
igi husz-a-mu kur-re nu-um-il2| my terrible eye, which the lands cannot sustain, 
a2-bad-a-mu lu2 la-ba-ta-e3| no-one shall leave my out-going out arm. 
a-ugu4-mu nam-gal ki-ag2-da| My father and begetter, with love of greatness, 
lugal a-ma-ru {d}en-lil2-la2| the king, flood of Enlil, 
igi husz-a-ni kur-da nu-il2| the border lands cannot sustain his terrible eye, 
{d}nin-gir2-su ur-sag {d}en-lil2-la2| Ningirsu, hero of Enlil, 
mu-sze3 mu-sa4| as name he named me. 
me 5(u)-a za3 mi-ni-kesz2| I collected the fifty ‘me’. 
{gesz}banszur mu-il2| I raised the offering table, 
szu-luh si bi2-sa2| I straightened the ‘šuluh’, 
szu si sa2-a-mu an ku3-ge u3-a ba-zi-ge| I will raise my straightened hand to the shiny heaven for abundance: 
nig2 szu-ga2 du10-ga-am3| the things of my hand are sweetness. 
a-ugu4-mu du10-ga-bi mu-gu7| My father and begetter ate the sweetness, 
an lugal dingir-re-ne-ke4| An, king of the gods, 
{d}nin-gir2-su lugal iszib an-na| ‘Ningirsu, king, priest of An’, 
mu-sze3 mu-sa4| as name he named me. 
ti-ra-asz2 abzu-gin7| Tiraš, like Abzu, 
nam-nun-na ki im-ma-ni-gar| he founded in princeliness. 
sza3-bi-a iti-da u4-sakar-ra| Within it, with (each) moon, on the new moon day, 
me gal-gal ezem an-na-mu szu gal ma-du7-du7| he perfected for me greatly the very large ‘me’, my heavenly festival. 
e2-husz ki husz-mu| Ehuš my Kihuš, 
musz-husz-gin7 ki szur2-ra bi2-du3| like the Mušhuš(u-dragon?), he built on a frightening place. 
ki-bala-ga2 nu-mi-ib2-du11-ga| my rebellious place, which is not argued against, 
u4 sza3-mu um-szi-mi-ri2-a| when my ‘heart’ has become angry with it, 
musz-ze2-gur5-a-gin7 usz ma-a-u3-KU-e| it produces poison for me like a poisonous snake. 
e2-babbar2 ki a2 ag2-ga2-ga2| Ebabbar, place of my decisions, 
ki {d}utu-gin7 dalla-a-ga2| place of my sun-like shining, 
ki-ba {d}isztaran-gin7 di iri-ga2 si ba-ni-ib2-sa2-e| on that spot, I straighten the (law) cases of my city like Ištaran. 
e2 ba-gara2 ki banszur-ra-mu| In the house Bagara, the place of my table, 
dingir gal-gal lagasz{ki}-a-ke4-ne| the great gods of Lagash, 
gu2 ma-si-si-ne| assemble for me. 
e2-mu e2 sag-kal kur-kur-ra| My house, ‘chief house of all lands’, 
a2 zi-da lagasz{ki}| ‘right arm of Lagash’, 
anzu2{muszen} an-szar2-ra sig4 gi4-gi4| ‘Anzu shrieking in all of heaven’, 
e2-ninnu e2 nam-lugal-mu| ‘Eninnu, my royal house’, 
sipa zi gu3-de2-a| righteous shepherd, Gudea, 
u4 szu zi ma-szi-tum3-da| when your righteous hand caries it out, 
an-sze3 szegx(IM.A)-e gu3 ba-de2| (when) you call the heaven for rain, 
an-ta he2-gal2 ha-mu-ra-ta-du| I will let bounty come to you from the heaven. 
ug3-e he2-gal2-la szu he2-a-da-pesz-e| May people stretch out the hand in bounty with you. 
e2-ga2 usz ki gar-ra-bi-da| With the founding of my house, 
he2-gal2 he2-da-dub| may abundance arrive. 
GAN2 gal-gal-e szu ma-ra-ab-il2-e| The great fields will lift the hand for you. 
e pa5 gu2-bi ma-ra-ab-zi-zi| The canals and the ditches will overflow their banks for you. 
du6-du6 ki a nu-e11-da| Mounds that are never submerged, 
a ma-ra-e11-de3| will be submerged for you. 
ki-en-gi-re6 i3 diri mu-da-de2| Sumer will pour out oil in excess with you, 
siki diri mu-da-la2| will weigh out wool in excess for you. 
u4 temen-mu ma-si-ge4-na| When you place my platform for me, 
e2-mu u4 szu zi ma-szi-tum3-da| when you put your righteous hand to my house, 
hur-sag ki {tu15}mer tusz-a-sze3| the mountain, the place where the North-Wind rests, 
giri3-mu ki i3-bi2-us2| (when) you have reached it, 
nita a2 diri-ke4 {tu15}mer-e hur-sag ki sikil-ta| the excessively strong male, the North-Wind, from the Mountain, the pure place, 
im si ma-ra-ab-sa2-e| will straighten a wind for you. 
ug3-e zi-sza3-gal2 u3-ma-szum2| After I have given life to the people, 
lu2 dili lu2 min-da kin mu-da-ak-ke4| a solitary man will work with another. 
ge6-a-na i3-ti ma-ra-e3-e3| At midnight the moon goes up for you, 
e-bar7-GAN2 u4-ma-dam ma-ra-e3-e3| at midday the abundance of the sun goes up for you. 
e2 u4-de3 ma-ra-du3-e| I will build the house for you at day, 
ge6-e ma-ra-ab-mu2-mu2| at night I will let it grow for you. 
sig-ta {gesz}ha-lu-ub2| From below: oak, 
{gesz}NE-HA-GAG mu-ra-ta-e11-de3| ‘peace’-tree will I bring down(!) to you. 
igi-nim-ta {gesz}erin {gesz}szu-ur2-me {gesz}za-ba-lum ni2-bi-a ma-ra-an-tum3| From above: cedar šurme-wood, zabalum-wood, by itself, 
kur {gesz}esi-a-ka| from(?) the ebony-land,

kur na-ka na gal hur-sag-ga2| In the land of stone, large boulders of stone from the mountains,

u4-bi-a a2-zu izi bi2-tag| On that day (when) your arm is touched with fire, 
geszkim-mu ha-mu-u3-zu| I will teach you my sign.” 
gu3-de2-a i3-zi u3-sa-ga-am3| Gudea rose, it was a dream. 
i3-ha-luh ma-mu-dam| He is afraid, it was a dream. 
inim du11-ga {d}nin-gir2-su-ka-sze3| To Ningirsu’s spoken word, 
sag sig ba-szi-gar| he bowed the head. 
masz2 babbar2-ra szu mu-gid2-de3| He is stretching the hand in a white goat. 
masz2-a szu ni-gid2 masz2-a-ni i3-sa6| He struck the hand into the goat, his goat is good. 
gu3-de2-a sza3 {d}nin-gir2-su-ka| For Gudea, the ‘heart’ of Ningirsu 
u4-dam mu-na-e3| it is the light, that dawned on him. 
gal mu-zu gal i3-ga-tum2-mu| He learned big, and now he will perform big. 
ensi2-ke4 iri-na lu2 dili-gin7| The governor, in his city, like a solitary man 
na-ri ba-ni-gar| he regulated the rites. 
ki lagasz{ki}-e dumu ama dili-a-gin7 sza3 mu-na-asz-e| area-Lagash makes its ‘heart’ like one for him, like one mothers sons. 
gesz szu mu-du8 {gesz}ad2 mu-zi| He tore up trees, he weeded. 
u2-gur5 mu-gar inim du11-ga bi2-gi4| He pruned, he returned accusations. 
szer7-da e2-ba im-ma-an-gi4| He returned ‘sin’ to its house. 
siki udu gan-na-kam szu-a mi-ni-gar-gar| wool from a pregnant sheep he placed in the hand (of the overseer). 
ama-a dumu-da gu3 nu-ma-da-de2| A mother does not accuse a son, 
dumu-u3 ama-ni-ra gu3 du3-a| accusations, a son to his mother 
nu-ma-na-du11| does not speak. 
ARAD2 a2-gesz-tag tuku-ra| The slave whose arm was touched by wood, 
lugal-a-ni sag nu-ma-da-dub2| his king does not smash his head.

al-e sa mu-la2 sag il2 mu-gen| He tied a sinew to the hoe, he went with raised head. 
{d}lugal-kur-dub2 igi-sze3 mu-na-gen| Lugalkurdub went in front of him, 
{d}ig-alim-ke4 gir2 mu-na-ga2-ga2| Igalim places the road for him, 
{d}nin-gesz-zi-da dingir-ra-ni| (and) Ningešzida, his god, 
szu mu-da-gal2-gal2| leads him by the hand. 
pisan u3-szub-ka a-sa-ga i3-ak| He did ‘asaga’ in the mold. 
ensi2-ra a-dab6 si-im a2-la2 mu-na-du12-am3| The ‘adab’, ‘sim’, and ‘ala’ were played for the governor. 
zu2 al sig4-bi sag im-mi-du8| He flattened the top of the brick with the tooth of the hoe. 
lal3 i3-nun i3-du10-nun-na al im-ma-ni-tag| He greased it with honey, butter oil, and fine butter oil. 
szembulug SZIMxPI gesz hi-a| Incense and resin from various trees 
uh-sze3 im-mi-ak| he made into a paste. 
dusu ku3 mu-il2 u3-szub-e im-ma-gub| He raised the shiny basket, he stood by the mold. 
gu3-de2-a im u3-szub-ba ni-gar| Gudea placed clay in the mold. 
nig2-du7 pa bi2-e3| The cultic order emerged. 
e2-a sig4-bi pa e3 mu-ni-ga2-ga2| The emergence of the brick of the house was placed. 
kur-kur-re i3 mu-da-su3-e| Foreigners sprinkle oil with him, 
erin mu-da-su3-e| sprinkle cedar (oil) with him. 
iri-ni ki lagasz{ki}-e se11-li2-a| His city, area-Lagash, in happiness(?) 
u4 mu-di3-ni-ib2-zal-e| passes the day with him. 
u3-szub mu-dub2 sig4 had2-de3 ba-szub| He shook the mold, he threw the brick to dry. 
zu2 al im aga3-ri2-na-ba-sze3| On its firing(?) 
igi zi ba-szi-bar| he looked righteously. 
SZIMxPI ha-szu-ur2 szembulug-a| incense, apples, and resin 
sag im-ma-ni-du8| he smeared on its top. 
sig4 u3-szub-ba mu-ni-gar-ra-ni| (About) his brick placed in the mold, 
{d}utu im-da-hul2| Utu was pleased with it. 
aga3-ri2 i7 mah-gin7 zi-ga-na| (About) his ‘agari’ which rises like a mighty river, 
lugal {d}en-ki-ke4 nam mu-na-tar| King Enki decided its destiny for him. 
sig4 mu-gar u3-szub e2-a i3-kux(KWU147)| He placed the brick, he brought the mold into the house, 
pisan u3-szub-ba-ta sig4 ba-ta-il2| he lifted the brick from the mold, 
men ku3 an-ne2 il2-la| it is a shiny throne raised to heaven. 
sig4 mu-il2 ug3-ga2-na mu-re6| He raised the brick, he brought it to his people, 
bir3 ku3 {d}utu sag bala-e-dam| it is the shiny team of Utu shaking its head. 
sig4-e e2-sze3 sag il2-la-bi| The brick raising its head to the house, 
ab2 {d}nanna tur3-ba rin2-rin2-dam| it is the cow of Nanna, whose pen is shining, 
sig4 mu-gar e2-a mu-lah5| He placed the brick, he walks in the house. 
e2-a gesz-hur-bi im-ga2-ga2| She is establishing the plan of the house, 
{d}nisaba sza3 szid zu-am3| it is Nisaba whose ‘heart’ knows counting. 
lu2-tur gibil-bi e2 du3-gin7| Like a young man building a new house, 
igi-ni u3 du10-ga nu-szi-kux(KWU147)-kux(KWU147)| he does not allow sweet sleep to enter his eyes. 
ab2 amar-bi-sze3 igi gal2-la-gin7| Like a cow whose eye are on its calf, 
e2-sze3 TE-TE-ma im-szi-gen| he walked to the house in great concern. 
lu2 ninda tur ka-a gub-ba-gin7| Like a man with (only) little food in the mouth, 
re7-e nu-szi-kusz2-u3| he is not resting in his walking. 
sza3 lugal-na u4-dam mu-e3| (That) his king’s ‘heart’ is the light (of the vision) dawned (on him). 
gu3-de2-a-ar inim {d}nin-gir2-su-ka uri3-am3 mu-du3| For Gudea, the word of Ningirsu is the sign he was building (under), 
sza3 gu3 di e2 du3-da-ka-na| in his ‘heart’ yearning for the building of the house, 
i5-gar sa6-ga-a lu2 im-ma-a-gar| a man gave me a good omen. 
hul2-la-gin7 im-ma-na-ni-ib2-gar| It was placed like something joyful for him, 
masz-a szu i3-gid2 masz-a-ni i3-sa6| he stretched his hand in the goat, his goat was good. 
a-mer-e sze ba-se3 igi-bi si ib2-sa2| He gave grain to the wave, its appearance was straight. 
gu3-de2-a sag-sze3 nu2| Gudea lying by the top, 
mu-nu2 inim mu-na-ta-e3| he slept, the word dawned on him. 
e2 lugal-na-ka du3-bi| To build his king’s house, 
e2-ninnu an ki-ta bad-bi| the separation of Eninnu from heaven and earth, 
igi-a mu-na-a-gal2| was brought to his attention. 
hul2-la-gin7 im-ma-na-ni-ib2-gar| It was placed like something joyful for him. 
gu mu-ba-ra me szu im-du7-du7| He threw the flax, he perfected the me. 
uz-ga ku3-ge esz3 mu-ga2-ga2| The shiny‘ uzga’ sustains the shrine. 
e2-a {d}en-ki-ke4 temen mu-si-ge| Enki places the foundation of the house, 
{d}nansze dumu eridu{ki}-ke4 esz-bar kin-ge26 mu10 ba-ni-du11| Nanše, the daughter of Eridu cared for the omen taking. 
ama lagasz{ki} ku3 {d}ga2-tum3-du10-ke4| The mother of Lagash, Shiny-Gatumdu, 
sig4-bi kur-kux(KWU147)-a mu-ni-du2| bore its bricks in flows. 
{d}ba-ba6 nin dumu-sag an-na-ke4| Baba, the lady, firstborn of An, 
i3 szim erin-na ba-ni-su3| was sprinkling oil and cedar oil there. 
e2-e en ba-gub la-gal ba-gub| The En and Lagar stood in the house, 
me-e szu si im-ma-sa2| they performed the me. 
{d}a-nun-na u3 di-de3 im-ma-szu4-szu4-ge-esz2| The Annunaki stood there admiring. 
gu3-de2-a lu2 e2 du3-a-ke4| Gudea, builder of the house, 
e2-a dusu-bi men ku3 sag-ga2 mu-ni-gal2| he placed the basket of the house, a shiny crown, on the head, 
usz mu-gar a2-gar ki im-mi-tag| he placed the foundation, the wall touched the ground, 
sa2 mu-se3 sig4-ga gu bi2-dub2| he gave a blessing, he stroked the brick with flax. 
e2-a silim 2(asz)-nam nam-mi-se3| For the second (time) did he not give a blessing in the house? 
gu kurun3-ba sag gal2-la-am3| It is flax in bloom placed on the top. 
e2-a silim 3(asz)-am3 nam-mi-se3| For the third (time) did he not give a blessing in the house? 
anzu2{muszen} amar-a a2 pag-am3| It is Anzu spreading its wings over the calfs. 
e2-a silim 4(asz) nam-mi-se3| For the fourth (time) did he not give a blessing in the house? 
pirig-tur pirig husz-a gu2-da la2-am3| It is a young lion embracing a terrible lion. 
e2-a sa2 5(asz)-am3 nam-mi-se3| For the fifth (time) did he not give a blessing in the house? 
an si-ga su2-lim il2-la-am3| It is the green sky, lifting terrifying radiance. 
e2-a sa2 6(asz)-am3 nam-mi-se3| For the sixths (time) did he not give a blessing in the house? 
u4 sa2 du11-ga hi-li gur3-am3| It is the dawn dressed in joy. 
e2-a sa2 7(asz) nam-mi-se3| For the seventh (time) did he not give a blessing in the house? 
e2-ninnu i3-ti u4 zal-la kalam si-am3| It is Eninnu—Moon passing (through)—filling the land. 
gesz ka2-na im-ga2-ga2-ne| They place the wood of the door. 
an se3-ga men il2-la-am3| It is the green sky lifting the crown. 
e2-mah an-da gu2 la2-am3| It is the lofty house embracing the heaven. 
e2 mu-du3 gesz-e im-ma-ru| He build the house, he planted the tree. 
e2 hur-sag-gin7 im-mu2-mu2-ne| They make the house grow like a mountain.

gu4-gin7 si im-mi-ib2-il2-il2-ne| They make it raise its hors like an ox.

e2-e hur-sag-gin7 an ki-a sag an-sze3 mi-ni-ib2-il2| The house raised the head to heaven like a mountain in heaven and earth. 
e2-ninnu sig4 ki-en-gi-ra2-ka hi-li mu-ni-ib2-du8-du8| Eninnu, brickwork of Kiengir, carries joy,

u2-a lagasz{ki} gu4 gal-gin7 a2 ba-il2-il2| The provider for Lagash raises the arm like a great ox. 
na gal-gal lagab-ba mi-ni-re6-a-na| His large stones brought in their blocks,

e2-ninnu ni2-bi kur-kur-ra| The fear of Eninnu, on all the lands,

e2 ku3 NE-a an-ne2 ki gar-ra| The house, founded by Anu with purified silver, 
szembi2-zi-da szu tag du11-ga| decorated with good perfume,

bar-bi an e2 mah he2-gal2-la zi-ga| its outside is a mighty house of abundance rising in heaven.

e2-ninnu im-bi im ha-mun| The clay of Eninnu, mixed clay, 
i7 edin-ta e11-da| is a flood draining(?) from the plain.

szu tag ba-ni-du11| decorated it.

gir2-PA-na-bi| The Girpana, 
gu4 gu7 udu gu7| feeding oxen, feeding sheep. 
e2 ki kur6-bi uz-ga ab-ga2-ga2| The provisions place, sustaining the uzga. 
ne-sag-bi| The wine-cellar(?) 
kur gesztin bi-bi-ze2| (called) ‘mountain dripping with wine’. 
e2-bappir3-bi-ta| From the brewery, 
i7 idigna a u3-ba gal2-la-am3| (called) ‘Tigris is being water in its might’. 
e2 nig2-gur11-bi-a za ku3 nagga| In the treasury, precious stones, silver, tin. 
e2 {gesz}gigir-ra-bi| The coach house, 
kur ki-a gub-ba| (called) ‘mountain standing on the ground’. 
a-ga balag-a-bi gu4 gu3 nun di| The inner room of haprs, (called) ‘ox roaring princely’. 
kisal-bi szu12 ku3 si-im a2-la2| The courtyard, shiny prayers, ‘sim’ and ‘ala’ (sounds). 
kun na4 e2-a nu2-a-bi| The stone basin sleeping in the house, 
hur-sag ul nun-ne2-esz2 nu2-am3| it is a mountain sleeping in full flowering. 
kun nagga ganun-sze3 da-a-bi| The tin basin, siding with the storeroom, 
nu11 kur-sze3 igi su3 il2-dam| it is the light lifting the distant gaze to the mountain. 
{gesz}kiri6-MI-edin e2-sze3 si-ga-bi| The garden of the black plain placed with the house, 
kur gesztin bi-bi-ze2 ki IM-NE-e mu2-am3| it is the frightening place grown together with ‘mountain driping with wine’. 
na 7(asz) e2-e dab6-ba-bi| The seven stones seized by the house, 
nig2 lugal-bi-da sza3 kusz2-kusz2-dam| are things counselling with its king. 
e2 nig2 ki-se3-ga| The house of funerary offerings, 
nig2-sikil abzu na ri-ga-am3| is a pure thing, instructed by Abzu. 
szim-na4 e2-a szu4-ga-bi| The fragrant stones standing in the house, 
e2 gudu4-ku3 a nu-silig5-ge-dam| it is the house of the purification priests never lacking water. 
bad3-si-an-na| The high battlements 
tu{muszen} du2-ru-na-bi| where pigeons dwell, 
eridu{ki} NAM hi-a GAG x-am3| it is Eridu, built in abundance(?). 
an-dul3 pa gal-gal gissu du10-ga-am3| it is a shade of large leaves, a sweet shadow. 
buru5{muszen} muszen-e sig4 mu-gi4-gi4| Buru-birds shrieking, 
e2-kur {d}en-lil2-la2 ezem gal2-la-am3| it is the Ekur of Enlil in a festival. 
e2-a ni2-gal-bi| The big fear of the house 
kalam-ma mu-ri| rests on the land. 
ka tar-ra-bi| Its praise 
kur-re ba-ti| reaches the mountains. 
e2-ninnu ni2-bi kur-kur-ra tug2-gin7 im-dul4| The fear of Eninnu covers all the lands like a garment. 
e2 lugal-bi hi-li-a ni-du3| The house (was) built in joy by its king. 
{d}nin-gesz-zi-da-ke4| Ningešzida 
ki-gal-la bi2-du3| built it on a big place. 
gu3-de2-a ensi2 lagasz{ki}-ke4| Gudea, governor of Lagash, 
temen-bi mu-si| placed its foundation. 
e2 {d}utu-gin7 kalam-ma e3-a| Temple--going out in the land, 
gu4 gal-gin7 sahar bar-ra gub-ba| standing outside in the dust like a big ox, 
i3-ti giri17-zal-gin7| like the moon pleasurably 
ukken-ne2 si-a| filling the assembly, 
hur-sag sig7-ga-gin7| like a green mountain 
hi-li gur3-a| clad in joy, 
u6 di-de3 gub-ba|--standing to be admired. 
e2-ninnu ki-bi gi4-a-ba| For the restoration of Eninnu 
{d}nin-gir2-su za3-mu10| Ningirsu be praised! 
e2 {d}nin-gir2-su-ka du3-a| The building of the house of Ningirsu, 
za3-mu10 mu-ru-bi-im| this is the middle of the praise. 
e2 dim-gal kalam-ma| House, mooring post of the Land,
an ki-da mu2-a| grown up from earth to heaven,
e2-ninnu szeg12 zi {d}en-lil2-e nam du10-ga tar-ra| Eninnu, the good Brick for which Enlil has made a favorable firm promise,
hur-sag sig7-ga u6-e gub-ba| green mountain range, standing to be admired,
kur-kur-ta e3-a| standing out above all the lands.
e2 kur gal-am3 an-ne2 im-us2| The House, being a great mountain, bordered on heaven,
{d}utu-am3 an-sza3-ge im-si| being the sun, it filled mid-heaven with light,
e2-ninnu anzu2{muszen}-babbar2-ra-am3| being Eninnu, the White Thunderbird,
kur-ra du10 mi-ni-ib2-bad| it (attacked) the mountain with spread wings.
ug3 ba-gar-gar kalam ba-re7| The people have all been settled (again), and the Land has gone home,
{d}a-nun-na u6 di-de3 im-ma-szu4-szu4-ge-esz2| (but) the Anunna gods are all standing in admiration.
ensi2 ku3-zu-am3 inim-zu-am3| The ruler, who is wise, is knowledgeable,
nam-dingir-re ka ki im-mi-su2-su2| kisses the ground over and over before the divinities;
siskur2-ra-zu-a nig2-dun-a ki im-mi-us2-us2| with rites and prayer, in submission, he touches the ground;
ensi2-ke4 dingir iri-na-ke4 ra2-zu im-ma-be2| the ruler, the (personal) god of his city, says a prayer.
e2 ninda-gu7-bi ninda ba-an-dah| For the bread-consuming House he added more bread,
kin-sig7 udu dab5-bi udu im-ma-a-dah| for the supper in need of mutton he added more sheep.
bur he2-gal2 an sza3-pi5-sza-gin7| As if it were for the abundance of vast midheaven,
gaba-ba si bi2-sa2| in front (of the House) he set up jars in a row.
a-nun-na-ke4-ne-er mu-ne-gen| He went to the Anunna gods,
szu12 mu-ne-ra2 {d}a-nun-na {d}a-nun-na u6 di-de3 ki lagasz{ki}| prayed to them: “O all you Anunna gods who are admiring (what) the Land of Lagaš (achieved),
{d}lamma kur-kur-ra du11-ga-ne-ne a mah e3-a| protectors of all the countries, whose command, a torrent of water,
lu2-u2-la2 ba-ab-la2-e| will make the one who (would try to) stem it founder,
szul zi lu2 igi mu-szi-bar-ra-ne| (but) who to the worthy man upon whom they looked
nam-ti mu-na-su3| have given a long life,
sipa-me e2 mu-du3 lugal-mu e2-a-na mi-ni-kux(KWU636)-kux(KWU636)| I, the shepherd, built the House, and my master will enter his House—
a-nun-na bar-mu-a szu12 he2-mi-sa4-sa3| would you, O Anunna gods, say a blessing on my behalf?”
sipa zi gu3-de2-a| The true shepherd Gudea
gal mu-zu gal i3-ga-tum2-mu| is wise and able, too, to realize things.
u2-du11 sa6-ga-ni igi-sze3 mu-na-gen| His friendly guardian walks in front of him,
{d}lamma sa6-ga-ni egir-ni im-us2| and his friendly protecting genius is following him,
lugal-ne2 e2 ul e2 libir ki-tusz-na-sze3| (and so) to his master for the House of yore, the old House, his (former) abode,
gu3-de2-a en {d}nin-gir2-su-ra| to the lord Ningirsu Gudea
nig2 ba-na-gu-ul-gu-ul| made great gifts.
en-ra e2-ninnu-a mu-na-gen| He went into Eninnu, to the lord,
szu12 mu-na-ra2| prayed to him:
lugal-mu {d}nin-gir2-su2| “My master Ningirsu,
en a-husz gi4-a| lord who has turned back the fierce waters,
en du11-ga-ni sag-pesz e3-a| lord whose command takes precedence,
ibila {d}en-lil2-la2 ur-sag ma-a-du11| Enlil’s male child, warrior, you spoke to me,
szu zi ma-ra-a-gar| and I did faithfully obey you.
{d}nin-gir2-su e2-zu mu-ra-du3| Ningirsu, I built you your House,
hul2-la ha-ni-kux(KWU636)-kux(KWU636)| may you enter it in joy.”
{d}ba-ba6-mu a2-mi-zu ma-ra-gar| (And he added) “My Baba, I erected your women’s quarters for you,
ki-tusz du10-ga-ma-ni-ib2| move in in comfort.”
gu3 de2-a-ni gesz ba-tuku-am3| His call was heard,
ur-sag-e siskur2 ra2-zu-ni| the warrior accepted from Gudea, the lord Ningirsu
gu3-de2-a-asz2 en {d}nin-gir2-su-ke4 szu ba-szi-ti| accepted from him, prayer and rite.
mu gen-na-am3 iti til-la-am3| (Meanwhile) the year had ended, the month had been completed,
mu gibil an-na im-ma-gub| the new year had appeared in the sky,
iti e2-ba ba-a-kux(KWU636)| the month “had entered its house,”
iti-bi u4 3(asz)-am3 im-ta-zal| and of that month the third day had passed:
{d}nin-gir2-su2 eridu{ki}-ta du-am3| (Then) Ningirsu had arrived from Eridu,
i3-ti sa-sa im-e3| (and) the most beautiful moonlight shone
kalam-ma u4 mu-gal2 e2-ninnu {d}suen u3-du2-da| illuminating the Land; Eninnu with the (new-)born moon (god)
sag im-ma-da-ab-sa2| vied.
gu3-de2-a gug za-gin3 mi-ni-uh| Gudea made a paste with carnelian and lapis lazuli,
ub da im-mi-du11| he put it in the corners
i3-hi-nun-na ki ba-ni-su3| and sprinkled abundant oil on the floor.
musz-da-ma lu2 kin ak-am3| He bade the builders, the workmen,
e2-ta ba-ta-e3| leave the House.
lal3 i3-nun gesztin ga-sze-a| Syrup, butter oil, wine, sour milk,
{gesz}par4 {gesz}pesz3 ninda gen-na| gipar-fruit, fig-cakes
ga sag-ba dim2-ma| topped with cheese,
zu2-lum gesz-an gesztin tur-tur| dates in clusters(?), small grapes,
nig2 izi nu-tag-ga| (all) things untouched by fire,
nig2-gu7 dingir-re-ne-kam| (to prepare) food for the gods,
lal3 i3-nun-na kin ba-ni-ak szeg12| he used syrup and butter.
u4 dingir zi-da du-da| From the moment when the sun rose in the good sky,
gu3-de2-a u4-te-ta| Gudea, from early morning
kin-se3-ge bi2-dab| till supper (time) passed to and fro.
e2-e {d}asar-re szu si ba-sa2| Asari saw to it that the House was all right,
{d}nin-ma-da-ke4 na-ri mi-ni-gar| Nin-mada gave advice,
lugal {d}en-ki-ke4 esz-bar-kin ba-an-szum2| king Enki provided oracular messages.
{d}nin-dub iszib-mah eridu{ki}-ka-ke4| Nin-duba, foremost lustration priest of Eridu,
na-de3 ba-ni-si| filled (the House) with incense,
{d}nin-garza-kal-la-ke4 {d}nansze szer3 ku3 inim zu e2-e ba-an-du11| the lady of precious rites, Nanše, who knows the words of sacred songs, put them to music for the House.
u8 ge6-ge umbin mi-ni-ib2-kin| She “sheared” the black ewes (of the sky),
im-ma-al an-na-ke4| and of the cow-of-heaven
akan si ba-ni-ib2-sa2| she milked the udder,
e2-ninnu im-ta-sikil-e-ne| they were cleaning Eninnu
im-ta-dadag-ge-esz2| until they had polished it to perfection.
ensi2-ke4 iri-a du10 bi2-gar| The ruler made the (whole) city kneel down,
kalam-ma sig bi2-gar| he made the Land prostrate itself.
du6-du6 mu-si-ig i5-gar mu-gi4| He leveled what was high, refused (to listen to) chance utterances,
a-ah-du11-ga gir2-ta gar-am3| “spittle” (of sorcery) was removed from the daggers.
iri-a ama lu2 tu-ra-ke4| In the city (only) the mother of a sick person
a silim gar-ra-am3 masz-ansze nig2-zi-gal2 edin-na| administered a potion—the wild animals, creatures of the steppe,
tesz2-bi-sze3 gam-ma-am3| all had crouched together.
ur-mah pirig uszumgal edin-na-ka| Lion, lioness(?) and the “dragon of the steppe”
u3 du10 gar-ra-am3| enjoyed sweet sleep.
u4 siskur2-re ge6 szu12-de3| Rites (had made) the day (go by), prayers the night,
i3-ti nig2 u4 zal-la-ke4| the early morning (had) the moonlight (caused to fade)—
lugal-bi mu-sag5-ge26-e| was the master (of the House) on his way?
ur-sag {d}nin-gir2-su e2-a mi-ni-kux(KWU636)-kux(KWU636)| (Yea,) the warrior Ningirsu was entering (his) House.
e2-a lugal-bi im-ma-gub| The master of the House had come to it
hu-ri2-in am-sze3 igi il2-il2-dam| like an eagle catching sight of an aurochs.
ur-sag e2-a-na kux(KWU636)-kux(KWU636)-da-ni| When the warrior was entering his House,
u4 me3-sze3 gu3 {ga2}gar-am3| he was a storm roaring towards battle,
{d}nin-gir2-su e2-na mu-lah5| Ningirsu went about his House,
esz3 abzu ezem gal2-la-am3| and it was (just as) in the Abzu sanctuary when a festival is going on.
lugal e2-a-ni-ta nam-ta-du| The owner indeed came out of his House (again),
{d}utu ki lagasz{ki}-e e3-am3| and he was (like) the sun god rising above the land of Lagaš.
{d}ba-ba6 a2-mi-ni-sze3 du-a-ni| When Baba went to her women’s quarters
munus zi e2-a-ni-sze3 szu ga2-ga2-dam| she was (like) a respectful woman caring for her house;
a2-nu2-da-ka-na kux(KWU636)-ra-ni| when she entered her bedroom
i7 idigna a u3-ba {ga2}gar-am3| she was (like) the Tigris at high waters,
nin dumu an ku3-ga {gesz}kiri6 nisi-ga kurun3 il2-la-am3| she was the lady, daughter of bright An, a green garden bearing fruit.
u4 e3-am3 nam tar-ra-am3| The day was about to rise, firm promise had been fulfilled,
{d}ba-ba6 a2-mi-na kux(KWU636)-ra-am3| Baba had entered her women’s quarters—
ki lagasz{ki} he2-gal2-la-am3| that meant) abundance for the land of Lagaš.
u4 im-zal {d}utu lagasz{ki}-ke4 kalam-ma sag mi-ni-il2| The day dawned, the sungod of Lagaš lifted his head over the Land.
gu4-ni udu-ni e2-e bi2-dab5| Fattened oxen and sheep were taken to the House,
bur an-na mu-gub tin mu-ni-de2-de2| (Gudea) set up a jar in the open air, poured much wine into it.
{d}a-nun-na ki lagasz{ki} en {d}nin-gir2-su-da ki-bi mu-da-rin2-ne2-esz2-am3| The Anunna gods of the land of Lagaš were installed around the lord Ningirsu.
e2-a nam-iszib-ba szu mi-ni-du7| (Gudea) performed the purification of the House in the most attentive way,
esz-bar-kin mi2 mi-ni-du11| and he took care of portents.
kurun2 bur gal-la im-ma-de2| Wine was poured from the big jar
esz3 {d}nin-dub-ke4 szeg12 mu-gi4-gi4| Nin-duba caused the sanctuary to be full of clatter and noise,
ninda had2-da ga masz2 lulim-ma| and with fresh bread, milk of hinds
u4 ge6-e re6-a| available day and night,
nir-gal2 dumu ki-ag2 {d}en-lil2-la2 ur-sag {d}nin-gir2-su2| the noble one, the beloved child of Enlil, the warrior Ningirsu.
u3-a mi-ni-zi-zi| he rouses from sleep.
me gal-gal-la sag mi-ni-il2-e| He (Ningirsu) proudly looks around, very sure of himself,
esz3 e2-ninnu ki-us2 mu-ga2-ga2| he lines up (to be assigned functions) for the sanctuary Eninnu.
zi-du-e szu si sa2-da| That he (Ig-alim) might guide the hand of the righteous one
erim2 du-e gu2 gesz ga2-ga2-da| and force the evil-doer’s neck into a neck stock,
e2 gi-ne2-da e2 du10-ge-da| that he might keep the House safe, keep it in harmony,
iri-ni esz3 gir2-su{ki} na-de6 szum2-mu-da| that he might give instructions to his city (and) the sanctuaries of Girsu,
{gesz}gu-za nam tar-ra gub-da| that he might establish a throne of firm promise,
gidri u4 su3-ra2 szu-a ga2-ga2-da| hand over a sceptre for long days,
sipa {d}nin-gir2-su-ke4 gu3 de2-a-ar| that he might make the shepherd called by Ningirsu
men sig7-ga-gin7 sag an-sze3 il2-da| lift high the head as if it wore a blue crown,
kusz-la2 gada-la2 sag-a mu4-a| that the “skin-clad,” the “linen-clad,” and the “covered head”
kisal e2-ninnu-ka ki-gub pa3-de3-da| he might appoint to (their) offices in the courtyard of Eninnu—
ig gal dim gir2-nun-na gal5-la2-gal gir2-su{ki}| the Great Door, the Pole of Girnun, the chief bailiff of Girsu,
{d}ig-alim dumu ki-ag2-ga2-ni| his beloved son Ig-alim,
en {d}nin-gir2-su-ra me-ni-da mu-na-da-dab-e| he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to the lord Ningusu.
e2 sikil-e-da szu4-luh ga2-ga2-da| That he (Šul-šaga) might keep the House clean, let hands always be washed,
szu ku3 a en-ra szum2-mu-da| have clean hands serve water to the lord,
kasz bur-ra de2-da kurun2 dug-a de2-da| that he might pour beer into bowls, wine into jars,
e2-lunga3 e2 a2 sikil-ba| that in (Eninnu’s) brewery, the “house (with) the clean arms,”
u2-lu5-szi-e a pap-sir2-gin7| emmer beer like the waters (of) Papsir
kun-ga-an za-a-da| might bubble,
gu4 du7 masz2 du7 udu niga| that unblemished oxen and goats and grain-fed sheep,
ninda had2-da ga masz2 lulim-ma| fresh bread, and milk of hinds
u4 ge6-e re6-a nir-gal2 dumu ki-ag2| be available day and night, that the noble one,
{d}en-lil2-la2 ur-sag {d}nin-gir2-su| Enlil’s beloved son, the warrior Ningirsu,
en szu4-luh dadag-ga dumu-sag e2-ninnu| the lord of the most careful hand-washing, the first-bom son of Eninnu,
{d}szul-sza3-ga {d}nin-gir2-su-ra| Šul-šaga, to Ningirsu
me-ni-da mu-na-da-dab-e| he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces).
szita2 sag 7(asz) szu du8-a-da| That the seven-headed club might be held (firmly) in hand,
e2 en-kar2 ka2 me3-ka ig-bi gal2 tak4-tak4| that the (“King who makes the mountain tremble") might keep open the door-wings of the Ankar house, the Battle gate,
eme-gir2 mi-tum {gesz}a-ma-ru| that he might cause the dagger blades, the mace “dead man,” the “floodstorm weapon,”
har-ra-tum gesz-hur me3-bi| the “Bitter one,” (all of them) battle tools,
si sa2-sa2-a-da| exactly to hit their targets,
kur gu2-erim2-gal2 {d}en-lil2-la2-ka| all of Enlil’s enemies’ lands
a-gin7 ga2-ga2-da| that he might inundate—
ur-sag {gesz}szar2-ur3 me3-a kur szu-sze3 gar-gar| the warrior “Mow-down-a-myriad” who in battle subdues all the lands,
szagina gu2-tuku e2-ninnu| the mighty general of Eninnu,
muszen sur2-du3 ki-bala-a| the falcon for the rebel land,
{d}lugal-kur-dub2 szagina-ni| “King who makes the mountain tremble,” his general,
en {d}nin-gir2-su-ra me-ni-da mu-na-da-dab-e| he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to Ningirsu.
mi-tum an-na-ke4 u4 husz-gin7| After the heavenly mace “dead man” like a fierce storm
kur-sze3 gu3 gar-ra-a| has roared against the mountain,
{gesz}szar2-ur3 a-ma-ru me3| (being) the “Mow-down-a-myriad,” the floodstorm of battle,
{gesz}naga3 ki-bala-a| the cudgel of the rebel land,
en-ne2 ki-bala kur sag-ki-ni u3-ma-da-gid2-da| after the lord has frowned at the rebels, the mountain,
gu3 mi-ri2-a-ni u3-ma-ra| and hurled at it his furious words,
en-na szagina 2(asz)-kam-ni| the lord’s second general who is (called)
kur szu-na buru5{muszen}-am3| “The-land-is-but-a-swallow-in-his-hand.”
dumu {d}en-lil2-la2-ra me-ni-da mu-na-da-dab-e| he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to Enlil’s son.
nam-szita ki lagasz{ki}| That supplications of the land Lagaš
szu du8-a-da| might be released,
siskur2 ra2-zu-bi du10-ga ga2-ga2-da| that he (Lugal-sisa) might perform rites and prayers for it, propitious ones,
ur-sag eridu{ki}-sze3 du-a-ni| that when the warrior is going to Eridu
silim-ma du10 di-da| he might bid farewell,
{d}nin-gir2-su eridu{ki}-ta du-ni| and that, (as a result) when he is returning from Eridu,
iri du3-a {gesz}gu-za-bi gi-na| the throne of the built-up city be firm;
nam-ti sipa zi| that for the life of the true shepherd
gu3-de2-a-da| Gudea
giri17 szu gal2-la-da| hands be placed at the mouth (in prayer)—
ad-gi4-gi4-ni| his adviser,
{d}lugal-si-sa2 en {d}nin-gir2-su| Lugal-sisa, to the lord Ningirsu
me-ni-da mu-na-da-dab-e| he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces).
tur du11-ga-da| Of what had been whispered
mah du11-ga-da| and what had been said aloud,
inim si sa2-e ka-kesz2 ak-da| of whether the one speaking straightforwardly be seen as a partner
ur-sag bara2 ku3-ga tusz-a-ra| that the warrior sitting on a pure dais,
{d}nin-gir2-su-ra e2-ninnu-a inim-bi kux(KWU636)-kux(KWU636)-da| Ningirsu, might be informed in Eninnu
en {d}nin-gir2-su-ra me-ni-da| to the lord Ningirsu he (Gudea) brings along with himself
mu-na-da-dab-e| (and introduces).
a ku3-ge-da naga sikil-e-da| That he (Kindazi) might clean with water, scrub with soap,
gesz-nu2 u2 za-gin3 ba-ra-ga-na| that he (Ningirsu) on his bedspread with blue flowers
u3 du10 kux(KWU636)-kux(KWU636)-da| might enjoy sweet sleep;
e2-nu2 e2-du10-ga-ni-a| his bedroom in his “good house”
bar-ra kux(KWU636)-kux(KWU636)-da| that he might enter from outside,
sza3-ga nu-e3-e3-da| but) not go out from it (again)—
{d}kinda-zi lu2 e2-du10-ga-kam| Kindazi, who is the one of the “good house”
en {d}nin-gir2-su-ra me-ni-da mu-na-da-dab-e| he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to the lord Ningirsu.
{ansze}dur9{ur3}-bi pirig-kas4-e-pa3-da| and that a donkey stallion, a lion-summoned-for-running,
ansze-ba si-ga-da| be included in that donkey(-team);
ansze sig-a ansze eridu{ki}-ka| that a slender donkey, one of Eridu,
lugal-bi {d}nin-gir2-su hul2-la tum2-mu-da| that they might carry their master Ningirsu in joy—
lu2 ug-gin7 sig4 gi4-a| the one roaring like a lion,
mar-uru5-gin7 zi-ga| rising like a floodstorm,
maszkim da-ga {d}nin-gir2-su-ka| Ningirsu’s hurrying bailiff,
{d}en-sig4-nun sipa ansze-ka-ni| Ensignun, his donkeyherd,
en {d}nin-gir2-su-ra me-ni-da mu-na-da-dab-e| he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to the lord Ningirsu.
i3 hi-a-da kasz hi-a-da| That there might be an abundance of fat and cream,
ud5 ku3 ud5 ga nag masz2 lulim| that the white goats, milking goats, and the hind,
ama {d}nin-gir2-su-ka| Ningirsu’s mother,
i3 ga-bi esz3 e2-ninnu-a musz nu-tum2-da| might never cease to provide fat and milk for the sanctuary Eninnu—

me-ni-da mu-na-da-dab-e| he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces).
ti-gi4 nig2 du10-ge si sa2-a-da| That the kettle drum(?) of beautiful sound be properly tuned,

gal mu-zu gal i3-ga-tum2-mu| is wise and able, too, to realize things.

{gesz}gigir kur mu-gam su-zi gur3 ni2 gal u5-a| The chariot (named) “It subdued the mountain,” which carries terror and has made great awe “ride” on it,

e2 IM ne-mur szub ki us2-sa an gu2 la2-a| "The temple that lets fear(?) fall like embers, set upon the earth and embracing heaven,

e2 anzu2{muszen}-zu an-ne2 ha-ra-ab-il2| May the House, your Thunderbird, soar in the skies for your (benefit).
{d}gilgamesx(BIL3.GA.MES)-da mu2-a| grown as tall as Gilgamesh,
{gesz}gu-za gub-ba-bi lu2 nu-kur2-e| its throne set there no one shall remove.
dingir-zu en {d}nin-gesz-zi-da dumu-KA an-na-kam| Your (personal) god is Ningešzida, grandson of An,
dingir-ama-zu {d}nin-sun2-na szaganx(AMA){gan} numun zi-da| your mother goddess is Ninsuna, the mother who bore healthy offspring

nam-ti ha-mu-ra-su3| may life be prolonged for you.”
e2 kur gal-gin7 an-ne2 us2-sa| O House that reaches to heaven like a great mountain,

kur-kur-re zu-a| all countries have learned

alan-na-ni-sze3| and into (this) his stone figure 
mu-du2| he formed it. 
nin an ki-a nam tar-re-de3| The lady who would determine the fates in heaven and earth, 
{d}nin-tu| Nintu, 
ama dingir-re-ne-ke4| the mother of the gods, 
gu3-de2-a| of Gudea, 
lu2 e2 du3-a-ka| the man who built the temple, 
nam-ti-la-ni mu-su3| his life she shall prolong, 
mu-sze3 mu-na-sa4| he named it for her, 
e2-a mu-na-ni-kux(KWU634)| and into the temple he had it brought to her. 
e2 {d}nin-gir2-su| Within the temple of Ningirsu 
lugal-na-ta| his master-
alan gu3-de2-a| for the statue of Gudea, 
ensi2| the ruler 
lagasz{ki}| of Lagash, 
lu2 e2-ninnu| the man by whom the Eninnu temple 
in-du3-a-ke4| was built, 
1(asz) sila3 kasz| one sila3 of beer, 
1(asz) sila3 ninda| one sila3 of bread, 
1/2(asz) sila3 zi3-dub-dub| one half sila3 of heaping-flour 
1/2(asz) sila3 nig2-ar3-ra imgaga3| and one half sila3 of emmer groats, 
sa2-du11-ba gal2-la-am3| being the regular offering existing for it, 
ensi2| a (future) ruler 
inim bi2-ib2-gi4-gi4-a| who shall revoke it 
me {d}nin-gir2-su-ka| and who the divine power of Ningirsu 
ba-ni-ib2-la2-a| shall thereby diminish, 
sa2-du11-na| may his regular offerings 
e2 {d}nin-gir2-su-ka-ta| within the temple of Ningirsu 
inim he2-eb2-gi4| be revoked 
du11-du11-ni he2-kesz2| and all his pronouncements be blocked! 
{d}nin-gir2-su| For Ningirsu, 
ur-sag kal-ga| strong hero 
{d}en-lil2-la2-ra| of Enlil, 
gu3-de2-a| Gudea, 
mu gil-sa| he of lasting fame, 
ensi2| ruler 
lagasz{ki}| of Lagash, 
sipa sza3-ge pa3-da| the shepherd chosen by the heart 
{d}nin-gir2-su-ka-ke4| of Ningirsu, 
igi zi bar-ra| regarded favorably 
{d}nansze-ke4| by Nanše, 
a2 szum2-ma| given might 
{d}nin-dar-a-ke4| by Nindara, 
lu2 inim-ma se3-ga| a person subject to the word 
{d}ba-ba6-ke4| of Baba, 
dumu tu-da| child born 
{d}ga2-tum3-du10-ke4| by Gatumdug, 
nam-nir-gal2 gidri mah szum2-ma| given authority and a great scepter 
{d}ig-alim-ka-ke4| by Igalima, 
zi-sza3-gal2-la szu dagal du11-ga| richly provided with encouragement 
{d}szul-sza3-ga-ka-ke4| by Šulšaga, 
sag zi ukken-na pa e3-a| rightful head of the assembly come forth in splendor 
{d}nin-gesz-zi-da| of Ningešzida 
dingir-ra-na-ke4| his (personal) god, 
u4 {d}nin-gir2-su-ke4| when Ningirsu 
iri-ni-sze3 igi zi im-szi-bar-ra| had directed his righteous gaze towards his city, 
gu3-de2-a| and Gudea 
sipa zi-sze3 kalam-ma ba-ni-pa3-da| he had chosen as the rightful shepherd in the nation, 
sza3 lu2 1(szar'u)-ta| and out of 36,000 people 
szu-ni ba-ta-an-dab5-ba-a| had taken him by the hand, 
iri mu-ku3 izi im-ma-ta-la2| he (Gudea) sanctified the city and refined it with fire. 
{gesz}u3-szub mu-gar| He set up the brick mold, 
sig4 masz-e bi2-pa3| and chose the (first) brick by kid-omen. 
lu2 uzug5-ga ni2 gal2| The sexually impure persons who inspire fear, 
gesz3 bir2| he with a shriveled(?) penis, 
munus kin du11-ga| and the woman who had been in labor(?), 
iri im-ta-e3| he sent out of the city. 
dusu-bi munus-e nu-il2| Women did not carry the earth baskets for it, 
sag-ur-sag-e mu-na-du3| (only) the chief warriors did the building for him. 
e2 {d}nin-gir2-su-ka| The temple of Ningirsu 
eridu{ki}-gin7| like (the city) Eridu 
ki sikil-la bi2-du3| in a clean place he built. 
usan3 la-ba-sag3| There was no beating with whips 
{kusz}a2-si la-ba-sag3| nor beating with leather straps. 
ama dumu-ne2 nig2 nu ma-ni-ra| No mother hit her child with anything. 
szagina| The military governors, 
nu-banda3| overseers, 
ugula| foremen, 
lu2-zi-ga| those who performed worker levies, 
kin-a gub-ba-ba| while stationed at the work 
siki {gesz}garig2-ak| (as light as) wool under the carding comb 
nam-sag3 szu-ba mu-gal2-am3| was the disciplining he put into their hands. 
ki-mah iri-ka al nu-gar| No pickax was used in the cemetery of the city, 
ad8 ki nu-tum2| no corpse was buried. 
gala-e balag nu-du er2 nu-ta-e3| The lamentation singer did not play the harp or bring forth laments, 
ama-er2-ke4 er2 nu-bi2-du11| The wailing women did not perform wailing. 
ki-sur-ra| Within the territory 
lagasz{ki}-ka| of Lagash, 
lu2 di tuku| a person having a lawsuit 
ki nam-erim2-sze3| to the place of oath-taking 
lu2 nu-gen| did not make another person go, 
lu2 ur5-ra| and a creditor 
e2 lu2-ka nu-kux(KWU634)| did not enter another person's house. 
{d}nin-gir2-su| For Ningirsu 
lugal-a-ni| his master 
nig2-du7-e pa mu-na-e3| he (Gudea) made a fitting thing come forth resplendently, 
e2-ninnu anzu2{muszen}-babbar2-ra-ni| (namely) his temple Eninnu with a white thunderbird 
mu-na-du3| he built for him 
ki-bi mu-na-gi4| and restored for him. 
sza3-ba gi-gun4 ki-ag2-ni| In the center of it his beloved high terrace 
szim erin-na| with aromatic cedar 
mu-na-ni-du3| he built for him. 
u4 e2 {d}nin-gir2-su-ka| When the temple of Ningirsu 
mu-du3-a| he built, 
{d}nin-gir2-su| Ningirsu, 
lugal ki-ag2-ni-e| his master who loved him, 
a-ab-ba igi-nim-ta| from the Upper Sea 
a-ab-ba sig-ga-sze3| to the Lower Sea 
giri3-bi gal2 mu-na-tak4| opened up the roads for him. 
ama-a-num2 hur-sag erin-ta| From the Amanus, the mountain range of cedar, 
{gesz}erin| cedars 
gid2-bi 1(gesz2) kusz3| whose length was sixty cubits, 
{gesz}erin| cedars 
gid2-bi 5(u) kusz3| whose length was fifty cubits, 
{gesz}taskarin| and boxwood 
gid2-bi 2(u) 5(disz) kusz3| whose length was twenty-five cubits, 
ad-sze3 mu-ak-ak| he made into planks 
kur-bi im-ta-e11| and brought them down from their mountains. 
szar2-ur3 a-ma-ru me3-ka-ni| Levels the Multitudes, his storm of battle, 
mu-na-du3| he constructed for him, 
szar2-gaz {uruda}gag igi-imin| and Slaughters the Multitudes, his copper seven-faced peg, 
mu-na-du3| he constructed for him. 
{uruda}gag dur10-da-ka-ni| His copper peg of a side-ax 
mu-na-du3| he constructed for him, 
{uruda}gag dur10 al-lu5-ni| and his copper peg of an allul-ax 
mu-na-du3| he constructed for him. 
{gesz}erin-bi| Those cedars 
ig gal-sze3| into big doors 
mu-dim2| he fashioned, 
ul ku3-ga mi-ni-gun3| decorated them with sacred flowers, 
e2-ninnu-a| and into the Eninnu 
mu-na-lah4| he had them brought for him. 
e2-mah ki a-sig de2-da-na| In his lofty temple where cold water would be poured, 
gesz-ur3-sze3 mu-na-gar| he (also) set them as roof-beams for him. 
iri ur-su{ki}| From the city of Ursu 
hur-sag eb-la-ta| and the mountain range of Ebla 
{gesz}za-ba-lum| juniper, 
{gesz}u3-suh5 gal-gal| big firs, 
{gesz}tu-lu-bu-um gesz kur| and plane trees, mountain trees, 
ad-sze3 mu-ak-ak| he made into planks, 
e2-ninnu-a| and in the Eninnu 
gesz-ur3-sze3 mu-na-gar| he set them as roof-beams for him. 
u3-ma-num2| From Umanum, 
hur-sag me-nu-a-ta| the mountain range of Menua, 
bu3-sal-la| and from Busala, 
hur-sag mar-tu-ta| the mountain range of the Martu, 
{na4}na gal| big stones 
im-ta-e11| he brought down. 
na-ru2-a-sze3| Into steles 
mu-dim2| he fashioned them, 
kisal e2-ninnu-ka| and in the courtyard of the Eninnu 
mu-na-ni-du3| he erected them for him. 
ti-da-num2| From Tidanum, 
hur-sag mar-tu-ta| the mountain range of the Martu, 
gesznux(SZIR)-gal lagab-bi-a| alabaster in blocks 
mi-ni-de6| he brought in, 
ur-pad-da-sze3| and into destroying lions 
mu-na-dim2-dim2| he fashioned them, 
sag-gul-sze3| and as gate bolts 
e2-a mi-ni-si-si| he mounted them in the temple. 
abul-at{ki}| In Abullat, 
hur-sag ki-masz-ka| the mountain range of Kimaš, 
uruda mu-ni-ba-al| he mined copper, 
szita2 ub-e nu-il2-sze3| and into the Mace Which the World Quarters Cannot Bear 
mu-na-dim2| he fashioned it for him. 
kur me-luh-ha| From the land of Meluhha 
{gesz}esi im-ta-e11| he brought down ebony, 
mu-na-du3| and erected(?) it for him. 
lagab nir3| A block of nir-stone 
im-ta-e11| he brought down, 
szita2 ur sag esz8-sze3| and into a mace with three lion heads 
mu-na-dim2| he fashioned it for him. 
ku3-sig17 sahar-ba| Gold in its ore 
hur-sag ha-hu-um-ta| from the mountain range of Hahum 
im-ta-e11| he brought down, 
szita2 ur sag esz8-a| and onto the mace with three lion heads 
mu-na-gar| he overlaid it for him. 
ku3-sig17 sahar-ba| Gold in its ore 
kur me-luh-ha-ta| from the land of Meluhha 
im-ta-e11| he brought down, 
e2-mar-uru5-sze3| and into a quiver 
mu-na-dim2| he fashioned it for him. 
ab2-RI| Zebus 
im-ta-e11| he brought down. 
gu-bi-in{ki}| From Gubin 
kur {gesz}ha-lu-ub2-ta| the land of oak(?) trees, 
{gesz}ha-lu-ub2| oak(?) 
im-ta-e11| he brought down, 
muszen szar2-ur3-sze3| and into the bird (named) Levels the Multitudes 
mu-na-dim2| he fashioned it. 
ma-ad-ga{ki}| From Madga, 
hur-sag i7 lu2-ru-da-ta| the mountain range of the ordeal river, 
esir2 gu2 1(szar'u)| a myriad of talents of bitumen 
im-ta-e11| he brought down, 
ki-sa2 e2-ninnu-ka| and in the platform of the Eninnu 
mu-ni-du3| he used it for construction. 
{im}ha-um| Ha'um-clay 
im-ta-e11| be brought down. 
hur-sag bar-me-ta| From the mountain range of Barme 
{na4}na lu-a| many stones 
ma2 gal-gal-a| into big boats 
im-mi-si-si| he loaded, 
ur2 e2-ninnu-ka mu-na-ni-gur| and he placed them around the base of the Eninnu. 
{gesz}tukul iri an-sza-an elam{ki}| The cities of Anšan and Elam with weapons 
mu-sag3| he smote, 
nam-ra-ak-bi| and the booty from them 
{d}nin-gir2-su-ra| to Ningirsu 
e2-ninnu-a| into the Eninnu 
mu-na-ni-kux(KWU634)| he had brought in. 
gu3-de2-a| Gudea, 
ensi2| the ruler 
lagasz{ki}-ke4| of Lagash, 
u4 e2-ninnu| when the Eninnu 
{d}nin-gir2-su-ra mu-na-du3-a| he had built for Ningirsu, 
gil-sa im-mi-ak| he made it as a (lasting) treasure. 
e2 ur5-gin7 dim2-ma| A temple fashioned like this 
ensi2 asz-e| not a single ruler 
{d}nin-gir2-su-ra| for Ningirsu 
nu-na-du3| had ever built. 
na-mu-du3| But he (Gudea) did indeed build it. 
mu mu-sar| He inscribed (his) name, 
nig2-du7 pa bi2-e3| and made (this) fitting thing come forth resplendently. 
du11-du11-ga| To the commands 
{d}nin-gir2-su-ka-ke4| of Ningirsu 
szu zi im-mi-gar| he set forth a faithful hand. 
kur ma2-gan{ki}-ta| From the land of Magan 
{na4}esi im-ta-e11| he brought down diorite 
alan-na-sze3| and into (this) stone figure 
mu-du2| he formed it. 
lugal-mu| For my master 
e2-a-ni| his temple 
mu-na-du3| I built, 
nam-ti nig2-ba-mu| (so) life is my reward, 
mu-sze3 mu-na-sa4| (was how) he named it for him, 
e2-ninnu-a| and into the Eninnu 
mu-na-ni-kux(KWU634)| he had it brought to him. 
gu3-de2-a| Gudea 
alan-e| to the statue 
inim im-ma-szum2-mu| gives (these) words: 
alan lugal-mu| Statue, to my master 
u3-na-du11| do say thus: 
u4 e2-ninnu| When the Eninnu, 
e2 ki-ag2-ga2-ni| his beloved temple, 
mu-na-du3-a| I built for him, 
ur5 mu-du8 szu szu mu-luh| I had debts remitted and I washed all hands. 
u4 7(asz)-am3 sze la-ba-ar3| For seven days no barley was ground. 
geme2 nin-a-ni mu-da-sa2-am3| The slave woman was made equal with her mistress, 
ARAD2-de3| and by the slave 
lugal-ni za3 mu-da-gub-am3| his master stood side by side. 
iri-ga2 u2-sig-ni| In my city the sexually impure with respect to him (Ningirsu) 
za3-ba mu-da-nu2-am3| I made to go out to sleep at the edge of it. 
nig2-erim2 e2-bi-a| Evil to its house 
im-mi-gi4| I made go back. 
nig2-gi-gi-na| To the laws 
{d}nansze| of Nanše 
{d}nin-gir2-su-ka-sze3| and Ningirsu 
en3 im-ma-szi-tar| I attended. 
nu-siki lu2 nig2-tuku nu-mu-na-gar| An orphan I did not let be put under the control of a rich person. 
na-ma-su lu2 a2-tuku nu-mu-na-gar| and a widow I did not let be put under the control of a powerful person. 
e2 dumu-nita2 nu-tuku| For an estate not having a son, 
dumu-munus-bi i3-bi2-la-ba| a daughter of it its heir 
mi-ni-kux(KWU634)| I made become. 
alan-na| The stone statue 
inim-sze3 im-ma-dab5| he made receptive to messages. 
alan-e| This statue 
u3 ku3 nu za-gin3 nu-ga-am3| is neither of silver, nor is it of lapis lazuli. 
u3 uruda nu u3 nagga nu| It is neither of copper nor of tin, 
zabar nu| nor is it of bronze. 
kin-ga2 lu2 nu-ba-ga2-ga2| No one must put it to any other use, 
{na4}esi-am3| and so it is (made only of) diorite. 
ki-a-nag-e ha-ba-gub| Let it stand at the place of libations. 
nig2 a2 zi-ga-ka| By an act of force 
lu2 nam-mi-gul-e| let no one destroy it. 
alan igi-zu| O statue, before you 
{d}nin-gir2-su-ka-kam| is (standing a statue) of Ningirsu! 
alan| The statue 
gu3-de2-a| of Gudea, 
ensi2| the ruler 
lagasz{ki}-ka| of Lagash, 
lu2 e2-ninnu| the man by whom the Eninnu 
{d}nin-gir2-su-ka| of Ningirsu 
in-du3-a| was built-
lu2 e2-ninnu-ta| any person who from the Eninnu 
im-ta-ab-e3-e3-a| shall remove it, 
mu-sar-ra-bi| or its inscription 
szu ib2-ta-ab-ur3-a| shall erase from it, 
lu2 ib2-ze-re-a| or any person who shall destroy it; 
za3-mu du10-ka| at the beginning of a good year, 
lu2 dingir-mu-gin7| a (future) person whom, as did my god, 
dingir-ra-ni| his (own) god 
{d}nin-gir2-su| Ningirsu, 
lugal-mu| my master, 
ug3-ga2 gu3 u3-na-de2-a| has called to from among all the people, 
di ku5-a-ga2| who (then) my judgments 
szu i3-ib2-bala-e-a| shall overturn, 
nig2-ba-ga2| my gifts 
ba-a-gi4-gi4-da| would revoke, 
en3-du ka kesz2-ra2-mu| and from my collected songs 
mu-mu u3-ta-gar| having displaced my name 
mu-ni ba-ga2-ga2| shall set his own name on them; 
kisal {d}nin-gir2-su lugal-ga2-ka| who in the courtyard of Ningirsu my master 
esz3 gar-ra-bi bi2-ib2-tak4-tak4-a| shall abandon its established shrines, 
igi-ni-sze3 nu-tuku-a| without having kept before his eyes 
u4 ul-li2-ta| that since days of old, 
numun i-a-ta| since the seed (first) emerged, 
ensi2| when a ruler 
lagasz{ki}| of Lagash, 
e2-ninnu| the Eninnu 
{d}nin-gir2-su| for Ningirsu 
lugal-mu| my master 
u3-na-du3-a| had built-
lu2 nig2-du7-e pa e3-a-am3| being a person who had made a fitting thing come forth resplendently-
inim-inim-ni| his words 
lu2 nu-u3-kur2-e| no one shall ever alter, 
di ku5-a-na szu nu-bala-e| nor ever overturn his judgments. 
gu3-de2-a| Therefore regarding Gudea, 
ensi2| the ruler 
lagasz{ki}-ka| of Lagash, 
lu2 inim-ni ib2-kur2-a| anyone who shall alter his word, 
di ku5-a-na szu i3-ib2-bala-e-a| or shall overturn his judgments, 
an-e| may An, 
{d}en-lil2-e| Enlil, 
{d}nin-hur-sag-ke4| Ninhursaga, 
{d}en-ki du11-ga zi-da-ke4| Enki, he of the righteous utterance, 
{d}suen mu-ni lu2 nu-du8-de3| Suen, whose name no one can explain, 
{d}nin-gir2-su| Ningirsu, 
lugal {gesz}tukul-ke4| the king of weaponry, 
{d}nansze| Nanše, 
nin in-dub-ba-ke4| the mistress of the boundary marker, 
{d}nin-dar-a| Nindara, 
lugal ur-sag-e| the king and warrior, 
ama lagasz{ki}| the mother of Lagash 
ku3 {d}ga2-tum3-du10-e| the holy Gatumdu, 
{d}ba-ba6| Baba, 
nin dumu-sag an-na-ke4| the lady, the eldest daughter of An, 
{d}inanna| Inanna, 
nin me3-ke4| the lady of battle, 
{d}utu| Utu, 
lugal ni-se3-ga-ke4| the king of greenery, 
{d}hendur-sag| Hendursag, 
nimgir kalam-ma-ke4| the herald of the nation, 
{d}ig-alim-ke4| Igalima 
{d}szul-sza3-ga-na-ke4| and Šulšagana, 
{d}nin-mar{ki}| Ninmar, 
dumu-sag {d}nansze-ke4| the eldest daughter of Nanše, 
{d}dumu-zi-abzu| Dumuzi'abzu, 
nin ki-nu-nir{ki}-ke4| the mistress of Kinunir, 
dingir-mu {d}nin-gesz-zi-da-ke4| and my (personal) god Ningešzida, 
nam-tar-ra-ni he2-dab6-kur2-ne| may they all change his fate. 
gu4-gin7| Like an ox 
u4-bar7-na he2-gaz| may he be slaughtered in his noonday (prime). 
am-gin7| Like an aurochs 
a2 husz-na he2-dab5| may he be seized by his fierce horns. 
{gesz}dur2-gar lu2 mu-na-gub-a-ni| May his throne which people had set up for him 
sahar-ra he2-em-ta-tusz| be made to sit out in the dust. 
tukumx(SZU.TUR)-bi| If 
mu-bi szu ur3-de3| to erasing this inscription 
gesztu2 he2-em-szi-gub| he should set his mind, 
mu-ni e2 dingir-ra-na-ta| let his own name in the house of his god 
dub-ta he2-em-ta-gar| from the tablets be removed. 
dingir-ra-ne2| May his own god 
ug3 ga2-ra-a igi na-szi-bar-re| not look upon the settled(?) people. 
szeg7 an-na he2-da-a-gi4| May he hold back the rain in the sky 
a ki-a he2-da-a-gi4| and hold back the waters upon the earth. 
mu nu-gal2-la ha-mu-na-ta-e3| May years of dearth stretch out for him, 
bala-a-na sze-gar he2-gal2| and may there be famine during his reign. 
lu2-bi| That person, 
lu2 lu2 si-sa2-ra nig2-erim2 ak-gin7| like a man who does evil to a righteous person, 
til-bi an-na ur3-ru14 he2-mi-gal2| may that one’s end produce a shutting(?) in heaven, 
szu na-ni-ba-re| and may it not be released. 
gaba-gal2 dingir-re-ne-ka| Of the most forceful of all the gods, 
en {d}nin-gir2-su-ka| of lord Ningirsu, 
nam-mah-a-ni| may his greatness 
kalam-e he2-zu-zu| be known by the nation. 
{d}nin-gesz-zi-da| Ningešzida 
dingir gu3-de2-a| is the (personal) god of Gudea, 
ensi2| the ruler 
lagasz{ki}| of Lagash, 
lu2 e2-an-na| the man by whom the Eanna (temple) 
in-du3-a-kam| was built. 
{d}inanna| For Inana, 
nin kur-kur-ra| the mistress of all the lands, 
nin-a-ni| his mistress, 
gu3-de2-a| Gudea, 
mu gil-sa| he of lasting fame, 
ensi2| the ruler 
lagasz{ki}| of Lagash, 
lu2 e2-ninnu| the man by whom the Eninnu 
{d}nin-gir2-su-ka| of Ningirsu 
in-du3-a| was built-
u4 {d}inanna-ke4| when Inana 
igi nam-ti-ka-ni| her eye of life 
mu-szi-bar-ra-a| she had sent out towards him, 
gu3-de2-a| Gudea, 
ensi2| the ruler 
lagasz{ki}| of Lagash, 
gesztu2 dagal-a-kam| being of broad intelligence 
ARAD2 nin-a-ne2| and a slave by his mistress 
ki-ag2-am3| beloved, 
ga2 u3-szub-ba-ka| in the shed of the brick mold 
gesz ba-hur| he made the design, 
ka-al-ka| and by the excavation 
uri3 ba-mul| he made the standards gleam. 
im-bi ki dadag-ga-a| The clay for it on a pure place 
im-mi-lu| he mixed together, 
sig4-bi| and the bricks for it 
ki sikil-a| onto a clean place 
im-mi-du8| he let fall out. 
usz-bi mu-ku3| Its foundation plot he sanctified 
izi im-ta-la2| and refined with fire. 
temen-bi| Its foundation pegs 
i3 ir nun-ka| with oil of princely scent 
szu tag ba-ni-du11| he adorned. 
e2 ki-ag2-ga2-ni| Her beloved temple, 
e2-an-na sza3 gir2-su{ki}-ka| the Eanna, in the center of Girsu 
mu-na-ni-du3| he built for her. 
kur ma2-gan{ki}-ta| From the mountains of Magan 
{na4}esi im-ta-e11| he brought down diorite 
alan-na-ni-sze3| and into (this) his stone figure 
mu-du2| he formed it. 
gu3-de2-a| Gudea, 
lu2 e2 du3-a-ka| the temple builder, 
nam-ti-la-ni he2-su3| may his life be long! 
mu-sze3 mu-na-sa4| he named it for her, 
e2-an-na-ka| and into the Eanna 
mu-na-ni-kux(KWU634)| he had it brought to her. 
lu2 e2-an-na-ta| A person who from the Eanna 
ib2-ta-ab-e3-e3-a| shall remove it, 
ib2-ze-re-a| or who shall destroy it, 
mu-sar-a-ba szu bi2-ib2-ur3-a| or erase its inscription, 
{d}inanna| Inana, 
nin kur-kur-ra-ke4| the mistress of all the lands, 
sag-ga2-ni ukken-na| his head in the assembly 
nam he2-ma-ku5-e| may she curse. 
{gesz}gu-za gub-ba-na| The throne that he has erected, 
suhusz-bi| its foundations 
na-an-gi-ne2| may she not keep secure. 
numun-a-ni he2-til| May she make his seed come to an end 
bala-a-ni he2-ku5| and cut short his reign. 
{d}nin-gir2-su| For Ningirsu, 
ur-sag kal-ga| the mighty warrior 
{d}en-lil2-la2| of Enlil,

ensi2| ruler 
lagasz{ki}| of Lagash, 
mu gil-sa| he of lasting fame, 
ma2-gid2| who tows the boat

lu2 inim-ma se3-ga| a man subject to the word

dumu tu-da| child born

{d}nin-gir2-su a zi {d}en-lil2-la2| Ningirsu, true offspring of Enlil,

ARAD2 ki-ag2 {d}lugal-uru11{ki}-ka-ke4| beloved slave of Lugal-Urub, 
ki-ag2 {d}dumu-zi-abzu-ka-ke4| beloved of Dumuzi-abzu, 
ur-{d}ba-ba6-me| I, Ur-Baba — 
{d}nin-gir2-su lugal-mu| for Ningirsu my master 
ki-gar n kusz3 mu-na-ba-al| an area of [n] cubits (deep) I dug out, 
sahar-bi za-gin7 mu-zar-zar| its earth like gems I stacked up,  
ku3-gin7 izi i3-la2| as if it were silver I refined it with fire, 
ninda2-gin7 ki dagal-la bi2-de6| as with a seeding funnel into a wide area I brought it out, 
sahar-bi sza3-ba im-szi-gi4| and (then) that earth into it I returned . 
usz-de2-bi mu-ak| Its poured out foundation I made. 
ugux(REC193)-bi-a ki-sa2-a 1(u) kusz3-am3 bi2-du3| Over it a foundation platform, 10 cubits (in height) I built, 
ugux(REC193) ki-sa2-a-ka| and over the platform

lu2 e2 {d}nanna| the man who the temple of Nanna 
in-du3-a| built,

gaba a-ab-ka-ka| on the sea coast 
ma2 ma2-gan szu-na mu-ni-gi4| and returned the boats of Magan to his control.

ur-{d}namma| Ur Namma,

{d}utu-ta| of Utu,

szu-na mu-ni-gi4| and returned it to his control. 
a-ba-{d}nanna x x-ni| His Aba-Nanna-[gin?] (object) 
a mu-na-ru| he dedicated to him. 
lu2 a2 nig2-hul-dim2-ma| A person who an evil order  
ib2-szi-ag2-ge26-a| shall issue against it, 
lu2 ki-gub-ba-bi| or a person who the place where it stands 
ib2-kur2-a| shall alter, 
{d}nanna| May Nanna 
he2-in-ti-e| may he make him live.

sag-ki-ni| his forehead 
ha-ba-da-gid2-de3| may he furrow (in a frown).

sahar-ra he2-em-ta-tusz| may he make him sit down in the dust. 
iri-ni| His city 
{gi}suhurx(KA)-ta| off among the reed huts(?) 
he2-ta-dag-dag-ge| may it roam. 
nam-ti-il| May life 
nig2-gig-ga-ni| a bitter thing to him 
he2-a| be indeed.

dumu-sag| the first-born son

ur-{d}namma| Ur-Namma, 
nita kal-ga| the mighty man, 
lugal uri5{ki}-ma| king of Ur 
lugal ki-en-gi ki-uri-ke4| and king of Sumer and Akkad, 
sug pesz du3-a| a swamp planted with (palm) seedlings - 
sug he2-me-am3| it was indeed a swamp - 
a-sza3-bi| a field of it 
szar2-gal GAN2-am3| which was 3600 (bur3) in area (= 233.28 sq. km)   
a-ta| from the water 
ha-mu-na-ta-DU| he brought out for him.  
e-bi 4(disz) da-na 4(gesz2) 2(u) nig2-ra2| Levees for it, 4 danna (= 43.2 km) and 260 nindan (= 1560 m),  
he2-na-ak| he made for him. 
uri5{ki}-e gil-sa-asz| Next to Ur, as a (lasting) treasure 
he2-mi-na| he made it.

mu-bi| is its name.

u4-ba tukum-bi lu2-u3| At that time: If a man
sag gesz bi2-in-ra| has committed murder,

sa-gaz-sze3 in-ak in-gaz-e| has acted like a robber, he shall be killed.

nam-ARAD2-da-ni-sze3| into one of his slaves
