8(asz) sze gur in-na-ag2-ag2-e| he shall measure out to him 8 gur of barley;
gu4 ab2 sag murub4 addir-bi| for the hire of oxen or cows for lead or middle (?),
6(asz) sze gur in-na-ag2-ag2-e| he shall measure out to him 6 gur of barley.
tukum-bi lu2 ba-usz2| If a man has died
dumu-nita2 nu-un-tuku| and has no sons,
dumu-munus dam nu-un-tuku-a| an umarried daughter
ibila-a-ni he2-a| shall become his heir.
tukum-bi lu2 ba-usz2| If a man has died,
szuku ad-da erin2-e i3-ba-e| but the father’s subsistance allotments shall be shared by the (estate’s) workers.
tukum-bi e2 lu2-ka lu2 sze i3-si| If a man has put barley into another man’s house,
e2-bi ba-burx(TUL2)| and that house has been broken into,
lugal sze-ke4 nam-erim2 u3-ku5| when the owner of the barley has taken an oath,
lugal e2-a-ke4 ib2-su-su| the owner of the house shall replace it.
tukum-bi lu2-u3 e2 lu2-ka sze i3-si| If a man has put barley into another man’s house,
lugal e2 ba-da-kur2| and the owner of the house has changed,
u3-ge-en8| after it has been verified,
sza3-bi min-am3 sze i3-na-ab-si-ge| he shall put in for him twice as much barley as was therein.
tukum-bi e2 lu2-ka lu2 sze i3-si| If a man has put barley into another man’s house,
tukum-bi lu2 dam i3-tuku-am3| If a man who married a wife
dam-ni in-tak4| has left his wife behind,
iti 6(disz) u3-na-tusz-am3| when she has stayed (waiting) 6 months for him
munus dam sza3-ga-na-ke4 ha-ba-an-du12-du12| the woman may be married by a husband of her choice.
tukum-bi lu2 dam i3-tuku-am3| If a man married a wife,
dam-ni ba-usz2| and his wife died,
nita2 en-na ba-an-du12-du12| the man, until he remarries,
sa12-rig7 dam-na he2-na-de6| his wife’s marriage gifts should be brought to him;
u4 nita2 dam ba-an-du12-du12-a| but when the man marries a (new) wife,
sa12-rig7 e2 lu2-na-ka he2-eb-gi4| the marriage gifts should return to her people’s household.
tukum-bi nita2 ba-usz2| If a man has died,
dam-a-ni en-na ba-an-du12-du12| his wife, until she remarries,
tukum-bi ad-da ba-usz2| If the father has died,
tukum-bi gu4 e2-tur3-ba u2-gu ba-an-de2| If an ox has been lost in its cattle pen,
unu3-de3-ne| the cowherds
ib2-su-su-ne| shall replace it.
tukum-bi udu ga2-udu-ba u2-gu ba-an-de2| If a sheep has been lost in its sheepfold,
sipa-de3-ne| the shepherds
ib2-su-su-ne| shall replace it.
tukum-bi gu4 udu ansze szah2 e2 LAGABxU-a iri-ka u2-gu ba-de2| If an ox, a sheep, a donkey, or a pig has been lost among the houses or in a well-pit of a city,
da-gi4-a| the district (authorities)
ib2-su-su| shall replace it.
tukum-bi lu2 nig2 na-me u2-gu la-ba-an-de2| If a man has not lost anything,
a-ne nig2-mu u2-gu ba-an-de2 bi2-du11| but he has declared: “I have lost something of mine;”
da-gi4-a| when by the district
u3-um-ge-en8| it has been proved,
lu2-bi i3-gaz| that man shall be killed;
egir-a-ni da-gi4-a ba-ab-tum3| the district shall take away his inheritance.
1(disz) gu4 ne-ri nig2-diri-bi 1(barig)-kam| The nig2-diri levy for 1 stolen ox is 1 barig;
1(disz) ansze ne-ri nig2-diri-bi 3(ban2)| the nig-diri levy for 1 stolen donkey is 3 ban2;
1(disz) udu ne-ri nig2-diri-bi 1(ban2) za3-mu-ka| the nig-diri levy for 1 stolen sheep is 1 ban2, (due) at the new year.
tukum-bi lu2 lu2 di in-da-tuku-am3| If a man takes another man to court,
a-ra2 3(disz)-am3 e3-ba i3-bi2-dib di til-am3| after he has made him proceed through (court) appearances regarding it for the 3rd time, the suit shall be ended.
tukum-bi en-te-na-ka| If in winter
1(disz) ma2 1(gesz2) gur lu2 i3-hun| a man has hired a 60-gur boat,
nig2-diri-bi 1(ban2)| its nig2-diri levy will be 1 ban2,
a2 u4 1(disz)-bi| its hire rate for 1 day will be (blank).
tukum-bi ma2 1(gesz2) gur lu2 i3-hun te-na 3(u) 1(asz) gur nig2-diri-bi 3(ban2)| If a man has hired a 60-gur boat: for 30 double-miles, its nig2-diri levy will be 3 ban2 per 1 gur;
2(u) te-na nig2-diri-bi 1(asz) gur 2(ban2)| for 20 double-miles its nig2-diri levy will be 2 ban2 per 1 gur;
1(u) te-na nig2-diri 1(asz) gur 1(ban2)| for 10 double-miles the nig2-diri levy will be 1 ban2 per 1 gur.
sze-kam ku3-bi 1/3(disz) gin2| It is of barley; its silver is 1/3rd shekel.
szitim-ma a2 u4 1(disz)-a-ni 3(ban2)| 1 day’s wages of a house-builder will be 3 ban2.
nagar aszgab ad-kup4 tug2-du8 simug lu2 azlag2 ku3-dim2 bur-gul| For a carpenter, leatherworker, reed-mat maker, felt maker, metalsmith, fuller, goldsmith, or stone-cutter,
a2 u4-buru14-ka-ne-ne 3(ban2)-ta| their harvest-time wages will be 3 ban2 each;
en-te-na-ka-ne-ne 2(ban2)-ta| their winter ones will be 2 ban2 each.
1(disz) dug kur-du3 sze-bi 1(ban2)| the barley for 1 kurdu pot will be 1 ban2;
1(disz) dug lah5-tan 1(asz) gur 3(ban2)| for 1 lahtan pot of 1 gur (capacity) it will be 3 ban2;
1(disz) tu-ru-na sze-bi 5(disz) sila3| the barley for 1 oven will be 5 sila3.
tukum-bi GA2xGIR3 lu2 ib2-ta-ha-asz-am3| If a man has broken a leg bone,
a-zu i3-sa6| and a physician has made him well,
ku3-bi 5(disz) gin2-am3| the silver for that will be 5 shekels.
tukum-bi lu2 ur-mah-e szu mu-sur5-sur5| If a man has been mauled by a lion,
a-zu i3-sa6| and a physician has made him well,
ku3-bi 5(disz) gin2-am3| the silver for that will be 5 shekels.
tukum-bi a-zu na4 mu-ta-de6| If a physician has taken out a ‘stone,’
ku3-bi 5(disz) gin2-am3| the silver for that will be 5 shekels.
tukum-bi a-zu igi du8-du8-a i3-sa6| If a physician has healed the eyesight,
ku3-bi 2(disz) gin2| the silver for that will be 2 shekels.
ku3-bi n gin2| the silver for that will be n shekels.
en-te-na-ka-ni 2(ban2)| his winter ones will be 2 ban2.
geme2 usz-bar tan4-tan4-na a2 u4 1(disz)-a-ka-ni n(ban2)| The daily wages of a female weaver when washing (fibers) will be n ban2;
geme2 usz-bar ama-tuku5-ka a2 u4 1(disz)-ni 2(ban2)| the daily wages of a senior female weaver will be 2 ban2;
geme2 usz-bar szu-dur-ka a2 u4 1(disz)-ni 2(ban2)| the daily wages of a female weaver of šudur-garments will be 2 ban2.
tukum-bi munus lu2-kurun-ke4 u4 buru14-ka| If a female tavern-keeper in the harvest season
1(disz) pihu4 lu2-ra szu-la2-a-sze3 in-na-an-szum2| has given 1 beer-jar to a person on credit,
tukum-bi lu2 lu2-ra| If a man to another man
1(asz) sze gur ur5-ra-sze3 in-na-an-szum2| has given 1 gur of barley as a loan,
mu 1(disz)-am3 masz2-bi 1(barig) 4(ban2) sze-am3| its interest for 1 year shall be 1 barig and 4 ban2 of barley.
tukum-bi lu2 lu2-ra| If a man to another man
1(u) gin2 ku3-babbar ur5-ra-sze3 in-na-an-szum2| has given 10 shekels of silver as a loan,
mu 1(disz)-am3 masz2-bi 2(disz) gin2-am3| its interest for 1 year shall be 2 shekels.
nu-ub-su-su| he need not replace it.
tukum-bi dumu lu2-ra lu2 ga i3-ni-gu7| If a person has fed another person’s child milk,
mu 3(disz)-a sze-ni 6(asz) gur| for 3 years her barley shall be 6 gur,
siki-ni 3(u) ma-na| her wool 30 minas,
i3-ni 3(u) sila3| and her oil 30 sila3;
nig2 nam-nu-gig-kam| it is a thing of the office of the nugig-women.
um-me-da hun-ga2 mu a2-ni 1(disz) gin2-am3| The fee per year of a hired wet-nurse shall be 1 shekel.
tukum-bi bala gu-du-ma-ka| If, during the term of Gutium,
lu2 sag i3-sa10| a man sold a slave,
sag-bi lu2 im-ma-du3| but that slave someone detained,
lugal sag-ga2-ke4 nam-erim2 u3-ku5| when the owner of the slave has taken an oath,
sag ha-ba-an-tum2-mu| he may take away the slave.
tukum-bi lu2 i3-sa10-a ba-usz2| If the man who did the selling has died,
lu2-ba dam-ni he dumu-ni he lu2 ki-inim-ma-ni he| (only) when that man’s wife, or his son, or his witness
nam-erim2 u3-ku5| has taken an oath
sag ha-ba-an-tum2-mu| may he take away the slave.
bala ur-{d}namma lugal nig2-diri| During the reign of Ur-Namma, the king of the nig2-diri levy,
{d}nanna ug3-e ba-il2-a-ta| after he had been elevated by Nanna over the people,
u4-ba tukum-bi lu2 sag i3-sa10-a| at that time, if the man who had sold the slave
tukum-bi nu-mu-tum2| if he has not brought in,
lu2-bi ni2-zuh-am3| that man is a thief.
tukum-bi lu2 ba-usz2 dam-PI-ni ibila 1(disz)-gin7 e2-a he2-dim2| If a man has died, his equal-ranking wife should act as the 1st heir in the house.
tukum-bi lu2 dam szesz-gal-na ba-an-du12-du12| If a man marries the wife of his older brother,
i3-gaz| he shall be killed.
tukum-bi ARAD2-de3 nin-a-ni ba-an-du12-du12 i3-gaz| If a slave marries his female owner, he shall be killed.
tukum-bi 1(disz) sar e2-du3-a lu2 in-sa10| If a man has bought 1 sar of a built house,
ku3-bi n gin2-am3| its silver shall be n shekels.
tukum-bi 1(disz) sar KI.KAL| If a vacant lot of 1 sar
lu2 in-sa10 ku3-bi 1(disz) gin2 ku3-babbar-am3| a man has bought, its silver shall be 1 shekel.
tukum-bi 1(disz) sar e2-du3-a| If 1 sar of a built house
lu2 mu-sar-ra-ba szu bi2-ib2-ur3-ru-a mu-ni bi2-ib2-sar-re-a| A person who erases this inscription and writes his own name on it,
asz2-bala-a-ba-ke4-esz lu2-kur2 szu ba-an-zi-zi-a| or because of this curse he incites another to do it,
lu2 mu-sar-ra-ba szu bi2-ib2-ur3-ru-a mu nu-sar-de3 in-na-ab-sar| and the person who erases this inscription and has written for him a name which should not be written,
{gesz}gu-za gub-ba sahar-ra he2-eb2-ta-an-tusz| may he who was seated on a throne sit down in the dust.
ug3-ni {gi}suhurx(KA)-ta he2-eb-ta-dag-dag-ge| May his people roam about among reed huts(?).
iri-ni iri {d}en-lil2 nu-sze-ga he2-a| May his city be a disagreeable city to Enlil.
abul iri-na-ke4 gal2 he2-eb2-tak4-tak4| May the gates of his city stand open.
nam-gurusz iri-na igi-nu-du8 he2-me-esz| May the young men of his city be blinded slaves.
nam-ki-sikil iri-na u3 nu-tu-da he2-me-esz| May the young women of his city be ones unable to bear.
dingir iri-na-ke4 {d}en-ki {d}iszkur {d}asznan| May the gods of his town, Enki, Iškur, and Ašnan,

gir2-su{ki} sze il2-la-ka| In Girsu, in the <month> of barley transporting,

e2-ta izi la2-a| (and?) the one who bears fire from the temple 
gaszam-kam| belong to the artians.

u3 igi-3(disz)-gal2| and a one-third (prebend)

lu2 kin-gi4-a ag-ga dumu en-me-bara2-ge4-si-ke4| Envoys of Aga, the son of Enmebaragesi, 
kisz{ki}-ta {d}gilgamesx(BIL3.GA.MES) unu{ki}-sze3 mu-un-szi-re7-esz| from Kish to Gilgamesh in Uruk came. 
{d}gilgamesx(BIL3.GA.MES) igi ab-ba-iri{ki}-na-sze3| Gilgamesh before the elders of his city, 
inim ba-an-gar inim i3-kin-kin-e| presented the issue, carefully choosing his words: 
tul2 til-le-da tul2 kalam til-til-le-da| There are wells to be finished, wells of the Land yet to be finished; 
tul2 nig2-tur-da kalam til-til-le-da| there are shallow wells of the Land yet to be finished, 
tul2 bur3-da esz2 la2 til-til-le-da| there are wells to deepen and hoisting gear to be completed. 
e2 kisz{ki}-sze3 gu2 nam-ba-an-ga2-ga2-an-de3-en {gesz}tukul nam-ba-an-sag3-ge-en-de3-en| To the house of Kish We should not submit! Should we not smite it with weapons? 
ukken gar-ra ab-ba-iri-na-ka| In the convened assembly, the elders of his city 
{d}gilgamesx(BIL3.GA.MES) mu-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4| answer Gilgamesh: 
tul2 til-le-da tul2 kalam til-til-le-da| “There are indeed wells to be finished, wells of the Land yet to be finished; 
tul2 nig2-tur-da kalam til-til-le-da| there are shallow wells of the Land yet to be finished, 
tul2 bur3-da esz2-la2 til-til-le-da| there are wells to deepen and hoisting gear to be completed. 
e2 kisz{ki}-sze3 gu2 ga-am3-ga2-ga2-an-de3-en {gesz}tukul nam-ba-sag3-ge-en-de3-en| So we should submit to the house of Kish. We should not smite it with weapons! 
{d}gilgamesx(BIL3.GA.MES) en kul-aba4{ki}-a-ke4| Gilgamesh, the lord of Kulaba, 
{d}inanna-ra nir-gal2-la-e| in Inanna placing his trust 
inim ab-ba-iri-na-ke4 sza3-sze3 nu-mu-na-gid2| the advice of the elders of his city did not take seriously. 
2(disz)-kam-ma-sze3 {d}gilgamesx(BIL3.GA.MES) igi gurusz iri{ki}-na-sze3| a second time Gilgamesh before the able-bodied men of his city 
inim ba-an-gar inim i3-kin-kin-e| presented the issue, carefully choosing his words: 
tul2 til-le-da tul2 kalam til-til-le-da| “There are wells to be finished, wells of the Land yet to be finished; 
tul2 nig2-tur-da kalam til-til-le-da| there are shallow wells of the Land yet to be finished, 
tul2 bur3-da esz2-la2 til-til-le-da| there are wells to deepen and hoisting gear to be completed. 
e2 kisz{ki}-sze3 gu2 nam-ba-an-gar-re-en-ze2-en {gesz}tukul nam-ba-an-sag3-ge-en-ze2-en| Never before have you submitted to the house of Kish. Should you not smite it with weapons? 
ukken gar-ra gurusz iri{ki}-na-ka {d}gilgamesx(BIL3.GA.MES) mu-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4| In the convened assembly, the able-bodied men of his city answer Gilgamesh: 
gub-gub-bu-de3 tusz-tusz-u3-de3| “Standing on duty and sitting in attendance, 
dumu lugal-la da ri-e-de3| the son of the king escorting, 
zib2 ansze dab5-dab5-be2-e-de3| the reins of the donkey always grasping, 
a-ba zi-bi mu-un-tuku-e-sze| who has the breath?,” as the saying goes. 
e2 kisz{ki}-sze3 gu2 nam-ba-an-gar-re-en-ze2-en {gesz}tukul nam-ba-an-sag3-ge-en-de3-en| To the house of Kish you all should not submit! With weapons should we not smite it?” 
unu{ki} gesz-kin-ti dingir-re-e-ne-ke4| “The structure of Uruk, the handiwork of the gods, 
e2-an-na e2 an-ta e11-de3| and of Eanna, the house from heaven lowered down, 
dingir gal-gal-e-ne me-dim2-bi ba-an-ak-esz-am3| the great gods created. 
bad3 gal bad3 an-ne2 ki us2-sa| The great wall, the wall which An founded, 
ki-tusz mah an-ne2 gar-ra-ni| the majestic residence which An established, 
sag mu-e-se3 za-e lugal ur-sag-bi| you watch over. You are its king and warrior, 
sag lum-lum nun an-ne2 ki-ag2| an exuberant person, a prince by An beloved. 
du-a-ni-ta a-gin7 ni2 ba-an-te| When Aga comes, what terror he will experience! 
erin2-bi al-tur a-ga-bi-ta al-bir-re| That army is small, at the rear scattered. 
lu2-be2-ne igi nu-mu-un-da-ru-gu2-usz| Its men will be incapable of confronting us.” 
u4-bi-a {d}gilgamesx(BIL3.GA.MES) en kul-aba4{ki}-ke4| Then Gilgamesh, the lord of Kulaba, 
inim gurusz iri-na-sze3 sza3-ga-ni an-hul2 ur5-ra-ni ba-an-zalag| at the advice of the able-bodied men of his city rejoiced and his spirit brightened. 
szubur-a-ni en-ki-du10-ra gu3 mu-na-de2-e| His servant Enkidu he addressed: 
ne-esz2 {gesz}szu-kar2 a2 me3 sa he2-em-mi-gi4| “On this account let the weaponry and arms of battle be made ready. 
{gesz}tukul me3 a2-zu-sze3 he2-em-mi-gi4| Let the battle mace to your side return. 
ni2-gal me-lam2-ma he2-em-dim2-dim2-e| A great terror and radiance may they create. 
e-ne du-a-ni-ta ni2-gal-mu he2-eb-szu2| When he comes, my great fearsomeness will overwhelm him. 
dim2-ma-ni he2-suh3 galga-a-ni he2-bir-re| His reasoning will become confused, his judgment disarrayed.” 
u4 nu 5(disz)-am3 u4 nu 1(u)-am3| Not 5 days, not 10 days had passed 
ag-ga dumu en-me-bara2-ge4-si-ke4 unu{ki} za3-ga ba-an-dab5-be2-esz| when Aga, the son of Enmebaragesi, to Uruk with his men laid siege . 
unu{ki}-ga dim2-ma-bi ba-an-suh3| Uruk’s reasoning became confused. 
{d}gilgamesx(BIL3.GA.MES) en kul-aba4{ki}-ke4| Gilgamesh, the lord of Kulaba, 
ur-sag-be2-ne-er gu3 mu-ne-de2-e| to its warriors speaks: 
ur-sag-mu-ne igi mu-un-suh-suh-u3-ne| “My warriors shall have the choice. 
sza3-tuku he2-en-zi-zi-i ag-ga-sze3 ga-an-szi-gen| Let someone with courage rise up, “I shall go against Aga” 
bir-hur-tur-ra lu2-sag lugal-a-ni| Birḫurtura, his royal guard, 
lugal-a-ni-ir za3-mu10 mu-un-na-ab-be2| in admiration to his king says: 
ge26-e ag-ga-sze3 ga-an-szi-gen| I shall go against Aga. 
dim2-ma-ni he2-suh3 galga-a-ni he2-bir-re| so that his reasoning will become confused, his judgment disarrayed.” 
bir-hur-tur-ra abul-la ba-ra-e11| Birḫurtura through the city gate went out. 
bir-hur-tur-ra abul-la e3-da-ni| As soon as Birḫurtura went out through the city gate, 
ka2 abul-la-ka mu-ni-in-dab5-be2-esz| at the gate of the city gate they captured him, 
bir-hur-tur-ra sukud-ra2-ni mu-ni-in-gum-gum-ne| Birḫurtura’s entire length beating. 
igi ag-ga-sze3 mu-ni-in-te| Into the presence of Aga he came 
ag-ga-sze3 gu3 mu-na-de2-e| speaking to Aga. 
inim-ma-ni nu-un-til zabar-dab5 unu{ki}-ga-ke4 bad3-sze3 im-me-e11-de3| His words were not done, a “mirror-holder” of Uruk, on the wall climbing up, 
bad3-da gu2-na im-ma-an-la2| out over the wall leaned. 
ag-ga igi im-ma-ni-in-du8| Aga trained his eyes, 
bir-hur-tur-re gu3 mu-na-de2-e| to Birḫurtura speaking: 
ARAD2 lu2 sze lugal-zu-u3| “Slave, is that man your king?” 
lu2 sze lugal-mu in-nu| “That man is not my king! 
lu2 sze lugal-mu he2-me-a| Were that man my king, 
sag-ki husz-a-ni he2-me-a| were that his angry brow, 
igi alim-ma-ka-ni he2-me-a| were those his bison eyes, 
su6 {na4}za-gin3-na-ka-a-ni he2-me-a| were that his lapis lazuli beard, 
szu-si sa6-ga-ni he2-me-a| were those his elegant fingers, 
szar2-ra la-ba-an-szub-bu-usz szar2-ra la-ba-an-zi-ge-esz| would he not cast down multitudes? Would he not raise up multitudes? 
szar2-ra sahar-ra la-ba-an-da-szar2-re-esz| Would multitudes not be smeared with dust? 
kur-kur du3-a-bi la-ba-an-da-szu2-a| Would not all the nations be overwhelmed? 
ka ma-da-ka sahar-ra la-ba-da-an-si| Would not the (canal-)mouths of the land be filled with silt? 
si {gesz}ma2-gur8-ra-ka la-ba-ra-an-ku5| Would not the horns of the barges be broken? 
ag-ga lugal kisz{ki}-a sza3 erin2-na-ka-ni szaga-a la-ba-ni-in-ak| Would he not take captive Aga, the king of Kish, in the midst of his army?” 
mu-ni-ib-ra-ra-ne mu-ni-ib-sag3-sag3-ge-ne| Hitting him, striking him, 
bir-hur-tur-re sukud-ra2-ni mu-ni-in-gum-gum-ne| Birḫurtura’s entire length they were beating. 
egir zabar-dab5 unu{ki}-ga-ke4 {d}gilgamesx(BIL3.GA.MES) bad3-sze3 im-me-e11-de3| After the “mirror-holder” of Uruk, Gilgamesh climbs up on the wall. 
ab-ba di4-di4-la2 kul-aba4{ki}-a-ke4 me-lam2 bi2-ib-szu2-szu2| the young and old of Kulaba his radiance overwhelms. 
gurusz unu{ki}-ga-ke4 {gesz}tukul me3 a2-ne-ne bi2-in-si| The able-bodied men of Uruk with battle maces he armed, 
{gesz}ig abul-la-ka sila-ba bi2-in-gub| on the causeway at the door of the city gate stationed. 
en-ki-du10 abul-la dili ba-ra-e11| Enkidu through the city gate alone went out. 
{d}gilgamesx(BIL3.GA.MES) bad3-da gu2-na im-ma-an-la2| Gilgamesh out over the wall leaned. 
igi bar-re-da-ni ag-ga igi ba-ni-in-du8| Looking up, Aga opened his eyes: 
ARAD2 lu2 sze lugal-zu-u3| “Slave, is that man your king?” 
lu2 sze lugal-mu i3-me-a| “That man is indeed my king.” 
bi2-in-du11-ga-gin7-nam| It was just as he had said: 
szar2-ra ba-an-szub-bu-usz szar2-ra ba-an-zi-ge-esz| Multitudes fell, multitudes rose up, 
szar2-ra sahar-ra ba-an-da-szar2-re-esz| multitudes with dust were smeared, 
kur-kur du3-a-bi ba-an-da-szu2-am3| all the nations were overwhelmed, 
ka ma-da-ka sahar-ra ba-da-an-si| the (canal-)mouths of the land with silt were filled, 
si {gesz}ma2-gur8-ra-ke4 ba-ra-an-ku5| the horns of the barges were broken, 
ag-ga lugal kisz{ki}-a sza3 erin2-na-ka-ni szaga-a ba-ni-in-ak| Aga, the king of Kish, in the midst of his army he took captive 
{d}gilgamesx(BIL3.GA.MES) en kul-aba4{ki}-ke4| Gilgamesh, the lord of Kulaba, 
ag-ga-a gu3 mu-na-de2-e| to Aga speaks: 
ag-ga ugula-mu ag-ga nu-banda3-mu| “Aga my foreman, Aga my lieutenant, 
ag-ga szagina erin2-na-mu| Aga my commander of the troops! 
ag-ga zi ma-an-szum2 ag-ga nam-ti ma-an-szum2| Aga gave me breath, Aga gave me life: 
ag-ga lu2-kar-ra ur2-ra bi2-in-tum2-mu| Aga a fugitive into his embrace took, 
ag-ga muszen kar-ra sze bi2-ib-si-si| Aga the fleeing bird with grain provided.” 
unu{ki} gesz-kin-ti dingir-re-e-ne-ke4| “Uruk, the handiwork of the gods, 
bad3 gal bad3 an-ne2 ki us2-sa| the great wall, the wall which An founded, 
ki-tusz mah an-ne2 gar-ra-ni| the majestic residence which An established, 
sag mu-se3 za-e lugal ur-sag-bi| you watch over. You are its king and warrior, 
sag lum-lum nun an-ne2 ki-ag2| an exuberant person, a prince beloved of An.” 
igi {d}utu-sze3 szu u4-bi-ta e-ra-an-gi4| “Before Utu, your former kindness is hereby repaid to you.” 
ag-ga kisz{ki}-sze3 szu ba-ni-in-ba| Aga to Kish he set free. 
{d}gilgamesx(BIL3.GA.MES) en kul-aba4{ki}-a-ke4| As to Gilgamesh, lord of Kulaba, 
za3-mu10-zu du10-ga-am3| your praise is sweet. 
{d}en-lil2 gu-ti-um{ki}| Enlil! Gutium,
musz-gir2 hur-sag-ga2| the fanged snake of the mountain ranges,
lu2 a2 zi-ga dingir-re-e-ne| a people who acted violently against the gods,
lu2 nam-lugal| people who the kingship
ki-en-gi-ra2| of Sumer
kur-sze3 ba-de6-a| to the mountains took away,
ki-en-gi-ra2| who Sumer
nig2-a-erim2 bi2-in-si-a| with wickedness filled,
dam tuku dam-ni| who from one with a wife his wife
ba-an-da-kar-ra| took away from him,
dumu tuku dumu-ni| who from one with a child his child
ba-an-da-kar-ra| took away from him,
nig2-a-erim2 nig2-a2-zi| who wickedness and violence
kalam-ma mi-ni-in-gar-ra| produced within the country—
{d}en-lil2 lugal kur-kur-ra-ke4| Enlil, the king of all the lands,
mu-bi ha-lam-e-de3| to obliterate its name,
{d}utu-he2-gal2| Utuḫegal,
nita kal-ga| the mighty man,
lugal unu{ki}-ga| the king of Uruk,
lugal an-ub-da limmu5-ba| the king of the four world quarters,
lugal du11-ga-na nu-gi4-gi4-da| the king whose utterances cannot be countermanded,
{d}en-lil2 lugal kur-kur-ra-ke4| Enlil, the king of all the lands,
a2-bi mu-da-an-ag2| issued to him a command about this.
{d}inanna nin-a-ni| To Inanna his lady
mu-na-an-gen| he went
szu12 mu-na-sza4| and prayed to her, (saying)
nin-mu pirig me3| “My lady, lioness of battle,
kur-kur-da du7-du7| who the foreign lands batters,
{d}en-lil2-le nam-lugal ki-en-gi-ra| Enlil, the kingship of Sumer
szu-ba gi4-gi4-de3| to return to its own control
a2-bi mu-da-an-ag2| he commanded me.
a2-dah-mu he2-me| May you be my ally.”
ugnim lu2 kur2-kur2-ra| An army of many foreigners
ki he2-ni-us2-us2| bore down upon the land everywhere.
ti-ri2-ga-a-an| Tirigan,
lugal gu-ti-um-ke4| the king of Gutium,
ka-bi ba-an-ba| opened its (canal?) mouths,
lu2 nu-mu-szi-e3| but no one came out against him.
i7 idigna gu2 min-a-ba| Both banks of the Tigris
bi2-in-dab5| he had seized.
sig-sze3 ki-en-gi-ra2| To the south, in Sumer,
GAN2 bi2-kesz2| the cultivated land he tied up,
igi-nim-sze3 giri3 i3-kesz2| to the north, the roads he tied up.
kaskal kalam-ma-ke4| On the highways of the country
u2-gid2-da bi2-in-mu2| he made tall grasses grow.
lugal {d}en-lil2-le| But the king to whom Enlil
a2 szum2-ma| had given power,
{d}inanna-ke4 sza3-ge pa3-da| whom Inanna by (her own) heart had chosen,
{d}utu-he2-gal2 nita kal-ga| Utuḫegal, the mighty man,
unu{ki}-ta mu-szi-e3| from Uruk went out against him.
e2 {d}iszkur-ka| In the temple of Iškur
gesz bi2-du3| he made an offering.
dumu iri-na-ke4-ne| To the citizens of his city
gu3 mu-ne-de2-e| he was calling out, (saying)
gu-ti-um{ki}| “Gutium
{d}en-lil2-le ma-an-szum2| Enlil has given to me.
nin-mu {d}inanna| My mistress Inanna
a2-dah-mu-um| is my ally.
{d}dumu-zi-ama-uszumgal-an-na-ke4| Dumuzi-Ama’ušumgalana
nam-mu bi2-du11| has declared ‛It is something that concerns me,’
{d}gilgames3| and Gilgameš,
dumu {d}nin-sun2-na-ke4| the son of Ninsun,
maszkim-sze3 ma-an-szum2| as bailiff he has given to me.”
dumu unu{ki}-ga| The citizens of Uruk
dumu kul-aba4{ki}-ka| and the citizens of Kullab
sza3 hul2-la ba-an-gar| he caused to rejoice at this.
iri-ni lu2 dili-gin7| His city, as one man,
egir-ra-ne2 ba-ab-us2| followed after him.
zu2-keszda igi-bar-ra| The military contingents and scouts
si bi2-sa2| he put in good order.
e2 {d}iszkur-ka zi-ga-ne2| After having departed from the temple of Iškur,
u4 4(disz)-kam-ma nag-su i7 en-uri3-gal-ka| on the 4th day in Nagsu on the Enurigal canal

u4 5(disz)-kam-ma bara2-i3-li2-tab-ba-e-ka| On the 5th day at Bara-Ilitappe
gesz bi2-du3| he made an offering.

sza3 ge6-ba-ka im-ma-an-zi| In the middle of that night he arose,
igi-nim adab{ki}| and north of Adab,
{d}utu e3-a| when Utu had risen,

{d}en-lil2-le ma-an-szum2| Enlil has given to me,

erin2 mu-na-lah5| and the troops he drove to him.
{d}utu-he2-gal2 nita kal-ga| Utuḫegal, the mighty man,

ba-da-an-kar-ra| he had fled,
dab6-ru-um{ki}-ma ba-an-sa6| in Dabrum, they (at first) were good to him.
lu2 dab6-ru-um-ma-ke4| (But) the people of Dabrum,
{d}utu-he2-gal2| Utuḫegal,
bar lugal {d}en-lil2-le a2 szum2-ma| because, he a king to whom Enlil had given power
i3-me-a i3-zu-ke4-esz2| he was, they had realized,

szu nu-ni-ba| they did not let go.
lu2-kin-gi4-a {d}utu-he2-gal2| By the envoys of Utuḫegal
ti-ri2-ga-a-an| Tirigan
u3 dam dumu-ni| and his wife and children
dab6-ru-um{ki}-ma mu-un-dab5| in Dabrum were captured.

nam-lugal ki-en-gi-ra szu-ba im-mi-gi4| and the kingship of Sumer to its control he returned.

{d}nanna| Nanna,
sag gal dingir-dingir a-nun-ke4-ne| great head of the Anuna gods, 
nir-gal2 e2-kur-ra| the most authoritative one of the Ekur,
me-ni an-ki-da gu2 la2-a| whose divine powers embrace heaven and earth
u18-ru sag2 nu-di| and which no storm can dissipate,
en asz-ni dingir pa e3-a| the lord who alone is a god who comes forth resplendentdly, 
dumu sag {d}en-lil2-la2| the first-born son of Enlil,
me ul-li2-a ki-be2 gi4-gi4| in order to restore the ancient divine attributes, 
gesz-hur uri2{ki}-ma| and the divine plans of Ur
si sa2-e-de3| to set right, 
dumu nun-e e2-kur-ta| from the Ekur the princely son 
me mah ib2-ta-an-e3| brought forth the exalted divine powers,
{d}i-din-{d}da-gan| and to Iddin-Dagan,
gesztu2 szum2-ma {d}en-ki-ka-ra| given wisdom by Enki,
mas-su2 inim pa3-de3| to the leader who reveals the matter,
nig2-nam gal-zu-ra| who knows everything well,
sipa zi ki-ag2-ga2-ni-ir| to the righteous shepherd whom he loves,
szu-ne2 im-ma-an-szum2| he (Nanna) put them into his hands. 
{d}i-din-{d}da-gan| Iddin-Dagan,
lugal kal-ga lugal uri2{ki}-ma| the strong king, king of Ur 
lugal ki-en-gi ki-uri| and king of Sumer and Akkad,
ki-ag2 {d}nanna u3 {d}nin-gal-ke4| beloved of Nanna and Ningal,
mu-na-dim2 nam-ti-la-ni-sze3| he fashioned (this) for him, and for his life 
a mu-na-ru| he dedicated it to him.
lu2 a2 nig2-hul-dim2-ma| A person who a wicked command
ib2-szi-ag2-ge26-a nig2 dim2-ma-mu| shall issue against it, and that which I have fashioned
ib2-ze-re-a| shall efface,
mu-sar-ra-ba szu bi2-ib2-ur3-a| or shall erase its inscription  
mu-ni bi2-ib2-sar-re-a| and write his own name upon it,
asz2-bala-a-ba-ke4-esz lu2-kur2| or, because of the curse, another person
szu ba-an-zi-zi-a| he shall get to raise a hand against it,
lu2-bi lugal he2-a| that person, whether a king,
en he2-a u3 lu2-u18 sag zi-gal2| an en-priest, or an ordinary living person
mu-ni sa4-a he2-a| called by name,  
lu2-be2 mu na-an-du12-du12| may that person not acquire a name
numun na-mi-i-i| and may he not produce progeny.  
lu2-ba {d}nanna lugal-mu| That person may Nanna my master
{d}nin-gal nin-mu| and Ningal my mistress
nam ha-ba-an-da-kur2-ne| curse,
{d}utu {d}inanna maszkim nu-ku2-bi he2-a| and may Utu and Inanna be it's unstoppable enforcer 
u4 da-ri2-sze3| forever.
{d}nin-lil2 nin dingir-re-e-ne-ra| For Ninlil, queen of the gods,
{d}i-din-{d}da-gan lugal kal-ga| Iddin-Dagan, the strong king,
igi-ni-sze3 in-gub| and set it up before her.  
nam-ti-la-ni-sze3 a mu-na-ru| For his life he dedicated it to her.
lu2 a2 nig2-hul-dim2-ma ib2-szi-ag2-ge26-a| A person who shall issue an order of wickedness
mu-sar-ra-ba mu-ni bi2-ib2-sar-re-a| who shall write his name on my inscription,

sag-ki zalag-(ga)| may the shining brow 
{d}nanna| of Nanna
an-ta he2-gi4| send him out in front(?). 
{d}nin-gal| May Ningal 
he2-en-da-hul2| rejoice over him.
e2-kisz-nu-gal2-la| In the Ekišnugal temple 
gu2 an-sze3| his neck up high  
he2-ni-in-zi-zi| may he raise. 
{d}alad| May a male guardian angel 
inim he2-ni-ib-sa6-sa6| say favorable words regarding him. 
nig2-gi-na| To rightness 
i-{d}utu-bi| and appeals for justice 
u4-szu2-usz-e| daily 
{d}lamma-ra-ni he2-sze-sze| may his female guardian angel be agreeable  
u4 da-ri2-sze3| forever. 
lu2 a2 nig2 hul-dim2-ma| A person who an order for a wicked thing 
ib2-szi-ag2-ge26-a| shall issue against it, 
nig2-dim2-ma-mu| who my creation 
ib2-zi-re-a| shall efface, 
mu-sar-ra-mu| or my inscription 
szu bi2-ib2-ur3-a| shall erase 
mu-ni| and his name 
bi2-ib2-sar-re-a| shall write upon it, 
ki-gub-ba-bi| or its standing place 
ib2-szi-ib-kur2-a| shall alter regarding it,

i-ni-ib-ku4-ku4-a| shall bring it, 
asz2-bala-ba-ke4-esz| or because of this curse 
lu2-kur2 szu ba-an-zi-zi-a| shall incite another person to (do) it,  
lu2-ba {d}nanna| that person may Nanna 
lugal-mu| my master 
{d}nin-gal| and Ningal 
nin-mu| my mistress
nam ha-ba-an-da-ku5-ne| both curse.
iri{ki}-bi| May that one's city  
du6-du6-ra| among the ruined mounds  
he2-en-szid| be counted. 
i7-da-be2| May its canal 
a nam-tum3| not bring forth water, 
a-sza3-ga-ne3| and his fields 
sze nam-tum3| not bring forth barley.

dumu sag| the first-born son

abzu e2 me ku3-ku3-ga-a-ni| an Abzu, his temple which makes holy the divine attributes,

u4 {d}utu larsa{ki}-ma| When the god Utu Larsa's 
nam-bi mu-un-tar-ra-a| fate had decreed, 
{gesz}gu-za-ba suhusz-bi| and the foundation of its throne 
su3-ra2-sze3 gi-ne2-de3| to secure forever,

szul {d}utu| the youthful Utu
inim nu-kur2-ru-da-ni| his unalterable word 
zi-de3-esz| steadfastly 
bi2-in-du11-ga| had spoken, 
nu-ur2-{d}iszkur| I, Nur-Adad, 
sipa nig2-gi-na-me-en| being a righteous shepherd  
sza3 su3-ra-na| in his remote heart 
zi-de3-esz| truly
mu-un-pa3-de3-en| he chose me.
nam du10 mu-un-tar| he decreed a good fate for me. 
iri{ki} ba-tu-de3-en-na-ga2| Of the city where I was born 
nam-sipa-bi ma-an-szum2| its shepherdship he gave to me. 
nam-u2-a esz3-e uri2{ki}-ma| The providing for the shrine Ur, 
nam-sag-en3-tar esz3 e2-babbar-ra| the care for the shrine Ebbbar, 
{d}utu-ra gu2-bi mi-ni-gur-gur| for Utu I stacked up. 
tur3 amasz mi-ni-dagal| I enlarged the cattle pens and sheepfolds. 
i3 gara2 mi-ni-szar2-szar2| I increased the fat and cheese. 
ug3-mu u2 szar2-ra| My people much food 
mi-ni-gu7| I let eat, 
a he2-gal2-la mi-ni-nag| and I let them drink abundant water. 
sza3-bi-a sa-gaz lu2 hul-gal2| From their midst the robbers, wicked persons, 
lu2 nig2-erim2 mu-ha-lam| and evildoers I obliterated. 
si-ga nu-mu-un-kusz lu2 ki-gul-la| The weak, the widows and the destitute 
su-bi mi-ni-du10| I improved their lives.
u4 bala sa6-ga-mu| At the time of my good reign, 
2(asz) sze gur-ta 2(ban2) i3-ta| each: 2 kor barley, 2 ban oil, 
1(u) ma-na siki-ta| 10 minas of wool,
1(u) gur zu2-lum-ta-am3| 10 kor dates, 
ganba sza3 ma-da-ga2-ka| at the market rate in my country  
ku3 1(disz) gin2-e| one shekel silver
ur5-gin7 ba-ra-sa10| thusly could purchase.
u4-bi-a bad3 gal larsa{ki}-ma| At that time, the great wall of Larsa 
hur-sag-gin7 ki sikil-la mu-du3| like a mountain range in a pure place I built.
a2 lu2 1(disz)-e| The wages per man 
3(ban2) sze-ta 2(disz) sila3 ninda-ta| were each: 3 ban barley, 2 sila bread, 
2(disz) sila3 kasz-ta| 2 sila beer, 
2(disz) gin2 i3-ta-am3| 2 shekels oil; 
u4 1(disz)-e ur5-gin7 szu ba-an-ti| such for one day they received.   
u4 da-ri2-sze3 mu-mu ga2-ga2-de3| In order to establish my name for eternity, 
bad3 gal-bi| for this great wall 
temen ku3 mi-ni-si| I sank the holy foundation pegs, 
{d}utu u3-ma-ni| and Utu His Victory
sa2 bi2-in-du11| has Attained
mu-sze3 im-mi-sa4| I named it. 
di nig2-gi-na {d}utu-ta| By the righteous verdict of Utu, 
iri{ki} x-sze3 ga-ba-al| the city against which battle 
mu-un-du3-a| he had waged 
bad3-bi du6-du6-ra mi-ni-szid| its walls I counted as ruined mounds.
gu2 nu-gar-ra-bi| Those of it that did not submit 
giri3 {d}utu lugal-ga2-sze3 mi-ni-gam| I made bend down to the feet of Utu my master.
in-dub {d}utu| The boundary mound of Utu 
lugal-ga2-ke4| my master 
ki-be2 im-mi-gi4| I restored.
en pirig gal ka-asz-bar an-ki| (for) the lord, great lion, the decider of heaven and earth, 
am an-sze3 izi-gar-gin7 ga2-ga2| wild bull who is set against the sky like a torch, 
ti-la ug5-ga en3 tar-bi-im| who attends to the living and the dead, 
me-be2 asz-a-ni szu du7-du7| who alone makes perfect those divine powers, 
nun szul {d}utu| the prince, youthful Utu, 
men ku3-ga gal-bi tum2-ma| most suited for the holy crown, 
arhusz2 su3 ga-ti-e ki-ag2| filled with compassion, who loves ex-votos,
a-ra-zu-e gesz tuku| who listens to prayers, 
lugal-a-ni-ir| for his master, 
{d}suen-i-din-nam nita kal-ga| Sin-iddinam, the mighty man, 
u2-a uri5{ki}-ma| provider of Ur,

ki-be2 bi2-in-gi4-a| did restore,

gir-su{ki}-ke4| and Girsu, 
ibila kal-ga sza3 a-a-na du10-du10| mighty heir who gladdens the heart of his father, 
dumu-sag {d}iszkur-ke4| first-born son of Iškur, 
alan gub ku3-babbar a-a ugu-na| a silver standing statue of the father who begot him,  
nu-ur2-{d}iszkur| Nur-Adad, 
lugal larsa2{ki}-ma-ke4| the king of Larsa, 
me-dim2 sa6| with beautiful features,
im-sar-ra si3-ga| set with inscriptions, 
mu-na-dim2| he fashioned for him,
nam-ti-la-ni-sze3| and for his life 
a mu-na-ru| he dedicated to him. 
kisal-mah esz3 e2-babbar-ra| In the main courtyard of the shrine Ebabbar, 
ki u6-di kalam-ma-ka| the most wonderous place of the nation, 
e2 mah siskur2-ra| in his exalted temple, for offerings  
he2-du7-na| most suitable,
bi2-in-gub| he stood it up. 
{d}suen-i-din-na-am| I, Sin-iddinam, 
nita kal-ga| the mighty man, 
u2-a uri2{ki}-ma| provider of Ur, 
lugal larsa{ki}-ma| king of Larsa, 
lugal ki-en-gi ki-uri| king of Sumer and Akkad, 
lugal e2-babbar e2 {d}utu-ke4| the king who the Ebabbar, the temple of Utu, 
mu-un-du3-a| did build, 
gesz-hur e2 dingir-re-e-ne| and who the divine plans of the temples of the gods 
ki-bi-sze3 bi2-gi4-a-me-en| did restore, 
u4 an-ne2 {d}en-lil2 {d}nanna {d}utu-bi| when An, Enlil, Nanna and Utu 
bala du10 nig2-si-sa2| a favorable reign of justice 
u4-bi su3-su3-ud-ra2| whose days have been prolonged 
ga2-ra sag-e-esz-e ma-ni-in-rig7-esz-a| did present to me, 
gesztu2 dagal-la-mu| by means of my broad wisdom 
mah-bi-sze3 gar| greatly established  
sag-bi-sze3 e3-a-ta| and pre-eminent,  
iri{ki} ma-da-mu-sze3| for my cities and land 
a du10 ga2-ga2-de3| to produce good water
a-ra2 za3-mi2| as well as the course and praise
nam-ur-sag-ga2-mu| of my heroism
u4-da eger-bi-sze3| today and afterwards 
pa e3 mah ak-de3| to make highly resplendent, 
an-ra {d}en-lil2-ra| to An and Enlil 
inim in-sa6-sa6| I made pleasing words, 
a-ra-zu gi-na-mu-sze3| and they to my righteous prayers  
hu-mu-szi-in-sze-ge-esz-a| having been agreeable, 
{i7}idigna ba-al-la-a-da| for the digging of the Tigris, 
ki-bi-sze3 gi4-a-da| and its restoring, 
u4 ti-la su3-ud-ra2-sze3| also through long days of life
mu-mu ga2-ga2-de3| to establish my name, 
inim nu-kur2-ru-bi-a| with their unalterable words
a2-bi hu-mu-da-an-ag2-esz| they issued orders to me. 
u4-ba du11-ga du11-ga| At that time, by the commands 
an {d}inanna-ta| of An and Inanna 
sze-ga {d}en-lil2 {d}nin-lil2-ta| with the agreement of Enlil and Ninlil, 
{d}iszkur dingir-mu| and of Iškur my (personal) god
a2-dah-ga2-ta| my helper, 
usu mah {d}nanna {d}utu-ta| and by the exalted power of Nanna and Utu, 
{i7}idigna| the Tigris, 
i7 he2-gal2-la {d}utu-ke4| Utu’s river of abundance, 
u3-ma-mu-ta| by means of my triumph 
gal-bi he2-em-mi-ba-al| I dug there in a grand fashion. 
ki-sur-ra in-dub pa3-mu-sze3| Up to the border territory, my chosen boundary mound, 
ka-bi um-mi-tum4| I brought its beginning, 
a-gam-ma-bi-sze3| and into a marsh 
si gal he2-em-mi-sa2| I directed it in a great fashion. 
a da-ri2| (Thus) a constant water supply, 
he2-gal2 musz3 nu-tum2-mu| a ceaseless abundance, 
larsa{ki} kalam-ma-mu-sze3| to my city Larsa of the nation  
he2-em-mi-gar| I established.
u4 {i7}idigna i7 gu-la| When the Tigris, the great river, 
mu-ba-al-la-a| I dug, 
a2 lu2 1(disz)-e| the wages for one man were 
sze 1(asz) gur-ta| 1 kor barley each, 
ninda 2(disz) sila3-ta| 2 sila bread each, 
kasz 4(disz) sila3-ta| 4 sila beer each 
i3 2(disz) gin2-ta-am3| and 2 shekels oil each, 
u4 asz-a| in one day 
ur5-gin7 szu ha-ba-an-ti| thusly they received it.
lu2 a2 la2| Either a man less wages, 
lu2 a2 dah| or a man more wages 
ba-ra-bi2-tuku| I did not let him take.
usu ma-da-mu-ta| Through the strength of the land 
kin-bi he2-em-mi-til| I completed that work. 
inim ka-asz-bar| By means of the commands and divine decisions 
dingir gal-e-ne-ta| of the great gods 
{i7}idigna i7 dagal-la| the Tigris, the wide river, 
ki-bi-sze3 he2-em-mi-gi4| I returned to its former place,
u4 ul du-ri2-sze3| and (so) for all future time 
mu-mu he2-em-mi-gub| I have indeed made my name stand forth. 
{d}utu| For Utu 
lugal-a-ni-ir| his master, 
{d}suen-i-din-na-am| Sin-iddinam, 
nita kal-ga| the mighty man, 
u2-a uri5{ki}-ma| provider of Ur,

e2-babbar| the Ebabbar, 
e2 ki-ag2-ga2-ni| his beloved temple,

mu-na-ni-in-du3| he built for him. 
me gesz-hur| The divine attributes and divine plans 
nam-en-na-ka-ni| of the office of en priest 
u4 ul-li2-a-asz| for all future days 
pa gal mu-na-an-e3| he made greatly resplendent for him. 
{d}suen-i-din-na-am| Sin-iddinam, 
nita kal-ga| the mighty man, 
u2-a uri2{ki}-ma| provider of Ur, 
lugal larsa{ki}-ma| king of Larsa 
lugal ki-en-gi ki-uri| and king of Sumer and Akkad, 
{d}utu lugal-mu| to Utu my master 
inim in-na-sa6-sa6| I spoke pleasing words, 
a-ra-zu sza3-ge de6-a-ga2| and to the prayers of my heart’s desire
hu-mu-szi-in-sze| he was agreeable.
u4-bi-a sze-ga {d}utu| At that time, through the willingness 
lugal-ga2-ta| of my master, 
e2-babbar e2 ki-ag2-ga2-ni| the Ebabbar, his beloved temple, 
hu-mu-na-du3| I built for him. 
hur-sag il2-la-gin7| Like a lifted up mountain range 
sag hu-mu-na-ni-il2| I raised up (its) top for him, 
ki-tusz sza3 du10-ga-na| and in his residence which pleases the heart 
{d}utu he2-em-mi-tusz| I let Utu dwell.
{d}utu| For Utu, 
en di-ku5 an-ki| lord and judge of heaven and earth,

ki-tusz-bi mu-na-an-dagal| he enlarged its residence. 
nig2 ak-bi-sze3| For that which was done   
{d}utu| may Utu

u4 {d}utu esz3 e2-babbar-ra| When Utu the shrine Ebabbar's

u4-ba {d}suen-i-din-na-am| then it was towards me, Sin-iddinam,

szul {d}utu kur kilib3-ba-ni-ta| that youthful Utu, out of all the lands,

ki-bi mi-ni-in-kin-kin| he sought out the place for it there.
2(disz) am gal ki asz-te| Two big wild bulls, at the location of the seat, 
erim2 lugal-la du7-de3| butting the king's enemies, 
zi-da gub2-bu-bi| on the right and left of it,
sig-ta im-mi-in-gar| below, he placed.

du10-ub-ba im-mi-in-gub| and set it up on its lap(?).
na4 1(asz) gu2| Stone (weight) of one talent, 
e2-gal {d}suen-i-ri-ba-am| palace of Sin-iribam. 
i-s,i-qa2-tar| Isi-qatar, 
dumu ka-mi-zu-um| son of Kamizum, 
ARAD {d}suen-i-ri-ba-am| servant of Sin-iribam.
{d}en-lil2| For Enlil, 
en u18-ru| the high lord, 
asz-a-ni mah| who alone is great, 
za3-dib an-ki-a| most excellent one of heaven and earth, 
sipa-gin7 edin| who like a shepherd in the steppe

nig2 a-na| who all things, whatever
mu sa4-a| the name, 
en3 tar-ra| does care for,

u4 asz-a ur5-gin7 hu-mu-ni-gar| for each day thus I set.
u4-me-da u4-da egir-bi-sze3| For now and forever afterwards

ARAD-ga2| my servant, 
nig2 mu sa4-a| whatever named thing

ARAD-ga2| my servant 
nu-ub-ta-ku5-ru-a| shall not cut off,

du-ri2 he2-em| be long-lasting.

kilib3 dingir gal-gal-e-ne-ne| and all the great gods, 
asz2 gig-ga| a grievous curse 
he2-ni-in-bal-e-ne| may they pass over onto him, 
e-ne u3 numun-a-ni| and him and his seed 
sza3 kalam-ma-ka| within the country 
nam-mu-ni-ib2-ga2-ga2-ne| may they not let be established there.
sza3 du10-du10 a-a-ugu-na| who constantly pleases the father who begot him, 
en-sza3-ki-ag2-{d}nanna| Enšaki'ag-Nanna, 
en igi-du-mu| the en-priestess who preceded me, 
{d}nanna| For Nanna, 
en dumu nun| lord, princely son, 
an ku3-ge dalla e3| who shines forth upon holy heaven, 
nam-szita a-ra-zu-e gesz tuku| who listens to prayer and supplication, 
lugal-mu-ra| my master, 
ARAD2-{d}suen| I, Warad-Sîn, 
u2-a e2-kur-ra| provider of the Ekur, 
sipa sag-en3-tar| shepherd who cares for 
e2-kisz-nu-gal2| the Ekišnugal, 
lu2 ni2-tuku| a man who reveres 
esz3 e2-babbar-ra| the shrine Ebabbar, 
me gesz-hur| who the divine powers and plans 
eridu{ki}-ga szu du7-du7| of Eridu perfects, 
lu2 nidba gu-ul-gu-ul| a man who enlarges the food offerings 
e2-ninnu-me-en| of the Eninnu, 
lagasz{ki} gir2-su{ki}| I, who Lagaš and Girsu 
ki-be2 gi4-gi4-me-en| is restoring, 
iri{ki} dingir ma-da-be2-ne| who the cities of the gods of their lands 
szu gibil bi2-in-ak-a| did rework anew 
{d}nanna {d}utu-bi| and for Nanna and Utu 
ki-tusz hun-ga2 du10 mu-un-ne-gal2-la| did provide good and restful residences,  
nun ni2-te-ge26| the (god-)fearing prince 
e2 lugal-la-na-sze3| who at the temple of his master 
zi ti-le-ni-sze3 gub-ba-me-en| stands to serve, for the sake of his life - 
u4 {d}asz-im2-babbar| when Ašimbabbar  
geszkim sa6-ga-ne2| his favorable signs 
igi ma-ni-in-du8-a| he caused me to see, 
igi nam-ti-la-ka-ni| and his eye of life 
mu-szi-in-bar-ra-a| he directed towards me, 
e2-a-ni du3-u3-de3| and about the rebuilding of his temple  
ki-be2 gi4-gi4-de3| and the restoring of his temple 
ga2-ar ma-an-du11-ga| having spoken to me, 
nam-ti-mu-sze3| for my life 
u3 nam-ti| and the life 
ku-du-ur-ma-bu-uk| of Kudur-mabuk 
a-a-ugu-ga2-ke4| the father who begot me, 
e2 sza3 hul2-la-ka-ni| his temple which gladdens the heart, 
e2-temen-ni2-gur3-ru| the Etemenniguru, 
mu-na-du3| I built for him. 
me-te u6-di kalam-ma-ka| As an ornament and marvel of the nation 
u4 da-ri3-sze3 bi2-in-gub| I made it stand unto distant times. 
{d}nanna lugal-mu| Nanna my master, 
za-e-me-en ba-e-a-ak| it is you who have done it; 
ga2-e a-na-mu-me-en| but I - what am I? 
nig2 ak-ak-da-ga2| For the things I have done 
{d}nanna en an-ki| O Nanna, lord of heaven and earth, 
hu-mu-hul2-le-en| may you rejoice over me. 
nam-tar nam-ti-la bala su3-ra2| May a fate of life, a long reign, 
{gesz}gu-za suhusz gi-na| and a throne with a secure foundation 
sag-e-esz ha-ma-ab-rig7-ge| be granted to me. 
lugal larsa{ki}-ma| king of Larsa, 
lugal ki-en-gi ki-uri| king of Sumer and Akkad, 
dumu ku-du-ur-ma-bu-uk| sn of Kudur-mabuk, 
ad-da e-mu-ut-ba-la| father of Emutbala, 
ARAD2-{d}suen nun| I, Warad-Sîn, 
sze-ga nibru{ki} szul| one obedient to Nippur, the youth 
gesz-hur szu du7-du7| and perfects the divine plans,  
ni2-tuku u3 nu-ku kalam-ma-me-en| the nation's (god)-fearing one who never sleeps - 
u4 {d}utu lugal-mu gu3 zi ma-ni-in-de2-a| when Utu my master spoke truly to me,  
zu2-lum n sila3-ta| n sila dates each, 
zi3 n sila3-ta| n sila flour each, 
kasz n sila3-ta| n sila beer each, 
mu-ni-gar| I established there. 
nam-bi-sze3| For this, 
{d}utu| may Utu
bala he2-gal2-la| a reign of abundance 
esz3 larsa{ki}-ma-ka| in the shrine city Larsa 
a2-gal2 e2-babbar| the powerful one of the Ebabbar 
inim-ma-ni sze-ga| whose word is agreeable, 
igi {d}utu u3 {d}{sze3}szer7-da-bi| before Utu and (his consort) Šerda 
i5-gar-bi hul-hul-de3| to make that one's oracular utterances bad,   
u4-bi-sze3| at(?) that time 
sag-bi he2-ha-za| may he hold fast to that (low) person. 
{d}lu2-husz-gal| May the god Big Fierce Man, 
sag szu bal-e| when the person 
a-ba-ni-in-ak| he has overturned(?), 
maszkim hul-gar nu-kur2-ru-a he2-a| may he be (his) unchanging evil-working bailiff-demon 
u4 da-ri2-sze3| forever. 
na-ru-a ARAD2-{d}suen| Stele of Warad-Sîn. 
ARAD2-{d}suen| I, Warad-Sîn, 
nita kal-ga| the mighty man, 
sipa nig2-gi| a shepherd of righteousness 
{d}en-lil2-le gar-ra| appointed by Enlil, 
u2-a uri5{ki}-ma| provider of Ur, 
lugal larsa{ki}-ma| king of Larsa 
lugal ki-en-gi ki-uri-ke4| and king of Sumer and Akkad, 
dumu ku-du-ur-ma-bu-uk| son of Kudurmabuk 
ad-da e-mu-ut-ba-la-me-en| and father of Emutbala -
uri2{ki} dagal-e-de3| in order to expand Ur 
mu mah tuku-tuku-de3| and to acquire a great name 
sun5-na-bi| humbly 
u3-gul im-ma-an-ga2-ga2| I addressed a plea about it, 
{d}nanna lugal-mu| and Nanna my master 
mu-szi-in-sze| was agreeable to me.
bad3 gal hur-sag il2-la-gin7 szu nu-tu-tu| The great city wall raised up like a mountain range, which cannot be opposed,  
ni2-bi-sze3 e3-a| which came forth by itself, 
mu-na-du3| I built for him  
iri-ne2 he2-em-mi-dab6| and made it encircle his city.  
bad3-ba| Of that wall 
{d}nanna suhusz ma-da ge-en-ge-en| Nanna Keeps Secure the Foundation of the Nation 
mu-bi-im| is its name.
ARAD2-{d}suen| Warad-Sîn, 
nita kal-ga| the mighty man, 
u2-a uri2{ki}-ma| provider of Ur, 
lugal larsa{ki}-ma| king of Larsa 
lugal ki-en-gi ki-uri| and king of Sumer and Akkad, 
dumu ku-du-ur-ma-bu-uk| son of Kudur-mabuk 
ad-da e-mu-ut-ba-la| and father of Emutbala - 
uri2{ki} dagal-e-de3| in order to widen Ur, 
ki-sa2-a-bi szu pesz11-e-de3| to expand its platform, 
mu mah tuku-tuku-de3| and to acquire a great name, 
{d}nanna lugal-mu| Nanna my master 
mu-szi-in-sze| was agreeable to me. 
bad3 gal hur-sag il2-la-gin7| The great city wall, raised up like a mountain range 
szu nu-tu-tu-de3| which cannot be opposed, 
ni2-bi-sze3 e3-a| which came forth on its own,  
mu-na-du3| I built for him. 
bad3-ba| Of that wall 
{d}nanna suhusz ma-da ge-en-ge-en| Nanna Keeps Secure the Foundation of the Nation 
mu-bi-im| is its name. 
nig2 ak-ak-da-ga2| For all the things I was able to do, 
{d}nanna lugal-mu| O Nanna my master 
hu-mu-hul2-le-en| may you be happy with me. 
nam-tar nam-ti-la| May a fate of life, 
bala su13-ra2| a long reign, 
{gesz}gu-za suhusz gi-na| and a throne with a firm foundation 
sag-e-esz| as a gift 
ha-ma-ab-rig7-ge| be presented to me. 
ARAD2-{d}suen| I, Warad-Sîn, 
nita kal-ga| the mighty man, 
sipa nig2-gi mu2-mu2| shepherd who makes justice blossom, 
ki-ag2 {d}en-lil2| beloved of Enlil, 
{d}nanna {d}utu-bi| Nanna and Utu, 
e2-babbar-da ni2-tuku| who reveres the Ebabbar, 
u2-a e2-kur-ra| provider of the Ekur, 
lu2 sza3 nibru{ki} du10-du10| the man who pleases the heart of Nippur, 
sag-us2 e2-kisz-nu-gal2| the constant supporter of the Ekišnugal, 
lugal larsa{ki}-ma| king of Larsa 
lugal ki-en-gi ki-uri| and king of Sumer and Akkad, 
dumu ku-du-ur-ma-bu-uk| son of Kudur-mabuk  
ad-da e-mu-ut-ba-la-me-en| and father of Emutbala -
{d}nanna lugal-mu inim sa6-sa6-ge-da-mu| Nanna my master, with my making excellent words, 
uri2{ki} dagal-e-de3| about widening Ur, 
ki-sa2-a-bi szu pesz11-e-de3| expanding its platform  
diri nig2 u4-bi-da-ka| more than any previous one, 
ki-gar-bi gu-ul-lu-de3| enlarging its grounds, 
mu mah tuku-tuku-de3| and (so) making it acquire a great name,  
en3 u3-bi2-tar| after I made (oracular) inquiries, 
egir-a-ne2 bi2-zukum| I trod after him 
sun5-na-bi u3-gul im-ma-an-ga2-ga2| and humbly addressed pleas for it.
{d}nanna lugal-mu mu-szi-in-sze|  Nanna my master was agreeable to me.
nam-ti-mu-sze3 u3 nam-ti| For my life and the life 
ku-du-ur-ma-bu-uk a-a tu-da-ga2-ke4| of Kudur-mabuk, the father who begot me, 
iri kur nam-ti-la| in the city, the mountain of life 
ki he2-gal2-la-ka| and place of abundance, 
ki-tusz kilib3-gal2 dingir-re-e-ne-ke4| the residence (where) the assembly of the gods  
nam-ni mu-un-tar-ra| determined his destiny, 
mu-ni-gin7 diri-ga| which like his name is surpassing, 
sag an-e us2-sa| whose head reaches the sky, 
a2-bi szu-ta kin ki en3 tar gar-ra| whose arms seeking with hands the place where inquiries are placed, 
an-dul3 dagal-la-ni kur-kur-ra sza-mu-un-me| whose wide shadow he therefore made to be over all the lands, 
ug3 sag-ge6-ga ur2-be2 mu-un-lu-lu| at its base he multiplied the Black Headed People,  
nam-ti kar-kar-re-me-esz| they who betook their lives there,  
bad3 gal-bi hu-mu-du3| its great wall I built.
hur-sag sig7-ga-gin ki sikil-la he2-bi2-mu2| Like a verdant mountin range I made it grow upon a pure place. 
mu nam-mah-bi-gin7 sag-bi hu-mu-ni-in-il2| Like its name and majesty I raised up its top there. 
u6-di kalam-ma-sze3 pa gal-le-esz he2-bi2-in-e3| As a marvel of the nation I made it appear greatly resplendent. 
u4 bad3 uri2{ki}-ma mu-du3-a| When I built the wall of Ur, 
a2 lu2 1(disz)-e 3(ban3) sze-ta| the wages for one man were: 3 ban barley, 
2(disz) sila3 ninda-ta 2(disz) sila3 kasz-ta| 2 sila bread, 2 sila beer, 
2(disz) gin2 i3-gesz-ta| and 2 shekels oil; 
u4 asz-a ur5-gin7 szu ha-ba-an-ti| one received this per one day.
sza3 ma-da-ga2-ka i-{d}utu he2-eb2-ta-zi| Throughout my country I removed complaints.
sag-ki zalag sza3 hul2-la-ga2-ka| With my shining brow and happiness of heart 
kin-bi asil-la2 ul4-le-esz he2-em-mi-til| this work I joyfully and quickly finished.  
gesztu2 dagal nam-ku3-zu-mu-sze3 gal-bi hu-mu-du3| With my wide intelligence and wisdom I built it grandly. 
bad3-bi {d}nanna suhusz ma-da ge-en-ge-en| That wall Nanna Makes Firm the Foundation of the Country  
mu-sze3 he2-em-mi-sa4| I named. 
nig2 ak-mu-sze3| For my deed, 
{d}nanna lugal-mu hu-mu-hul2-le-en| O Nanna my master, may you rejoice over me,  
u4 sza3 hul2-la bala nam-he2-a| and may days of happiness, a reign of abundance, 
ti nig2 du10 mu he2-gal2-la-ka| a good life, years of plenty,
{gesz}gu-za suhusz gi-na| and a throne with a secure foundation  
sag-e-esz ha-ma-ab-rig7-ge| be presented to me. 
{d}dingir-mar-tu| To Dingir-Mardu, 
dingir-a-ni-ir| his god, 
nam-ti| for the life 
ARAD2-{d}suen| of Warad-Sîn 
lugal larsa{ki}-ma| the king of Larsa, 
al-la-ra-pi| Alla-rapi, 
(x) u2-KU-u2-a| son(?) of Uku'a, 
ARAD-da-a-ni-sze3| as(?) his servant,
a mu-na-ru| dedicated it (this object). 
u4 an {d}en-lil2-bi| When An and Enlil 
nun da-ri2 a-a dingir-re-e-ne| the eternal princes, the fathers of the gods, 
nam tar-tar-re-me-esz| they who decide the fates, 
{d}nanna dumu zi-le| to Nanna, the good son, 
ki-ag2 e2-kur-ra-ra| the beloved of the Ekur - 
u4-szu2-usz nam-sun5-na| who daily, in humility, 
szu-kin dab5-be2-da-ni-sze3| while prostrating himself  
igi-bi-a al-gub-ba| standing before them, 
ka ba-bi-sze3 gizzal im-szi-ak| heeds what they say
du11-ga-bi-sze3 mu-un-gur-e| and bows to their commands - 
gu3 hul2 mu-ni-in-de2-esz| they spoke to him happily. 
ad-gi4 an-ki-ka| The counsel of heaven and earth,  
umusz ka-asz-bar-re {d}a-nun-na| the good advice and divine decisions of the Anunna gods, 
szu-na bi2-in-gar-re-esz| they placed in his hands. 
uri2{ki} ki-sur-ra dingir-re-ne gar-ra-na| In his city Ur, the demarcated territory of the gods,  
bala sa6-ga su3-ra2-sze3 ak-de3| to exercise a good reign for the future, 
bara2-bi sukud il2-de3| to raise high its dais(es), 
kilib3 da-ga-an sag zi-gal2-la| and all the assembly of living beings 
gu2-un il2-i-de3| to make bear tribute
giri3-ne2 szu-ne2 ri-e-de3| and set it down at his feet and his hands, 
inim ku3 nig2 nu-kur2-ru-da-ne-ne| their holy word, which cannot be altered, 
gi-ne2-sze3 bi2-in-ne-esz-am3| they firmly spoke. 
u4-bi-a {d}asz-im2-babbar-re| At that time, Ašimbabbar, 
esz-bar-re gal-zu dumu {d}nin-lil2-la2-ke4| wise as to decisions, the son of Ninlil, 
igi an {d}en-lil2-bi-ta| who before An and Enlil 
sag il2-la ul-le-esz e3-da-ni| in beauty had come forth head held high, 
ma-da inim-a-ne2 te-en-te-ne| who soothes the land with his word, 
sag-ge6 zi-de3-esz bi2-in-e3-a| who has faithfully manifested it to the Black Headed People,  
ug3 szar2-ra-bi-sze3 arhusz bi2-in-tuku-am3| and has shown compassion to its numerous people, 
iri-ni uri5{ki}-ma ama sig{ig} kur-ra| in his city Ur, the weak(?) mother of the land, 
sag-ki zalag sza3 hul2-la-ni-ta| with his shining brow and happy heart
igi mu-un-na-szi-bar-re-en| he(?) looked at her(?),
sag-ni bi2-in-il2-la| and having raised his head  
mu mah bi2-in-tuku-am3| he made it acquire an exalted name. 
hur-sag a-ab-ba nam-he2-bi gu7-de3| Letting it have the use of the abundance of the sea and mountains 
me3 szen kalam-ma hub2-sa-ra ak-ke3-de3| and (as well) making it rush into war and battle in the nation,   
sag-e-esz im-mi-in-rig7| he gave it as a gift.
sipa-gin7 zi-gal2 tum2-tum2-e-de3| To provide refuge for the living, 
ma-da-bi-im szu-a gi4-gi4-de3| to return what was their land to their control, 
sza3-be2 a ga2-ga2-de3 u4-bi su3-su3-u5-de3| to establish water therein, and (so) to prolong their lives 
inim sikil-be2 bi2-in-tum3| by their word they brought him to do this. 
nam-bi-sze3 ARAD-{d}suen| For this, Warad-Sîn, 
gal-zu gesztu2 tuku-tuku nig2-gi-na ki-ag2-me-en| me, the wise one possessing intelligence, who loves what is right, 
sza3 ama-ugu-mu-ta ku3-ge-esz gun3-a-me-en| me who was colored(?) in sacred fashion from the very womb of my mother, 
nam-sipa kalam-ma-na mu-un-gar-re-en| he (Nanna) placed me in the position of shepherd in his land. 
nam-si-sa2-ga2 gidri ma-an-szum2| For my rectitude he gave me the scepter, 
bala hul2-la szu zi ma-ni-in-gar| bestowed upon me a happy reign, 
ni-szi3 lu-lu-a-ni inim-mu-sze3 ma-ni-in-dur2| and made his numerous people dwell under my command.  
e2-temen-ni2-gur3-ru gibil-gibil-de3| To renovate the Etemenniguru temple, 
ur3 esz3 e2-babbar gur-re-de3| to thicken the base(?) of the shrine Ebabbar, 
iri{ki} dingir ma-da-be2-e*-ne du3-u3-de3| to rebuild the cities of the gods of the land, 
gesz-hur libir sukud ili2-de3| to raise high the old divine plans, 
szu-luh ha-lam-ma-bi ki-be2 gi4-gi4-de3| to restore their forgotten lustration rites,
{d}nanna en me an-ki szu du7| Nanna, the lord who perfects the divine attributes of heaen and earth, 
nam ni2-tuku-mu-sze3 a2-bi hu-mu-da-ki-ag2| because of my reverence he ordered me to do this. 
ad-gi4-a-mu ki-bi-sze3 nig2 sag-bi-sze3 e3-a| My counsel for that(?) is a superior thing,  
en3-tar galam-ma-mu nig2 sag2 nu-di-dam| my skillful care is a thing that cannot be disrupted. 
a-ra2 nam-lugal-la-ga2 ug3-ga2 zu-zu-de3| About lettiing my people know the ways of my kingship 
nam-gal nam-mah-ga2 u4 da-ri2-sze3 gal2-le-de3| about making my greatness and majesty exist forever, 
uri5{ki} dagal-e-de3| about widening Ur,   
ki-sa2-a-bi szu pesz11-e-de3| expanding its platform,
diri nig2 u4-bi-ta-ka| and greater than previously  
ki-gar-bi gu-ul-lu-de3| enlarging its grounds,  
en3 u3-bi2-tar egir-a-ni bi2-zukum| after I had inquired about these (things), I trod after him 
sun5-na-bi u3-gul2 mu-na-ni-in-gar| and humbly I addressed pleas to him.
{d}nanna lugal-mu mu-szi-in-sze| Nanna, my master, was agreeable to me. 
nam-ti-mu-sze3 u nam-ti| For my life and the life 
ku-du-ur-ma-bu-uk a-a tu-da-ga2-ke4| of Kudur-mabuk, the father who begot me - 
iri kur nam-ti-la ki he2-gal2-la-ka| the city, the mountain of life and place of abundance, 
ki-tusz kilib3-gal2 dingir-re-e-ne-ke4| the residence and assembly (place) of the gods, 
nam-bi mu-un-tar-re-sza| whose destiny they (the gods) having decided, 
mu-ni-gin7 diri-ga| whose name is surpassing, 
sag an-e us2-sa| with top reaching the heavens, 
a2-bi szu-ta kin en3-tar gar-ra| whose arms seek with the hands the put inquiries, 
an-dul3 dagal-la-ni kur kalam-ma dul| whose wide shadow covers foreign land as well as the nation, 
ur2 du10-ga-ni-ta ug3 sag-ge6-ga| from whose good base the Black Headed People 
mu-un-lu2-lu2 nam-ti kar-kar-re-mesz| he has multiplied, those who betake their lives (there) -
bad3-bi du3-u3-de3 szu-ga2 im-mi-gar| the building of its wall he placed in my hands.  
muru4-ba iti 5(disz)-am3 ba-ra-ab-zal| In the middle of that, five months had not elapsed 
szeg12-bi hu-mu-du8| when I had baked its bricks.
bad3 gal-bi hu-mu-til| I finished that great wall 
bad3-si-bi hu-mu-il2| and raised up its parapets. 
hur-sag sig7-ga-gin7 ki sikil-la he2-bi2-mu2| Like a verdant mountain range I made it grow on a pure place. 
sukud-ra2-bi he2-bi2-diri su-lim he2-bi2-du8-du8| Its height I made surpassing and set free its awesome radiance. 
mu nam-mah-bi-gin7 sag-bi hu-mu-ni-in-il2| Commensurate with its name and greatness I raised up its top. 
u6-di kalam-ma-sze3| As a marvel of the nation 
pa gal-le-esz he2-bi2-in-e3| I made it grandly resplendent.  
uru4-ba temen nam-lugal-la-ga2| In its foundations, for the foundation documents of my kingship 
ki he2-em-ma-ni-in-pa3| I sought out the place. 
abul-la-ba sag he2-bi2-il2| I raised the top of its main gate. 
eg2{eg} sur-ra-ba hu-mu-kal| I strengthened its demarcating levee, 
szeg12-bi hu-mu-da| circled it with bricks, 
hi-ri2-tum-bi hu-mu-ba-al| and dug its moat. 
u4 bad3 uri5{ki}-ma| When the wall of Ur 
mu-du3-a| I built, 
a2 lu2 1(disz)-e 3(ban3) sze-ta| the wages for one man were: 3 ban barley, 
2(disz) sila3 ninda-ta 2(disz) sila3 kasz-ta 2(disz) gin2 i3-gesz-ta| 2 sila bread, 2 sila beer, 2 shekels oil, 
u4 asz-a ur5-gin7 szu ha-ba-an-ti| in one day a man received thus. 
sza3 ma-da-ga2-ka| From the midst of my land 
i-{d}utu he2-eb2-ta-zi| I removed (cause for) complaint. 
sag-ki zalag sza3 hul2-la-ga2-ka| With my shining brow and happy heart 
kin-bi asil-la2-a ul4-le-de3-esz he2-em-mi-til| I finished this work quickly and joyfully. 
gesztu2 dagal nam-ku3-zu-mu-ta gal-bi he2-em-mi-kin| With my wide intelligence and wisdom I did the work in grand fashion. 
bad3-ba {d}nanna suhusz ma-da ge-en-ge-en| That wall: Nanna Makes Firm the Foundations of the Land 
mu-sze3 he2-em-mi-sa4| I named it.
nig2 ak-mu-sze3 {d}nanna lugal-mu hu-mu-hul2-le-en| For my deeds, O Nanna my master, may you rejoice over me,  
u4 sza3 hul2-la bala nam-he2-a| and may days of happiness, a reign of abundance, 
nam nu-kam2-me mu he2-gal2-la-ka| a fate which cannot be overturned(?), years of plenty, 
gesz-szub ti nig2 du10 ha-la nam-lugal-la| a good life as (my) lot and kingship as (my) portion, 
sag-e-esz ha-ma-ab-rig7-ge| be presented to me.
nam-sipa-mu nibru{ki}-a uri5{ki} larsa{ki}-bi| May my shepherdship in Nippur, Ur, and Larsa
su3-ud-sze3 nam-ba-kur2-ru| never ever be altered. 
nun ki-ag2 {d}nanna {d}nin-gal-bi he2-em| May I be the prince beloved of Nanna and Ningal. 
u4-mu he2-su3-su3-ud| May my days be long. 
{d}nin-isin2{si}-na| For Nininsina, 
nin gal ama kalam-ma| the great lady, the mother of the nation, 
zi-gal2 kalam dim2-dim2-me| who creates the living things of the nation, 
dumu-sag an ku3-ga| first-born child of holy An, 
nin-a-ni-ir| his mistress - 
ARAD2-{d}suen| Warad-Sîn, 
nita kal-ga| the mighty man, 
u2-a uri5{ki}-ma| provider of Ur, 
lugal larsa{ki}-ma| king of Larsa 
lugal ki-en-gi ki-uri| and king of Sumer and Akkad, 
sipa nig2-gi gesz-hur szu du7-du7-me-en| shepherd who perfects justice and the divine plans, 
e2 u2 nam-ti-la| the Plant of Life temple, 
unu2 ku3-ga| the sacred dining hall, 
ki ni2 dub2-bu-da-ni| her place of relaxation -
e2-a-ni nig2 u4 ul-li2-a-ta| her temple which in a past time 
ba-du3-a-ba ba-sumun| had been built and had grown old - 
nam-ti-mu-sze3| for his life
u3 nam-ti| and the life 
ku-du-ur-ma-bu-uk| of Kudur-mabuk 
a-a ugu-ga2-ke4| the father who begot him, 
hu-mu-na-du3| he rebuilt for her 
ki-be2 he2-em-mi-gi4| and restored for her. 
ki-tusz sza3 du10-ga-na| In her residence that gladdens the heart 
gal-le-esz he2-em-mi-tusz| I caused her to dwell in grand fashion, 
mu nam-lugal-la-ga2| and my royal name 
du-ri2-sze3 he2-em-mi-gal2| I put there everlastingly. 
egir u4-da-asz| For ever after today 
ar2-mu ak-ke3-de3| to do the praising of me, 
temen ar2 nam-nun-na-ga2| foundation documents in praise of my princeliness 
uru4-be2 ki he2-bi2-tum2| I buried into its foundation, 
e2-gar8 sikil-bi he2-bi2-si| and a pure brick wall for it I placed upon it. 
nig2 ak-mu-sze3| For my deeds, 
{d}nin-isin2{si}-na| O Nininsina 
nin-mu hu-mu-hul2-le-en| my mistress, may you rejoice over me. 
nam-tar nam-ti-la| May a fate of life, 
bala su3-ud mu he2-gal2-la| a long reign, years of abundance, 
{gesz}gu-za suhusz gi-ne2| and a throne with a secure foundation 
sag-e-esz ha-ma-ab-rig7-ge| be presented to me.
esz3 larsa{ki}-ma-ka| In the shrine of Larsa, 
iri ba-dim2-me-na-ga2| the city where I was created,  
u4-mu he-su3-su3-ud| may my days be long.
{d}nergal| For Nergal, 
en ir9 kur a2-gal2| mighty lord of the netherworld, strong one, 
dumu-sag {d}en-lil2-la2| first-born son of Enlil, 
lugal-mu-ur2| my master, 
ARAD2-{d}suen| I, Warad-Sîn, 
sag-en3-tar e2-babbar-ra| who takes care of the Ebabbar temple, 
u2-a uri5{ki}-ma| provier of Ur, 
{d}en-lil2-le gar-ra| put in place by Enlil, 
{d}nanna {d}utu-be2 ki-ag2| beloved by Nanna and Utu, 
lugal larsa{ki}-ma| king of Larsa 
lugal ki-en-gi ki-uri| and king of Sumer and Akkad, 
dumu ku-du-ur-ma-bu-uk| son of Kudur-mabuk 
ad-da e-mu-ut-ba-la| and father of Emutbala, 
lu2 szu gar e2-babbar-ra-ke4| a man who a favor for the Ebabbar
bi2-in-gi4-a| did repay, 
sun5-sun5-na dingir gal-gal-e-ne-er| who most humbly before the great gods 
zi ti-le-ni-sze3 gub-ba-me-en| stands serving for his life's sake, 
{d}nergal| (for) Nergal, 
a2-dah {gesz}tukul-la-ga2| the helper of my weapon, 
nam-ga-me-esz3 ak-da-ga2| in my having established a colleague status (with him), 
e2 libir-ra-ka-ni| his old temple  
e2 ku3-ga ki-tusz sza3 du10-ga-na| the sacred temple and residence which gladdens his heart, 
nam-ti-mu-sze3| for my life 
u3 nam-ti| and the life 
ku-du-ur-ma-bu-uk| of Kudur-mabuk,  
a-a ugu-ga2-sze3| the father who begot me, 
mu-na-du3| I built for him. 
hur-sag su3-ra2-gin7| like a distant mountain range 
u6-di ug3 szar2-ra-ba he2-bi2-gub| I made it stand as a marvel to the numerous people. 
nig2 ak-ak-da-ga2| For the things I have done 
{d}nergal dingir-mu| may Nergal my god 
hu-mu-hul2-le| rejoice over me. 
nam-tar nam-ti-la| A fate of life, 
bala su3-ra2| a long reign, 
{gesz}gu-za gi-na| and a secure throne 
sag-e-esz ha-ma-ab-rig7| may he present to me. 
{d}za-ba4-ba4| For Zababa, 
en ur-sag gal| lord, great hero, 
dumu mah {d}en-lil2-la2| exalted son of Enlil, 
dingir ir9 igi szen-szen-na du| mighty god who goes in the van of battle, 
a2-dah {gesz}tukul-la-ka-ni-ir| his helper of weapons, 
ARAD2-{d}suen| Warad-Sîn, 
u2-a uri5{ki}-ma| provider of Ur, 
lugal larsa{ki}-ma| king of Larsa 
lugal ki-en-gi ki-uri| and king of Sumer and Akkad, 
dumu ku-du-ur-ma-bu-uk| son of Kudur-mabuk 
ad-da e-mu-ut-ba-la| and father of Emutbala, 
sipa nig2-si-sa2| shepherd of justice 
ug3 dagal-la-na| who made the wide peoples 
u2-sal bi2-in-nu2-a| lie down in fine meadows - 
mu ki szu-il2-la-ga2| because in my place of Raised Hand prayers 
mu-un-us2-en| you stood by me, 
erim2-gal2-ga2| and my enemies 
szu-mu-usz bi2-in-si-a| you put fully into my hands, 
ur5-sze3-am3| therefore 
{d}za-ba4-ba4| for Zababa, 
en geszkim sa6-ga-ga2| the lord of my favorable signs, 
nam-ga-me-esz3 ak-da-ga2| whereas I had established a colleague status (with him), 
e2-a-ni| his temple 
sza3 uri5{ki}-ma| in Ur 
nam-ti-mu-sze3| for my life 
hu-mu-na-du3| I did indeed build for him. 
e2-ba| That house,
e2-ki-tusz-sza3-te-en-bi| Temple - Residence that Cools the Heart
mu-bi he2-em-mi-sa4| I named it.
{d}nanna| For Nanna, 
lugal-a-ni-ir| his master, 
ARAD2-{d}suen| Warad-Sîn, 
u2-a uri5{ki}-ma| provider of Ur, 
e2-babbar-da ni2 tuku| who reveres the Ebabbar temple, 
lugal larsa{ki}-ma| king of Larsa, 
u4 {d}nanna| when Nanna 
{d}nin-gal-bi| and Ningal 
sza3-ne mu-un-ne-sza4-asz| I implored, 
ki szu-il2-la-ga2| in my place of Raised Hand prayer 
mu-un-us2-en| you stood by me: 
i7 {d}nanna-hul2| that the Nanna Rejoices canal 
mu-ba-al-la-a| I shall dig 
ki-be2 bi2-in-gi4-a| and restore. 
{d}nin-gublaga| For Ningublaga, 
igi-gal2 szen-szen-na| wise in battle,  
{d}lamma e2-kisz-nu-gal2| guardian angel of the Ekišnugal 
sza3 uri5{ki}-ma| in Ur, 
a2-dah nam-lugal-la-ka-ni-ir| his helper in kingship - 
ARAD2-{d}suen| I, Warad-Sîn, 
nita kal-ga| the mighty man, 
u2-a uri5{ki}-ma| provider of Ur, 
lugal larsa{ki}-ma| king of Larsa 
lugal ki-en-gi ki-uri| and king of Sumer and Akkad,
dumu ku-du-ur-ma-bu-uk| son of Kudur-mabuk 
ad-da e-mu-ut-ba-la-me-en| and father of Emutbala, 
u4 {d}nin-gublaga lugal-mu| when Ningublaga my master 
a2-ag2-ga2-ni in-de6-a| had brought his instructions:  
lu2-kur2-ra-ga2 mu-un-gur2-en| that I shall make the people who are hostile to me submit to me 
lugal gu2-du3-a-ga2 inim-ga2 bi2-in-tusz-a| and settle the kings who hated me under my command, 
nam-bi-sze3| because of this, 
inim sa6-sa6-ge-da-ga2| while I was making beautiful words (of prayer),  
e2-ga2-bur-ra| the Egabura temple,  
tur3 i3 gara2 kur he2-gal2-la| with cattle pens for butterfat and cheese, a mountain of abundance, 
unu2 ku3-ga nig2-dab5 dingir-ra-na| his sacred dining hall with things required for a deity,  
a kilib-ba hu-mu-du3| and with all kinds of water, I built 
ki-be2 he2-em-mi-gi4| and restored. 
nam-gal nam-lugal-la-ga2| The greatness of my kingship 
kalam-ma igi he2-bi2-in-du8| I let be seen throughout the nation, 
mu mah-ga2| and my great name
du-ri2-sze3 he2-em-mi-gar| I established there forever.
{d}inanna| For Inanna, 
nin ni2 gal gur3-ru| clad in great fearsomeness, 
me szar2-ra tab-ba| who clasps myriad divine powers, 
dumu gal {d}suen-na| great child of Suen, 
nin-a-ni-ir| his mistress, 
ARAD2-{d}suen| I, Warad-Sîn, 
nun sze-ga nibru{ki}| the obedient prince of Nippur, 
u2-a uri5{ki}-ma| provider of Ur, 
sag-en3-tar gir2-su{ki}| who tends to Girsu 
ki-lagasz{ki}-a| and the whole state of Lagaš,
e2-babbar-da ni2 te-ge26| who reveres the Ebabbar, 
lugal larsa{ki}-ma| the king of Larsa 
lugal ki-en-gi ki-uri| and king of Sumer and Akkad, 
szul a2-ag2-ga2 kin-kin| the youth who seeks out the (divine) instructions
gesz-hur szu du7-du7| and perfects the divine plans, 
e2 dingir-re-e-ne| who the temples of the gods
szu gibil bi2-in-ak| renovated 
{uruda}alan gal-gal| and who who great statues 
mu pa3-da nam-lugal-la-ka-na| that demonstrate his kingship  
gal-bi bi2-in-su8-ga| did erect in grand fshion, 
iri szub-szub-ba-bi| who its dilapidated cities 
bad3-bi mu-du3-a| and its walls rebuilt, 
ma-da dagal-a-na| by whom the ones of his wide land 
e2 ne-ha bi2-in-tusz-a| were made to dwell in peaceful houses, 
erin2 szu-a gi4-gi4-me-en| who returned the troops to (my) control - 
gesztu2 dagal| the wide wisdom 
kin da-ri2 dim2-me-de3| to fashion eternal works, 
{d}en-ki-ke4 ma-an-szum2-ma| having been given to me by the god Enki, 
nam-bi-sze3 {d}inanna nin-ga2| therefore, in order that Inanna my mistress, 
inim sa6-sa6-ge-da-ga2| as I was making beautiful words, 
e2-tilmun-na| the Dilmun Temple, 
ki-tusz ni2 dub2-bu| her relaxing residence  
sza3 hul2-la-ka-ni| of happiness 
igi du8-u3-de3| might experience, 
sza3-be2 asila si| whose interior is full of jubilation - 
diri u4-bi-da-ke4| when more than before 
e2-szu-si3-ga-bi| its Ešusiga
u3-mu-dagal| I had widened, 
u4 ul-sze3| for far future days  
nam-ti-mu-sze3 hu-mu-du3| for my life I built it 
sag-bi mu-ni-il2| and raised up its top 
hur-sag-gin7 hu-mu-mu2| and made it grow forth like a mountain range. 
nig2 ak-ak-da-ga2 ne-e-sze3| For these things that I have done 
{d}inanna nin-mu| may Inanna my mistress 
ha-ma-szi-hul2| rejoice over me.

asz-te suhusz gi-na| a throne with a secure foundation,  
gidri ug3 gur2-gur2| and a scepter which makes the people bow down  
sag-e-esz ha-ma-ni-in-rig7| may she present to me.

lugal larsa{ki}-ma| king of Larsa

ARAD2-{d}suen| Warad-Sîn,

dumu ku-du-ur-ma-bu-uk| son of Kudur-mabuk,

a mu-na-ru| dedicated it (this eyestone).
me-dim2 s,i-li2-esz4-dar| Bodily features of Şillī-Eštar, 
lu2 masz-kan2-szabra{ki}| the Man of Maškan-šapir, 
lu2-erim2 larsa{ki}-ma| enemy of Larsa, 
hul-gal2 e-mu-ut-ba-lum{ki}-sze3| who harbors evil against Emutbala, 
igi {d}nanna {d}utu-bi-ir| whom in front of Nanna and Utu

ku-du-ur-ma-bu-uk(BI)| (and also of) Kudur-mabuk, 
lugal lu2 mu-ni-in-sa6-ga-ni| the king who to the man who has been good to him

du11-ga mah {d}en-lil2 {d}nin-urta| who by the command of Enlil, Ninurta, 
{d}nanna {d}utu-bi| Nanna, and Utu,

giri3 (x) bi2-in-gub-ba| and placed his feet upon it/them, 
rab sze29-a-bi| (also) the neck stock of a captive,

e2 {d}nin-lil2-la2-ka| the temple of Ninlil, 
du10 bad-ra2-a-ni-ta| (he striding) with his knees opened,  
sag*-ra gir3 us2-sa| a foot planted on the head.

{d}iszkur| For Iškur,  
en ur-sag dumu an-na| lord, hero, son of An, 
su-zi mah ri-a| clad in an exalted awesome radiance, 
te-esz du11-ga-ni-ta| who by using his voice   
dungu-SILA ka kesz2-re| gathers the thick(!) clouds 
ubur utah-he tak4 la2| and opens the teat of heaven, 
ki-szar2-ra ma-dam he2-gal2 szar2-re| who multiplies everywhere plentiful yields and abundance,

sag-e-esz he2-en-na-rig7| may he present to him.
{d}inanna nin gu2-sag| For Inanna, the mistress of everything, 
me kilib3-ba du10 gal2| who makes good(?) all the divine powers,

{d}nergal en mah| For Nergal, the exalted lord  
usu gal tuku| who possesses great strength,  
ni2 me-lam2 szu du7| adorned with fearsomeness and divine radiance, 
sag-kal kur gu2-erim2 su hul di| foremost one who exerts a ruinous hand against hostile foreign lands, 
ki-bala zar-re-esz du8| heaping up rebel lands into stacks, 
dingir-ra-ni-ir| his god, 
ri-im-{d}suen| Rīm-Sîn, 
nun ni2-tuku nibru{ki}| the prince who reveres Nippur,

u3 nam-ti| and the life

{d}nergal| Nergal,
dingir sag du-ga-na| the god who engendered him, 
igi zalag u3-mu-un-szi-in-bar| having directed his shining eye at him,   
ki me3-ka| on the battleground
a2 zi-da-na| (with) his steadfast arm   
he2-en-da-ab-ri| may he press down together with him,    
kur nig2 bala-a-na| and the foreign land that rebels against him   
szu-ni sa2 he2-eb2-be2| may he let him conquer. 
{d}en-ki| For Enki, 
en nam gal tar-tar-re| the lord who determines the great destinies, 
a2 kilib3-ba ag2-e| who issues all the instructions, 
gal-zu en sa2-gar| the all-knowing one, lord, counselor
dingir gal-gal-e-ne-er| of the great gods, 
umusz galga szum2-mu| who provides good counsel and understanding,  
nun gal du11-ga-ni nu-kam3-me-dam| great prince whose pronouncements cannot be altered, 
inim-ma-ni u18-ru| whose word is powerful, 
he2-gal2 szar2-re| who multiplies abundance, 
ug3-e asilax(EZEMxX) si-si| who fills the people with joy 
zi-gal2-la-asz ha-la szum2-mu| and apportions the shares to living beings,  
lugal-a-ni-ir| his master - 
ri-im-{d}suen| Rīm-Sîn, 
nun ni2-tuku nibru{ki}| the prince who reveres Nippur,  
u2-a uri2{ki}-ma| provider of Ur, 
sag-en3-tar| who cares for  
gir2-su{ki} ki-lagasz{ki}-a| Girsu and the whole area of Lagaš, 
me gesz-hur eridu{ki}-ga szu du7-du7| who makes perfect the divine powers and plans of Eridu, 
e2-babbar-da ni2-te-ge26| who shows fear of the Ebabbar, 
lugal larsa{ki}-ma| king of Larsa 
lugal ki-en-gi ki-uri| and king of Sumer and Akkad, 
lu2 e2 dingir-re-e-ne szu gibil bi2-in-ak| the man who renovated the temples of the gods, 
gesz-hur szu-luh gal-bi szu im-mi-in-du7-a| who, having correctly performed their great divine plans and lustration rites, 
nam-szita a-ra-zu-e u4-szu2-usz-e gub-ba| daily stands serving at the šita and arazu prayers - 
e2-gesztu2-szu-du7| the Temple Which Perfects Understanding, 
ki-tusz ki-ag2-ga2-ni| his beloved residence, 
mu-na-du3| he built for him.
diri u4-bi-ta-sze3| More than previously 
e2-szu-se3-ga-bi mu-dagal| he expanded the Ešusega house,
sag-bi im-mi-in-il2| raised up its top,
hur-sag-gin7 bi2-in-mu2| and made it grow like a mountain range. 
sag-en3-tar| one who tends to 
gir2-su{ki}| Girsu 
ki-lagasz{ki}-a| and the area of Lagaš, 
me gesz-hur eridu{ki}-ga szu du7-du7| who makes perfect the divine powers and plans of Eridu, 
e2-babbar-da ni te-ge26| who shows fear of the Ebabbar, 
lugal larsa{ki}-ma| the king of Larsa 
lugal ki-en-gi ki-uri-ke4| and king of Sumer and Akkad, 
e2-i3-ra2-ra2| the House of the Perfumers 
ir-si-im-bi du10-ga-am3| whose scent is sweet, 
gesz hi-a-bi pesz-pesz| whose various (aromatic) woods are (piled) thick, 
mu-na-du3| he built for him (the deity). 
{d}nin-szubur| For Ninšubur, 
nin sukkal zi an-na| the lady, the trusty messenger of An, 
me ku3-ga szu du7| who perfects the holy divine powers, 
sag il2 igi-sze3 du dingir-re-e-ne| the one who proudly goes at the fore of the gods,  
a2-ag2-ga2 szum2-mu gal-zu| who gives the instructions, all-knowing, 
sza3 kusz2 sza3 du10-du10 {d}inanna| who counsels and pleases the heart of Inanna, 
nam-szita-e ki-ag2| who loves prayer, 
nin-a-ni-ir| his mistress, 
ri-im-{d}suen| Rīm-Sîn, 
nita kal-ga| the mighty man, 
sipa inim sa6-sa6-ge nibru{ki}| the shepherd who makes beautiful words to Nippur, 
u2-a uri5{ki}-ma| provider of Ur, 
e2-babbar-da ni2 te-ge26| who shows fear of the Ebabbar, 
me eridu{ki}-ga szu du7-du7| who constantly makes perfect the divine powers of Eridu, 
sag-en3-tar gir2-su{ki} ki-lagasz{ki}-a| tho tends to Girsu and the whole area of Lagaš. 
lu2 e2 dingir-re-e-ne szu gibil bi2-in-ak| the man who renovated the temples of the gods, 
lugal larsa{ki}-ma| the king of Larsa

ka2-dingir-ra{ki}| Babylon, 
ra-pi2-qum{ki}| Rapiqum, 
su-ti-um{ki}-be2| and Sutium 
{gesz}tukul in-sag3-ga| he struck with weapons, 
me3-ba| in that battle,  
ARAD-ne-ne lugal unu{ki}-ga in-dab5-ba| when he had seized ARADnene, king of Uruk, 
musz-gin7 sag-ga2-ne2| and, as with a snake, upon his head 
giri3-ni in-us2-sa| he had laid his foot, 
u4-ba e2-nin-be2-tum2| then the Temple Fitting for Its Mistress,  
ki-tusz ki-ag2-ga2-ni| her beloved temple,

iri didli ma-da unu{ki}-ga| and the various cities of the land of Uruk 
mu-na-an-szum2-ma-a| had given to him,
{gesz}tukul kal-ga {d}nin-urta| by means of the mighty weapon of Ninurta, 
a2 zi-da du-na-ta| the one that goes at his right side,

nam-nir-gal2 {d}nergal| and by means of the authority of Nergal,  
dingir sag du-ga-na-ta| the god who begot him,

{d}nin-lil2 nin-a-ne2| Ninlil, his mistress, 
inim sa6-sa6-ge-da-ne2| at his making words beautiful, 
szu12-da-a-ne2 gesz in-ni-in-tuku-am3| listened to his prayers
szu-il2-la-a-ni in-szi-in-sze-ga-am3| and was agreeable to his Raised Hand entreaties.

{d}nin-gesz-zi-da| For Ningšzida, 
ur-sag i-szi ni2 di sag-ki-bi sur2 hu-hu-ul| hero with a radiance which inspires fear, whose brow destroys(?) in rage,

lugal-mu-ra| my master, 
{d}ri-im-{d}suen| I, Rīm-Sîn, 
nita kal-ga| the mighty man,

{gesz}tukul mu-sag3-ga| I struck with weapons,

inim an lugal dingir-re-e-ne-ta| through the word of An the king of the gods, 
du11-ga mah {d}en-lil2 lugal-ga2-ta| through the exalted utterance of Enlil my master, 
{d}nin-lil2 nin-ga2-ta| through Ninlil my mistress,

{d}nin-hur-sag du10 ki si-ig-ge4-ga2-ta| through Ninhursag, the one who puts goodness on the earth, 
geszkim sa6-ga {d}nanna-ta| through the favorable (lunar) signs of Nanna, 
nam-nir-gal2 {d}utu lugal-ga2-ta| through the authority of Utu my master, 
a2-ag2-ga2 sa6-ga {d}iszkur-ta| through the positive instructions of Iškur, 
usu {d}nergal dingir sag du-ga2-ta| through the power of Nergal, the god who begot me, 
{d}inanna nin me3-ga2-ta| through Inanna, the mistress of my battles, 
{d}nin-isin2{si}-in nin a2-ga2-ta| through Nininsina, the mistress of my military forces, 
{d}nin-szen-szen-na ma-zalag-ga2-ta| through Ninšenšena my one who shines for me -  
iri didli ma-da unu{ki}-ga mu-si3-si3-ga| when the various cities of the land of Uruk I had struck down, 
nam-ra-ak nig2-GA a-na gal2-la-bi| and the booty and property, however much it was, 
larsa{ki}-sze3| to Larsa 
im-mi-ku4-ra| I had brought in, 
u4-ba {d}nin-gesz-zi-da| at that time, to Ningišzida 
lugal-mu-ra| my master 
inim sa6-sa6-ge4-da-mu-ne| while I was making beautiful words (of prayer) 
e2-nig2-gi-na| the Temple of Righteousness, 
ki-tusz ki-ag2-ga2-ni| his beloved residence,

hur-sag-gin7 mu-na-mu2| and made it grow up like a mountain range. 
{d}nanna| For Nanna, 
en gal me-lam2-ma sag il2| the great lord who raises his head in an aura of fearsome splendor 
an-ki-a pa e3| and appears resplendently in heaven and earth, 
su-lim dagal sze-er-zi-bi mu2-mu2| who makes grow broad awesome brilliance and radiance 
ug3 szar2-ra-asz u4 ga2-ga2| and generates light for the numerous peoples, 
nun u18-ru me-ni a-re-esz kal| powerful prince whose divine powers are praiseworthy and mighty,  
nig2-nam-ma-ni ku3-ku3-ug| everything of whom is most holy, 
dumu zi-le kur-gal {d}en-lil2-le| best son of Great Mountain Enlil, 
nun ki-ag2 e2-kur-ra| prince beloved by the Ekur temple,

szutumx(E2.GI.NA.AB.TUM) ku3 {d}nanna| the holy storehouse of Nanna,

{d}nin-szubur| For Ninšubur, 
en gal me kilib3-ba ag2-e| great lord who measures out all the divine powers,

dingir gal-gal-e-ne| the great gods, 
unu{ki} iri ul| Uruk, the ancient city, 
szu-mu-sze3 ma-ni-in-si-esz-a| they put into my hand, 
{d}nin-subur lugal-mu-ur2| for Ninšubur my master, 
inim sa6-sa6-ge-da-mu-ta| through my making fine words (of prayer),
