{d}nin-szubur| For Ninšubur, 
en gal umusz galga za3 il2| great lord, who bears complete(?) discernment and understanding, 
inim zi du11-ga-ni nu-kam3-me| whose righteous words cannot be changed,  
sukkal-mah u3-luh gi4-rin szu du7| the chief minister who holds(?) the flowered scepter,  
a2-ag2-ga2 an-ki-a si sa2-e| who guides straight the instructions of heaven and earth 
ba-an-gi4 szum2-mu dingir gal-gal-e-ne-er| and gives responses to all the great gods,  
a-ra-zu-e gesz tuku| who listens to prayer, 
lugal-mu-ra| my master - 
{d}ri-im-{d}suen nita kal-ga| Rīm-Sîn,
szul gesz tuku kur-gal-la| the youth who heeds the Great Mountain (Enlil),  
sipa gu2-un kar2 nibru{ki}| shepherd who makes sparkle(?) the tribute/taxes of Nippur, 
me gesz-hur szu du7 eridu{ki}-ga| who makes perfect the divine powers and plans of Eridu, 
engar zi u2-a uri2{ki}-ma| the faithful farmer and provider of Ur, 
e2-babbar-da ni2 te-ge26| who shows fear of the Ebabbar, 
sag-en3-tar gir2-su{ki} ki-lagasz{ki}| who tends to Girsu and the whole area of Lagaš, 
inim sa6-sa6-ge-bi mah-a| whose finely wrought words (of prayer) are lofty, 
e2-babbar gal-gal-la-e| who makes the Ebabbar very great, 
nidba nu-szilig-ge| who makes unceasing the food offerings 
{d}lugal-gu2-du8-a-sze3| to Lugalgudua 
sa2-du11 lah5 e2-an-na-sze3| and brings regular offerings to the Eanna (in Uruk), 
lugal larsa{ki}-ma| the king of Larsa 
lugal ki-en-gi ki-uri-me-en| and king of Sumer and Akkad - 
u4 an {d}en-lil2 {d}en-ki| when An, Enlil, Enki 
u3 dingir gal-gal-e-ne| and all the great gods 
unu{ki} iri ul| Uruk, the ancient city, 
szu-mu-sze3 bi2-in-si-esz-a| they put fully into my hands, 
nam-bi-sze3| for this, 
{d}nin-szubur lugal-mu-ra| for Ninšubur my master, 
nam-ga-me-esz3-ak-da-mu-ne| at my establishing colleagueship (with him), 
e2-me-kilib3-ba-sag-il2| the Temple Which Raises its Top Within All the Divine Powers, 
ki-tusz nam-dingir-bi-sze3 tum2-ma| the residence worthy of his divinity, 
nam-ti-mu-sze3| for my life 
mu-na-du3| I built. 
diri u4-bi-ta-sze3| More than previously 
e2-szu-si3-ga-bi mu-dagal| I widened its Ešusiga house, 
temen mu pa3-da nam-lugal-mu| and foundation documents showing my name and kingship, 
u4 ul-sze3 im-mi-gar| I put there for future days. 
en-an-e-du7| Enanedu, 
en ki-ag2 {d}inanna| the beloved en priestess of Inanna,  
dumu ku-du-ur-ma-bu-uk| daughter of Kudur-mabuk, 
gesztu2 {d}en-ki-ke4| to whom Enki wisdom 
mu-na-an-szum2-ma| did give, 
me e2-kisz-nu-gal2-ta mu-un-ur4-ur4| gathered up the divine powers from the Ekišnugal temple, 
iri e2-szu-{d}suen{ki}| the city Bīt-Šu-Sîn, 
iri im-gur-{d}gibil6{ki}| the city Imgur-Gibil, 
bad3{ki}| Dũrum, 
ki-sur-ra{ki}| Kisurra, 
unu{ki} lugal-ne-ne| and Uruk - their kings 
u3 ma-da ma-da-ne-ne| and all their lands -
szu-ne2 sa2 bi2-in-du11-ga| when he had conquered them, 
bad3-bi im-mi-in-si3| and he demolished their walls. 
nam-bi-sze3| Because of this, 
u4 an {d}en-lil2 {d}en-ki {d}nin-mah-bi| When An, Enlil, Enki, and Ninmah
igi zi mu-un-szi-bar-re-esz-a| directed a righteous eye towards me, 
larsa{ki} ki-ur3* ki-ag2-ga2-ne-ne| and when for Larsa, their beloved leveled place, 
nam-bi mu-un-tar-re-esz-a| they determined its destiny.  
inim nu-kur2-ru-ba-ne-ne-a u3-tu-bi bi2-ne2-esz-a| and with their unalterable word they commanded its creation, 
bala nam-he2 a nu-szilig-ge| and a reign of abundance with unceasing water 
sag-e-esz mu-un-rig7-ge*-esz| they presented to me. 
a da-ri2 ha-la kalam-ma-ka| Everlasting water as the portion of the nation, 
a {i7}idigna {i7}buranun-na-bi-da| water which the Tigris and Euphrates 
u4 ul-li2-a-ta mu-un-tum3-be2-esz-a| since ancient times had always brought forth
u4 na-me-ka a-bi nu-szilig-ge| and at no time ever ceases, 
masz-bi {i7}{d}ma-mi-szar-ra-at i7 he2-gal kalam-ma| half of it the Mamišarrat Canal, the canal of abundance of the nation,  
a-bi {i7}idigna {i7}buranun-na-bi-da| whose waters were from the Tigris and the Euphrates, 
u3-ba-e-ni-in-kar| when it had taken them away from there 
a-ab-ba-sze3 ha-ba-an-de2| it poured them into the Sea. 
en {d}nu-nam-nir-e du11-ga-ni sag ba-an-du| Lord Nunamnir, whose utterances create with great care, 
sipa sza3 du10-ga-na-ka-sze3 mu-un-szi-in-gur| turned towards the shepherd who pleased him 
gu3 hul2 u3-mu-un-de2 nam du10 mu-ni-in-tar| and, having spoken joyously, determined for him a good fate: 
i7 ba-al-e-de3 ki-en-gi ki-uri| (namely) to dig canals in order into Sumer and Akkad    
a he2-gal2-la tum3-u3-de3| to bring waters of abundance, 
a-gar3 gal-gal-be2 sze gu-nu mu2-mu2-de3| to make the speckled barley grow on its great agricultural tracts, 
pu2 {gesz}kiri6-bi x x lal3 gesztin du8-u3-de3| to make its irrigated orchards richly produce date syrup and grapes, 
ambar-bi ku6 muszen ul-e-esz gar-gar-e-de3| to make its marshes joyfully provide fish and birds,  
kur-gal {d}en-lil2-le a2 gal mu-da-an-ag2| Great Mountain Enlil issued the great orders.   
sipa ni2-tuku a2 {d}en-lil2 lugal-a-ni-sze3 i3-du-a-me-en| I who am the (god-)fearing shepherd who walks beside Enlil,  
{d}ri-im-{d}suen-me-en lu2 kur-gal {d}en-lil2-la2-ma-en| I, Rīm-Sîn, who am the man of Great Mountain Enlil,  
igi-gal2 tuku gesztu2 zi szu du7| one who possesses wisdom and perfects true intelligence, 
{d}ri-im-{d}suen sipa zi sag-ge6-ga-me-en| I, Rīm-Sîn, the faithful shepherd of the Blacked Headed (People),  
gesztu2 dagal {d}en-ki-ke4 ma-ni-in-szum2-ma-a| when the wide wisdom given to me by Enki  
u3-mu-ni-in-sa6 i7-da bal-e-de3| he improved(?) regarding it, to dig the canal 
sza3-mu he2-bi2-in-tum2| he inspired me. 
i7-bi za3 {i7}{d}ma-mi-szar2-ra-at i7 he2-gal2 kalam-ma-ka| that canal alongside the Mama-šarrat canal, the canal of abundance of the nation, 
ug3 szar2-ra nam-sipa-bi {d}en-lil2 ma-an-szum2-ma| When the numerous peoples whose shepherding Enlil gave to me 
sig-ta igi-nim-sze3 u3-mu-un-nigin| from below and above I had brought together, 
usu kal-ga-mu-ta hu-mu-un-kin| by my mighty strength I did the task.
e min-a-bi hur-sag-gin7 u3-mu-un-dim2 me-lam2 hu-mu-du8-du8| When I had built its two levees like a mountain range, I filled them up with divine radiance. 
ka-be2 a he2-gal2-la u3-bi2-ge-en| After I had secured abundant water at its intake,  
kun-bi hu-mu-un-su3-e| I continued extending its outlet. 
gu2-gu2-be2 u2-szim giri17-zal-a hu-me3-szar2-szar2| Upon its banks I multiplied luxuriant sweet-smelling grasses. 
i7-bi {i7}tug2-ma-at-{d}er3-ra| That canal - the Tuqmat-Erra Canal 
mu-bi he2-bi2-ib-sa4| they named it. 
a da-ri2 {i7}idigna {i7}buranun-na-bi-da| The everlasting waters of both the Tigris and the Euphrates  
hu-mu-ni-in-gi4| I restored.
{d}ri-im-{d}suen lugal larsa{ki}-ma| I, Rīm-Sîn, the king of Larsa 
lugal ki-en-gi ki-uri-me-en| and king of Sumer and Akkad, 
kalam dagal-la-mu suhusz-bi hu-mu-un-ge-en| I made secure the foundations of my wide country. 
iri a2-dam-bi ki-bi-sze3 he2-mi-in-gi4| I restored its cities and settlements. 
ug3 szar2-ra-mu-sze3 u2 gu7* a nag he2-bi2-in-gar| For my numerous people I established food to eat and water to drink. 
ki-en-gi ki-uri gu3 tesz2 u3-bi2-se3-ke| When I had unified harmoniously Sumer and Akkad, 
sza3 {d}en-lil2-la2 hu-mu-un-du10| I indeed pleased the heart of Enlil. 
nam-bi-sze3 an {d}en-lil2 {d}en-ki {d}nin-mah-bi| For this, may An, Enlil, Enki and Ninmah 
nam-ti u4 su3-ra2{ra} ga2-ra ha-ma-ni-in-szum2| give to me a long life,  
bala he2-gal2-la {gesz}gu-za suhusz gi-na| and a reign of abundance, a throne with a firm foundation 
sag-e-esz ha-ma-ab-rig7-e-ne| may they present to me. 
te-me-en mu pa3-da nam-lugal-ga2 a-ar2 u3-bi2-sar| When I have had foundation documents inscribed to praise my royal revealed name, 
u4 ul-li2-a-sze3 ug3 szar2-ra a-ar2 mu-un-ak-ak-ne| the numerous peoples will praise me forever. 
{d}nin-e2-gal| For Ninegal, 
nin gal me kilib3 szu-na dab5-be2| the great lady who holds all the divine powers in her hands,  
ug3 szar2-ra-asz igi-bi gal2| who sees the numerous peoples,  
na-de5 mah szita5-du3 sag-ge6| exalted counselor, overseer of the Black Headed (People) 
a-ra2-bi za3 nu-sa2| whose ways are unrivaled, 
nir-gal2 ukken-na du11-ga-ni igi-sze3 du| authoritative one of the assembly, whose utterance takes precedence, 
dingir zi ki a-a ugu-ni-ta| steadfast goddess from the father who engendered her, 
ka ba-ni sze-ga| whose speech is favorable,
dumu gal {d}suen-na| great daughter of Suen,  
nin-a-ni-ir| her mistress, 
si-ma-at-{d}inanna| Simat-Ištar, 
dam ki-ag2| beloved wife 
{d}ri-im-{d}suen| of Rīm-Sîn 
lugal larsa{ki}-ma| the king of Larsa,  
dumu-munus ARAD2-{d}nanna-ke4| daughter of Warad-Nanna - 
u4 {d}nin-e2-gal nin-a-ne2| when Ninegal her mistress 
mu sa6-ga-ni in-sa4-a| called her good name, 
e2-a2-ag2-ga2-kilib3-ur4-ur4| the Temple That Assembles All the Instructions, 
ki-tusz nam-dingir-bi-sze3 tum2-ma| the residence worthy of her divinity, 
nam-ti {d}ri-im-{d}suen| in order that the life of Rīm-Sîn 
u4 da-ri2-sze3 gal2-le-de3| might exist forever, 
u3 nam-ti-la-ni-sze3| and for her own life, 
mu-na-du3| she built.
diri u4-bi-ta-sze3| More than previously 
e2-szu-si3-ga-bi mu-un-dagal| she widened its Ešusiga house, 
temen mu pa3-da nam-nin-a-ka-na| and foundation documents revealing her queenly name 
u4 su3-ra2-sze3 im-mi-in-gar| she placed there for all future time.
{d}nin-e2-gal| For Ninegal, 
nin gal kilib3 sag-ge6 szar2-ra-ba| the great lady, who all the Black Headed (People)   
an {d}en-lil2 {d}en-ki-bi| An, Enlil, and Enki 
szu-ni-sze3 bi2-in-si-esz-a| did fill into her hands, 
di esz-bar-bi si sa2-sa2-e| she who correctly delivers verdicts and decisions, 
sa2-gar-gar en3-tar-tar gal-zu| the all-knowing counselor and inquirer, 
gu2 dingir gal-gal-e-ne-ka| the one among all the great gods  
inim mah du11-ga-ni nu-kam3-me| whose august spoken words cannot be altered, 
ki igi zalag-ga-ni an dagal-la dag-ga| where her bright eye roams in the wide heavens, 
ki igi zi bar-ra-na| in the place where she directs her righteous eye 
{d}lamma nir-gal2| a trusty protective genie 
bi2-ib2-szum2-mu-a| she provides, 
dingir arhusz su3 szu-nigin-bi du10| goddess with far-reachng mercy, whose compassion is sweet, 
szud3 a-ra-zu-e gesz tuku| who listens to prayers and entreaties, 
dumu-gal {d}suen-na| great daughter of the god Suen, 
a2-ag2-ga2 an-ki-a ur4-ur4| who assembles the commands of heaven and earth, 
nin-a-ni-ir| her lady- 
si-ma-at-{d}inanna| Simat-Eštar,  
dam ki-ag2| beloved spouse

szul gesz tuku {d}en-lil2-la2| the youth who listens to Enlil 
igi du8-a an-na sza3 ku3-ge pa3-da| and looks to An, chosen by the pure heart, 
lugal ki-ag2 dingir gal-gal-e-ne| king beloved of the great gods, 
szu-il2-la-ni sze-ga| whose Lifted Hand prayers are agreeable, 
sipa gu2-un kar2 nibru{ki}| shepherd who makes the tribute sparkle for Nippur, 
me gesz-hur szu du7 eridu{ki}-ga| who perfects the divine powers and plans of Eridu, 
engar zi u2-a uri2{ki}-ma| reliable farmer, provider of Ur, 
e2-babbar-da ni2 te-ge26| who reveres the Ebabbar temple, 
lugal larsa{ki}-ma| king of Larsa  
lugal ki-en-gi ki-uri-ke4| and king of Sumer and Akkad: 
munus sun5-na| (Simat-Eštar), the humble woman, 
me-te lugal-sze3 tum2-ma| ornament befitting the king,

{d}nin-e2-gal-ka-sze3| are for Ninegal, 
u4 {d}nin-e2-gal nin-a-ne2| when Ninegal, her lady,  
mu sa6-ga-ne2 gu3 zi bi2-in-de2-a| faithfully spoke her good name, 
e2 a2-ag2-ga2 kilib3 ur4-ur4| the Temple That Assembles All the Instructions,   
ki-tusz nam-dingir-bi-sze3 tum2-ma| the residence befitting her divinity, 
sag-bi hur-sag gal-gin7 im-mi-in-il2| she raised up its top like a mountain,  
nam-ti {d}ri-im-{d}suen| and so that the life of Rīm-Sîn 
u4 da-ri2-sze3 gal2-le-de3| would exist forever,

u4 su3-ra2-sze3 im-mi-in-gar| for future days she put there. 
{d}nin-si4-an-na| For Ninsiana, 
dingir an sikil-ta giszgal-bi im-zalag| goddess whose (astral) station shines forth from pure heaven, 
gesz-nu11-bi pa e3| whose light appears resplendently, 
an-ta-gal2 unu7-gal-e si-a| exalted one who fills the great dining hall, 
ka ba-a-ni sze-ga| whose speech is favorable, 
nir-gal2 ukken-ta he2-am3-bi dugud-da| authoritative one, whose Amen in the assembly is weighty, 
igi-sze3 du dingir gal-e-ne| who goes at the fore of the great gods, 
mes sag me galam-ma szu du7| foremost heroine who makes perfect the artful divine powers,

di-ku5 na-de5 mah| exalted judge and councelor

dingir arhusz su3 lu2 ni2 te-ge26-na| goddess full of compassion, who for the person who fears her

u4 nam-ti-la mah-a| and a tremendously long life 
bi2-ib2-gar-re-a| she will bring about for that one,

{d}nin-si4-an-na lugal-mu-ur2| for Ninsiana my 'master'

{d}ama-gu-la| For Amagula,

en-an-e-du7| Enanedu, 
en {d}nanna| en priestess of Nanna, 
nam gal nam-en-na sza3 ku3-ta nam-gi7 an-na| having the great fate of the en office from the womb on, a nobility of heaven, 
sza3 ki-ag2 {d}nin-gal-e nig2-UD nam-en-na bar szu-ta gar| beloved of (her) heart, the brightness(?) of the en office set upon her body by Ningal's own hand,  
me-te e2-kisz-nu-gal2 za3-sza4 utah-he u9-na| fitting one of the Ekišnugal temple, the rival of high heaven, 
he2-du7 agrun-na u4 sa-sa-ha kalam-sze3 e3| ornament of the agrun cella, burning light coming forth for the nation, 
aga nam-en-na-sze3 ku3-ge-esz-e tum2-ma| sacredly suited for the crown of the en office, 
gesz-hur szu-luh nam-dingir-sze3 zi-de3-esz pa3-da| properly chosen for the divine plans and lustrations of the en office,

en-an-e-du7| I, Enanedu, 
en igi-du8-a {d}nanna {d}nin-gal-bi| the en priestess who may look upon Nanna and Ningal 
uri5{ki} iri{ki} za3-e3 ki-en-gi-ra| (in) Ur, the foremost city of Sumer, 
ki szu-tag za-na-ru en {d}asz-im2-babbar-e| where zanaru instruments are played for Ašimbabbar, 
lu2 gi6-par3 nam-en-bi-sze3 ki sikil-la du3-a gal-bi tum2-ma-me-en| a person most fitting for the gipar built on a pure place for its office of en - 
u4 {d}nanna {d}nin-gal-bi| when Nanna and Ningal 
sag-ki zalag-ga-ne-ne-a igi bar-ra-bi nam-ti-la| having looked (at me) with their shining brows, and life 
igi hul2-la-bi mu-un-szi-in-szum2-esz-am3| and a joyous regard they gave to me,  
esz3 e2-kisz-nu-gal2 ki-tusz nam-dingir-ne-ne-a| and in the shrine Ekišnugal, the residence of their divinity, 
mu-mu mi-ni-in-mah-esz-a| they having exalted my name,  
ka-mu sikil-la nam-szita nam-ti-la mu-un-gar-re-esz-am3| having placed in my pure mouth prayers of life,
szu si-sa2-mu u4 nam-ti {d}ri-im-{d}suen| and my correctly guiding hand - in order that the life of Rīm-Sîn, 
szesz tam-ma-na-mu| my twin(!) brother, 
su3-USZ-u5-de3 mu-un-de3-ri-esz-a| could be extended - they, togther with him, did exert it,  
kur gu2-erim2-gal2-la-ni| and so his foreign enemies 
szu-ni-sze3 bi2-in-si-isz-esz-a| they having put fully into his hands -
u4-ba gi6-par3 ku3-ga ki-tusz nam-en-na-mu| at that time, the sacred gipar, my residence of the en office, 
szeg12-bi ur2-bi-ta nu-us2-sa| its bricks no longer lying against(?) its base, 
en-a-e-du7| I, Enanedu, 
en mu mah zi-de3-esz sa4-a| en priestess, truly named with an exalted name, 
dumu ku-du-ur-ma-bu-uk-me-en| the daughter of Kudur-mabuk, 
gi6-par3 ku3-ga ur2-bi sun-a szeg12 zi-du he2-ni-us2| I laid correctly fitting bricks against the old base of the sacred gipar. 
e2-gar8-bi szu-si tag-ga im dul3 hu-mu-ak| I covered with plaster its inner walls fitted to (within) a finger-length. 
e2-bi gibil-be2-esz hu-mu-tu| I created that house anew. 
u4-ba unu2 ses ba-an-tum3 kislah nam-tar-ra| At that time, the Hall That Has Brought Bitterness, the cleared land of 'fates' 
en-en-e-ne libir-ra-me-esz| (where) the old en priestesses were, 
ki-bi bad3 nu-dab6 gu2-gir3-bi EDIN-BUR2-bi he2-szub| that place was not encircled with a wall, and its entrances and its .. had collapsed. 
en-nu-un ba-ra-gar ki-bi ba-ra-sikil| No watch was set up and that place was no longer pure. 
ga2-e gesztu2 gal-zu-mu-ta| I, by my great wisdom, 
nam-tar u4-da egir-ra ki-bi bi2-kin-kin| sought out a place for (going to one's) fate forever afterward.  
diri ki-nu2 en-en-e-ne libir-ra-me-esz| Surpassing the resting place of the old en priestesses 
u2-zu-ug dagal-la hu-mu-gar| I established a broad sacred area. 
ki-bi szub-ba bad3 gal-e hu-mu-dab6| I surrounded that collapsed place with a big wall,
en-nu-un kal-ga bi2-gar ki-bi hu-mu-sikil| set there a strong watch, and I purified that place. 
mu pa3-da nam-en-na-mu pa3-pa3-de3-de3| To show my name chosen for the office of en,  
kin-bi ki-bi-sze3 he2-em-mi-gar| I did indeed restore this work. 
temen ar2 nam-en-na-mu mu-sar| Foundation documents in praise of my office of en I had inscribed 
u4 a-na gal2-la-ka-ta he2-em-mi-us2| and had it laid there for whatsoever time it may exist.  
bad3-bi ni2 te-ge26-mu he2-em-i mu-bi he2-em-mi-sa4| I named that wall: May the One Who Shows Fear of Me Be Praised.

a sikil-la szu tag-ga-sze3 tum2-ma| suitable for pure touching-water - 
nig2 u4-bi-ta nin igi-du-mu-ne| something which previously no queen who came before me 
ba-ra-an-dim2-ma-a| had ever fashioned - 
u3-mu-dim2| when I had fashioned it, 
ka2 ku3 kisal-mah e2-me-ur4-ur4| at the sacred gate of the main courtyard of the Emeurur temple 
ki u6-di kalam-ma-ka| a place of marvel of the nation 
ul-sze3 mu-ni-gub| I happily set it up . 
szu lu2 hul hesz5{esz2}-ta| In order from evil-doers and violent men  
li-ri-isz-ga-am-lum kar-re-de3| to keep Lirīš-gamlum away,  
a2-sag3 asz-bur2 su-a-na gal2-la| and the asakku or ašbur diseases that may be in her body 
ni2 nu-zu-ur2 szum2-mu-de3| to give over (instead) to that which knows not fear, 
sza3-hal igi-ni-a zi-zi-i-de3| to remove the šahal from within her eye, 
zi-ne2 uri3 ak-de3| and to act as guardian for her life, 
nam-ti li-ri-isz-ga-am-lum dumu-munus-mu| for the life of Lirīš-gamlum my daughter 
u3 nam-ti-mu-sze3| and for my own life, 
geme2 ni2-tuku-ni-me-en| I, the servant who has fear of her (Inanna),
a mu-na-ru| dedicated it (this object) to her.
u4-me-da u4-da egir-bi-sze3| For ever after today,  
lu2 kin ak-a-mu ib2-zi-ir-re-a| a person who may efface the work I have made, 
ki-gub-ba-bi ib2-da-ab-kur2-ru-a| who shall remove it from its standing place 
ki kur2-ra bi2-ib2-gub-bu-a| and stand it up in another place, 
mu-sar-ra-ba szu bi2-ib2-ur3-a| who shall erase its inscription 
mu-ni bi2-ib2-sar-re-a| and inscribe his own name upon it, 
asz2-bala-ba-ke4-esz| or because of this curse 
lu2-kur2 szu ba-an-zi-zi-i-a| shall incite a stranger to it,  
lu2-ba {d}inanna nin kur-kur-ra-ke4| upon that person may Inanna, queen of all the lands, 
sza3 ib2-ba lipisz bal-a-ne2| with her angry heart and fury  
asz2 gig-ga he2-en-e| wreak upon him a grievous curse.
e-ba-ra-ad| Ebarad, 
lugal an-sza-an u3 szuszin| king of Anshan and Susa: 
si-il-ha-ha| Silḫaḫa 
sukkal-mah| Grand-Regent, 
an-sza-an u3 szuszin-am3| Anshan and Susa 
ad-da-hu-szu| did Addaḫušu 
dumu nin9 si-il-ha-ha| son of the sister of Silḫaḫa 
mu-du3| build. 
ha-am-mu-ra-pi2| I, Hammu-rāpi, 
lugal kal-ga| the mighty king, 
lugal ka2-dingir-ra{ki}| king of Babylon, 
u4 {d}utu lugal-mu| when Utu my master  
dagal-e-de3| to widen   
inim in-du11-ga-a| when he told me, 
gesz in-tuku-ni-me-en| I heeded him.   
gu3 hul2 ma-an-de2| He spoke to me joyously 
a2-bi hu-mu-da-an-ag2| and gave me that order. 
u4-ba| At that time, 
sza3-gal2 diri-de3| to increase food, 
a-gar3 a gar-ra| in a flooded agricultural tract 
e hu-mu-si-ga| when I had put up levees,  
ugu2-ba| on top of that 
bad3 ga2-gi4-a| the wall of a cloister
hu-mu-du3| I built.
sza3-ba| Therein 
{i7}{d}a-a-he2-gal2| the Aia is Abundance canal 
hu-mu-ba-al| I dug out, 
a nam-he2| and abundant water 
he2-bi2-de2| I let flow in it. 
nam-bi-sze3| Because of this, 
{d}a-a| may Aia, 
nin zimbir{ki}| the lady of Sippar,
he2-en-szi-hul2-le| rejoice over me, 
ki {d}utu| and together with Utu 
gidlam-ni-da| her spouse 
ti u4-su3-ra2| a long life,  
sag-e-esz2| and as a gift 
ha-ma-ab-rig7-ge| may she present them to me. 
u4 {d}utu| When Utu, 
en gal an-ki-bi-da| great lord of heaven and earth, 
lugal dingir-re-e-ne-ke4| king of the gods, 
ha-am-mu-ra-pi2| at me, Hammurapi, 
nun sze-ga-ni-me-en| the prince agreeable to him, 
igi zalag-ga-na| with his shining eyes 
hul2-la-bi| happily 
mu-un-bar-re-en| looked, 
nam-lugal da-ri2| and an everlasting kingship

suhusz ma-da| and the foundation of the land,

zimbir{ki}| of Sippar 
ka2-dingir-ra{ki} ug3-bi| and Babylon their people 
ki-tusz ne-ha tusz-u3-da| to settle in peaceful habitations

du3-u3-da| to build 
sag-bi il2-i-da| and its top to raise up 
a2 gal hu-mu-da-an-ag3| he gave me the great order. 
u4-ba| At that time, 
ha-am-mu-ra-pi2| I, Hammurapi, 
lugal kal-ga| the mighty king,

ni2-tuku| (god-)fearing one

usu mah {d}utu-ke4| by the exalted strength which Utu 
ma-ni-in-szum2| gave me, 
ugnim zi-ga| through a troop levy 
ma-da-mu-ta| of my land 
usz8 bad3 zimbir{ki}| the foundation of the wall of Sippar 
sahar-ta hur-sag gal-gin7| with earth like a huge mountain 
sag-bi he2-em-mi-il2| its top I raised up, 
bad3 mah hu-mu-du3| and the great wall I built. 
u4 ul-li2-a-ta| That which since olden days 
lugal-lugal-a-ne2-er| among all the kings

ba-ra-an-dim2-ma| had ever built, 
{d}utu lugal-ga2| for Utu my master 
gal-bi hu-mu-na-du3| I built in a grand manner. 
bad3-bi| That wall: 
du11-ga {d}utu-ta| By the Command of Utu 
ha-am-mu-ra-pi2| May Hammurapi 
gaba-ri na-an-tuku-tuku| Have No Equal 
mu-bi-im| is its name. 
bala sa6-ga-ga2| In my favorable reign 
{d}utu-ke4| which Utu

iri{ki} ul-la| the ancient city 
{d}utu-ke4| of Utu,

hu-mu-ba-al| I dug, 
ki-in-gub-ba| and in its emplacements 
a da-ri2| perpetual water 
he2-em-mi-gar| I established. 
he-nun he2-gal2-bi| Abundance and plenty 
he2-ni-gar-gar| I established everywhere there. 
ug3 zimbir{ki}-sze3| For the people of Sippar 
asila he2-bi2-gar| I produced joy, 
nam-ti-ga2| and (so) for my life 
szud3 he2-em-mi-sza4-asz| they indeed prayed. 
su {d}utu lugal-ga2| What for the well-being of Utu my master 
{d}a-a nin-mu| and Aia my mistress 
du10-ga-ra he2-bi2-ak| was good I did.

u4-szu2-usz| daily

du-ri2-sze3| and that forever 
nu-ha-lam-e| it may not be forgotten, 
ka ug3-ta he2-bi2-gar| I put it in the mouths of the people.

mu-na-an-ge-ne2-esz-a| did make firm for him -
u4-ba {d}marduk| then Marduk,
{d}en-lil2 kalam-ma-na| the Enlil of his land,
dingir nam-ku3-zu| the god who wisdom
an-dim2-dim2-me-a| creates,
sa-am-su-i-lu-na| to me, Samsu-iluna,
lugal la-la-ni i3-me-en-na-ta| who is the king his delight,
kur-kur kilib3-ba-bi| of all those lands
nam-sipa-bi ak-de3| to exercise their shepherding
ma-an-szum2| he did give me,
kalam-ma-ni| and his country
u3-sal-la nu2-de3| to make lie down in riverine meadows,
ug3 dagal-la-ni| and his wide-spread people
silim-ma du-ri2-sze3 tum2-tum2-mu-de3| to lead forever in well-being,
a2 gal hu-mu-da-an-ag2| he issued to me (these) great instructions.
sa-am-su-i-lu-na| I, Samsu-iluna,
lugal kal-ga| the mighty king,
lugal ka2-dingir-ra{ki}| king of Babylon,
lugal an-ub-da limmu2-ba| king who among the four world quarters
ka tesz2-a bi2-in-si3-ga-me-en| established harmony,
usu ni2-ga2| by my own power
igi-gal2 gal-mu-ta| and through my great intelligence,
bad3 an-za-gar3-{d}en-lil2-la2{ki}| the fort Dimat-Enlil
{d}nin-hur-sag-ga2| for Ningursaga

mu nam-lugal-la-mu-um| because my kingship
bi2-ib2-gu-ul-la-asz| he had made very great,

u3 bad3 u2-s,i-a-na-er3-ra{ki}| and the fort Uṣi-ana-Erra
{d}nergal| for Nergal
tu10 lu2-erim2-mu-um| because the smiting of my foes
bi2-in-ak-a-asz| he did accomplish,
6(disz) bad3 gal-gal-la-bi| these six great fortressess
su-mu-la-il3| which Sūmû-la-Il,
a-a gu-la-mu| my forefather
pa-bil2-ga 5(disz)-kam-ma-mu| my fifth(-generation) ancestor,
mi-ni-in-du3-a| did build,
nam-sumun-ba ni2-te-a-ne-ne-a| but which in their old age by themselves
i3-szub-szub-bu-usz-am3| did collapse,
sza3 iti 2(disz)-kam-ma-ta| within two months
szeg12-bi mi-ni-du8| their bricks I had made,
gal-bi im-mi-du3| and I rebuilt them in a grand fashion.
sag-ne-ne hur-sag-gin7 mi-ni-il2| Their tops I raised up like mountains,
kilib3 kur-kur-ra-ke4| (and thus) of the whole of the lands
suhusz-bi mi-ni-ge-en| their foundations I made secure.
ka2-dingir-ra{ki}| Babylon's
mu-bi hu-mu-ni-mah| name I made supreme,
an-ub-da limmu2-ba he2-bi2-diri| and within the four world quarters I truly made it pre-eminent.
ni2 me-lam2| The fearsomeness of the divine radiance
nam-lugal-la-mu| of my kingship
za3 an-ki-ke4 he2-en-dul| truly covered the edges of heaven and earth.
ur5-sze3-am3| For this,
dingir gal-gal-e-ne| the great gods
igi zalag-ga-ne-ne-a| their shining faces
hu-mu-szi-in-bar-re-esz| they directed towards me,
nam-ti-la {d}nanna-gin7| and life, which like (the moon-god) Nanna
iti-iti-da mu2-mu2-da| waxes month after month,
nam-sipa ub-da limmu2-ba| shepherdship of the four world quarters
silim-ma du-ri2-sze3 ak-da| to exercise in well-being forever,
sza3 kur-ku-da-mu| the desire of my heart
dingir-gin7 sa2-di-da| to attain like a god,
u4-szu2-sze3 sag il2-la| (and) daily with an uplifted head
asila sza3 hul2-la-ta du-du-da| to walk in joy and happiness
sag-e-esz hu-mu-rig7-esz| they presented to me as a gift.

{d}za-ba4-ba4 {d}inanna| because Zababa and Inanna

du11-ga-ni szu nu bal-e-dam| whose utterance cannot be overturned

sukkal kal-ga| my envoy, mighty

ki-bi-sze3 gar-ra in-zu-a| knows how to put in place,
gesz-nu11 zalag-ga-ni he2-me-en-ze2-en| may you both be his shining light.
dingir-e-ne-er szilig-ga-me-esz| (Zababa and Ištar) the most majestic of the gods,
inim a-a-bi {d}en-lil2| at the words that their father Enlil

sza3-bi hi-li su13 in-hul2| their hearts rejoiced full of delight.

inim ul mu-un-da-ab-bal-bal-e-ne| and joyfully they conversed with him.
sa-am-su-i-lu-na| O Samsu-iluna,
numun da-ri2 dingir-e-ne-ke4| eternal seed of kingship,
he2-du7 nam-lugal-la| one fitting for kingship,
{d}en-lil2-le| Enlil

udug-za silim-ma-ta ak-de3| To act with well-being as (your) guardian genies
a2 ba-me-da-an-ag2| he has commanded us.

am-mi-s,a-du-qa2 %a am-mi-s,a-du-qa| Ammī-ṣaduqa, 
dingir zib-ba-ke4 %a mi-gir te-li-ti| favorite of Telītum, 
ki-ti gi da-ri-a %a {d}lamma mesz2-ri-i| a protective lamassu-statue of prosperity 
du10-ba %a sza i-kar-ra-bu| which makes a gesture of blessing 
szu an-e3-a %a szu-ul-ma-ni-x| for (his) well-being, 
za kal-la galam du3-du3-a %a ab-nam a-qar-tam s,u2-ud-du-rat| artfully built with precious stones, 
{d}utu| For Utu, 
en gal| the great lord 
dingir-re-e-ne-er| of the gods, 
lugal e2-di-ku5-da-ta| the king of the Edikudata temple, 
nam-ti-la| for the life 
am-mi-s,a-du-qa2-a| of Ammī-ṣaduqa, 
lugal kal-ga| the mighty king, 
lugal ka2-dingir-ra{ki}| king of Babylon, 
lugal-a-ni-ir| his master, 
gi-mil-{d}marduk di-ku5| Gimil-Marduk, the judge, 
dumu s,il2-li2-{d}utu| son of Şillī-Šamaš, 
u4 {d}utu lugal-a-ni| after Utu, his master, 
inim in-na-an-du11-ga-ni| regarding the word he had spoken to him 
an-da-gen-na-ta| had walked with him, 
sza3-la2 in-szi-in-su3-am3| and, being filled with compassion towards him, 
zi nam-ti-la| breath and life 
in-na-an-ba-a| he granted to him, 
{uruda}alan sza3-ne-sza4| a copper suppliant statue, 
du10 bi2-in-gurum-ma| with a knee bent, 
musz3-me-bi ku3-babbar gar-ra| its face plated with silver, 
szud3 in-na-an-ne2-a-ni| speaking prayers for him, 
in-na-ni-in-dim2| he had fashioned for him. 
{uruda}alan-ne-e| This statue 
igi {d}utu| before Utu 
e2-di-ku5-da-ta| in the Edikudata temple, 
du11-ga-ni| who to his word 
in-szi-in-sze-ga| had been favorable, 
mu-ni-gub| he erected.

lugal-an-na-mu-un-du3 nita kal-ga| I, Lugalanamundu, the strong man,
u2-a nibru{ki} lugal adab{ki}-a-me-en| who provides for Nippur, king of Adab
lugal an-ub-da limmu2-ba x-x-me-en| and king of the four world quarters,
gu2 ug3 kur-kur-ra-ke4 mi-ni-in-gi-na| secured tribute upon the people of all the lands,

u4-ba mi-gir-{d}en-lil2 ensi2 mar-ha-szi{ki}| At that time, Migir-Enlil, ruler of Marḫaši,

u4 {d}en-lil2-le| When Enlil,
lugal dingir-re-e-ne| the king of the gods,
en gal kur-kur-ra-ke4| the great lord of all the lands,
{d}utu-ra igi sa6-ga-na| towards Utu his gracious eyes
mu-un-szi-in-bar-ra-am3| did direct,
zimbir{ki}| and of Sippar,
iri ul ki-szu-pesz-a-ni| his ancient city and cult site,
bad3-bi du3-u3-de3| its wall to build,
e2-babbar-ra| the Ebabbar temple
ki-be2 gi4-gi4-de3| to restore,
u6-nir gi-gun4-na mah-a-ni| of his ziggurrat and lofty high terrace
sag-bi an-gin7 il2-i-de3| its top to raise as high as the sky,

inim nig2 nu-kur2-ru-da-na| with his word which cannot be altered
bi2-in-du11-ga-a| he spoke to him -
u4-bi-a| At that time,
ur-sag szul {d}utu| for the hero, youthful Utu,
nam gal {d}en-lil2-le| a great destiny that by Enlil
zimbir{ki} e2-babbar-ra| regarding Sippar and the Ebabbar temple
mu-ni-in-tar-ra-sze3| had been decreed
hul2-la-gin7| happily
im-ma-na-ni-ib2-gar| was set in place for him.
sa-am-su-i-lu-na| To me, Samsu-iluna,
lugal szu du11-ga-ni-me-en| the king created by him,
gu3 hul2 ma-an-de2| he spoke happily,
a2-bi mu-da-an-ag2| and he issued to me the order for it.
u4-bi-a| At that time,
kilib3 ki-en-gi ki-uri| all of Sumer and Akkad
lu2 gu2 mu-da-ab-du3-usz-a| whose people had become hostile to me,
sza2 mu asz-a-ka| within one year
a-ra2 8(disz)-am3| eight times
{gesz}tukul-ta he2-em-mi-sag3| I struck them with weapons.
iri didli gu2-bar-ra-mu-ne| The various cities of my enemies
du6 ka-ar2-me-sze3 he2-ni-ku4| I turned into mounds and ruins.
lu2 erim2| The enemies
lu2 hul-gal2| and evil-doers
suhusz-bi kalam-ta he2-em-mi-bu| I tore out from the country their foundations,
kur gu2-si-a| and the whole land
du11-ga-ga2 hu-mu-ni-tusz| I made dwell under my command.
nig2 u4 ul-li2-a-ta| From the time long ago
szeg12 e2-babbar-ra| when the brickwork of the Ebabbar temple
ba-dim2-ma-ta| had been constructed,
lugal igi-du-ne-ne-er| among the kings who had gone before

bad3 zimbir{ki}| and so the wall of Sippar

{d}marduk-bi-da-ka| and Marduk,

ma-da-mu-ta| of my land

u3 nam-ti-la-ke4| and Life

mu-bi-im| is its name.

sag nam-bara2-ga-ni| who his throne

2(gesz2) 2(u) gurusz u4 1(disz)-sze3| 148 workdays,
gurx(SZE.KIN)-a zar3 tab-ba a-sza3 bad3-du3-a a-sza3 iszib-e-ne u3 a-sza3 u2-du-lu2-saga| harvested and sheaves piled up in the field Constructed Wall, in the Incantation priests field and in
1(gesz2) 1(u) 5(disz) gurusz u4 1(disz)-sze3| 75 workdays,
gurx(SZE.KIN)-a zar3 tab-ba a-sza3 u2-du-{d}nin-a-ra-li u3 gaba a-sza3 gibil| harvested and sheaves piled up in the field Cattle-herder-of-Nin-Arali and (in the field) across from the new field.
3(gesz2) 3(u) 5(disz) gurusz u4 1(disz)-sze3| 215 workdays,
a-da gub-ba a-sza3 a-u2-da-gu-la a-sza3 a-u2-da-tur u3 a-sza3 nun-na| irrigation work in the Audagula field, in the Audatur field and in the Prince field.

pisan-dub-ba| Basket-of-tablets: 
gurum2-ak| inspections 
sipa unu3| of shepherds and cattle herdsmen 
ki-nu-nir{ki}| in Kinunir, 
nigin6{ki}| Nigin, 
gu2-ab-ba{ki}| and Gu’abba;

lugal| king 
kisz| of Kish. 
dumu e2-dub-ba-a u4-ul-la-a me-sze3 i3-du-de3-en| Schoolboy, where have you been going so long? 
e2-dub-ba-a-sze3 i3-du-de3-en| To the school I have been going. 
e2-dub-ba-a a-na-am3 i3-ak| In school, what were you doing? 
dub-mu i3-szid ninda-ka-gub-mu i3-gu7| My tablet I recited, my lunch I ate; 
dub-mu i3-dim2 i3-sar i3-til-ma| my tablet I prepared, wrote, finished, 
mu-gub-ba-mu ma-an-gub-bu-usz| my ‘standing’ lines they set out for me, 
kin-sig im-szu-mu ma-an-gub-bu-usz| during afternoon meal my hand-tablet they prepared for me, 
u4 e2-dub-ba-a du8-u-de3 e2-sze3 i3-du-de3-en| when school was released, home I used to go, 
e2-e i3-ku4-re-en ad-da-mu al-tusz| home I entered, my father was sitting there; 
ad-da-mu im-szu-mu inim i3-na-ra-du11-ma| to my father about my hand-tablet I spoke, 
dub-mu in-na-an-szid ad-da-mu mu-un-sa6| my tablet I recited to him, my father was happy. 
igi ad-da-mu-sze3 i3-gub-bu-nam| In the presence of my father I stood, indeed, 
enmen2 tuku a nag-mu-ub-ze2-en| being thirsty, “Water let me drink!” 
szagar tuku ninda szum2-ma-ab-ze2-en| being hungry, “Bread give me!” 
giri3-mu luh-ha-ab-ze2-en {gesz}na2 gub-ba-ab-ze2-en ga-ba-nu2-e-sze| “My feet wash, my bed set up, I would lie down!” saying. 
a2-gu2-zi-ga-ta zi-mu-ub-ze2-en| “In the morning wake me up, 
u4 na-ab-zal-en um-mi-a-mu mu-un-tud2-de3-en| that the morning not pass, my teacher will hit me. 
a2-gu2-zi-ga-ta zi-zi-da-mu-ne| In the morning at my rising, 
ama-mu igi-mu in-na-an-gar-ma| (on) my mother my eye I placed, and 
ninda-ka-gub-mu szum2-ma-ab e2-dub-ba-a-sze3 ga-DU-DU in-na-an-du11| “My lunch give me, to school I wish to go” I said to her; 
ninda-ka-gub-mu szum2-ma-ab e2-dub-ba-a-sze3 i3-du-de3-en| “My lunch give me, to school I am going.” 
e2-dub-ba-a lu2-bala-ke4 a-na-asz-am3 u4 mu-zal ma-an-du11 ni2-ba-te sza3-mu ba-dar| In school the man on term: “Why did the morning pass?” asked me, with fear my gut was torn; 
igi um-mi-a-ga2 i-in-ku4-re-ma ki ib2-za| into the presence of my teacher I enter, a place I took, 
ad-da e2-dub-ba-a-mu dub-mu ma-an-szid| my school-father my tablet to me recited, 
um-mi-a a2-ag2-ga2 e2-dub-ba en3 tar-re-da-ni| the teacher, the instructions of the school checking, 
lu2 tag-tag-ge-da e2 sila-a igi i-ni-in-bar tug2-gaba-zu nu-ub-sir2-re-e-sze in-tud2-de3-en| the beater in the house and the street looked: “Your breast garment you do not tie?” saying, beating me. 
ad-da e2-dub-ba-mu dub-mu ma-an-de6| My school-father my tablet brought me. 
en3 nu-tar-ra-bi inim-sze3 inim-ga2 nu-zu-e| its unchecked places to words of mine I do not understand. 
lu2 pa-x-ke4 a-na-sze-am3 ge26-da nu-me-a gu2-zi nu-mu-un-zi-e-sze in-tud2-de3-en| The man of the switch: “Why, in my absence, the ‘true-neck’ did you not raise?” asking, beats me. 
lu2 ka2-na-ke4 a-na-asz-am3 ge26-da nu-me-a ib2-ta-e3-e-sze in-tud2-de3-en| The man of the gate: “Why, in my absence, do you go out?” asking, beats me. 
lu2 eme-gi7-ra-ke4 eme-gi7 bi2-in-du11-e-sze in-tud2-de3-en| The man of Sumerian: “Sumerian you call that?” asking, beats me. 
um-mi-a-mu szu-zu nu-sa6-sa6-e-sze in-tud2-de3-en| My teacher: “Your hand is not at all pretty” saying, beats me. 
nam-dub-sar-ra gu2 bi2-du nam-dub-sar-ra im-szub bi2-ak| Scribal art I neglected, scribal art I let fall. 
nig2-ba-ni szum2-ma-ab a-ra2 ha-ra-szum2-mu| his gift give, that he many times over give, 
szid nig2-szid-de3 szu he2-mi-bar-re| that he from the account-recitation release me; 
inim-inim-ma e2-dub-ba-a gal2-la| of all the words that are in the school, 
dumu e2-dub-ba-a-ke4-ne ab-szid-de3 ge26-e hu-mu-un-szid-de3| all the schoolboys counting, may he count me. 
dumu e2-dub-ba-a-ke4-ne nig2 bi-in-du11-ga ad-da-ni inim-ma ba-ni-gi4| In what the schoolboy(s) had said, his father responded; 
um-mi-a e2-dub-ba-a-ta lu2 im-ma-da-an-ri| the teacher from school was brought round; 
e2-a u3-mu-ni-in-ku4 za3-mu-la bi2-in-tusz| after the house he entered, in the “zamula” he sat; 
dumu e2-dub-ba-a-ke4 szu-kin an-dab5 igi-ni-sze3 al-gub| the schoolboy bowed down, before him standing, 
nam-dub-sar-ra a-na bi2-in-zu-na| of scribal art what he had learned 
ad-da-na szu-na ba-ni-in-szum2| into his father’s hand he gave. 
ad-da-ni sza3 hul2-la-ni-ta| His father from the joy of his gut 
ad-da e2-dub-ba-a-ke4-ne gu2-hul2 ba-ni-de2-e| to the school-fathers friendly words speaks: 
lu2-tur-mu szu-ni i-ni-in-bad-du ku3-zu i-ni-in-ku4-re-en| “My little one, his hand opening, into silver-knowledge you let him enter, 
nam-dub-sar-ra nig2-galam-galam-ma-bi mu-ni-in-pa3-pa3-de2-en| of scribal art, all its tricks, you reveal for him; 
sza3 dub-ba-a szid nig2-ka9 ki-bur2-bur2-ra igi mu-un-na-si-ga-asz| the gut of the tablet, the calculation of accounts, to its solutions you fill his eyes. 
gu-szum2-ma ki-dul-dul-a-bi dalla mu-ni-ne| Of writing the covered places he lights up for him; 
kasz saga-gin7 i3 ir-da de2-mu-na-ni-ib banszur gub-mu-na-ab| like good beer, oil and fragrances for him pour, the table set out for him; 
i3 du10-ga murgu2{gu2} sza3-ga-na a-gin7 mi-ni-ib-bala-bala| good oil on his back and his gut like water offering, 
tug2 ga-ni-mu4 nig2 ga-na-ba har szu-na ga-bi-du11| “With a garment I will clad, a gift I will give him, a ring on his hand I will put!” 
kasz saga-gin7 i3 ir-da mu-na-ni-de2-e banszur mu-na-gub| Like good beer, oil and fragrances for him he pours, the table he puts out for him, 
i3 du10-ga murgu2{gu2} sza3-ga-na a-gin7 mi-ni-ib-bala-bala-e| good oil on his back and his gut like water he offers, 
tug2 mu-ni-mu2 nig2 mu-na-an-ba har szu-na bi2-in-du3| with a garment he clad, a gift he gave him, a ring on his hand he put. 
um-mi-a sza3 hul2-la-ni-ta szu12 mu-na-sa4| The teacher in joy of gut a blessing spoke to him: 
lu2-tur inim-mu-sze3 gu2 li-bi2-du3-a im-szub li-bi2-ak| “The little one my words not having neglected, did not do let fall; 
nam-dub-sar-ra sag-be2 us2-sa za3-bi-sze3 til-la| of the art of writing its head, to the very edge of its side, completed, 
nig2-na-me la-ba-gil-bi-na-za szu-mu-un-sze3 mu-e-szum2-ma| nothing shall be an obstacle for you, who into my hands gave, 
nig2-ba a2-kusz-a diri mu-ni-in-gar-ra nam-dugud mu-e-dah-am3| to a gift that, in additional effort placed, heft you added, 
{d}nisaba nin {d}lamma-ke4 {d}lamma-zu he2-am3| may Nisaba, the lady of the protective deities, be your protective deity! 
gi-du3-a-za sa6-ge hu-mu-ra-ga2-ga2| A pretty stylus may she place for you! 
im-szu-gub-ba-zu hul he3-ri-in-du12-du12| and if they of your tablet sing, “Bad!,” 
szesz-zu-ne igi-du-bi he2-me-en| of your ‘brothers’ may you their leader be! 
du10-sa-zu-ne sag-kal-bi he2-me-en| Of your friends may you their hero be! 
an-ta-gal2 dumu e2-dub-ba-ke4 he2-me-en| Exalted-schoolboy may you be! 
lu2-tur ad-da ba-an-zu ge26-e us2-a-ni-me-en| little one, father knows best; I am the one following him. 
szu12 i-ri-DU-a nam i-ri-tar-ra| The blessing brought to you, your fate having been decided, 
dingir ad-da-zu inim-bi-ta szu-zi ha-ra-ga2-ga2-ne| your god and father, with their words true hand may they set for you. 
{d}nisaba nin-za nig2 dingir-za-gin7 szu12 siskur2-ra u3-gul mu-na-ga2-ga2| To Nisaba, your lady, as if your own god, blessings, offerings, prayers you will set, 
um-mi-a-ba nig2 ad-da-za-gin7 sud3 x-sza4-sza4| your teacher, as if your own father, will bless you; 
ur5-ra-am3 nam-um-mi-a-ka sag-ki szesz-gal-la-ka| suchlike, the art of teaching, at the forehead of ‘big brothers,’ 
szu nam-sa6-ga mu-e-gar-ra-a-zu| good hand your having placed, 
a2-ag2-ga2 e2-dub-ba pa bi-e3 lu2 umun2 bi2-ak| to the instructions of the school light went out, making a man of wisdom; 
{d}nisaba nin ki-umun2-ma nam-mah-a-ni bi2-in-du11| Nisaba, lady of the place of wisdom, his greatness proclaimed; 
{d}nisaba za3-mu10| Nisaba, praise! 
ege-nun-e ege-nun-e e2-ta nam-ta-ab-e3| The princely lord, the princely lord came forth from the house.

ab-ub-da-limmu {d}en-lil2-ra {gesz}kiri6-ginx mu-na-sa7| The four corners of heaven became green for Enlil like a garden.

{d}en-lil2-le kesz3{ki} za3-mi2 am3-ma-ab-be2| Enlil spoke the praises of Keš.

e2-kur-da-mu2-a kur-ra sag-il2-bi| growing as high as E-kur, lifting its head among the mountains! 
abzu ginx ri-a hur-sag-bi sig7-sig7-ga| Rooted in the abzu, verdant like the mountains!

bi2-ib2-tak4-tak4-a| shall cause it to be held back,
dingir gal-gal an-ki-ke4-ne| may the great gods of heaven and earth
nam ha-ba-an-da-ku5-ne| curse him.
{d}en-lil2 du11-ga u18-ru di-zu sukud dagal-la-am3| O Enlil with exalted utterances, your judgments being high and wide, 
{d}isz-me-{d}da-gan gurusz kalag sa su pirig szul kalag ni2 gal2-la| Išme-Dagan, the strong young man with the muscles and body of a lion, strong youth possessing fearsomeness, 
dili-i-ni mah en mu du10 sa4-a-ni kur szar2-ra pa3-da| who alone is exalted, lord whose called good name is demonstrated in all lands, 
e-ne-da zi-gal2-la im-mi-in-lu-a| under his sway he has made the living creatures numerous, 
a2 bad3 ug3 dur2-ru-na-bi-sze3 sag-ge6 szu mu-na-szum2-ma| and into whose hand were given the Black Headed People in their shelters where the people reside, 
nesag kur-ra-da si sza-mu-na-ni-ib-sa2-asz| They prepared correctly for him the first-fruit offerings of the land. 
e2-gal du10-ga-na ki la-ba-na-tag-ge| They are not (merely?) left to him in his good palace. 
u4-ba {d}isz-me-{d}da-gan szul ur-sag giri3 du10 gal2-e-ne-ke4| At that time, Išme-Dagan, the youth, the hero of the runners, 
nibru{ki} iri numun ug3 szar2-ra i-i ti-le u3-tu gal2-la-sze3| to Nippur, being the city where the seed of the myriad people sprang up, where the living were born, 
kas4-di hu-luh-e ge6 an-bar7-ba gub-bu musz3 nu-tum2-mu| the reverent(?) runner who serves night and day without ceasing, 
u4-szu2-usz nig2-nam tum3 sa2 gal-e-esz na-an-gar| who daily brings everything (needed), made a great resolution. 
zi-ga-ni u18-lu a-ma-ru im sur2-ba de6-a| When he rises up it is gigantic, a flood bringing a wind in its fury, 
a2-na bad-ra2-a-ba ga2-ga2-ga2 da-na su3-u4-bi-sze3 mu-gir2-gir2-re| With his arms swinging open over and over, he flashes across distant miles 
pirig husz edin-na-gin7 usu nam-szul-ba du-a| like a fierce lion of the steppe going with strength and youthfulness. 
du10 kaskal-la bad-bad-da-ni-a gesz-la2 me3-sze3 gub-bu| opening wide his knees on the highway, striding towards battle and combat, 
dumu nig2 tum2-tum2 {d}en-lil2-la2-ka| the son who brings everything for Enlil, 
nig2 sza3 hul2-hul2 {d}nin-lil2-la2-ka| and also that which gladdens the heart of Ninlil, 
lugal-e esz3 za-gin3-na-sze3 musz3 la-ba-ra-tum2-mu| the king cares unceasingly for the lapis lazuli shrine. 
u4-ba {d}isz-me-{d}da-gan {uruda}alan mir-re-e kas4-kas4-e hu-luh-ha-na| At that time, Išme-Dagan, a copper statue which inspires fear as it races against the storm, 
e2 ni2 gur3 bara2 kal-kal-la-na| in the temple clad in fearsomeness, upon his most precious dais, 
mu-ni-in-gub sze-er-zi-de3-esz bi2-in-gun3| he set it up and colored it brilliantly. 
nun gal za3 an-na en du11-ga nu-kam3-me-da| The great prince of the whole heaven, the lord whose utterance cannot be altered, 
sag-ki zalag igi zi il2-la-na-sze3| his shining brow and raised righteous eyes 
he2-en-szi-ni-gal2 sipa zi tu-da-ni-sze3| may he let be upon him, directed towards the faithful shepherd whom he has engendered. 
lugal a2 nig2-hul-dim2-ma ib2-szi-ag2-e-a| But a king who orders a wicked thing, 
mu-sar-ra-ba szu bi2-ib2-ur3-ra-a mu-ni bi2-ib2-sar-a| and erases this inscription and writes his own name upon it, 
asz2-bala-a-ba-ke4-esz lu2-kur2 szu ba-an-zi-zi-i-a| or because of this curse incites another person to do it, 
lu2-ba {d}en-lil2 lugal-mu {d}nin-lil2 nin-mu nam ha-ba-an-da-ku5-ru-ne| may Enlil my master and Ninli my mistress curse that person. 
{d}en-ki {d}iszkur {d}asznan {d}szakan2 en he2-gal2-la-ke4-ne| May Enki, Iškur, Ezinu, and Šakan, the lords of abundance, 
{d}nin-lil2 erisz mah| For Ninlil, the exalted queen,  
{d}a-nun-ke4-ne pa e3| most resplendant of of the Anuna gods, 
men gidri szum2-ma-am3| he the one given the crown and scepter,
ama gal {d}a-nun-na-ke4-ne| for the great mother of the Anuna gods, 
e2-kur esz3 mah-a| the exalted shrine Ekur's 
me-bi bar tam-e-de3| divine attributes to select, 
esz3 nibru{ki} dur-an-ki-ka| the Nippur shrine Duranki's 
szu-luh-bi sikil-e-de3| ritual lustrations to cleanse, 
garza szu-ta szub-ba-be2| to make the divine rites that had fallen away 
dalla mah e3-de3| reappear magnificently,
nibru{ki} masz2 sag kalam-ma| and Nippur, the bellwether of the nation,
ki-be2 gi4-gi4-de3| to restore to its previous state,
ur-{d}nin-urta-ke4| it was Ur-Ninurta,
e2-kur-sze3 gub-ba-am3| the one serving the Ekur,
{d}en-lil2 lugal kur-kur-ra-ke4| upon whom Enlil, the king of all the lands,
ug3 dagal szar2-ra-da| out over the broad population
igi mi-ni-in-il2| did lift his eye
zi-de3-esz bi-in-pa3| and did rightly choose.
an {d}en-lil2 {d}nin-lil2 x| (for) An, Enlil, (and) Ninlil
nig2-hul im-ta-bu-ur2| I removed evil,
x mu-ne-su8| I set them up for them.
{uruda}alam me-dim2-bi| (Further,) copper figures whose bodily features  
musz3-me-ga2 se3-ga| were made to resemble me, 
masz kadra-ka| with an offering kid,
im-tur-tur-re| were made in miniature(?), 
nam-szita-mu-sze3 gub-ba| and, set up for (the delivering of) my prayers, 
kisal mah ga2-gesz-szu2-a-ka| as the main courtyard of the Gagiššua's  
me-te-bi mu-na-dim2| ornament, I fashioned for her (Ninlil), 
nam-ti-la-mu-sze3| and for my life
a mu-na-ru| I dedicated them to her.
lu2 a2 nig2-hul-dim2-ma| A person who an order of wickedness  
ib2-szi-ag2-ge26-a| shall issue against it,
nig2 dim2-ma-mu| and my creation 
ib2-zi-re-a| shall efface,
x-du11 mah {d}en-lil2-la2-ke4| by the exalted command of Enlil
e2-kur-ta inim he2-mi-ib2-gi4-gi4| be revoked from within the Ekur.
{d}nin-urta ur-sag kal-ga {d}en-lil2-la2| May Ninurta, the mighty warrior of Enlil, 
maszkim nu-ku5-ru-bi he2-a| be the inseparable bailiff for this
u4 da-ri2-sze3| for an eternity of days!
{d}en-lil2 lugal kur-kur-ra| To Enlil, the king of all the lands, 
lugal-a-ni-ir| his master, 
{d}en-lil2-ba-ni| Enlil-bāni,
lugal kal-ga lugal i3-si-in{ki}-na| the mighty king, king of Isin 
lugal ki-en-gi ki-uri| and king of Sumer and Akkad, 
ki-ag2 {d}en-lil2| beloved of Enlil 
u3 {d}nin-isin2{si}-na-ka-ke4| and Nininsina,
{d}nin-lil2| For Ninlil, 
nin dingir-re-e-ne-ra| queen of the gods, 
{d}i-din-{d}da-gan lugal-e| king Iddin-Dagān  
{uruda}alan gal-gal min-a-bi mu-na-dim2| fashioned two big copper statues 
nibru{ki}-sze3 nu-un-de6| but did not bring them to Nippur. 
szu {d}i-din-{d}da-gan-ta| From (the hands of) Iddin-Dagān 
en-na {d}en-lil2-ba-ni lugal-e| until king Enlil-bāni 
mu 1(gesz2) 5(u) 7(disz)-kam| it was 117 years 
sza3 i3-si-in-na-ka i3-su8-ge-esz-am3| that they stood in Isin. 
{d}nin-lil2-le sza3 hul2-la-ni-ta| Ninlil, with a happy heart 
al in-du3 in-du11-ma| desired it and gave command, and so  
{d}en-lil2-ba-ni lugal kal-ga| Enlil-bāni, the strong king, 
lugal i3-si-in-na lugal ki-en-gi ki-uri| king of Isin, king of Sumer and Akkad,

sza3 i3-si-in-na-ta| from within Isin 
nibru{ki}-sze3 in-de6| to Nippur he had brought. 
kisal-mah e2 ga2-gesz-szu2-a-ka| In the great courtyard of the Gageššua temple 
{d}nin-lil2 nin-a-ni-ir mu-na-gub| before Ninlil his mistress he set them up. 
mu-bi-sze3 {d}nin-lil2-le| Because of this, Ninlil 
nam-ti {d}en-lil2-ba-ni| the life of Enlil-bāni, 
ki {d}en-lil2-la2-ta u4-bi ba-ni-in-su3| from (her) place (beside) Enlil, she lengthened its days. 
lu2 mu-sar-ra-ba szu bi2-ib-ur3-ra| A person who shall erase this inscription,

ur-nig2 dumu lugal-gaba| Ur-nig, son of Lugal-gaba, 
e2-usz-bar {d}szu-{d}suen| weaving house of Šu-Suen, 
sza3 nigin6{ki}| in Nigin, 
iti GAN2-masz| month “GANmaš,” 
mu us2-sa bad3 mar-tu-ta| from the year following: “The Amorite wall.” 
u4 2(u) 6(disz) ba-zal| the 26th day passed, 
mu {d}szu-{d}suen lugal uri5{ki}-ma-ke4 e2 {d}szara2 umma{ki}-ka mu-du3-sze3| to the year: “Šu-Suen, king of Ur, the house of Šara in Umma erected;”

u4 2(u) 6(disz)-kam| 26th day, 
iti diri 1(disz)-am3| the extra month is 1, 
ba-zal| passed, 
i3-gal2| are here.
