za-gin3 sa6-ga-zu| No one should be allowed to split apart your good quality lapis lazuli among the beads of the gem cutter 
{d}inanna| No one should be allowed to bend over the young woman Inanna (dead) in the netherworld 
ga2-nu| Come, Inanna, enter! 
{d}inanna| As Inanna was entering 
gi-disz-ninda| He removed the measuring rod and measuring line from her hand 
abul| As she was entering the first gate 
esz2-GAN2 za-gin3 1(disz)-kam-ma| She held the lapis measuring rod and line 
| As Inanna was entering the first gate 
si-a {d}inanna me kur-ra-ke4| Be satisfied, Inanna! This is the rite of the netherworld that is being completed 
{d}inanna garza kur-ra-ke4| Inanna! This is the procedure of the netherworld, you should not speak aloud 
abul 2(disz)-kam-ma| As Inanna was entering the 2nd gate 
hi-li sag-ki-na| The man removed the wig/allure that was upon her forehead 
x x| Be satisfied, Inanna! This is the rite of the netherworld that is being completed(?) 
si-a x x x| Be satisfied, Inanna! This is the rite of the netherworld that is being completed 
garza| Inanna! This is the procedure of the netherworld, you should not speak aloud 
{d}inanna garza kur-ra-ke4 ka-zu na-an-ba-e| Inanna! This is the procedure of the netherworld, you should not speak aloud (to interrupt it) 
ku3-sig17 szu-na x| The man removed the gold bracelet from upon her hand (i.e. wrist) 
si-a {d}inanna me kur-ra-ke4| Be satisfied, Inanna! This is the rite of the netherworld that is being completed 
{d}inanna garza kur-ra-ke4| Inanna! This is the procedure of the netherworld, you should not speak aloud 
abul 6(disz)-kam-ma| As Inanna was entering the 6th gate 
{na4}nunuz-tab-ba nig2 TUR-TUR| The man removed the necklace of tiny(?) ovoid beads upon her chest 
si-a| Be satisfied, Inanna! This is the rite of the netherworld that is being completed 
{d}a-nun-ke4-e-ne| The seven judges of the Anuna judged her case before her(?) 
{gesz}gag-ta| He hung her from a peg 
mu| After seven years, seven months and seven days elapsed(?) 
giri3-ni| She took a single path to the Ekur, the temple of Enlil 
sahar kur-ra-ka| No one should be allowed to mix your good quality silver with the unrefined ore of the mountain 
gesz nagar-x| No one should be allowed to split apart your boxwood among the wood of the carpenter 
bi2-du11 ki gal-e| My child wished for great heaven and the great earth 
an gal-ta ki gal-sze3 gesztu2-ga-ni na-an-gub| From the great heaven she set her mind on the great below. 
dingir an gal-ta ki gal-sze3 gesztu2-ga-ni na-an-gub| From the great heaven the goddess set her mind on the great below. 
{d}inanna an gal-ta ki gal-sze3 gesztu2-ga-ni na-an-gub| From the great heaven Inana set her mind on the great below. 
nin-gu10 an mu-un-szub ki mu-un-szub kur-ra ba-e-a-e11| My mistress abandoned heaven, abandoned earth, and descended to the underworld. 
{d}inanna an mu-un-szub ki mu-un-szub kur-ra ba-e-a-e11| Inana abandoned heaven, abandoned earth, and descended to the underworld. 
nam-en mu-un-szub nam-lagar mu-un-szub kur-ra ba-e-a-e11| She abandoned the office of en, abandoned the office of lagar, and descended to the underworld. 
unu{ki}-ga e2-an-na mu-un-szub kur-ra ba-e-a-e11| She abandoned the Eanna in Uruk, and descended to the underworld. 
bad3-tibira{ki}-a e2-musz3-kalam-ma mu-un-szub kur-ra ba-e-a-e11| She abandoned the E-muš-kalam in Bad-tibira, and descended to the underworld. 
zabala{ki}-a gi-gun4{ki}-na mu-un-szub kur-ra ba-e-a-e11| She abandoned the Giguna in zabala, and descended to the underworld. 
adab{ki}-a e2-szar-ra mu-un-szub kur-ra ba-e-a-e11| She abandoned the E-šara in Adab, and descended to the underworld. 
nibru{ki}-a bara2-dur2-gar-ra mu-un-szub kur-ra ba-e-a-e11| She abandoned the Bara-dur-gara in Nibru, and descended to the underworld. 
kisz{ki}-a hur-sag-kalam-ma mu-un-szub kur-ra ba-e-a-e11| She abandoned the Hursag-kalama in Kiš, and descended to the underworld. 
a-ga-de3{ki}-a e2-ul-masz{ki} mu-un-szub kur-a ba-e-a-e11| She abandoned the E-Ulmaš in Agade, and descended to the underworld. 
umma{ki}-a eb-gal mu-un-szub kur-ra ba-e-a-e11| She abandoned the Ebgal in Umma, and descended to the underworld. 
uri2{ki}-ma e2-dilmun-na mu-un-szub kur-ra ba-e-a-e11| She abandoned the E-Dilmuna in Ur, and descended to the underworld. 
kisig2{ki}-a amasz-e2-ku3 mu-un-szub kur-ra ba-e-a-e11| She abandoned the Amaš-e-ku in Kisiga, and descended to the underworld. 
gir2-su{ki}-a e2-esz2-dam-ku3 mu-un-szub kur-ra ba-e-a-e11| She abandoned the E-ešdam-ku in Girsu, and descended to the underworld. 
i3-si-in-na{ki} e2-szeg12-mu-sze3-du7 mu-un-szub kur-ra ba-e-a-e11| She abandoned the E-sig-meše-du in Isin, and descended to the underworld. 
akszak{ki}-a an-za-gar3 mu-un-szub kur-ra ba-e-a-e11| She abandoned the Anzagar in Akšak, and descended to the underworld. 
szuruppak{ki}-e nigin3-gar-ku3 mu-un-szub kur-ra ba-e-a-e11| She abandoned the Nigin-gar-ku in Šuruppak, and descended to the underworld. 
ka-zal-lu{ki} e2-sza3-hul2-la mu-un-szub kur-ra ba-e-a-e11| She abandoned the E-cag-hula in Kazallu, and descended to the underworld. 
me 7(disz)-bi za3 mu-ni-in-kesz2| She took the seven divine powers. 
me mu-un-ur4-ur4 szu-ni-sze3 mu-un-la2| She collected the divine powers and grasped them in her hand. 
me du10 giri3 gub-ba i-im-gen| With the good divine powers, she went on her way. 
tug2-szu-gur-ra men edin-na sag-ga2-na mu-un-gal2| She put a turban, headgear for the open country, on her head. 
hi-li sag-ki-na szu ba-ni-in-ti| She took a wig for her forehead. 
{na4}za-gin3 di4-di4-la2 gu2-na ba-an-la2| She hung small lapis-lazuli beads around her neck. 
na4-nunuz tab-ba gaba-na ba-ni-in-si| She placed twin egg-shaped beads on her breast. 
{tug2}pala3 tug2 nam-nin-a bar-ra-na ba-an-dul| She covered her body with a pala dress, the garment of ladyship. 
szembi lu2 he2-em-du he2-em-du igi-na ba-ni-in-gar| She placed mascara “Let a man come, let him come” on her eyes. 
tu-di-da lu2 ga2-nu ga2-nu gaba-na ba-an-gid2| She pulled the pectoral “Come, man, come” over her breast. 
har ku3-sig17 szu-na ba-an-du8| She placed a golden ring on her hand. 
gi-1(disz)-ninda2 esz2-GAN2 za-gin3 szu ba-ni-in-du8| She held the lapis-lazuli measuring rod and measuring line in her hand. 
{d}inanna kur-sze3 i-im-gen| Inanna traveled towards the underworld. 
sukkal-a-ni {d}ga-sza-an-szubur-ra egir-a-na i-im-gen| Her minister Ninšubur traveled behind her. 
ku3 {d}inanna-ke4 {d}nin-szubur-ra gu3 mu-na-de2-e| Holy Inanna says to Ninšubur: 
ga2-nu sukkal zi e2-an-na-gu10| “Come my faithful minister of Eanna, 
sukkal e-ne-ag2 sa6-sa6-ga-gu10| my minister who speaks fair words, 
ra-gaba e-ne-ag2 ge-en-ge-na-gu10| my escort who speaks trustworthy words 
u4-da kur-sze3 e11-de3-en| “On this day I will descend to the underworld. 
u4-da kur-sze3 gen-na-gu10-ne| When I have arrived in the underworld, 
er2 du6-du6-dam mar-mar-ma-ni-ib| make a lament for me on the ruin mounds. 
szem3 gu2-en-na du12-du12-a-ma-ni-ib| Beat the drum for me in the sanctuary. 
e2 dingir-re-e-ne nigin2-nigin2-na-ma-ni-ib| Make the rounds of the houses of the gods for me. 
i-bi2-zu hur-ma-ab giri17-zu hur-ma-ab| “Lacerate your eyes for me, lacerate your nose for me. 
ki mu-lu-da nu-di hasz4-gal-zu hur-ma-ab| In private, lacerate your buttocks for me. 
mu-lu nu-tuku-gin7 tug2 dili-a mu4-ma-ab| Like a pauper, clothe yourself in a single garment 
e2-kur-re e2 {d}mu-ul-lil2-la2-sze3 me-re-zu dili gub-mu-un| and all alone set your foot in the E-kur, the house of Enlil. 
e2-kur-re e2 {d}mu-ul-lil2-la2-sze3 ku4-ku4-da-zu-ne| “When you have entered the E-kur, the house of Enlil, 
i-bi2 {d}mu-ul-lil2-la2-sze3 er2 szesz2-a| lament before Enlil: 
a-a {d}mu-ul-lil2 du5-mu-zu mu-lu kur-ra nam-ba-da-an-gam-e| “Father Enlil, don’t let anyone kill your daughter in the underworld. 
ku3 sa6-ga-zu sahar kur-ra-ka nam-ba-da-ab-szar2-re| Don’t let your precious metal be alloyed there with the dirt of the underworld. 
za-gin3 sa6-ga-zu za zadim-ma-ka nam-ba-da-an-di-il-si-il| Don’t let your precious lapis lazuli be split there with the mason’s stone. 
{gesz}taszkarin-zu gesz nagar-ra-ka nam-ba-an-dar-dar-e| Don’t let your boxwood be chopped up there with the carpenter’s wood. 
ki-sikil {d}ga-sza-an-na kur-ra nam-ba-da-an-gam-e| Don’t let young lady Inanna be killed in the underworld.” 
u4-da {d}mu-ul-lil2 e-ne-eg3-ba nu-ri-gub uri2{ki}-sze3 gen-na| “If Enlil does not help you in this matter, go to Ur. 
uri2{ki} e2-mu12-kur-ra-ka| In the E-mukura at Ur, 
e2-kisz-nu-gal2 {d}nanna-sze3 ku4-ku4-da-zu-ne| when you have entered the E-kišnugal toward Nanna, 
i-bi2 {d}nanna-sze3 er2 szesz2-a| lament before Nanna: 
a-a {d}nanna du5-mu-zu mu-lu kur-ra nam-ba-da-an-gam-e| “Father Nanna, don’t let anyone kill your daughter in the underworld. 
ku3 sa6-ga-zu sahar kur-ra-ka nam-ba-da-ab-szar2-re| Don’t let your precious metal be alloyed there with the dirt of the underworld. 
za-gin3 sa6-ga-zu za zadim-ma-ka nam-ba-da-an-di-il-si-il| Don’t let your precious lapis lazuli be split there with the mason’s stone. 
{gesz}taszkarin-zu gesz nagar-ra-ka nam-ba-an-dar-dar-e| Don’t let your boxwood be chopped up there with the carpenter’s wood. 
ki-sikil {d}ga-sza-an-na kur-ra nam-ba-da-an-gam-e| Don’t let young lady Inanna be killed in the underworld.” 
u4-da {d}nanna e-ne-ag2-ba nu-ri-gub uru2-ze2-eb{ki}-sze3 gen-na| “And if Nanna does not help you in this matter, go to Eridu. 
uru2-ze-eb{ki} e2 {d}am-an-ki-ka3-sze3 ku4-ku4-da-zu-ne| In Eridu, when you have entered the house of Enki, 
i-bi2 {d}am-an-ki-ka3-sze3 er2 szesz2-am3| lament before Enki: 
a-a {d}am-an-ki du5-mu-zu mu-lu kur-ra nam-ba-da-an-gam-e| “Father Enki, don’t let anyone kill your daughter in the underworld. 
ku3 sa6-ga-zu sahar kur-ra-ka nam-ba-da-ab-szar2-re| Don’t let your precious metal be alloyed there with the dirt of the underworld. 
za-gin3 sa6-ga-zu za zadim-ma-ka nam-ba-da-an-di-il-si-il| Don’t let your precious lapis lazuli be split there with the mason’s stone. 
{gesz}taszkarin-zu gesz nagar-ra-ka nam-ba-an-dar-dar-e| Don’t let your boxwood be chopped up there with the carpenter’s wood. 
ki-sikil {d}ga-sza-an-na kur-ra nam-ba-da-an-gam-e| Don’t let young lady Inanna be killed in the underworld.” 
a-a {d}am-an-ki u3-mu-un mu-usz-gesz-tug2 da-ma-al-la-ke4| “Father Enki, the lord of great wisdom, 
u2 nam-ti-la mu-un-zu a nam-ti-la mu-un-zu| knows about the life-giving plant and the life-giving water. 
e-ne ma-ra hu-mu-un-ti-le-en| He is the one who will restore me to life.” 
{d}inanna kur-sze3 gen-na-ni-ta| When Inanna traveled on towards the underworld, 
sukkal-a-ni {d}nin-szubur-ra-ke4 egir-a-ni i3-im-gen| her minister Ninšubur traveled on behind her. 
sukkal-a-ni {d}nin-szubur-ra gu3 mu-na-de2-e| She says to her minister Ninšubur: 
gen-na {d}ga-sza-an-szubur-gu10 sag kesz2 he2-ak| “Go now, my Ninšubur, and pay attention. 
e-ne a-ra-du11-ga-gu10 gu2-zu la-ba-szi-szub| Don’t neglect the instructions I gave you.” 
{d}inanna e2-gal ganzer-sze3 um-ma-te| When Inanna arrived at the palace Ganzer, 
{gesz}ig kur-ra-ka szu hul ba-an-us2| she pushed aggressively on the door of the underworld. 
abul kur-ra-ka gu3 hul ba-an-de2| She shouted aggressively at the gate of the underworld: 
e2 gal2-u3 i3-du8 e2 gal2-u3| “Open up, doorman, open up. 
e2 gal2-u3 {d}ne-ti e2 gal2-u3 dili-gu10-sze3 ga-ku4| Open up, Neti, open up. I am all alone and I want to come in.” 
{d}ne-ti i3-du8 gal kur-ra-ke4| Neti, the chief doorman of the underworld, 
ku3 {d}inanna inim mu-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4| answers holy Inanna: 
a-ba-me-en za-e| “Who are you?” 
me-e {d}ga-sza-an na-na ki {d}utu e3-a-asz| “I am Inanna going to the east.” 
tukum-bi za-e {d}inanna ki {d}utu e3-a-asz| “If you are Inanna going to the east, 
a-na-am3 ba-du-un kur nu-gi4-sze3| why have you traveled to the land of no return? 
har-ra-an lu2 du-bi nu-gi4-gi4-de3 sza3-zu a-gin7 tum2-mu-un| How did you set your heart on the road whose traveller never returns?” 
ku3 {d}inanna-ke4 mu-na-ni-ib2-gi4-gi4| Holy Inanna answers him: 
nin9 gal-gu10 ku3 {d}ga-sza-an-ki-gal-la-ke4| “Because lord Gud-gal-ana, 
mu dam-a-ni u3-mu-un gu4-gal-an-na ba-an-ug5-ga| the husband of my elder sister holy Ereškigal, has died; 
ki-se3-ga-na i-bi2 du8-u3-de3| in order to have his funeral rites observed, 
kasz ki-se3-ga-na gu-ul ba-ni-in-de2 ur5 he2-na-nam-ma| she offers generous libations at his wake; that is the reason.” 
{d}ne-ti i3-du8 gal-kur-ra-ke4| Neti, the chief doorman of the underworld, 
ku3 {d}inanna-ra mu-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4| answers holy Inanna: 
gub-ba-a {d}inanna nin-ga2 ga-an-na-ab-du11| “Stay here, Inanna. I will speak to my mistress. 
nin-gu10 {d}eresz-ki-gal-la-ra ga-an-na-du11 inim-zu ga-an-na-ab-du11| I will speak to my mistress Ereškigal and tell her what you have said.” 
{d}ne-ti i3-du8 gal kur-ra-ke4| Neti, the chief doorman of the underworld, 
nin-a-ni {d}eresz-ki-gal-la-ra| to his mistress Ereškigal 
e2-a-ni-sze3 ba-szi-in-ku4 gu3 mu-na-de2| entered the house and said: 
nin-gu10 ki-sikil 1(disz)-am3| “My mistress, there is a lone girl outside. 
{d}inanna nin9-zu e2-gal ganzer-sze3 um-ma-te| It is Inanna, your sister, and she has arrived at the palace Ganzer. 
{gesz}ig kur-ra-ka szu hul ba-an-us2| She pushed aggressively on the door of the underworld. 
abul kur-ra-ka gu3 hul ba-an-de2| She shouted aggressively at the gate of the underworld. 
e2-an-na mu-un-szub kur-ra ba-e-a-e11| She has abandoned Eanna and has descended to the underworld. 
me 7(disz)-bi za3 mu-ni-in-kesz2| “She has taken the 7 divine powers. 
me mu-un-ur4-ur4 szu-ni-sze3 mu-un-la2| She has collected the divine powers and grasped them in her hand. 
me du10 giri3 gub-ba i-im-gen| She has come on her way with all the good divine powers. 
tug2-szu-gur-ra men edin-na sag-ga2-na mu-un-gal2| She has put a turban, headgear for the open country, on her head. 
hi-li sag-ki-na szu ba-ni-in-ti| She has taken a wig for her forehead. 
{na4}za-gin3 di4-di4-la2 gu2-na i-im-la2| She has hung small lapis-lazuli beads around her neck. 
na4-nunuz tab-ba gaba-na i-im-si| “She has placed twin egg-shaped beads on her breast. 
{tug2}pala3 nam-nin-a bar-ra-na i-im-dul| She has covered her body with the pala dress of ladyship. 
szembi lu2 he2-em-du igi-ni i-im-gar| She has placed mascara “Let a man come” on her eyes. 
tu-di-da lu2 ga2-nu ga2-nu gaba-na i-im-gid2| She has pulled the pectoral “Come, man, come” over her breast. 
har ku3-sig17 szu-na i-im-la2| She has placed a golden ring on her hand. 
gi-1(disz)-ninda esz2-GAN2 za-gin3 szu-na i-im-du8| She is holding the lapis-lazuli ‘reed-1-ninda’ measuring rod and measuring line in her hand.” 
u4-ba {d}eresz-ki-gal-la-ke4 hasz2 bar-bi bi2-in-ra| When she heard this, Ereškigal slapped the side of her thigh. 
nundum zu2 bi2-in-gub inim sza3-sze3 ba-ti| She bit her lip and took the words to heart. 
{d}ne-ti i3-du8 gal-ni-ir gu3 mu-na-de2-e| She says to Neti, her chief doorman: 
ga2-nu {d}ne-ti i3-du8 gal kur-ra-gu10| “Come Neti, my chief doorman of the underworld, 
inim a-ra-du11-ga-gu10 gu2-zu la-ba-an-szub-be2-en| don’t neglect the instructions I will give you. 
abul kur-ra 7(disz)-bi {gesz}si-gar-bi he2-eb-us2| Let the seven gates of the underworld be bolted. 
e2-gal ganzer dili-bi {gesz}ig-bi szu ha-ba-an us2| Then let each door of the palace Ganzer be opened separately. 
e-ne ku4-ku4-da-ni-ta| As for her, after she has entered, 
gam-gam-ma-ni tug2 zil-zil-la-ni-ta lu2 ba-an-de6| and crouched down and had her clothes removed, they will be carried away.” 
{d}ne-ti i3-du8 gal kur-ra-ke4| Neti, the chief doorman of the underworld, 
inim nin-a-na-sze3 sag kesz2 ba-szi-in-ak| paid attention to the instructions of his mistress. 
abul kur-ra 7(disz)-bi {gesz}si-gar-bi bi2-ib2-us2| He bolted the 7 gates of the underworld. 
e2-gal ganzer dili-bi {gesz}ig-bi szu ba-an-us2| Then he opened each of the doors of the palace Ganzer separately. 
ku3 {d}inanna-ra gu3 mu-na-de2-e| He says to holy Inanna: 
ga2-nu {d}inanna ku4-um-ma-ni| “Come on, Inanna, and enter.” 
{d}inanna ku4-ku4-da-ni-ta| And when Inanna entered, 
tug2-szu-gur-ra men edin-na sag-ga2-na lu2 ba-da-an-ze2-er| the turban, headgear for the open country, was removed from her head. 
ta-am3 ne-e| “What is this?” 
si-a {d}inanna me kur-ra-ke4 szu al-du7-du7| “Be satisfied, Inanna, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. 
{d}inanna garza kur-ra-ke4 ka-zu na-an-ba-e| Inanna, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld.” 
abul 2(disz)-kam-ma ku4-ku4-da-ni-ta| When she entered the 2nd gate, 
{na4}za-gin3 di4-di4-la2 gu2-na lu2 ba-da-an-ze2-er| the small lapis-lazuli beads were removed from her neck. 
ta-am3 ne-e| “What is this?” 
si-a {d}inanna me kur-ra-ke4 szu al-du7-du7| “Be satisfied, Inanna, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. 
{d}inanna garza kur-ra-ke4 ka-zu na-an-ba-e| Inanna, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld.” 
abul 3(disz)-kam-ma ku4-ku4-da-ni-ta| When she entered the 3rd gate, 
na4-nunuz tab-ba gaba-na lu2 ba-da-an-ze2-er| the twin egg-shaped beads were removed from her breast. 
ta-am3 ne-e| “What is this?” 
si-a {d}inanna me kur-ra-ke4 szu al-du7-du7| “Be satisfied, Inanna, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. 
{d}inanna garza kur-ra-ke4 ka-za na-an-ba-e| Inanna, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld.” 
abul 4(disz)-kam-ma ku4-ku4-da-ni-ta| When she entered the 4th gate, 
tu-di-da lu2 ga2-nu ga2-nu gaba-na lu2 ba-da-an-ze2-er| the pectoral “Come, man, come” was removed from her breast. 
ta-am3 ne-e| “What is this?” 
si-a {d}inanna me kur-ra-ke4 szu al-du7-du7| “Be satisfied, Inanna, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. 
{d}inanna garza kur-ra-ke4 ka-zu na-an-ba-e| Inanna, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld.” 
abul 5(disz)-kam-ma ku4-ku4-da-ni-ta| When she entered the 5th gate, 
har ku3-sig17 szu-na lu2 ba-da-an-ze2-er| the golden ring was removed from her hand. 
ta-am3 ne-e| “What is this?” 
si-a {d}inanna me kur-ra-ke4 szu al-du7-du7| “Be satisfied, Inanna, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. 
{d}inanna garza kur-ra-ke4 ka-zu na-an-ba-e| Inanna, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld.” 
abul 6(disz)-kam-ma ku4-ku4-da-ni-ta| When she entered the 6th gate, 
gi-1(disz)-ninda esz2-GAN2 za-gin3 szu-na lu2 ba-da-an-ze2-er| the lapis-lazuli measuring rod and measuring line were removed from her hand. 
ta-am3 ne-e| “What is this?” 
si-a {d}inanna me kur-ra-ke4 szu al-du7-du7| “Be satisfied, Inanna, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. 
{d}inanna garza kur-ra-ke4 ka-zu na-an-ba-e| Inanna, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld.” 
abul 7(disz)-kam-ma ku4-ku4-da-ni-ta| When she entered the 7th gate, 
{tug2}pala3 tug2 nam-nin-a bar-ra-na lu2 ba-da-an-ze2-er| the pala dress, the garment of ladyship, was removed from her body. 
ta-am3 ne-e| “What is this?” 
si-a {d}inanna me kur-ra-ke4 szu al-du7-du7| “Be satisfied, Inanna, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. 
{d}inanna garza kur-ra-ke4 ka-zu na-an-ba-e| Inanna, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld.” 
gam-gam-ma-ni tug2 zil-zil-la-ni-ta lu2 ma-an-de6| After she had crouched down and had her clothes removed, they were carried away. 
nin9-a-ni {gesz}gu-za-ni-ta im-ma-da-an-zi| Then she made her sister Ereškigal rise from her throne, 
e-ne {gesz}gu-za-ni-ta dur2 im-mi-in-gar| and instead she sat on her throne. 
{d}a-nun-na di-ku5 7(disz)-bi igi-ni-sze3 di mu-un-da-ku5-ru-ne| The Anuna, the seven judges, rendered their decision against her. 
igi mu-szi-in-bar i-bi2 usz2-a-kam| They looked at her—it was the look of death! 
inim i-ne-ne inim lipisz gig-ga-am3| They spoke to her—it was the speech of anger! 
gu3 i-ne-de2 gu3 nam-tag-tag-ga-am3| They shouted at her—it was the shout of heavy guilt! 
munus tu-ra uzu nig2 sag3-ga-sze3 ba-an-ku4| The afflicted woman was turned into a corpse! 
uzu nig2 sag3-ga {gesz}gag-ta lu2 ba-da-an-la2| And the corpse was hung on a hook. 
u4 3(disz) ge6 3(disz)-am3 um-ta-zal-la-ta| After 3 days and 3 nights had passed, 
sukkal-a-ni {d}nin-szubur-ra-ke4| her minister Ninšubur 
inim nin-a-na-sze3 gesztu2 ba-szi-in-gub| carried out the instructions of her mistress. 
er2 du6-du6-dam mu-un-na-ga2-ga2| She made a lament for her in her ruined (houses). 
szem3 gu2-en-ne mu-un-du12-a| She beat the drum for her in the sanctuaries. 
e2 dingir-re-e-ne-ke4 mu-un-na-nigin2-nigin2| She made the rounds of the houses of the gods for her. 
igi-ni mu-un-na-hur giri17-ni mu-un-hur| She lacerated her eyes for her, she lacerated her nose. 
ki lu2-da nu-u6-di hasz4-gal-a-ni mu-un-na-hur| In private she lacerated her buttocks for her. 
mu-lu nu-tuku-gin7 tug2 dili-a im-ma-an-mur10| Like a pauper, she clothed herself in a single garment, 
e2-kur e2 {d}en-lil2-la2-sze3 giri3-ni dili mu-un-gub| and all alone she set her foot in the E-kur, the house of Enlil. 
e2-kur e2 {d}en-lil2-la2-sze3 ku4-ku4-da-ni-ta| When she had entered the E-kur, the house of Enlil, 
igi {d}en-lil2-la2-sze3 er2 im-ma-sze8-sze8| she laments before Enlil: 
a-a {d}mu-ul-lil2 du5-mu-zu mu-lu kur-ra nam-ba-da-an-gam-e| “Father Enlil, don’t let anyone kill your daughter in the underworld. 
ku3 sa6-ga-zu sahar kur-ra-ka nam-ba-da-ab-szar2-e| Don’t let your precious metal be alloyed there with the dirt of the underworld. 
{na4}za-gin3 sa6-ga-zu za zadim-ka nam-ba-da-an-si-il-si-il| Don’t let your precious lapis lazuli be split there with the mason’s stone. 
{gesz}taszkarin-zu gesz nagar-ra-ka nam-ba-dar-dar-re| Don’t let your boxwood be chopped up there with the carpenter’s wood. 
ki-sikil {d}ga-sza-an-na kur-ra nam-ba-da-an-gam-e| Don’t let young lady Inanna be killed in the underworld.” 
a-a {d}en-lil2 lipisz bala-a-ni {d}nin-szubur-ra-ke4 mu-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4| In his rage father Enlil answers Ninšubur: 
dumu-gu10 an gal al bi2-in-du11 ki gal al bi2-in-du11| “My daughter craved the great heaven and she craved the great below as well. 
{d}inanna an gal al bi2-in-du11 ki gal al bi2-in-du11| Inanna craved the great heaven and she craved the great below as well. 
me kur-ra me al nu-di-da sa2 bi2-in-du11-ga-bi kur-re he2-eb-us2| The divine powers of the underworld are divine powers which should not be craved, for whoever gets them must remain in the underworld. 
a-ba-am3 ki-bi sa2 in-na-an-du11-e11-de3 al mu-ni-in-du11| Who, having got to that place, could then expect to come up again?” 
a-a {d}en-lil2 inim-bi nu-mu-na-gub uri2{ki}-sze3 ba-gen| Thus father Enlil did not help in this matter, so she went to Ur. 
uri2{ki} e2-mu12-kur-ra-ka| In the E-mud-kura at Ur, 
e2-kisz-nu-gal2 e2 {d}nanna-sze ku4-ku4-da-ni-ta| when she had entered the E-kišnugal, the house of Nanna, 
igi {d}nanna-sze3 er2 im-ma-sze8-sze8| she laments before Nanna: 
a-a {d}nanna du5-mu-zu mu-lu kur-ra nam-ba-da-an-gam-e| “Father Nanna, don’t let your daughter be killed in the underworld. 
ku3 sa6-ga-zu sahar kur-ra-ka nam-ba-da-ab-szar2-e| Don’t let your precious metal be alloyed there with the dirt of the underworld. 
{na4}za-gin3 sa6-ga-zu za zadim-ka nam-ba-da-an-si-il-si-il-i| Don’t let your precious lapis lazuli be split there with the mason’s stone. 
{gesz}taszkarin-zu gesz nagar-ra-ka nam-ba-dar-dar-re| Don’t let your boxwood be chopped up there with the carpenter’s wood. 
ki-sikil {d}ga-sza-an-na kur-ra nam-ba-da-an-gam-e| Don’t let young lady Inanna be killed in the underworld.” 
a-a {d}nanna lipisz bala-a-ni {d}nin-szubur-ra-ke4 mu-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4| In his rage father Nanna answers Ninšubur: 
dumu-gu10 an gal al bi2-in-du11 ki gal al bi2-in-du11| “My daughter craved the great heaven and she craved the great below as well. 
{d}inanna an gal al bi2-in-du11 ki gal al bi2-in-du11| Inanna craved the great heaven and she craved the great below as well. 
me kur-ra me al nu-di-da sa2 bi2-in-du11-ga-bi kur-re he2-eb-us2| The divine powers of the underworld are divine powers which should not be craved, for whoever gets them must remain in the underworld. 
a-ba-am3 ki-bi sa2 in-na-an-du11-e11-de3 al mu-ni-in-du11| Who, having got to that place, could then expect to come up again?” 
a-a {d}nanna inim-bi nu-mu-na-gub uru2-ze2-eb{ki}-sze3 ba-gen| Thus father Nanna did not help her in this matter, so she went to Eridu. 
uru2-ze2-eb{ki} e2 {d}en-ki-ka3-sze3 ku4-ku4-da-ni-ta| In Eridu, when she had entered the house of Enki, 
igi {d}en-ki-ka3-sze3 er2 im-ma-sze8-sze8| xshe laments before Enki:xx 
a-a {d}en-ki du5-mu-zu mu-lu kur-ra nam-ba-da-an-gam-e| “Father Enki, don’t let anyone kill your daughter in the underworld. 
ku3 sa6-ga-zu sahar-ka nam-ba-da-ab-szar2-e| Don’t let your precious metal be alloyed there with the dirt of the underworld. 
{na4}za-gin3 sa6-ga-zu za zadim-ka nam-ba-da-an-si-il-si-il-i| Don’t let your precious lapis lazuli be split there with the mason’s stone. 
{gesz}taszkarin-zu gesz nagar-ra-ka nam-ba-dar-dar-re| Don’t let your boxwood be chopped up there with the carpenter’s wood. 
ki-sikil {d}ga-sza-an-na kur-ra nam-ba-da-an-gam-e| Don’t let young lady Inanna be killed in the underworld.” 
a-a {d}en-ki {d}nin-szubur-ra-ke4 mu-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4| Father Enki answered Ninšubur: 
dumu-gu10 a-na bi2-in-ak ge26-e mu-un-kusz2-u| “What has my daughter done? She has me worried. 
{d}inanna a-na bi2-in-ak ge26-e mu-un-kusz2-u| What has Inanna done? She has me worried. 
nin kur-kur-ra-ke4 a-na bi2-in-ak ge26-e mu-un-kusz2-u| What has the mistress of all the lands done? She has me worried. 
nu-u8-gig an-na-ke4 a-na bi2-in-ak ge26-e mu-un-kusz2-u| What has the hierodule of An done? She has me worried.” 
umbin-si-in mu-dur7 ba-ra-an-de6 kur-gar-ra-asz ba-an-dim2| He removed some dirt from the tip of his fingernail and created the kur-gar. 
umbin-si 2(disz)-kam-ma mu-dur7 ba-ra-an-de6 gala-tur-ra-asz ba-an-dim2| He removed some dirt from the tip of his 2nd fingernail and created the gala-tur. 
kur-gar-ra u2 nam-ti-la ba-an-szum2| To the kur-gar he gave the life-giving plant. 
gala-tur-ra a nam-ti-la ba-an-szum2| To the gala-tura he gave the life-giving water. 
a-a {d}en-ki gala-tur-ra kur-gar-ra gu3 mu-na-de2-e| Then father Enki speaks out to the gala-tura and the kur-gar: 
gen-na-an-ze2-en giri3 kur-sze3 nu2-ba-an-ze2-en| Go and direct your steps to the underworld. 
{gesz}ig nim-gin7 dal-dal-e-de3-en-ze2-en| Flit past the door like flies. 
za-re lil2-gin7 gur-gur-re-de3-en-ze2-en| Slip through the door pivots like phantoms. 
ama-gan-e nam dumu-ne-ne-sze3| The birth-mother, on account of her children, 
eresz-ki-gal-la-ke4 i-nu2-nu2-ra-am3| Ereškigal, is lying there. 
mur ku3-ga-na gada nu-um-bur2| Her holy shoulders are not covered by a linen cloth. 
gaba-ni bur szagan-gin7 nu-um-gid2| Her breasts are not full like a cagan vessel. 
szu-si-ni {uruda}lub-bi-gin7 am3-da-gal2| Her nails are like a pickaxe (?) upon her. 
siki-ni ga-rasz{sar}-gin7 sag-ga2-na mu-un-ur4-ur4-re| The hair on her head is bunched up as if it were leeks. 
u-u8-a sza3-gu10 du11-ga-ni| “When she says “Oh my heart,” 
kusz2-u3-me-en nin-me a sza3-zu du11-ga-zu-ne-ne| you are to say “You are troubled, our mistress, oh your heart.” 
u-u8-a bar-gu10 du11-ga-ni| When she says “Oh my liver,” 
kusz2-u3-me-en nin-me a bar-zu du11-ga-zu-ne-ne| you are to say “You are troubled, our mistress, oh your liver.” 
a-ba-am3 za-e-me-en-ze2-en| (She will then ask:) “Who are you? 
sza3-gu10-ta sza3-zu-sze3 bar-gu10-ta bar-zu-sze3 du11-ga-na-ab-ze2-en| Speaking to you from my heart to your heart, from my liver to your liver— 
dingir he2-me-en-ze2-en inim ga-mu-ra-an-du11| if you are gods, let me talk with you; 
lu2-ulu3 he2-me-en-ze2-en nam-zu-ne he2-eb-tar-re| if you are mortals, may a destiny be decreed for you.” 
zi an-na zi ki-a pa3-de2-ne-ze2-na-am3| Make her swear this by heaven and earth. 
a i7-bi ma-ra-ba-e-ne szu nam-ba-gid2-i-en-ze2-en| They will offer you a riverful of water—don’t accept it. 
a-sza3 sze-ba ma-ra-ba-e-ne szu nam-ba-gid2-i-en-ze2-en| They will offer you a field with its grain—don’t accept it. 
uzu nig2 sag3-ga {gesz}gag-ta la2 szum2-me-ab du11-ga-na-ab-ze2-en| But say to her: “Give us the corpse hanging on the hook.” 
uzu nig2 sag3-ga ga-sza-an-zu-ne-ne| (She will answer:) “That is the corpse of your queen.” 
nig2 lugal-me en he2-a nig2 nin-bi he2-a szum2-ma-ze2-en du11-ga-na-ab-ze2-en| Say to her: “Whether it is that of our king, whether it is that of our queen, give it to us.” 
uzu nig2 sag3-ga {gesz}gag-ta la2-a im-ma-da-ab-szum2-mu-ze2-en| She will give you the corpse hanging on the hook. 
1(disz)-am3 u2 nam-ti-la 1(disz)-am3 a nam-ti-la ugu-na szub-bu-de3-en-ze2-en| 1 of you sprinkle on it the life-giving plant and 1 the life-giving water. 
{d}inanna ha-ba-gub| Thus let Inanna rise up.” 
gala-tur kur-gar-ra inim {d}en-ki-ka3-sze3 sag kesz2 ba-szi-in-ak-esz| The gala-tura and the kur-gar paid attention to the instructions of Enki. 
{gesz}ig nim-gin7 mu-un-dal-dal| They flitted through the door like flies. 
za-ra lil2-gin7 mu-un-gur-gur| They slipped through the door pivots like phantoms. 
ama gan-e nam dumu-ne-ne-sze3| The birth-mother, because of her children, 
{d}eresz-ki-gal-la-ke4 i-nu2-nu2-re-am3| Ereškigal, was lying there. 
mur ku3-ga-na gada nu-un-bur2| Her holy shoulders were not covered by a linen cloth. 
gaba-ni bur szagan-na nu-un-gid2| Her breasts were not full like a cagan vessel. 
szu-si-ni {uruda}lub-bi-gin7 an-da-gal2| Her nails were like a pickaxe (?) upon her. 
siki-ni ga-rasz{sar}-gin7 sag-ga2-na mu-un-ur4-ur4| The hair on her head was bunched up as if it were leeks. 
u3-u8-a sza3-gu10 du11-ga-ni| When she said “Oh my heart,” 
kusz2-u3-me-en nim-me a sza3-zu in-na-ne-esz| they said to her “You are troubled, our mistress, oh your heart.” 
u3-u8-a bar-gu10 du11-ga-ni| When she said “Oh my liver,” 
kusz2-u3-me-en nin-me a bar-zu in-na-ne-esz| they said to her “You are troubled, our mistress, oh your liver.” 
a-ba-am3 za-e-me-en-ze2-en| (Then she asked:) “Who are you? 
sza3-gu10-ta sza3-zu-sze3 bar-gu10-ta bar-zu-sze3 ba-e-de3-en-ze2-en| I tell you from my heart to your heart, from my liver to your liver— 
dingir he2-me-en-ze2-en inim ga-mu-ra-an-du11| if you are gods, I will talk with you; 
lu2-ulu3 he2-me-en-ze2-en nam-zu-ne ga-mu-re-eb-tar| if you are mortals, may a destiny be decreed for you.” 
zi an-na zi ki-a mu-ni-in-pa3-de3-esz| They made her swear this by heaven and earth. 
i7 a-ba mu-ne-ba-e szu nu-um-ma-gid2-de3| they were offered a river with its water—they did not accept it. 
a-sza3 sze-ba mu-ne-ba-e szu nu-um-ma-gid2-de3| They were offered a field with its grain—they did not accept it. 
uzu nig2 sag3-ga {gesz}gag-ta la2 szum2-me-eb in-na-an-ne-esz| They said to her: “Give us the corpse hanging on the hook.” 
ku3 {d}eresz-ki-gal-la-ke4 gala-tur kur-garza mu-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4| Holy Ereškigal answers the gala-tura and the kur-gar: 
uzu nig2 sag3-ga nig2 ga-sza-an-zu-ne-ne-kam| “The corpse is that of your queen.” 
nig2 lugal-me nig2 nin-me he2-a szum2-me-eb in-na-an-ne-esz| They said to her: “Whether it is that of our king or that of our queen, give it to us.” 
uzu nig2 sag3-ga {gesz}gag-ta la2 im-me-ne-szum2-usz| They were given the corpse hanging on the hook. 
1(disz)-am3 u2 nam-ti-la 1(disz)-am3 a nam-ti-la ugu-a bi2-in-szub-bu-usz| 1 of them sprinkled on it the life-giving plant and 1 the life-giving water. 
{d}inanna ba-gub| And thus Inanna rose up. 
{d}eresz-ki-gal-la gala-tur kur-gar-ra gu3 mu-na-de2-e| Ereškigal says to the gala-tura and the kur-gar: 
{d}inanna inim {d}en-ki-ka3-ta kur-ta e11| Inanna, because of Enki’s instructions, was about to ascend from the underworld. 
{d}inanna kur-ta e11-da-ni| But as Inanna was about to ascend from the underworld, 
{d}a-nun-na-ke4-e-ne ba-ab-ha-za-asz| the Anuna seized her: 
a-ba-am3 lu2 kur-ta im-ta-e11-de3 kur-ta silim-ma-ni bi2-in-e11-de3| “Who has ever ascended from the underworld, has ascended unscathed from the underworld? 
u4-da {d}inanna kur-ta-ba-e11-de3| If Inanna is to ascend from the underworld, 
sag-dili sag-ga2-na ha-ba-ab-szum2-mu| let her provide a substitute for herself.” 
{d}inanna kur-ta ba-e11-de3| So when Inanna left the underworld, 
lu2 igi-na sukkal nu-me-a {gesz}gidri szu bi2-in-du8| the one in front of her, though not a minister, held a sceptre in his hand; 
bar-ra-na ra-gaba nu-me-a {gesz}tukul ur2-ra bi2-in-la2| the one behind her, though not an escort, carried a mace at his hip, 
gal5-la2 tur-tur gi-szukur-gin7| while the small demons, like a reed enclosure, 
gal5-la2 gal-gal gi dub-ba-an-na-gin7 za3-ga-na ba-an-dab5-be-esz| and the big demons, like the reeds of a fence, restrained her on all sides. 
lu2 e-ne-ra in-szi-re7-esz-am3| Those who accompanied her, 
lu2 {d}inanna-ra in-szi-re7-esz-am3| those who accompanied Inanna, 
u2 nu-zu-me-esz a nu-zu-me-esz| know no food, know no drink, 
zi3 dub-dub-ba nu-gu7-me-esz| eat no flour offering 
a bala-bala-a nu-na8-na8-me-esz| and drink no libation. 
kadra nig2 du10-ge szu nu-gid2-me-esz| They accept no pleasant gifts. 
ubur ummeda{da} la2-ka dumu szu ti-a-me-esz| They take away the child hanging on a wet-nurse’s breasts. 
szum2{sar} nig2-ses-a nu-gum-e-me-esz| They crush no bitter garlic. 
lu2 ku6 nu-gu7-me-esz lu2 ga-rasz{sar} nu-gu7-me-esz| They eat no fish, they eat no leeks. 
lu2 {d}inanna mu-un-szi-re7-esz-am3| They, it was, who accompanied Inanna. 
{d}inanna kur-ta e11-da-ni| After Inanna had ascended from the underworld, 
{d}nin-szubur-ra-ke4 kan4 ganzer-ra-ka giri3-ni-sze3 ba-an-szub| Ninšubur threw herself at her feet at the door of the Ganzer. 
sahar-ra ba-da-an-tusz tug2-mu-dur7-ra ba-an-mu12| She had sat in the dust and clothed herself in a filthy garment. 
gal5-la2-e-ne ku3 {d}inanna-ra gu3 mu-un-na-de2-e| The demons said to holy Inanna: 
{d}inanna iri-zu-sze3 gen-ba e-ne ga-ba-ab-tum2-mu-de3-en| “Inanna, proceed to your city, we will take her back.” 
ku3 {d}inanna-ke4 gal5-la2-e-ne mu-un-ne-ni-gi4-gi4| Holy Inanna answers the demons: 
sukkal e-ne-ag2 sa6-sa6-ga-gu10| “This is my minister of fair words, 
ra-gaba e-ne-ag2 ge-en-gi-na-gu10| my escort of trustworthy words. 
na de5-ga-gu10 szu nu-un-bar-re| She did not forget my instructions. 
e-ne-ag2 ma-ra-ab-du11-ga-gu10-usz gu2-ni la-ba-da-an-szi-szub| She did not neglect the orders I gave her. 
er2 du6-du6-dam ma-an-ga2-ga2| She made a lament for me on the ruin mounds. 
szem3 gu2-en-na ma-an-du12-am3| She beat the drum for me in the sanctuaries. 
e2 dingir-re-e-ne ma-an-nigin2-nigin2| She made the rounds of the gods’ houses for me. 
i-bi2-ni ma-an-hur giri17-ni ma-an-hur| She lacerated her eyes for me, lacerated her nose for me. 
ki mu-lu-da nu-di hasz4-gal-a-ni ma-an-hur| In private, she lacerated her buttocks for me. 
mu-lu nu-tuku-gin7 tug2 dili-a im-ma-an-mu12| Like a pauper, she clothed herself in a single garment. 
e2-kur-re e2 {d}mu-ul-lil2-la2-sze3| “To the house of Enlil, 
uri5{ki}-ma e2 {d}nanna-sze3| and to Ur, to the house of Nanna, 
uru2-ze2-eb{ki} e2 {d}am-an-ki-ka3-sze3| and to Eridu, to the house of Enki, 
giri3-ni dili mu-un-gub| all alone she directed her steps. 
e-ne ma-a-ra mu-un-ti-le-en| She brought me back to life. 
e-ne ta-gin7 nam-ma-ra-ab-ze2-eg3-en-ze-en| How could I turn her over to you? 
ga-an-szi-re7-de3-en umma{ki}-a szeg12-kur-sza3-ga-sze3 ga-am3-szi-re7-de3-en| Let us go on. Let us go on to the Šegkuršaga in Umma.” 
umma{ki}-a szeg12-kur-sza3-ga-ta| At the Šegkuršaga in Umma, 
{d}szara2 iri-ni-a giri3-ni-sze3 ba-an-szub| Šara, in his own city, threw himself at her feet. 
sahar-ra ba-da-an-tusz tug2-mu-dur7-ra ba-an-mu12| He had sat in the dust and dressed himself in a filthy garment. 
gal5-la2-e-ne ku3 {d}inanna-ra gu3 mu-na-de2-e| The demons say to holy Inanna: 
{d}inanna iri-zu-sze3 gen-ba e-ne ga-ba-ab-tum2-mu-de3| “Inanna, proceed to your city, we will take him back.” 
ku3 {d}inanna-ke4 gal5-la2-e-ne mu-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4| Holy Inanna answered the demons: 
en3-du du {d}szara2-gu10| “Šara is my singer, 
umbin ku5-ku5-ra-gu10 gu2-tar la2-gu10| my manicurist and my hairdresser. 
en3 ta-gin7 nam-ma-ra-ni-ib-ze2-eg3-gen| How could I turn him over to you? 
ga-e-re7-en-de3-en ba3-tibira{ki}-a e2-musz3-kalam-ma-sze3 ga-an-szi-re7-en-de3-en| Let us go on. Let us go on to the E-muškalama in Bad-tibira.” 
bad3-tibira{ki}-a e2-musz3-kalam-ma-ta| At the E-muškalama in Bad-tibira, 
{d}lu2-lal3-e iri-ni-a giri3-ni-sze3 ba-an-szub| Lulal, in his own city, threw himself at her feet. 
sahar-a im-da-an-tusz tug2-mu-dur7-ra ba-an-mu12| He had sat in the dust and clothed himself in a filthy garment. 
gal5-la2-e-ne ku3 {d}inanna-ra gu3 mu-na-de2-e| The demons said to holy Inanna: 
{d}inanna iri-zu-sze3 gen-ba e-ne ga-ba-ab-tum2-mu-ub-de3-en| “Inanna, proceed to your city, we will take him back.” 
ku3 {d}inanna-ke4 gal5-la2-e-ne mu-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4| Holy Inanna answers the demons: 
{d}lu2-lal3 za3 e3-a a2 zi-da gab2-ba-gu10 us2-sa| “Outstanding Lulal follows me at my right and my left. 
e-ne ta-gin7 nam-ma-ra-ab-ze2-eg3-en-ze2-en| How could I turn him over to you? 
ga-e-re7-de3-en {gesz}haszhur gul-la edin kul-aba4{ki}-sze3 ga-an-szi-re7-en-de3-en| Let us go on. Let us go on to the great apple tree in the plain of Kulaba.” 
{gesz}haszhur gul-la edin kul-aba4{ki}-sze3 giri3-ni-sze3 ba-e-re7{re}-esz| They followed her to the great apple tree in the plain of Kulaba. 
{d}dumu-zi tug2 mah-a i-im-mu12 mah-a dur2-a dur2 im-ma-gar| There was Dumuzi clothed in a magnificent garment and seated magnificently on a throne. 
gal5-la2-e-ne hasz4-a-na i-im-dab5-be2-esz| The demons seized him there by his thighs. 
{dug}szakir 7(disz)-e ga mu-un-de2-esz-am3| The 7 of them poured the milk from his churns. 
sipa-de3 gi-gid2 gi-di-da igi-ni szu nu-mu-un-tag-ge-ne| They would not let the shepherd play the pipe and flute before her (?). 
igi mu-un-szi-in-bar igi us2-a-ka| She looked at him, it was the look of death. 
inim i-ne-ne inim lipisz gig-ga| She spoke to him (?), it was the speech of anger. 
gu3 i-ne-de2 gu3 nam-tag-tag-ga| She shouted at him (?), it was the shout of heavy guilt: 
en3-sze3 tum3-mu-an-ze2-en| “How much longer? Take him away.” 
ku3 {d}inanna-ke4 su8-ba {d}dumu-zi-da szu-ne-ne-a in-na-szum2| Holy Inanna gave Dumuzi the shepherd into their hands. 
lu2 e-ne lu2 mu-un-ne-re7-esz-am3| Those who had accompanied her, 
lu2 {d}dumu-zi mu-un-szi-re7-esz-am3| who had come for Dumuzi, 
u2 nu-zu-me-esz a nu-zu-me-esz| know no food, know no drink, 
zi3 dub-dub-ba nu-gu7-me-esz| eat no flour offering, 
a bala-bala-a nu-na8-na8-me-esz| drink no libation. 
ur2 dam nig2 du10-ge-esz2 nu-sig9-ge-esz| They never enjoy the pleasures of the marital embrace, 
dumu nig2-ku7-ku7-da ne nu-su-ub-me-esz| never have any sweet children to kiss. 
dumu lu2 du10-ub-ta ba-ra-an-zi-ge-esz| They snatch the son from a man’s knee. 
e2-gi4-a e2 uszbar-ra-ka um-ta-an-e3-esz| They make the bride leave the house of her father-in-law. 
{d}dumu-zi-de3 er2 im-da-pa4 szex(SIG7)-szex(SIG7) i3-ga2-ga2| Dumuzi let out a wail and turned very pale. 
gurusz-e {d}utu-ra an-sze3 szu-ni ba-an-na-zi| The lad raised his hands to heaven, to Utu: 
{d}utu murum5-gu10-me-en ge26-e mussa-zu-me-en| “Utu, you are my brother-in-law. 
e2 ama-zu-sze3 i3 gur3-ru-me-en| I am your relation by marriage. I brought butter oil to your mother’s house 
e2 {d}nin-gal-sze3 ga gur3-ru-me-en| I brought cheese to Ningal’s house. 
szu-gu10 szu musz-a u3-mu-ni-in-szum2| Turn my hands into snake’s hands 
giri3-gu10 giri3 musz-a u3-mu-ni-in-szum2| and turn my feet into snake’s feet, 
gal5-la2-gu10 ga-ba-da-kar nam-mu-un-ha-za-ne| so I can escape my demons, let them not keep hold of me.” 
{d}utu er2-na szu ba-an-szi-in-ti| Utu accepted his tears. 
szu-ni szu musz-a mu-e-ni-szum2| Utu turned Dumuzi’s hands into snake’s hands. 
giri3-ni giri3 musz-a mu-e-ni-szum2| He turned his feet into snake’s feet. 
gal5-la2-e-ne ba-ni-kar| Dumuzi escaped his demons. 
ku3 {d}inanna-ke4 mu-ud-na-ni er2 gig i3-sze8-sze8| Holy Inanna wept bitterly for her husband. 
{u2}numun2 i3-bur12-re {u2}numun2 i3-ze2-e| She tore at her hair like esparto grass, she ripped it out like esparto grass. 
dam lu2 ur2-zu-ne-ne nu2-a me dam kal-la-gu10| “You wives who lie in your men’s embrace, where is my precious husband? 
dumu lu2 ur2-zu-ne-ne nu2-a me dumu kal-la-gu10| You children who lie in your men’s embrace, where is my precious child? 
nim-e-ku3 {d}inanna-ra gu3 mu-na-de2-e| A fly speaks to holy Inanna: 
ge26-e ki lu2-zu ga-mu-re-pa4 a-na-am3 nig2-ba-gu10-um| “If I show you where your man is, what will be my reward?” 
ku3 {d}inanna-ke4 nim-e mu-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4| Holy Inanna answers the fly: 
za-e ki mu-lu-gu10 ba-ab-pa4-de3-en nig2-ba a-ra-ba-e| “If you show me where my man is, I will give you this gift: 
ki-sikil {d}inanna-ke4 nim-e nam mu-ni-ib2-tar-re| The young lady Inanna decreed the destiny of the fly: 
du5-mu lu2 ku3-zu-ke4-ne-gin7 nam x| You will live (?) like the sons of the wise.” 
i3-ne-esz2 nam-tar-ra {d}inanna-ke4 ur5 he2-en-ne-nam-ma-am3| Now Inanna decreed this fate and thus it came to be. 
za-e mu ba7-am3 nin9-zu mu ba7-am3| You for half the year and your sister for half the year: 
u4 za-e al di-di-e u4-bi he2-tusz-e| when you are demanded, on that day you will stay, 
u4 nin9-zu al di-di-e u4-bi he2-gur2-e| when your sister is demanded, on that day you will be released.”

egir a-ma-ru ba-ur3-ra-ta| After the flood had swept over 
u3 ge16-le-eg3 kur-ra-ke4 ba-an-gar-ra-ta| and brought about the destruction of the countries;

u4-ba a lagasz{ki} du3| In those days, because the water of Lagaš was held back, 
gir2-su{ki} sza3-gar i3-gal2-am3| there was famine in Ĝirsu. 
i7 nu-un-dun-na-am3| Canals were not dug, 
e pa5-re szu-luh nu-ak-am3| the levees and ditches were not cleaned. 
GAN2-ne2 GAN2 zi-de3 a he2-gal2-la nu-un-de2| there was no water to irrigate abundantly all the cultivated fields:

gu2 nu-mu-un-il2| it bore no yield.

u4 ne u4 te-en-e um-ma-te-a-ta| One day, after the evening had arrived,

u4-ba MUSZ3.KA.UL e2-din {d}SZE.TIR-ka| It was then that the cupbearer of Ezina's wine-house,
{disz}szar-ru-um-ki-in u3-sa2-gin7 la-ba-nu2 ma-mu2-de3 ba-nu2| Sargon, lay down not to sleep, but lay down to dream.
ku3 {d}inanna-ke4 ma-mu2 i7 mud-sze3 mu-un-gir5-gir5| In the dream, holy inanna drowned Ur-Zababa in a river of blood.
{disz}szar-ru-um-ki-in dum-dam-ma-na zu2 ki-sze3 ba-da-ab-ra-ah| The sleeping Sargon groaned and gnawed the ground.

MUSZ3.KA.UL ma-mu2 ge6 u3-na x-na u3-mu-ri-du8| "Cupbearer, was a dream revealed to you in the night?"
{disz}szar-ru-um-ki-in lugal-a-ni im-ma-ni-ib-gi4-gi4| Sargon answered his king:
lugal-gu10 ma-mu2-gu10 u3-mu-ri-du11-ga| My king, this is my dream, which I will tell you about:
{lu2}ki-sikil 1(disz)-am3 an-gin7 sukud-da-ni ki-gin7 dagal-la-ni| There was a young woman who was as high as the heavens and as broad as the earth.
suhusz bad3-da-gin7 gar-gar-ra| She was firmly set as the base of a wall.
i7 mah i7 mud-sze3 ga2-ra mu-un-gir5-re-de3-en| For me, she drowned you in a great river, a river of blood."

ne-esz2 MUSZ3.KA.UL zabar-szu-ga2 a-ra-x-ab-de6| Now then, when the cupbearer has delivered my bronze hand-mirror (?) to you

lugal-e 1(disz) szar-ru-um-ki-in gu3 mu-na-de2-e| The king spoke to Sargon:
gen-na zabar-szu-ga2 simug-gal-sze3 tum2-mu-na-ni-ib| "Go and deliver my bronze hand-mirror (?) to the chief smith!"
ku3 {d}inanna-ke4 za3 zi-da-ni musz3 nu-tum2-mu| Holy inanna, however, did not cease to stand at his right hand side,

e2-sikil-la e2 ku3-ga na-nam lu2 mud nu-mu-un-ku4-re| "The E-sikil is a holy house! No one polluted with blood should enter it!"
ka2 e2 nam tar-ra-ka simug-gal lugal-la-ke4 gaba mu-un-da-ri| Thus he met the chief smith of the king only at the gate of the fated house.
zabar-szu lugal-la-ke4 simug-gal-sze3 mu-un-de6-a-ta| After he delivered the king's bronze hand-mirror (?) to the chief smith,
{disz}szar-ru-um-ki-in u4 5(disz)-am3 u4 1(u)-am3 ba-zal-la-ta| After five or 10 days had passed, Sargon

GA2xMI-ka ki-tusz ku3-ga-ni {d}ur-{d}za-ba4-ba4 mi-ni-ib-hu-luh| Ur-Zababa became frightened in the bed-chamber, his holy residence.
sza3-ga-ni-sze3 mu-un-zu eme-na nu-ga2-ga2 lu2-da nu-mu-un-da-ab-be2| He realised what was it about, but did not put into words, did not discuss it with anyone.
u4-bi-ta inim im-ma gub-bu he2-gal2 im si-si-ge ba-ra-gal2-la-am3| In those days, although writing words on tablets existed, putting tablets into envelopes did not yet exist.
lugal {d}ur-{d}za-ba4-ba4 1(disz) szar-ru-um-ki-in dingir-re-e-ne szu du11-ga-ar| King Ur-Zababa despatched Sargon, the creature of the gods,
im-ma gub-bu nig2 ni2 ba-ug7-a-ta| with a message written on clay, which was about murdering Sargon
unu{ki}-ga lugal-za3-ge4-e-si szu ba-ni-ib-tag4-tag4| to Lugal-zage-si in Uruk.
ga2-nam-ma sig4 e2-an-na-sze3 giri3 mu-un-gub| "Come! He directed his steps to brick-built E-ana!"
lugal-za3-ge4-si sza3-ga-ni nu-un-zu ugu kin-gi4-a nu-mu-un-du11-du11| Lugal-zage-si did not grasp it, he did not talk to the envoy.
en-e u8 bi2-in-du11 sahar-ra ba-an-da-tusz| "Alas!" and sat in the dust.
lugal-za3-ge4-si kin-gi4-a-ar im-szi-in-gi4| Lugal-zage-si replied to the envoy:
kin-gi4-a szar-ru-ki-in gu2 nu-mu-un-se3-se3| "Envoy, Sargon does not yield."
sag-ki gid2-da {d}en-lil2-la2-ke4| After Enlil’s frown 
kisz{ki} gu4 an-na-gin7 im-ug5-ga-ta| had slain Kiš as if it were the Bull of Heaven, 
e2 ki unu{ki}-ga gu4 mah-gin7 sahar-ra mi-ni-ib-gaz-a-ta| had slaughtered the house of the land of Uruk in the dust as if it were a mighty bull, 
ki u4-ba szar-ru-ge lugal a-ga-de3{ki}-ra| Then, to Sargon, king of Agade, 
sig-ta igi-nim-sze3 {d}en-lil2-le| from the south as far as the highlands did Enlil 
nam-en nam-lugal-la mu-un-na-an-szum2-ma-ta| give the rulership and kingship. 
u4-ba esz3 a-ga-de3{ki} ku3 {d}inanna-ke4| at that time, holy inanna established the sanctuary of Agade 
ama5 mah-a-ni-sze3 im-ma-an-du3-du3| as her celebrated woman’s domain; 
ul-masz{ki}-a {gesz}gu-za ba-ni-in-gub| she set up her throne in Ulmaš. 
lu2-tur gibil-bi e2 du3-u3-gin7| Like a young man building a house for the first time, 
dumu banda3{da} ama5 ga2-ga2-gin7| like a girl establishing a woman’s domain, 
e2 nig2-gur11-ra nig2 sa2 di-de3| So that the warehouses would be provisioned; 
iri{ki}-bi dur2 ki gar szum2-mu-de3| that dwellings would be founded in the city; 
ug3-bi u2 nir-gal2 gu7-u3-de3| that its people would eat splendid food; 
ug3-bi a nir-gal2 na8-na8-de3| that its people would drink splendid beverages; 
sag a tu5-a kisal hul2-le-de3| that those bathed for holidays would rejoice in the courtyards; 
ki ezem-ma ug3 sig7-ge-de3| that the people would throng the places of celebration; 
lu2 zu-u3-ne tesz2-bi gu7-u3-de3| that acquaintances would dine together; 
lu2 bar-ra muszen nu-zu-gin7 an-na nigin2-nigin2-de3| that foreigners would cruise about like unusual birds in the sky; 
mar-ha-szi{ki} le-um-ma gur-ru-de3| that even Marhaši would be re-entered on the tribute rolls; 
{ugu}ugu4-bi am-si mah ab2-za-za u2-ma-am ki bad-ra2| that monkeys, mighty elephants, water buffalo, exotic animals 
sza3 sila dagal-la-ke4 tesz2-bi tag-tag-ge-de3| would jostle each other in the public squares. 
ur-gi7 ur-nim dara3 kur-ra udu a-lum SIKI.SU3 si| as well as thoroughbred dogs, lions, {mountain ibexes}, and alum sheep with long wool 
ku3 {d}inanna-ke4 u3 nu-um-szi-ku-ku| holy inanna did not sleep as she ensured all of this. 
u4-ba a-ga-de3{ki} e2 ziz2-a-ba ku3-sig17 mi-ni-in-si| She then filled Agade’s stores for emmer wheat with gold, 
e2 ziz2 babbar-ra-ba ku3-babbar mi-ni-in-si| she filled its stores for white emmer wheat with silver; 
E2.USZ.BU.DA sze-ba uruda nagga {na4}lagab za-gin3-na sa2 im-mi-in-du11-du11| she delivered copper, tin, and blocks of lapis lazuli to its granaries 
guru7-bi bar-ta im ba-an-ur3| and sealed its silos from outside. 
um-ma-bi ad gi4-gi4 ba-an-szum2| She endowed its old women with the gift of giving counsel, 
ab-ba-bi ka-inim-ma ba-an-szum2| she endowed its old men with the gift of eloquence. 
ki-sikil-bi KI.E.NE.DI ba-an-szum2| She endowed its young women with the gift of entertaining, 
gurusz-bi a2 {gesz}tukul-la ba-an-szum2| she endowed its young men with martial might, 
di4-di4-la2-bi sza3 hul2-la ba-an-szum2| she endowed its little ones with joy 
UM.ME-ga-la2 szu gid2 dumu szagina-ke4-ne| The nursemaids who cared for the general’s children 
{gesz}al-gar-MA2.SIG7-da e-ne im-di-ne| played the drumsticks. 
iri{ki} sza3-bi tigi-a bar-bi-ta gi-gid2 za-am-za-am-ma| Inside the city tigi drums sounded; outside it, flutes and zamzam instruments. 
kar {gesz}ma2 us2-bi mud5-me-gar-ra| Its harbour where ships moored was full of joy. 
kur-kur u2-sal-la i-im-nu2| All foreign lands rested contentedly, 
ug3-bi ki sa6-ga igi bi2-ib-du8| and their people experienced happiness. 
lugal-bi sipa {d}na-ra-am-{d}suen-e| Its king, the shepherd Naram-Suen, 
bara2 ku3 a-ga-de3{ki}-sze3 u4-de3-esz2 im-e3| rose as the daylight on the holy throne of Agade. 
bad3-bi hur-sag-gin7 an-ne2 im-us2| Its city wall, like a mountain, reached the heavens. 
abul-a-ba {i7}idigna a-ab-ba-sze3 du-u3-gin7| Its city-gates were like the Tigris {going to} the sea 
ku3 {d}inanna-ke4 ka-bi gal2 bi2-in-tak4| when Inanna opened its portals 
ki-en-gi-ra nig2-gur11 ni2-ba-ta {gesz}ma2 im-da-gid2-de3| and made Sumer bring its own possessions upstream by boats. 
mar-tu kur-ra lu2 sze nu-zu| The highland Martu, people ignorant of agriculture, 
gu4 du7 masz2 du7-da mu-un-na-da-an-ku4-ku4| brought spirited cattle and kids for her. 
me-luh-ha{ki} lu2 kur ge6-ga-ke4| The Meluḫans, the people of the black land, 
nig2-szu kur2-kur2-ra mu-un-na-ra-ab-e11-de3| brought exotic wares up to her. 
elam{ki} su-bir4{ki} ansze bara2 la2-gin7 nig2 mu-na-ab-la2-la2| Elam and Subir loaded themselves with goods for her as if they were packasses. 
ensi2-ensi2 sanga-e-ne| All the governors, the temple administrators, 
sa12-du5 gu2-edin-na-ke4-ne| and the accountants of the Gu-edina 
nidba iti-da za3-mu-bi si am3-sa2-e-ne| regularly supplied the monthly and New Year offerings. 
abul a-ga-de3{ki}-ka a-gin7 kusz2 mi-ni-ib-gal2| What a weariness all these caused at Agade’s city gates! 
nidba-bi ku3 {d}inanna-ke4 szu te-ge26 nu-zu| Holy inanna could hardly receive all these offerings. 
dumu-gi7-gin7 e2 ki gar di-da la-la-bi nu-um-gi4| As if she were a citizen there, she could not restrain (?) the desire (?) to prepare the ground for a temple. 
inim e2-kur-ra me-gin7 ba-an-gar| But the statement coming from the E-kur was disquieting. 
a-ga-de3{ki} tuk4-e mu-un-na-la2-la2| Because of Enlil (?) all Agade was reduced (?) to trembling, 
ul-masz{ki}-a ni2 im-ma-ni-in-te| and terror befell inanna in Ulmaš. 
iri{ki}-ta dur2-ra-ni ba-ra-gen| She left the city, returning to her home. 
ki-sikil ama5-na szub-bu-gin7| Like someone abandoning the young women of her woman’s domain, 
ku3 {d}inanna-ke4 esz3 a-ga-de3{ki} mu-un-szub| Holy inanna abandoned the sanctuary of Agade 
ur-sag {gesz}tukul-a sag ga2-ga2-gin7| Like a warrior hurrying to arms, 
lu2-kur2-ra-ra gaba ba-ni-in-ri| and handed them over to the enemy. 
u4 nu-5(disz)-am3 u4 nu-1(u)-am3| Not even five or 10 days had passed 
sa nam-en-na aga nam-lugal-la| and the jewels of rulership, the royal crown, 
ma-an-si-um {gesz}gu-za nam-lugal-la szum2-ma| the emblem and the royal throne bestowed on Agade, 
{d}nin-urta-ke4 e2-szu-me-sza4-na ba-ni-in-ku4| did Ninurta bring back into his E-šu-me-ša. 
iri{ki} ka-inim-ma-bi {d}utu ba-an-de6| Utu took away the eloquence of the city. 
gesztu2-bi {d}en-ki-ke4 ba-an-de6| Enki took away its wisdom. 
me-lam2 an-ne2 im-us2-sa-a-bi| Its fearsomeness that reaches heaven, 
{gesz}MA2.MUG ku3 im-du3-du3-a-bi| Its well-anchored holy mooring pole 
{d}en-ki-ke4 abzu-a mi-ni-in-bu| Enki tore out from the abzu. 
{gesz}tukul-bi {d}inanna-ke4 ba-an-de6| inanna took away its weapons. 
esz3 a-ga-de3{ki} zi-bi suhur{ku6} tur-ra-gin7 engur-ra ba-an-til| The life of Agade’s sanctuary was brought to an end as if it had been only the life of a tiny carp in the deep waters, 
iri{ki} tesz2-bi igi-bi am3-da-gal2| and all the cities were watching it. 
am-si mah-gin7 gu2 ki-sze3 mi-ni-ib-gar| Like a mighty elephant, it bent its neck to the ground 
gu4 mah-gin7 si am3-da-il2-il2| while they all raised their horns like mighty bulls. 
uszumgal usz2-a-gin7 sag am3-ma-ze2-re| Like a dying dragon, it dragged its head on the earth 
me3-gin7 nam-dugud-ba am3-da-ab-lah4-lah4-e| and they jointly deprived it of honour as in a battle. 
nam-lugal a-ga-de3{ki} ki-tusz ge-na du10 nu-tusz-u3-de3| Enlil would not let the kingdom of Agade occupy a pleasant, lasting residence, 
egir-bi nig2 na-me nu-sa6-ge-de3| that he would make its future altogether unfavourable, 
e2 tuk4-e URUxGAR sag2 di-de3| that he would make its temples shake and would scatter its treasures - 
{d}na-ra-am-{d}suen masz2-ge6-ka igi ba-ni-in-du8-a| - Naram-Suen saw that in a nocturnal vision. 
sza3-ga-ni-sze3 mu-un-zu eme-na nu-um-ga2-ga2 lu2-da nu-mu-un-da-ab-be2| He realised what the dream was about, but did not put into words, and did not discuss it with anyone. 
nam e2-kur-ra-sze3 tug2-mu-dur7-ra ba-an-mu4| Because of the E-kur, he put on mourning clothes, 
{gesz}gigir-ra-ni {gi}kid-ma2-sza3-ga ba-an-szu2| covered his chariot with a reed mat, 
a2-szita4-a nam-lugal-la-ka-ni im-ma-ra-an-ba-ba| and gave away his royal paraphernalia. 
{d}na-ra-am-{d}suen mu 7(disz)-am3 mu-un-ge-en| Naram-Suen persisted for seven years! 
lugal mu 7(disz)-am3 szu sag-ga2 du11-ga a-ba igi im-mi-in-du8-a| Who has ever seen a king burying his head in his hands for seven years? 
sza3-ga-ni-sze3 mu-un-zu eme-na nu-ga2-ga2 lu2-da nu-mu-un-da-ab-be2| He realised what the dream was about, but did not put into words, and did not discuss it with anyone. 
e2-sze3 masz2-am3 szi-gid2-de3| Then he went to perform extispicy on a kid regarding the temple, 
e2 du3-a masz2-a nu-mu-un-de3-gal2| but the omen had nothing to say about the building of the temple. 
2(disz)-kam-ma-sze3 e2-sze3 masz2-am3 szi-gid2-de3| For a second time he went to perform extispicy on a kid regarding the temple, 
e2 du3-a masz2-a nu-mu-un-de3-gal2| but the omen again had nothing to say about the building of the temple. 
i3-se3-ga-na szu-a bala-e-de3| In order to change what had been inflicted (?) upon him, 
{d}en-lil2 nig2-du11-ga-ni ba-en-de3-kur2| he tried to to alter Enlil’s pronouncement. 
gu2 gar-ra-ni sag2 ba-an-da-ab-du11| Because his subjects were dispersed, 
erin2-na-ni zi-ga ba-ni-in-gar| he now began a mobilization of his troops. 
a2-tuku kisal mah-sze3 ku4-ku4-gin7| Like a wrestler who is about to enter the great courtyard, 
du10-tuku SZU.KAL-sze3 gam-e-gin7| Like an athlete bent to start a contest, 
gi-gun4-na-asz 3(u) gin2 ba-szi-in-ak| he treated the giguna as if it were worth only thirty shekels. 
nita lu2 la-ga iri{ki} lah5-gin7| Like a robber plundering the city, 
e2-sze3 {gesz}kun5 gal-gal ba-szi-in-ri-ri| he set tall ladders against the temple. 
e2-kur {gesz}ma2 mah-gin7 gul-gul-lu-de3| To demolish E-kur as if it were a huge ship, 
kur ku3 ba-al-gin7 sahar du8-u3-de3| to break up its soil like the soil of mountains where precious metals are mined, 
hur-sag {na4}za-gin3-na-gin7 ku5-re-de3| to splinter it like the lapis lazuli mountain, 
iri{ki} {d}iszkur-re ba-an-de2-a-gin7 gu2 ki-sze3 ga2-ga2-de3| to prostrate it like a city inundated by Iškur; 
e2-e kur-{gesz}erin-ku5 nu-me-a| alhough the temple was not the Mountains of Cedar-felling, 
{uruda}ha-zi-in gal-gal ba-szi-in-de2-de2| he had large axes cast, 
{uruda}aga-silig-ga a2 2(disz)-na-bi-da u4-sar ba-an-ak| he had double-edged agasilig axes sharpened to be used against it. 
ur2-bi-a {uruda}ge2-dim ba-an-gar| He set spades against its roots 
suhusz kalam-ma-ka ki ba-e-la2| and it sank as low as the foundation of the Land. 
pa-bi-a {uruda}ha-zi-in ba-an-gar| He put axes against its top, 
e2-e gurusz ug5-ga-gin7 gu2 ki-sze3 ba-an-da-ab-la2| and the temple, like a dead soldier, bowed its neck before him, 
gu2 kur-kur-ra ki-sze3 ba-an-da-ab-la2| and all the foreign lands bowed their necks before him. 
{gesz}alal-bi im-ma-ra-an-zil(NUN)-zil(NUN)| He ripped out its drain pipes, 
im szeg3-szeg3 an-na ba-e-e11| and all the rain went back to the heavens. 
gesz-ka2-na-ke4 ba-ra-an-si-ig tesz2 kalam-ma ba-kur2| He tore off its upper lintel and the Land was deprived of its ornament. 
ka2 sze nu-ku5-da sze i-ni-in-ku5| From its Gate from which Grain is never Diverted, he diverted grain, 
szu kalam-ma-ta sze ba-da-an-ku5| and the Land was deprived of grain. 
ka2 silim-ma-bi {gesz}al-e bi2-in-ra| He struck the Gate of Well-Being with the pickaxe, 
kur-kur-re silim-silim-bi ba-kur2| and well-being was subverted in all the foreign lands. 
e2-kur-ra {uruda}ge2-dim gal-gal-bi kusz3-kusz3-a bi2-in-se3-se3 {uruda}ge2-dim| he cast large spades to be used against the E-kur. 
GA2xMI e2 u4 nu-zu-ba ug3-e igi i-ni-in-bar| The people could see the bedchamber, its room which knows no daylight. 
dub-szen ku3 dingir-re-e-ne-ke4 uri{ki} igi i-ni-in-bar| They could look into the holy treasure chest of the gods. 
la-ha-ma dub-la2 gal e2-e su8-ga-bi| its laḫama deities of the great pilasters standing at the temple, 
lu2 an-zil(NUN) gu7-a nu-me-esz-a| though they had committed no sacrilege, 
{d}na-ra-am-{d}suen sza3 izi-ka ba-an-sag3| were thrown into the fire by Naram-Suen. 
{gesz}erin {gesz}szu-ur2-2(u) {gesz}za-ba-lum {gesz}taskarin| The cedar, cypress, juniper and boxwood, 
ku3-sig17-bi mi-si-ISZ-ra bi2-in-ak| He put its gold in containers 
ku3-babbar-bi {kusz}lu-ub2 {kusz}lu-ub2-szir-ra bi2-in-ak| and put its silver in leather bags. 
uruda-bi sze mah de6-a-gin7 kar-ra bi2-in-si-si| He filled the docks with its copper, as if it were a huge transport of grain. 
ku3-bi ku3-dim2-e im-dim2-e| The silversmiths were re-shaping its silver, 
za-bi za-dim2-e im-dim2-e| jewellers were re-shaping its precious stones, 
uruda-bi simug im-tu11-be2| smiths were beating its copper. 
nig2-gur11 iri{ki} hul-a nu-me-a| Though they were not the goods of a plundered city, 
e2-e {gesz}ma2 gal-gal kar-ra ba-an-us2| large ships were moored at the temple, 
e2 {d}en-lil2-la2-sze3 {gesz}ma2 gal-gal kar-ra ba-an-us2| large ships were moored at Enlil’s temple 
nig2-gur11 iri{ki}-ta ba-ra-e3| and its possessions were taken away from the city. 
nig2-gur11 iri{ki}-ta e3-da-ni| With the possessions being taken away from the city, 
a-ga-de3{ki} dim2-ma-bi ba-ra-e3| good sense left Agade. 
{gesz}ma2-e kar ib2-kur2 umusz a-ga-de3{ki} ba-kur2| As the ships moved away from the docks, Agade’s intelligence was removed. 
u4 te-esz du11-ga kalam tesz2-a gar-ra| The roaring storm that subjugates the entire land, 
a-ma-ru zi-ga gaba-szu-gar nu-tuku| the rising deluge that cannot be confronted, 
{d}en-lil2-le nam e2-kur ki ag2-ga2-ni ba-hul-a-sze3 a-na-am3 im-gu-lu-a-ba| Enlil was considering what should be destroyed in return for the wrecking of his beloved E-kur. 
kur gu2-bi2-na-sze3 igi na-an-il2| He lifted his gaze towards the Gubin mountains, 
hur-sag dagal tesz2-bi nam-ta-an-si-ig| and made all the inhabitants of the broad mountain ranges descend (?). 
ug3-ga2 nu-se3-ga kalam-ma nu-szid-da| Those who do not resemble other people, who are not reckoned as part of the Land, 
gu-ti-um{ki} ug3 kesz2-da nu-zu| the Gutians, an unbridled people, 
dim2-ma lu2-u18-lu GA2xGAR ur-ra SIG7.ALAN {ugu}ugu4-bi| with human intelligence but canine instincts and monkeys’ features - 
{d}en-lil2-le kur-ta nam-ta-an-e3| Enlil brought them out of the mountains. 
SZID-SZID buru5{muszen}-gin7 ki am3-u2-us2| Like small birds they swooped on the ground in great flocks. 
a2-bi gu masz2-ansze-gin7 edin-na mu-un-na-an-la2| Because of Enlil, they stretched their arms out across the plain like a net for animals. 
nig2 na-me a2-bi la-ba-ra-e3| Nothing escaped their clutches, 
lu2 na-me a2-bi la-ba-an-tag4-tag4| no one left their grasp. 
lu2-kin-gi4-a har-ra-an-na nu-mu-un-gen| Messengers no longer travelled the highways, 
{gesz}ma2 ra-gaba i7-da nu-mu-un-dib-be2| the courier’s boat no longer passed along the rivers. 
ud5 ge {d}en-lil2-la2 amasz-ta ba-ra-ra-asz na-gada-bi bi2-in-us2-u2-us2| The Gutians drove the trusty (?) goats of Enlil out of their folds and compelled their herdsmen to follow them, they drove the cows out of their pens and compelled their cowherds to follow them. 
szilam tur3-bi-ta ba-ra-ra-asz unu3-bi bi2-in-us2-u2-us2| they drove the cows out of their pens and compelled their cowherds to follow them. 
gesz-gu2-ka en-nu-ug3 ba-e-du3| Prisoners manned the watch. 
har-ra-an-na lu2-sa-gaz ba-e-tusz| Brigands occupied the highways. 
abul kalam-ma-ka {gesz}ig im-ma ba-e-gub| The doors of the city gates of the Land lay dislodged in mud, 
kur-kur-ra bad3 iri{ki}-ne-ne-ka gu3 gig mi-ni-ib-be2-ne| and all the foreign lands uttered bitter cries from the walls of their cities. 
iri{ki} sza3 edin bar dagal nu-me-a mu2-sar mu-un-de3-gal2| They established gardens for themselves within the cities, and not as usual on the wide plain outside. 
u4 iri{ki} ba-dim2-dim2-ma-ba ba-se3-se3-ga-ba| As if it had been before the time when cities were built and founded, 
a-gar3 gal-gal-e sze nu-um-de6| the large arable tracts yielded no grain, 
a-gar3 su3-su3-ge ku6 nu-um-de6| the inundated tracts yielded no fish, 
pu2-{gesz}kiri6 lal3 gesztin nu-um-de6| the irrigated orchards yielded no syrup or wine, 
IM.U4 sir2-da la-ba-szeg3 {gesz}masz-gur2 la-ba-mu2| the thick clouds (?) did not rain, the mašgurum plant did not grow. 
u4-ba i3 1(disz) gin2-e 1/2(disz) sila3-am3| In those days, oil for one shekel was only half a litre, 
sze 1(disz) gin2-e 1/2(disz) sila3-am3| grain for one shekel was only half a litre, 
siki 1(disz) gin2-e 1/2(disz) ma-na-am3| wool for one shekel was only one mina, 
ku6 1(disz) gin2-e {gesz}ba-an-e ib2-si| fish for one shekel filled only one ban measure 
ganba iri{ki}-ba-ka ur5-gin7 ib2-sa10-sa10| these sold at such prices in the markets of the cities! 
ur3-ra nu2-a ur3-ra ba-usz2| Those who lay down on the roof, died on the roof; 
e2-a nu2-a ki nu-um-tum2| those who lay down in the house were not buried. 
ug3 sza3-gar-bi-ta ni2-bi-a szu im-dub2-dub2-ne| People were flailing at themselves from hunger. 
ki-ur3 ki gal {d}en-lil2-la2-ke4| By the Ki-ur, Enlil’s great place, 
ur sila si-ga zu2 ba-ni-ib-kesz2| dogs were packed together in the silent streets; 
sza3-ba lu2 2(disz) du tesz2-e ba-ni-ib-gu7| if two men walked there they would be devoured by them, 
lu2 3(disz) du tesz2-e ba-ni-ib-gu7| and if three men walked there they would be devoured by them. 
giri17 ba-dub-dub sag ba-dab5-dab5| Noses were punched (?), heads were smashed (?), 
giri17 ba-dub sag numun-e-esz ba-ab-gar| noses (?) were piled up, heads were sown like seeds. 
sag zi sag lul-la szu bala ba-ni-ib-ak| Honest people were confounded with traitors, 
mes mes-e an-ta i-im-nu2| heroes lay dead on top of heroes, 
usz2 lu2-lul-e usz2 lu2 zi-da-ke4 an-ta na-mu-un-DU| the blood of traitors ran upon the blood of honest men. 
u4-ba {d}en-lil2-le esz3 gal-gal-la-ni-ta| At that time, Enlil rebuilt his great sanctuaries 
esz3 gi tur-tur im-ma-ra-an-du3| into small reed (?) sanctuaries 
u4 e3-ta u4 szu2-usz URUxGAR-bi ba-tur| and from east to west he reduced their storehouses. 
um-ma u4-ta ba-ra-ab-tak4-a| The old women who survived those days, 
ab-ba u4-ta ba-ra-ab-tak4-a| the old men who survived those days, 
gala-mah mu-ta ba-ra-ab-tak4-a| and the chief lamentation singer who survived those years 
u4 7(disz) ge6 7(disz)-sze3| for seven days and seven nights 
balag 7(disz)-e an-ur2 gub-ba-gin7 ki mu-un-szi-ib-us2| set up seven balaĝ drums, 
ub3 me-ze2 li-li-is3 {d}iszkur-gin7 sza3-ba mu-na-an-du12| ub, meze, and lilis drums made them resound to Enlil like Iškur. 
um-ma a uru2-gu10 nu-ga2-ga2| The old women did not restrain the cry “Alas for my city!” 
ab-ba a lu2-bi nu-ga2-ga2| The old men did not restrain the cry “Alas for its people!” 
gala-e a e2-kur nu-ga2-ga2| The lamentation singer did not restrain the cry “Alas for the E-kur!” 
ki-sikil-bi siki szab-bi nu-ga2-ga2| Its young women did not restrain from tearing their hair. 
gurusz-bi gir2 sag11 nu-ga2-ga2| Its young men did not restrain from sharpening their knives. 
er2-bi er2 ama a-a {d}en-lil2-la2-ke4| Their laments were as if Enlil’s ancestors 
du6 ku3 su zi gur3-ru du10 ku3 {d}en-lil2-la2-ke4 i-im-ga2-ga2-ne| were performing a lament in the awe-inspiring Holy Mound by the holy knees of Enlil. 
nam-bi-sze3 {d}en-lil2 GA2xMI ku3 ba-an-ku4 sza3-ka-tab-ba ba-an-nu2| Because of this, Enlil entered his holy bedchamber and lay down fasting. 
u4-ba {d}suen {d}en-ki {d}inanna {d}nin-urta {d}iszkur {d}utu {d}PA.DUG {d}nisaba dingir gal-gal-e-ne| At that time, Suen, Enki, inanna, Ninurta, Iškur, Utu, Nuska, and Nisaba, the great gods 
sza3 {d}en-lil2-la2-ke4 a sze17 im-sze17-e-ne a-ra-zu-ta ba-ab-be2-ne| cooled Enlil’s heart with cool water and prayed to him: 
{d}en-lil2 iri iri-zu im-hul-a iri-zu-gin7 he2-du3| “Enlil, may the city that destroyed your city be treated as your city has been treated! 
gi-gun4-na-zu szu bi2-in-la2-la2 nibru{ki}-gin7 he2-du3| May the one that defiled your giguna be treated as Nibru! 
iri-ba sag tul2-ba he2-ni-ib-si-si| In this city, may heads fill the wells! 
lu2 lu2-u3 zu-ne na-an-ni-in-pa3-de3| May no one find his acquaintances there, 
szesz-e szesz-a-ni geszkim na-an-ni-in-e3| may brother not recognise brother! 
ki-sikil-bi ama5-na gesz hul he2-en-da-ab-ra| May its young woman be cruelly killed in her woman’s domain, 
ad-da-bi e2 dam usz2-a-na gu3 gig-bi he2-em-me| may its old man cry in distress for his slain wife! 
tu{muszen}-bi ab-lal3-ba sze he2-ni-in-sza4| May its pigeons moan on their window ledges, 
buru5{muszen}-bi a2-bur2-ba nig2 he2-ni-ib-ra| may its small birds be smitten in their nooks, 
tu{muszen} ni2 te-a-gin7 ur5-da he2-ak-e| may it live in constant anxiety like a timid pigeon!” 
2(disz)-kam-ma-sze3 {d}suen {d}en-ki {d}inanna {d}nin-urta {d}iszkur {d}utu {d}PA.DUG {d}nisaba dingir he2-em-me-esz| Again, Suen, Enki, inanna, Ninurta, Iškur, Utu, Nuska and Nisaba, all the gods whosoever, 
iri{ki}-sze3 igi-ne-ne i-im-ga2-ga2-ne| turned their attention to the city, 
a-ga-de3{ki} asz2 hul-a im-ma-ab-bala-e-ne| and cursed Agade severely: 
iri{ki} e2-kur-sze3 ba-e-a-ul4-en {d}en-lil2 he2-am3| “City, you pounced on E-kur: it is as if you had pounced on Enlil! 
a-ga-de3{ki} e2-kur-sze3 ba-e-a-ul4-en {d}en-lil2 he2-am3| Agade, you pounced on E-kur: it is as if you had pounced on Enlil! 
bad3 ku3-zu en-na sukud-ra2-bi a-nir he2-em-da-sa2| May your holy walls, to their highest point, resound with mourning! 
gi-gun4-na-zu sahar-gin7 he2-dub| May your giguna be reduced to a pile of dust! 
dub-la2 la-ha-ma su8-su8-ga-bi| May your pilasters with the standing lahama deities 
gurusz mah gesztin nag-a-gin7 ki-sze3 he2-em-ta-ga2-ga2| fall to the ground like tall young men drunk on wine! 
im-zu abzu-ba he2-eb-gi4| May your clay be returned to its abzu, 
im {d}en-ki-ke4 nam ku5-ra2 he2-a| may it be clay cursed by Enki! 
sze-zu ab-sin2-ba he2-eb-gi4| May your grain be returned to its furrow, 
sze {d}SZE.TIR-e nam ku5-ra2 he2-a| may it be grain cursed by Ezina! 
gesz-zu tir-bi-a he2-eb-gi4| May your timber be returned to its forest, 
gesz {d}nin-ildu2-ma-ke4 nam ku5-ra2 he2-a| may it be timber cursed by Ninilduma! 
gu4 gaz-gaz-e dam he2-en-gaz-e| May the cattle slaughterer slaughter his wife, 
udu szum-szum-zu dumu he2-en-szum-e| may your sheep butcher butcher his child! 
kar-ke4-zu ka2 esz2-dam-ma-na-ka ni2 ha-ba-ni-ib-la2-e| May your prostitute hang herself at the entrance to her brothel! 
ama nu-gig-zu ama nu-bar-zu dumu he2-en-gi4-gi4| May your pregnant (?) priestesses and cult prostitutes abort (?) their children! 
ku3-sig17-zu ku3-sze3 he2-sa10-sa10| May your gold be bought for the price of silver, 
ku3-babbar-zu nig2 za-ha-am-sze3 he2-sa10-sa10| may your silver be bought for the price of pyrite (?), 
uruda-zu a-gar5-sze3 he2-sa10-sa10| and may your copper be bought for the price of lead!” 
a-ga-de3{ki} a2-tuku-zu a2-ni he2-eb-ta-ku5| “Agade, may your strong man be deprived of his strength, 
ansze-ni-is-kum-zu a2-ni na-an-hul2-e u4 szu2-a he2-nu2| and will not have the joy of controlling your superior asses; may he lie idle all day! 
iri{ki}-bi sza3-gar-ra he2-ni-ib-usz2-e| May this make the city die of hunger! 
dumu-gi7 ninda sa6-ga gu7-gu7-zu u2-szim-e ha-ba-nu2| May your citizens, who used to eat fine food, lie hungry, 
TAG-TAG gesz-ur3-ra-na he2-gu7-e| eat the coating on his roof, 
{gesz}ig gal {kusz}gurx(E.TUM) e2 ad-da-na-ka| The leather hinges on the main door of his father’s house, 
{kusz}gurx(E.TUM)-bi zu2-ni-ta he2-ur5-re| may he chew their leather hinges! 
e2-gal sza3 hul2-la du3-a-za sza3 sag3 he2-en-szub du3-a-za| May depression descend upon your palace, built for joy! 
lu2 hul edin ki si-ga-ke4 gu3 hu-mu-ra-ra-ra| May the evils of the desert, the silent place, howl continuously!” 
ki uz-ga szu-luh-ha gar-ra-zu| “Your uzga precinct, established for purification ceremonies, 
ka5 du6 gul-gul-la-ke4 kun he2-ni-ib-ur3-ur3-re| may foxes that frequent its ruin mounds and brush it with their tails 
abul kalam-ma gar-ra-zu| Your gateways, established for the Land, 
u3-ku-ku{muszen} muszen sza3 sag3-ga-ke4 gud3 he2-em-ma-an-us2| May the ukuku, the bird of depression, make its nest in them! 
iri{ki} tigi-da u3 nu-ku-ku-za| In your city that could not sleep because of the tigi drums, 
sza3 hul2-la-da nu-nu2-za| that could not rest from its joy, 
tur3-e si gu4 {d}nanna-ke4| may the bulls of Nanna that fill the pens 
edin ki si-ga-ke4 nigin2-nigin2-na-gin7 szix(KAxBALAG) hu-mu-un-gi4-gi4-gi4| bellow like those who wander in the desert, the silent place! 
gu2 {gesz}ma2 gid2-da i7-da-zu u2 gid2-da he2-em-mu2| May the grass grow long on your canal-bank tow-paths, 
har-ra-an {gesz}gigir-ra ba-gar-ra-zu u2-a-nir he2-em-mu2| may the grass of mourning grow on your highways laid for waggons! 
2(disz)-kam-ma-sze3 gu2 ma2 gid2-da ki a-la2 i7-da-zu| Moreover, on your tow-paths built up with canal sediment, 
edin sza3 u2 sa6-ga mu2-a-zu gi er2-ra he2-em-mu2| In your plains where fine grass grows, may the reed of lamentation grow! 
a-ga-de3{ki} a du10-ga de2-a-zu a mun-na he2-em-de2 a-ga-de3{ki}| Agade, may brackish water flow, where fresh water flowed for you! 
iri{ki}-bi-a ga-tusz bi2-in-du11-ga ki-tusz na-an-ni-du10-ge| If someone decides, “I will dwell in this city!,” may he not enjoy the pleasures of a dwelling place! 
a-ga-de3{ki}-a ga-nu2 bi2-in-du11-ga ki-nu2 na-an-ni-du10-ge| If someone decides, “I will rest in Agade!,” may he not enjoy the pleasures of a resting place!” 
i-ne-esz2 {d}utu u4 ne-e-a ur5 he2-en-na-nam-ma-am3| And before Utu on that very day, so it was! 
gu2 {gesz}ma2 gid2-da i7-da-ba u2 gid2-da ba-an-mu2| On its canal bank tow-paths, the grass grew long. 
har-ra-an {gesz}gigir-ra ba-gar-ra-ba u2-a-nir ba-an-mu2| On its highways laid for waggons, the grass of mourning grew. 
2(disz)-kam-ma-sze3 gu2 {gesz}ma2 gid2-da ki a-la2 i7-da-ba| Moreover, on its tow-paths built up with canal sediment, 
szeg9-bar mul musz ul4 kur-ra-ke4 lu2 nu-mu-ni-in-dib-be2| wild rams (?) and alert snakes of the mountains allowed no one to pass. 
edin sza3 u2 sa6-ga mu2-a-bi gi er2-ra ba-an-mu2| On its plains, where fine grass grew, now the reeds of lamentation grew. 
a-ga-de3{ki} a du10-ga de2-a-bi a mun-na ba-an-de2| Agade’s flowing fresh water flowed as brackish water. 
iri{ki}-bi-a ga-tusz bi2-in-du11-ga ki-tusz nu-um-ma-an-da-du10| When someone decided, “I will dwell in that city!,” he could not enjoy the pleasures of a dwelling place. 
a-ga-de3{ki}-a ga-nu2 bi-in-du11-ga ki-nu2 nu-um-ma-an-na-du10| When someone decided, “I will rest in Agade!,” 
a-ga-de3{ki} hul-a {d}inanna za3-mi2| For the destruction of Agade, Inanna be praised! 
gesztu2-bi {d}en-ki-ke4 ba-de6| Enki took away its wisdom. 
me-lam2 an-ne2 im-us2-bi| Its fearsomeness that reaches heaven, 
an-ne2 an-sza3-ga ba-e11| An took it up into the midst of heaven. 
{gesz}dar-kak ku3 im-da-du3-a-bi| Its well-anchored holy mooring pole, 
{d}en-ki-ke4 abzu-a mi-ni-bu| Enki tore it out from the abzu 
egir-sze3 nig2 na-me nu-sa6-de3| That he would make its future altogether unfavourable; 
e2 tuk4-e URUxGAR sag3 di-de3| that he would make its temples shake and would scatter its treasures - 
na-ra-am-{d}suen-e masz2-ge6-ka igi ba-ni-in-du8-a| - Naram-Suen saw that in a nocturnal vision. 
i3-se3-ga-na szu bala-e-gin7| as if he were to change what had been inflicted (?) upon him. 
gu2 gar-ra-ni sag2 mu-na-ab-du11| His subjects were dispersed, 
erin2-na-na zi-ga14 ba-ni-gar| so he began a mobilization of his troops. 
a2-tuku kisal mah-a ku4-ku4-gin7| Like a wrestler who is about to enter the great courtyard, 
du10-tuku liru3-sze3 gam-e-gin7| Like an athlete bent to start a contest, 
gi-gun4-sze3 3(u) gin2 ba-szi-ak| he treated the giguna as if it were worth only thirty shekels. 
nita lu2-kid2 iri ri-ri| Like a robber plundering the city, 
e2-sze3 {gesz}kun5 gal-gal ba-szi-lah4| he set tall ladders against the temple. 
e2-e kur erin-na nu-me-a| Though the temple was not a mountain of cedars, 
ha-zi-in{uruda} gal-gal i3-ma-ta-de2| he had large axes cast to be used against it. 
{uruda}aga-silig x a2 min-na-bi-da u3-sa-ar ba-ak| He had double-edged agasilig axes sharpened to be used against it. 
ugur2 mah a-esztub dugud-a-gin7| As if they were for great tracts of land with huge carp-filled waters, 
ge2-dim gal-gal-bi kusz3-a bi2-se3-se3| he cast large spades. 
ur2-bi-a ge2-dim ba-gar| He put spades against its roots. 
szu kalam-ma-ta sze ba-da-ku5| and the Land was deprived of grain. 
ka2 silim-ma-bi al-e bi2-in-szub| He struck the Gate of Well-Being with the pickaxe 
kur-kur x silim-silim-bi ba-gul| and well-being was destroyed in all the foreign lands. 
giri17 ba-an-dub-dub sag ba-an-tu-tu| Noses were punched, heads were smashed (?), 
giri17 ba-an-dub sag numun-e-esz ba-ab-gar| noses (?) were piled up, heads were sown like seeds. 
u3-ri2-in lu2-lul lu2 zi-ra an-ta ma| the blood of traitors ran (?) upon honest men. 
{d}en-lil2-le e2 gal-gal-la-ni| Enlil rebuilt his great sanctuaries 
esz3 gi tur-tur ba-ra-du3| into small reed (?) sanctuaries 
1(u) 5(disz) gurusz u4 5(disz)-sze3| 15 male laborers for 5 workdays,
e2-szitim gub-ba| at the builder-house stationed, 
ugula ukken-ne2| foreman: Ukkene, 
giri3 lu2-giri17-zal| via Lu-girizal, 
kiszib3 bi2-du11-ga| under seal of Biduga; 
mu ki-masz{ki} mu-hul| year: “Kimaš was destroyed.”

mu sza-asz-ru-um{ki} ba-hul| year: “Šašrum was destroyed.”

ensi2| governor 
umma{ki}| of Umma: 
ur-am3-ma| Ur-amma, 
dub-sar| scribe, 
dumu na-silim| son of Nasilim, 
ARAD2-zu| is your servant. 
{d}ba-ba6| For Baba, 
nin-a-ni-ir| his lady, 
a mu-na-ru| dedicate this.

am-e tur3-ra-na musz3 mi-ni-in-ga amasz-a-na lil2-e| The wild bull has abandoned his cow-pen and has let the breezes haunt his sheepfold. 
u3-mu-un kur-kur-ra-ke4 musz3 mi-ni-in-ga amasz-a-na lil2-e| The lord of all the lands has abandoned it and has let the breezes haunt his sheepfold.

ki-ru-gu2 1(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 1st kirugu. 
amasz-a-na lil2-e ba-ni-in-gar i-si-isz-bi mu-un-kusz2-u3| She has let the breeze haunt her sheepfold, she groans grievously over it. 
ab2 gu3-zu {e2}tur3-ra nu-mu-un-gal2 tur3 nun nu-ul| O cow, your lowing no longer fills the byre, the cow-pen no longer brings joy (?) to the prince. 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its gišgigal. 
uru2 a-sze-er gig-ga a-sze-er-zu gar-ra| O city, the lament is bitter, the lament made for you. 
a-sze-er-zu gig-ga-am3 uru2 a-sze-er-zu gar-ra| Your lament is bitter, O city, the lament made for you. 
uru2 zi gul-la-na a-sze-er-bi gig-ga-am3| In his righteous destroyed city its lament is bitter. 
uri2 zi gul-la-na a-sze-er gig-ga a-sze-er-zu gar-ra| In his righteous destroyed Ur, the lament is bitter, the lament made for you. 
a-sze-er-zu gig-ga-am3 uru2 a-sze-er-zu gar-ra| Your lament is bitter, O city, the lament made for you. 
uri2{ki} gul-la-na a-sze-er-bi gig-ga| In his destroyed Ur its lament is bitter. 
a-sze-er-zu gig-ga ga-sza-an-zu mu-lu er2-re en3-sze3 mu-un-kusz2-u3| How long will your bitter lament grieve your lord who weeps?
