a-sze-er-zu gig-ga-am3 {d}nanna mu-lu er2-re en3-sze3 mu-un-kusz2-u3| How long will your bitter lament grieve Nanna who weeps? 
uru2 mu-zu i3-gal2 za-e ba-e-da-gul-e| O city, your name exists but you have been destroyed. 
uru2 bad3-zu i3-il2 kalam-zu ba-e-da-til| O city, your wall rises high but your Land has perished. 
uru2-gu10 u8 zi-gin7 sila4-zu ba-e-da-tar| O my city, like an innocent ewe your lamb has been torn from you. 
uri2{ki} ud5 zi-gin7 masz2-zu ba-e-da-til| Ur, like an innocent goat your kid has perished. 
uru2 garza-zu im-me-de3-kur2-ra| O city, your rites have been alienated from you, 
me-zu me kur2-ra szu bala ba-ni-ib-ak| your powers have been changed into alien powers. 
a-sze-er-zu gig-ga-am3 ga-sza-an-zu mu-lu er2-re en3-sze3 mu-un-kusz2-u3| ow long will your bitter lament grieve your lord who weeps? 
a-sze-er-zu gig-ga-am3 {d}nanna mu-lu er2-re en3-sze3 mu-un-kusz2-u3| How long will your bitter lament grieve Nanna who weeps? 
ki-ru-gu2 2(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 2nd kirugu. 
uru2 zi gul-la-na a-sze-er-bi gig-ga-am3| In his righteous destroyed city its lament is bitter. 
uri2{ki} gul-la-na a-sze-er-bi gig-ga-am3| In his destroyed Ur its lament is bitter. 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its gišgigal. 
nin lu2 e2 hul-a-ta uru2-ni er2-re ba-an-di-ni-ib-gar| Together with the lord whose house had been devastated, his city was given over to tears. 
{d}nanna lu2 kalam ba-an-da-til-la| Together with Nanna whose Land had perished, 
uri2{ki}-e a-nir-ra bar ba-da-an-tab| Ur joined the lament. 
munus zi nin uru2{ki}-ni-sze3 kusz2-u3-de3| The good woman, to disquiet the lord concerning his city, 
{d}nin-gal kalam-ma-ni-sze3 u3 nu-ku-ku-de3| Ningal, to give him no rest concerning his Land, 
e-ne-ra nam uru2-na mu-na-te er2 gig i3-sze8-sze8| approached him for the sake of his city - bitterly she weeps. 
nin-ra nam e2-a-na mu-na-te er2 gig i3-sze8-sze8| She approached the lord for the sake of his house - bitterly she weeps. 
nam uru2 hul-a-na mu-na-te er2 gig i3-sze8-sze8| She approached him for the sake of his devastated city -- bitterly she weeps. 
nam e2 hul-a-na mu-na-te a-nir gig-ga-bi im-da-ra-da-ga2-ga2| She approached him for the sake of his devastated house -- before him she makes its bitter lament. 
munus-e ad-a-ni balag er2-ra ki al-gar-ra-ba| The woman, after she had composed her song (?) for the tearful balag instrument, 
i-lu ma si-ga tur-tur-bi ni2-te-na mi-ni-ib-be2| herself utters softly a lamentation for the silent house: 
u4-da ma-al-ma-al-la i-si-isz-bi ma-la2-la2| “The storm that came to be -- its lamentation hangs heavy on me. 
u4-da na-ag2-bi-sze3 sumur-sumur-a-gu10-ne| Raging about because of the storm, 
lu2 {nu}nunus-gen u4-da ma-al-ma-al-la| I am the woman for whom the storm came to be. 
u4-da ma-al-ma-al-la i-si-isz-bi ma-la2-la2| The storm that came to be - 
u4-da u4 gig-ga ma-ra-ma-al-ma-al-la| - its lamentation hangs heavy on me. 
me-e u4-bi-sze3 zarah he2-em-szi-ak| I trembled on account of that day 
u4-da a2-bi-sze3 ba-ra-ba-ra-e3-en| but I did not flee before the day's violence. 
u4 tur-bi-sze3 bala-gu10 u4 sa6-ga bala-gu10 u4 sa6-ga i-bi2 ba-ra-bi2-in-du8-a| Because of this debilitating storm I could not see a good day for my rule, not one good day for my rule.” 
ge6-sze3 a-sze-er gig ma-ra-ma-al-ma-al-la| “The bitter lament having come to be for me during the night, 
me-e ge6-bi-sze3 zarah he2-em-szi-ak| trembled on account of that night 
ge6 a2-bi ba-ra-ba-ra-e3-en| but I did not flee before the night's violence. 
u4 uru2-gin7 gul-lu-ba ni2-bi ha-ma-la2-la2| The awesomeness of this storm, destructive as the flood, truly hangs heavy on me. 
na-ag2-bi-sze3 ki-nu2 ge6 u3-na-ga2 ki-nu2 ge6 u3-na-ga2 lib ba-ra-an-mar| Because of its existence, in my nightly sleeping place, even in my nightly sleeping place truly there was no peace for me. 
u4 tur-bi-sze3 ki-nu2-ga2 mu-usz-la2-a-bi ki-nu2-ga2 gesz-la2-a-bi nu-szi-in-ga-mu-ni-ib-DU| Nor, because of this debilitating storm, was the quiet of my sleeping place, not even the quiet of my sleeping place, allowed to me. 
ka-na-ag2-gu10-ta ni2 szub me-e ba-ra-ba-da-ak| (2 mss. add 1 line:) Truly I did not forsake my Land.” 
ka-na-ag2-gu10 ag2-gig-ga ba-gal2-la-ke4-esz| “Because there was bitterness in my Land, 
ab2 amar-ra-gin7-nam ki szu he2-em-mi-ib-ak| I trudged the earth like a cow for its calf. 
ka-na-ag2-gu10 ni2 szu-a ba-ra-mu-da-ab-gi4| My Land was not granted success. 
uru2-gu10 du-lum gig ba-gal2-la-ke4-esz| Because there was bitter distress in my city, 
muszen an-na-gin7 a2 dub2 he2-em-szi-ak| I beat my wings like a bird of heaven 
me-e uru2-gu10-sze3 he2-em-szi-dal-dal-en| and flew to my city; 
uru2-gu10 ki-gal2-ba he2-en-ga-mu-de3-gul| and my city was destroyed in its foundations; 
uri2{ki} ki-nu2-bi-a he2-en-ga-mu-de3-til| and Ur perished where it lay. 
szu u4-da an-ta ba-gal2-la-ke4-esz| Because the hand of the storm appeared above, 
gu3 hu-mu-dub2 edin-na u4 gi4-a me-e he2-em-ma-du11| I screamed and cried to it “Return, O storm, to the plain.” 
u4-da gaba-bi ba-ra-mu-da-zi| The storm's breast did not rise.” 
{nu}nunus-gen agrun-ku3 e2 na-ag2-{d}ga-sza-an-na-gu10| “To me, the woman, in the Agrun-kug, my house of queenship, 
bala-ba u4 su3-ra2 na-ma-ni-in-gar-re-esz-am3| they did not grant a reign of distant days. 
er2 a-sze-er-ra ki ha-ma-ab-us2-am3| Indeed they established weeping and lamentation for me. 
e2 ki ur5 sa6-ge sag-ge6-ga i3-me-a-ke4-esz| As for the house which used to be where the spirit of the black-headed people was soothed, 
ezem-bi-ta ib2-ba su-mu-ug-ga he2-en-ga-mu-da-tab-tab-be2-esz| instead of its festivals wrath and terror indeed multiply. 
u4 tur-bi-sze3 e2-gu10 ki sa6-ga| Because of this debilitating storm, into my house, the favourable place, 
e2 zi hul-a-gu10 i-bi2 ba-ra-bi2-in-du8-am3| my devastated righteous house upon which no eye had been cast, 
ur5 usz2-a a-sze-er ag2-gig-ga| depression, and lament and bitterness, 
a-sze-er ag2-gig-ga hu-mu-ni-tum2-tum2-mu-usz| lament and bitterness have been brought into it. 
e2 lu2 zi-de3 ba-ab-gar-ra-gu10| My house founded by the righteous 
gi-sig kiri6-gin7 bar-ba he2-bi2-in-dub2| was pushed over on its side like a garden fence.” 
e2-kisz-nu-gal2 e2 nam-lugal-la-gu10| “For E-kiš-nu-gal, my house of royalty, 
e2 zi e2 er2-ra ba-an-di-ni-ib-gar-ra-gu10| the good house, my house which has been given over to tears, 
lul-e-esz du3-u3-ba zi-de3-esz gul-lu-ba| its building, falsely, and its perishing, truly - 
ha-la ba-bi-a ha-ma-ni-in-gar-re-esz-am3| they granted this to me as its lot and share. 
za-lam-gar e2 ki-buru14 bu-ra-gin7| As onto a tent, a shelter on the denuded harvest ground, 
e2 ki-buru14 bu-ra-gin7 tu15 szeg3-ga2 ha-ba-an-gar| as onto a shelter on the denuded harvest ground, wind and rain have been made to fall on it. 
uri2{ki} ama5 nig2 diri-gu10| Ur, my all-surpassing chamber, 
e2 uru2 si-ga mu-un-bu-bu-bu| the house and the smitten city, all have been uprooted. 
amasz {lu2}sipa-da-gin7 ha-ba-bu-bu| Like a shepherd's sheepfold it has been uprooted. 
nig2-gur11 uru2 gal2-gal2-la-gu10 sug-ge hu-mu-da-ab-gu7| The swamp has swallowed my possessions accumulated in the city.” 
ki-ru-gu2 3(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 3rd kirugu. 
uri2{ki} er2-re ba-an-di-ni-ib-gar| Ur has been given over to tears. 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its gešgigal. 
u4-ba u4 ne-en ba-sag3-sag3-ga-ba| “On that day, when such a storm had pounded, 
nin-da uru2-ni ba-an-da-gul-la-ba| when in the presence of the queen her city had been destroyed, 
u4-ba u4 ne-en ba-dim2-dim2-ma-ba| on that day, when such a storm had been created, 
uru2-gu10 gul-gul-da im-me-ne-esz-a-ba| when they had pronounced the utter destruction of my city, 
uri2{ki} gul-gul-da im-me-ne-esz-a-ba| when they had pronounced the utter destruction of Ur, 
ug3-bi ug5-ge-de3 a2 mu-un-ag2-esz-a-ba| when they had directed that its people be killed, 
u4-ba me-e uru2-gu10-sze3 ga2-la ba-ra-ba-ra-dag| on that day I did not abandon my city, 
ka-na-ag2-gu10-ta ni2 szub me ba-ra-ba-da-ak| I did not forsake my land.” 
an-ra a i-bi2-ga2 me-e he2-em-ma-na-de2| “Truly I shed my tears before An. 
{d}mu-ul-lil2-ra ni2-gu10 sza3-ne-sza4 he2-em-ma-na-ak| Truly I myself made supplication to Enlil. 
uru2-gu10 nam-ba-gul-lu he2-em-me-ne-du11| “Let not my city be destroyed,” I implored them. 
uri2{ki} nam-ba-gul-lu he2-em-me-ne-du11| “Let not Ur be destroyed,” I implored them. 
ug3-bi nam-ba-til-le he2-em-me-ne-du11| “Let not its people perish,” I implored them. 
an-ne2 e-ne-eg3-bi ba-ra-mu-un-gur| But An did not change that word. 
{d}mu-ul-lil2-le i3-sa6 he2-am3-bi sza3-gu10 ba-ra-bi2-in-sze17| Enlil did not soothe my heart with an “It is good - so be it.”" 
2(disz)-kam-ma-sze3 pu-uh2-rum ki sag-ki ba-da-ab-gal2-la| “A second time, when the council had settled itself in the pre-eminent place, 
{d}a-nun-na e-ne-eg3 zu2 kesz2-da-bi ba-da-an-dur2-ru-ne-esz-a| and the Anuna had seated themselves to ratify decisions, 
ur2 he2-em-ma-su3-su3 a2 he2-em-ma-la2-la2| I prostrated (?) myself and stretched out my arms. 
an-ra a i-bi2-ga2 me-e he2-em-ma-na-du11| Truly I shed my tears before An. 
{d}mu-ul-lil2-ra ni2-gu10 sza3-ne-sza4 he2-em-ma-ak| Truly I myself made supplication to Enlil. 
uru2-gu10 nam-ba-gul-lu he2-em-me-ne-du11| “Let not my city be destroyed,” I implored them. 
uri2{ki} nam-ba-gul-lu he2-em-me-ne-du11| “Let not Ur be destroyed,” I implored them. 
ug3-bi nam-ba-til-le he2-em-me-ne-du11| “Let not its people perish,” I implored them. 
an-ne2 e-ne-eg3-bi ba-ra-mu-un-gur| But An did not change that word. 
{d}mu-ul-lil2-le i3-sa6 he2-am3-bi sza3-gu10 ba-ra-bi2-in-sze17| Enlil did not soothe my heart with an “It is good -- so be it.”" 
uru2-gu10 gul-gul-lu-ba a2-bi he2-em-ma-an-ag2-esz| “They gave instructions that my city should be utterly destroyed. 
uri2{ki} gul-gul-lu-ba a2-bi he2-em-ma-an-ag2-esz| They gave instructions that Ur should be utterly destroyed. 
ug3-bi ug5-ge-de3 na-ag2-bi ha-ba-an-tar-re-esz| They decreed its destiny that its people should be killed. 
me-e nig2-du11-gu10 mu-ne-szum2-ma-gin7| In return for the speech (?) which I had given them, 
me-e uru2-gu10-da he2-en-ga-mu-un-da-la2-esz| they both bound me together with my city 
uri2{ki}-gu10 ma-da he2-en-ga-mu-da-la2-e-esz| and also bound my Ur together with me. 
an-ne2 du11-ga-ni hur nu-kur2-ru-dam| An is not one to change his command, 
{d}mu-ul-lil2-le ka-ta e3-a-ni szu nu-bala-e-de3| and Enlil does not alter what he has uttered.” 
ki-ru-gu2 4(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 4th kirugu. 
uru2-ni ba-an-da-gul-la me-ni ba-an-da-kur2-ra| Her city has been destroyed in her presence, her powers have been alienated from her. 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its gišgigal. 
{d}en-lil2-le u4-de3 gu3 ba-an-de2 ug3-e sze am3-sza4| Enlil called the storm -- the people groan. 
u4 he2-gal2-la kalam-da ba-da-an-kar ug3-e sze am3-sza4| He brought the storm of abundance away from the Land -- the people groan. 
u4 du10 ki-en-gi-da ba-da-an-kar ug3-e sze am3-sza4| He brought the good storm away from Sumer -- the people groan. 
u4 hul-gal2-e a2 ba-da-an-ag2 ug3-e sze am3-sza4| He issued directions to the evil storm -- the people groan. 
kin-gal-u4-da u4-da gub-ba szu-na im-ma-an-szum2| He entrusted it to Kin-gal-uda, the keeper of the storm. 
u4 kalam til-til-e gu3 ba-an-de2 ug3-e sze am3-sza4| He called upon the storm that annihilates the Land -- the people groan. 
im-hul-im-hul-e gu3 ba-an-de2 ug3-e sze am3-sza4| He called upon the evil gales - the people groan. 
{d}en-lil2-le {d}gibil a2-tah-a-ni mu-na-ni-in-ku4-re| Enlil brought Gibil as his aid. 
u4 gal an-na-ke4 gu3 ba-an-de2 ug3-e sze am3-sza4| He called the great storm of heaven - the people groan. 
u4 gal-e an-ta gu3 im-me ug3-e sze am3-sza4| The great storm howls above -- the people groan. 
u4 kalam til-til-e ki-a mur im-sza4 ug3-e sze am3-sza4| The storm that annihilates the Land roars below -- the people groan. 
im-hul-e a mah e3-a-gin7 gu2-bi nu-ga2-ga2| The evil wind, like a rushing torrent, cannot be restrained. 
{gesz}tukul uru2-ke4 sag gaz i3-ak-e tesz2-bi i3-gu7-e| The weapons in the city smash heads and consume indiscriminately. 
an-na ur2-ba kana6 mu-un-nigin2-nigin2 ug3-e sze am3-sza4| The storm whirled gloom around the base of the horizon -- the people groan. 
u4-da igi-ba izi mu-un-bar7-bar7-e ug3-e sze am3-sza4| In front of the storm, heat blazes -- the people groan. 
u4 mer-mer-da izi-ge6-edin-na bar ba-da-an-tab| A fiery glow burns with the raging storm. 
an-bar7 bar-szeg3 il2-il2-la-gin7 izi im-ma-an-bar7-bar7| After the haze had lifted at noon, he made fires blaze. 
an-bar7-gan2 u4 zalag e3-a u4 du10-da ba-da-an-tab| He locked up the day and the rising of the bright sun together with the good storm 
kalam-ma u4 zalag-ga la-ba-an-e3 mul an-usanx(DUR)-gin7 ba-zal| In the Land he did not let the bright sun rise; it shone like the evening star. 
ge6 giri17-zal a2 sze4 gar-ra-ba {tu15}u18-lu ba-da-an-tab| n the delightful night, the time when coolness sets in, he redoubled the south wind. 
szika bar7-bar7-re-da sahar im-da-tab-tab ug3-e sze am3-sza4| The scorching potsherds made the dust glow (?) -- the people groan. 
sag-ge6-ga tu15-tu15 ba-an-dal ug3-e sze am3-sza4| He swept the winds over the black-headed people -- the people groan. 
ki-en-gi gesz-bur2-ra i3-bala-e ug3-e sze am3-sza4| Sumer was overturned by a snare -- the people groan 
kalam-e sag e2-gar8(SIG4) du3 i3-ak-e tesz2-bi i3-gu7-e| It attacked (?) the Land and devoured it completely. 
u4 gig er2-re nam nu-tar-re ug3-e sze am3-sza4| Tears cannot influence the bitter storm -- the people groan. 
u4 szu ur4-ur4-re kalam i3-ur3-ur3-re| The reaping storm dragged across the Land. 
u4 a-ma-ru-gin7 uru2 i3-gul-gul-e| Like a flood storm it completely destroyed the city. 
u4 kalam til-til-e uru2-a me bi2-ib-gar| The storm that annihilates the Land silenced the city. 
u4 nig2 u2-gu de2-de2 hul-gal2-esz ba-e-DU| The storm that will make anything vanish came doing evil. 
u4 izi-gin7 bar7-a ug3-e szu bi2-ib-gar| The storm blazing like fire performed its task upon the people. 
u4 hul gig du11-ga {d}en-lil2-la2 u4 kalam-ta be4-be4| The storm ordered by Enlil in hate, the storm which wears away the Land, 
uri2{ki}-ma tug2-gin7 ba-e-dul gada-gin7 ba-e-bur2| covered Ur like a garment, was spread out over it like linen. 
ki-ru-gu2 5(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 5th kirugu. 
u4 ug-am3 al-du7-du7 ug3-e sze am3-sza4| The storm, like a lion, has attacked unceasingly -- the people groan. 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its gišgigal. 
u4-ba u4 uru2-da ba-da-an-gar uru2-bi du6-du6-da| Then the storm was removed from the city, that city reduced to ruin mounds. 
a-a {d}nanna uru2-ni du6-du6-da ba-da-an-gar ug3-e sze am3-sza4| It was removed from Father Nanna's city reduced to ruin mounds -- the people groan. 
u4-ba u4 kalam-ta ba-da-an-kar ug3-e sze am3-sza4| Then, the storm was taken from the Land -- the people groan. 
u4 du10 ki-en-gi-da ba-da-an-kar ug3-e sze am3-sza4| (2 mss. add 1 line:) The good storm was taken from Sumer -- the people groan. 
ug3-bi szika ku5-da nu-me-a bar-ba ba-e-si| Its people littered its outskirts just as if they might have been broken potsherds. 
bad3-bi gu2-giri3 im-ma-an-gar-gar ug3-e sze am3-sza4| Breaches had been made in its walls -- the people groan. 
abul mah giri3 gal2-la-ba ad6 im-ma-an-gar-gar| On its lofty city-gates where walks had been taken, corpses were piled. 
sila dagal ezem-ma du3-a-ba sag bala-e-esz ba-ab-gar| On its boulevards where festivals had been held, heads lay scattered (?). 
e-sir2-e-sir2 giri3 gal2-la-ba ad6 im-ma-an-gar-gar| In all its streets where walks had been taken, corpses were piled. 
eszemen kalam-ma gal2-la-ba ug3 zar-re-esz ba-an-du8| In its places where the dances of the Land had taken place, people were stacked in heaps. 
u3-mun kalam-ma-ke4 uruda nagga-gin7 sur3-sur3 ba-ni-in-de6-esz| They made the blood of the Land flow down the wadis like copper or tin. 
ad6-bi {uzu}i3-udu u4-de3 gal2-la-gin7 ni2-bi-a mu-un-zal-esz| Its corpses, like fat left in the sun, melted away of themselves. 
lu2 {uruda}ha-zi-in-e im-til-la-gin7 sag tug2 la-ba-ab-dul-esz| The heads of its men slain by the axe were not covered with a cloth. 
masz-da3 gesz-bur2-ra dab5-ba-gin7 ka sahar-ra bi2-in-us2| Like a gazelle caught in a trap, their mouths bit the dust. 
lu2 gesz-gid2-da mu-un-ra-bi nig2-la2 ba-ra-bi2-in-la2-esz| Men struck down by the spear were not bound with bandages. 
i-gi4-in-zu ki ha-ri-isz-ta ama-ba-ka usz2-bi-a mu-un-nu2-esz| As if in the place where their mothers had laboured, they lay in their own blood. 
lu2 {gesz}mitumx(KA.AN)-e im-til-la-gin7 tug2 gibil ba-ra-bi2-in-la2-esz| Its men who were finished off by the battle-mace were not bandaged with new (?) cloth. 
lu2 kurun nag-a nu-me-esz-a gu3 za3-ga bi2-in-gal2-esz| Although they were not drunk with strong drink, their necks drooped on their shoulders. 
{gesz}tukul-e gub-ba {gesz}tukul-e in-gaz ug3-e sze am3-sza4| He who stood up to the weapon was crushed by the weapon -- the people groan. 
lu2-kar-ra-bi u4 im-ma-du-bu-ul ug3-e sze am3-sza4| He who ran away from it was overwhelmed (?) by the storm -- the people groan. 
uri2{ki}-ma si-ga kal-ga-bi sza3-gar-ra im-til| The weak and the strong of Ur perished from hunger. 
um-ma ab-ba e2-ta nu-e3 izi mu-ni-in-se3-se3-ge5-esz| Mothers and fathers who did not leave their houses were consumed by fire. 
di4-di4-la2 ur2 ama-ba-ka nu2-a ku6-gin7 a ba-an-de6| The little ones lying in their mothers' arms were carried off like fish by the waters. 
UM.ME{da} SZU.KAL kal-ga-bi SZU.KAL ba-an-da-du8| Among the nursemaids with their strong embrace, the embrace was pried open. 
dim2-ma kalam-ma u2-gu im-ta-an-de2 ug3-e sze am3-sza4| The Land's judgment disappeared -- the people groan. 
GA2xGAR kalam-ma sug-ge4 ba-ab-gu7 ug3-e sze am3-sza4| The Land's counsel was swallowed by a swamp -- the people groan. 
ama dumu-ni igi-ni ba-ra-e3 ug3-e sze am3-sza4| The mother absconded before her child's eyes -- the people groan. 
ad-da dumu-ni-ta ba-da-an-kur2 ug3-e sze am3-sza4| The father turned away from his child -- the people groan. 
uru2-a dam ba-szub dumu ba-szub nig2-gur11 ba-bir-bir-re| In the city the wife was abandoned, the child was abandoned, possessions were scattered about. 
sag-ge6 ki-sag-gal2-la-ba im-me-de3-re7-esz| The black-headed people were carried off from their strongholds. 
nin-bi muszen ni2 te-a-gin7 uru2-ni ba-ra-e3| Its queen like a bird in fright departed from her city. 
nin-gal-e muszen ni2 te-a-gin7 uru2-ni ba-ra-e3| Ningal like a bird in fright departed from her city. 
nig2-gur11 kalam-ma gar-gar-ra-ba szu pe-el-la2 ba-ab-du11| All the treasures accumulated in the Land were defiled. 
ama5 kalam-ma szar2-szar2-ra-ba izi im-ma-an-bar7-bar7| In all the storehouses abounding in the Land fires were kindled. 
a-nigin2-ba {d}gibil lu2 sikil-la kin mu-un-tuku-tuku| In its ponds Gibil, the purifier, relentlessly did his work. 
hur-sag sukux(SUKUD)-ra2 szu nu-te-ge26 e2-kisz-nu-gal2-la| The good house of the lofty untouchable mountain, E-kiš-nu-gal, 
e2 zi-ba {uruda}ha-zi-in gal-gal-e tesz2-bi i3-gu7-e| was entirely devoured by large axes. 
szimaszki{ki} elam{ki} lu2 ha-lam-ma 3(u) gin2 ba-an-ak-e-esz| The people of Šimaški and Elam, the destroyers, counted its worth as only thirty shekels. 
e2 zi {gesz}al-a mi-ni-ib-bala-e-ne| They broke up the good house with pickaxes. 
uru2 du6-du6-dam mu-un-ga2-ga2-ne| They reduced the city to ruin mounds. 
nin-bi a uru2-gu10 im-me a e2-gu10 im-me| Its queen cried, “Alas, my city", cried, “Alas, my house.” 
{d}nin-gal-e a uru2-gu10 im-me a e2-gu10 im-me| Ningal cried, “Alas, my city,” cried, “Alas, my house. 
lu2 nu-nus-e u3 uru2-gu10 mu-da-gul u3 e2-gu10 mu-da-gul| As for me, the woman, both my city has been destroyed and my house has been destroyed. 
{d}nanna esz3 uri2{ki} mu-da-gul mu-lu-bi ba-ug5-ga-esz| O Nanna, the shrine Ur has been destroyed and its people have been killed.” 
ki-ru-gu2 6(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 6th kirugu 
tur3-ra-na amasz-a-na nu-nus-e inim gig mu-ni-ib-be2| n her cow-pen, in her sheepfold the woman utters bitter words: 
uru2 u4-de3 am3-gul-e| “The city has been destroyed by the storm.” 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its gišgigal. 
ama {d}nin-gal uru2-ni lu2-erim2-gin7 bar-ta ba-da-gub| Mother Ningal, like an enemy, stands outside her city. 
lu2 nu-nus-e er2 e2 hul-a-na gig-ga-bi im-me| The woman laments bitterly over her devastated house. 
egir3-re esz3 uri2{ki} hul-a-na gig-ga-bi im-me| Over her devastated shrine Ur, the princess bitterly declares: 
an-ne2 uru2-gu10 na-ag2 ha-ba-da-an-ku5 uru2-gu10 hu-mu-da-gul| “An has indeed cursed my city, my city has been destroyed before me. 
{d}mu-ul-lil2-le e2-gu10 szu he2-bi2-in-bala {gesz}al-e ha-ba-ra| Enlil has indeed transformed my house, it has been smitten by pickaxes. 
sig-ta di-ga2 izi ha-ba-ni-in-szub a uru2-gu10 hu-mu-da-gul| On my ones coming from the south he hurled fire. Alas, my city has indeed been destroyed before me. 
{d}mu-ul-lil2-e i-bi2 nim-ta di-ga2 u3-bu-bu-ul ha-ba-ni-in-szub| n my ones coming from the highlands Enlil hurled flames. 
uru2 bar-ra uru2 bar hu-mu-da-an-gul a uru2-gu10 ga-am3-du11| Outside the city, the outer city was destroyed before me -- I shall cry “Alas, my city.” 
uru2 sza3-ba uru2 sza3-ab hu-mu-da-an-gul a uru2-gu10 ga-am3-du11| Inside the city, the inner city was destroyed before me -- I shall cry “Alas, my city.” 
e2 uru2 bar-ra-gu10 ha-ba-gul-gul a e2-gu10 ga-am3-du11| My houses of the outer city were destroyed -- I shall cry “Alas, my houses.” 
e2 uru2 sza3-ba-gu10 ha-ba-gul-gul a e2-gu10 ga-am3-du11| My houses of the inner city were destroyed -- I shall cry “Alas, my houses.”" 
uru2-gu10 u8 zi-gin7 ba-ra-ma-lu sipa zi-bi ba-ra-gen| “My city no longer multiplies for me like good ewes, its good shepherd is gone. 
uri2{ki} u8 zi-gin7 ba-ra-ma-lu kab-bar-bi ba-ra-gen| Ur no longer multiplies for me like good ewes, its shepherd boy is gone. 
gu4-gu10 tur3-bi-a ba-ra-mu-un-szub mu-lu-bi ba-ra-gen| My bull no longer crouches in its cow-pen, its herdsman is gone. 
e-ze2-gu10 amasz-bi-a ba-ra-mu-un-szub na-gada-bi ba-ra-gen| My sheep no longer crouch in their fold, their herdsman is gone. 
i7 uru2-ga2-ke4 sahar ha-ba-nigin2 e2 ka5-a ha-ba-an-du3| In the river of my city dust has gathered, and the holes of foxes have been dug there. 
sza3-ba a zal-le ba-ra-mu-un-de6 mu-un-ku5-bi ba-ra-gen| In its midst no flowing water is carried, its tax-collector is gone. 
gan2 uru2-ga2-ke4 sze ba-ra-ma-al mu-un-gar3-bi ba-ra-gen| In the fields of my city there is no grain, their farmer is gone. 
gan2-gu10 gan2 {gesz}al-e ri-a-gin7 mul-gan2 bil2 ha-ba-mu2| My fields, like fields from which the hoe has been kept away (?), have grown tangled (?) weeds. 
pu2-kiri6 lal3 gurun diri-gu10 {gesz}{u2}kiszi17 kur-ra ha-ba-mu2| My orchards and gardens that produced abundant syrup and wine have grown mountain thornbushes. 
edin giri17-zal-bi du3-du3-a-gu10 gir4-gin7 ha-ba-hur-hur| My plain that used to be covered in its luxurious verdure has become cracked (?) like a kiln.” 
mu-un-gur11-gu10 buru4{muszen}-dugud zi-ga-gin7 dal-dal-bi ha-ba-ab-in-zi mu-un-gur11-gu10 ga-am3-du11| “My possessions, like a flock of rooks rising up, have risen in flight -- I shall cry “O my possessions.” 
mu-un-gur11-gu10 sig-ta di-ga2 sig-sze3 ha-ba-ab-ir mu-un-gur11-gu10 ga-am3-du11| He who came from the south has carried my possessions off to the south -- I shall cry “O my possessions.” 
mu-un-gur11-gu10 i-bi2 nim-ta di-ga2 i-bi2 nim-sze3 ha-ba-ab-ir mu-un-gur11-gu10 ga-am3-du11| He who came from the highlands has carried my possessions off to the highlands -- I shall cry “O my possessions.” 
ku3 za {na4}za-gin3-gu10 hu-mu-da-an-bir-bir-re mu-un-gur11-gu10 ga-am3-du11| My silver, gems and lapis lazuli have been scattered about -- I shall cry “O my possessions.” 
gil-sa-gu10 sug-ge4 hu-mu-da-ab-gu7 mu-un-gur11-gu10 ga-am3-du11| The swamp has swallowed my treasures -- I shall cry “O my possessions.” 
ku3-gu10 lu2 ku3 nu-zu-u3-ne szu-bi ha-ba-da-ab-si| Men ignorant of silver have filled their hands with my silver. 
za-gu10 lu2 za nu-zu-u3-ne gu2-bi ha-ba-da-ab-si| Men ignorant of gems have fastened my gems around their necks. 
buru5{muszen} muszen-gu10 hu-mu-dal-dal a uru2-gu10 ga-am3-du11| My small birds and fowl have flown away -- I shall say “Alas, my city.” 
gi4-in du5-mu-gu10 ma2-e ha-ba-ab-lah4-e-esz a uru2-gu10 ga-am3-du11| My slave-girls and children have been carried off by boat -- I shall say “Alas, my city.” 
me-li-e-a gi4-in-gu10 uru2 kur2-ra szu-sze-er kur2 ha-ba-an-dab5| Woe is me, my slave-girls bear strange emblems in a strange city. 
szul-gu10 edin ki nu-zu-na tug2-mu-un-dur7 ha-ba-an-ak| My young men mourn in a desert they do not know.” 
me-li-e-a uru2-gu10 nu-me-a me-e ga-sza-an-bi nu-gen| “Woe is me, my city which no longer exists -- I am not its queen. 
{d}nanna uri2{ki} nu-me-a me-e lu2-bi nu-gen| Nanna, Ur which no longer exists -- I am not its owner. 
ar2-mur-ra e2-gu10 ha-ba-du3-a uru2-gu10 ha-ba-gul-la| Whose house has been made into ruins, 
nu-nus zi-gen uru2-gu10-ta uru2 kur2 ha-ba-ra-du3-du3-a| I am the good woman whose city has been destroyed, in place of whose city a strange city has been built. 
ar2-mur-ra uru2-gu10 ha-ba-du3-a e2-gu10 ha-ba-gul-la| Whose house has been made into ruins, 
ga-sza-an-gal-gen uru2-gu10-ta e2 kur2 ha-ba-ra-du3-du3-a| I am Ningal whose city has been destroyed, in place of whose city a strange city has been built. 
me-li-e-a uru2 mu-da-gul u3 e2-gu10 mu-da-gul| “Woe is me, the city has been destroyed, my house too has been destroyed. 
{d}nanna esz3 uri2{ki} mu-da-gul mu-lu-bi ba-ug5-ga-esz| Nanna, the shrine Ur has been destroyed, its people killed. 
me-li-e-a me-a tusz-u3-de3 me-a gub-bu-de3| Woe is me, where can I sit, where can I stand? 
me-li-e-a uru2-gu10-ta e2 kur2 ma-ra-an-du3-u3-de3| Woe is me, in place of my city a strange house is being erected. 
nu-nus zi-gen e2-gu10-ta uru2 kur2 ma-ra-an-ga2-ga2-de3| I am the good woman in place of whose house a strange city is being built. 
ki-bi-ta edin-ta bad-ra2-a-bi a mu-lu-gu10 ga-am3-du11| Upon its removal from its place, from the plain, I shall say “Alas, my people.” 
uru2-gu10 uri2{ki}-ta bad-ra2-a-bi a uru2-gu10 ga-am3-du11| Upon my city's removal from Ur, I shall say “Alas, my house.”" 
lu2 siki-ni ZI&ZI.LAGAB-bur-gin7 szu mu-ni-in-dub2-dub2| The woman tears at her hair as if it were rushes. 
gaba-ni ub3 ku3-ga-am3 i3-sag3-ge a uru2-gu10 im-me| She beats the holy ub drum at her chest, she cries “Alas, my city.” 
igi-ni er2-ra mi-ni-ib-zi-zi-i-zi er2 gig i3-sze8-sze8| Her eyes well with tears, she weeps bitterly: 
me-li-e-a uru2-gu10 nu-me-a me-e ga-sza-an-bi nu-gen| “Woe is me, my city which no longer exists -- I am not its queen. 
{d}nanna esz3 uri2{ki} nu-me-a me-e mu-lu-bi nu-gen| Nanna, the shrine Ur which no longer exists -- I am not its owner. 
me-li-e-a {e2}tur3 bu-ra-gen ab2 sag2 du11-ga-gen| Woe is me, I am one whose cow-pen has been torn down, I am one whose cows have been scattered. 
{d}ga-sza-an-gal-gen na-gada pe-el-la2-gin7 {gesz}tukul ganam4-ma bi2-in-szub| I am Ningal on whose ewes the weapon has fallen, as in the case of an unworthy herdsman. 
me-li-e-a uru2-ta e3-a-gen ni2 nu-dub2-bu-gen| Woe is me, I have been exiled from the city, I can find no rest. 
{d}ga-sza-an-gal-gen e2-ta e3-a-gen ki-tusz nu-pa3-de3-gen| I am Ningal, I have been exiled from the house, I can find no dwelling place. 
i-gi4-in-zu gir5 uru2 kur2-ra sag il2 tusz-a-gen| I am sitting as if a stranger with head high in a strange city. 
e2 ur5-ra mu-lu tusz-bi tusz-tusz-a gu3 e-ne-eg3 nu-diri-gen| “I am one who, sitting in a debtors prison among its inmates, can make no extravagant claims. 
ki-ba nam uru2-na mu-un-na-te er2 gig i3-sze8-sze8| In that place I approached him for the sake of his city -- I weep bitterly. 
nin-ra nam e2-a-na mu-un-na-te er2 gig i3-sze8-sze8| I approached the lord for the sake of his house -- I weep bitterly. 
nam e2 hul-a-na mu-un-na-te er2 gig i3-sze8-sze8| I approached him for the sake of his destroyed house -- I weep bitterly. 
nam uru2 hul-a-na mu-un-na-te er2 gig i3-sze8-sze8| I approached him for the sake of his destroyed city -- I weep bitterly. 
me-li-e-a na-ag2 uru2-gu10 ga-am3-du11 na-ag2 uru2-gu10 gig-ga-am3| Woe is me, I shall say “Fate of my city, bitter is the fate of my city.” 
nin-gen e2 gul-la-gu10 ga-am3-du11 na-ag2 e2-gu10 gig-ga-am3| I the queen shall say “O my destroyed house, bitter is the fate of my house.” 
sze-eb uri2{ki}-ma a du11-ga-am3 a bi2-gi4-a-gu10| O my brick-built Ur which has been flooded, which has been washed away, 
e2 zi-gu10 uru2-gu10 du6-du6-da ba-mar-re-en-na-gu10| O my good house, my city which has been reduced to ruin mounds, 
bur2-ra e2 zi gul-la-za-ka ba-e3-de3-nu2-u3-nam| in the debris of your destroyed righteous house, I shall lie down alongside you. 
gu4 szub-ba-gin7 in-gar-zu-ta ba-ra-mu-e-da-zi-ga| Like a fallen bull, I will never rise up from your wall (?).” 
me-li-e-a du3-a-zu lul-la-am3 gul-la-zu gig-ga-am3| “Woe is me, untrustworthy was your building, and bitter your destruction. 
{nu}nunus-gen esz3 uri2{ki} nidba-bi i3-ba-kur2-ra-am3| I am the woman at whose shrine Ur the food offerings have been terminated. 
agrun-ku3 e2 gibil-gibil-la-gu10 la-la-bi nu-gi4-a-gu10| O my Agrun-kug, the all-new house whose charms never sated me, 
uru2-gu10 du3-a la-ba-mar-ra-gu10 ta-a-asz hul-a-gu10| O my city no longer regarded as having been built -- devastated for what reason? 
ba-gul in-ga-ba-hul-a-gu10 ta-a-asz hul-a-gu10| O my house both destroyed and devastated -- devastated for what reason? 
a-da-al u4 hul gig du11-ga a2-bi la-ba-ra-e3| Nobody at all escaped the force of the storm ordered in hate. 
uri2{ki}-ma e2 {d}suen-na-gu10 gul-la-bi gig-ga-am3| O my house of Suen in Ur, bitter was its destruction.” 
ki-ru-gu2 7(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 7th kirugu 
a uru2-gu10 a e2-gu10| “Alas, my city, alas, my house.” 
gesz-gi-gal2-bi-im| Its gišgigal. 
munus zi lu2 uru2 ba-e-da-gul-la i3-ne-esz2-gin7 i3-e-am3-mu2| O good woman whose city has been destroyed, now how do you exist? 
u4 uru2-zu im-ma-gul-la-ba i3-ne-esz2-gin7 i3-e-am3-mu2| After your city has been destroyed, now how do you exist? 
uru2-zu uru2 kur2-ra ba-ab-gar i3-ne-esz2-gin7 i3-e-am3-mu2| Your city has become a strange city, now how do you exist? 
uru2 du6-du6-da ba-gar-ra-zu muszen-bi nu-gen| You are not a bird of your city which has been reduced to ruin mounds. 
e2 zi {gesz}al-e ba-gar-ra-za tusz-bi-sze3 la-ba-tusz-en| You cannot live there as a resident in your good house given over to the pickaxe. 
ug3 ki-lul-la ba-ab-re7-a-za nin-bi-sze3 la-ba-ku4-re-en| You cannot act as queen of a people led off to slaughter. 
er2-zu er2 kur2-ra ba-ab-gar ka-na-ag2-zu nu-sze8-sze8| Your tears have become strange tears, your Land no longer weeps. 
er2-sza3-ne-sza4 nu-tuku-am3 kur-kur im-ma-an-tusz| With no lamentation prayers, it dwells in foreign lands. 
uru2-zu du6-du6-da im-ma-an-gar i3-ne-esz2-gin7 i3-e-am3-mu2| Your city has been made into ruins; now how do you exist? 
uri2{ki} esz3 lil2-e im-ma-an-gar i3-ne-esz2-gin7 i3-e-am3-mu2| Ur, the shrine, is haunted by the breezes, now how do you exist? 
en-bi ge6-par3-ra ba-ra-mu-un-til i3-ne-esz2-gin7 i3-e-am3-mu2| Its en priestess no longer lives in the gipar, now how do you exist? 
ud5-ga lu2 szu-luh-e ki ag2-e szu-luh nu-mu-ra-an-ga2-ga2| In the uzga shrine the priest who cherishes purification rites makes no purification rites for you. 
a-a {d}nanna iszib-zu szita ku3-ga szu nu-mu-ra-ni-in-du7| Father Nanna, your išib priest does not make perfect holy supplications to you. 
lu2-mah-zu gi-gun4-na ku3-zu sza3 gada la-ba-an-la2| Your lumaḫ priest does not dress in linen in your holy giguna shrine. 
en zi sza3 hi-li-a pa3-da-zu e2-kisz-nu-gal2-la-am3| Your righteous en priestess chosen in your ardent heart, she of the E-kiš-nu-gal, 
esz3-da ge6-par3-sze3 hul2-la-na nu-mu-ni-in-dib-dib-be2| does not proceed joyously from the shrine to the gipar. 
a-u3-a e2 ezem-ma-za ezem nu-mu-ni-in-du10-ge-esz| The aua priests do not celebrate the festivals in your house of festivals. 
szem3 {kusz}a2-la2-e nig2 sza3 hul2-le-da tigi-a nu-mu-ra-an-du12-usz| They do not play for you the šem and ala instruments which gladden the heart, nor the tigi. 
ug3 sag-ge6-ga ezem-zu-sze3 a la-ba-an-tu5-tu5-ne| The black-headed people do not bathe during your festivals. 
en3-du-zu er2-ra ba-e-da-an-ku4 en3-tukum-sze3 mu2| Your song has been turned into weeping before you -- how long will this last? 
tigi-zu a-nir-ra ba-e-da-an-ku4 en3-tukum-sze3 mu2| Your tigi music has been turned into lamentation before you -- how long will this last? 
gu4-zu tur3-bi-a ba-ra-mu-un-de6 i3-bi nu-mu-ra-ak-e| Your bull is not brought into its pen, its fat is not prepared for you. 
udu-zu amasz-bi-a ba-ra-mu-un-dur2-ru ga-bi nu-mu-ra-dulu(SZU.BU)-e| Your sheep does not live in its fold, its milk is not made abundant for you. 
i3 gur3-ru-zu tur3-ta nu-mu-ra-de6 en3-tukum-sze3 mu2| Your fat carrier does not come to you from the cow-pen -- how long will this last? 
ga gur3-ru-zu amasz-ta nu-mu-ra-de6 en3-tukum-sze3 mu2| Your milk carrier does not come to you from the sheepfold -- how long will this last? 
szu-pesz ku6 gur3-ru-zu hul-gal2-e ba-an-dab5 en3-tukum-sze3 mu2| An evildoer has seized your fisherman who was carrying fish -- how long will this last? 
muszen-du3 muszen gur3-ru-zu gir2-gir2-re im-DU| Lightning carried off your fowler who was carrying birds -- how long will this last? 
i7 ma2-gur8-ra ba-ab-du7-a-zu sza3-ba teme{sar} ba-mu2| The teme plants grow in the middle of your watercourses which were once suitable for barges, 
har-ra-an {gesz}gigir-ra ba-ab-gar-ra-za {gesz}{u2}kiszi17 kur-ra ba-mu2| and mountain thornbushes grow on your roads which had been constructed for waggons. 
nin-gu10 uru2-zu ama-bi-gin7-nam er2 mu-e-szi-sze8-sze8| My queen, your city weeps before you as its mother. 
uri2{ki}-ma dumu sila ha-lam-ma-gin7 ki mu-e-szi-kin-kin| Ur, like a child lost in a street, seeks a place before you. 
e2-zu lu2 nig2 u2-gu de2-a-gin7 szu mu-e-szi-sza-an-sza| Your house, like a man who has lost everything, stretches out (?) its hands to you. 
sig4 e2 zi-da-zu lu2-ulu3-gin7 me-a-zu im-me| Your brick-built righteous house, like a human being, cries “Where are you?.” 
nin-gu10 e2-ta e3-a he2-me-en uru2-ta ba-ra-e3-me-en| My queen, you have indeed left the house, you have left the city. 
en3-sze3-am3 uru2-za lu2-erim2-gin7 bar-ta ba-e-da-gub| How long will you stand aside from your city like an enemy? 
ama {d}nin-gal uru2-zu lu2-erim2-gin7 gaba-za ba-e-de3-sa2| Mother Ningal, you confronted your city like an enemy. 
nin uru2-ni ki ag2 he2-me-en-na amasz-zu-ta ba-e-ni-tag| Although you are a queen who loves her city, you abandoned your sheepfold. 
kalam-ma-ni-sze3 kusz2-u3 he2-me-en-na za-e izi-ba mu-un-tag| Although you are one who cares for her Land, you set it on fire. 
ama {d}nin-gal gu4-gin7 tur3-zu-sze3 udu-gin7 amasz-zu-sze3| Mother Ningal, return like a bull to your cattle-pen, like a sheep to your fold, 
gu4-gin7 tur3 u4-bi-ta-sze3 udu-gin7 amasz-zu-sze3| like a bull to your cattle-pen of former days, like a sheep to your fold. 
dumu banda3{da}-gin7 ama5-zu-sze3 nin-gu10 e2-zu-sze3| My queen, like a young child to your room, return to your house. 
an lugal dingir-re-e-ne-ke4 musz3-am3-zu he2-em-me| May An, king of the gods, declare “Enough!” to you. 
{d}en-lil2 lugal kur-kur-ra-ke4 nam-zu he2-eb-tar-re| May Enlil, king of all the lands, decree your fate. 
uru2-zu ki-bi ha-ra-ab-gi4-gi4 nam-nin-bi ak-a| May he restore your city for you -- exercise its queenship! 
nibru{ki} ki-bi ha-ra-ab-gi4-gi4 nam-nin-bi ak-a| May he restore Nibru for you -- exercise its queenship! 
uri2{ki} ki-bi ha-ra-ab-gi4-gi4 nam-nin-bi ak-a| May he restore Ur for you -- exercise its queenship! 
i3-si-in{ki} ki-bi ha-ra-ab-gi4-gi4 nam-nin-bi ak-a| May he restore Isin for you -- exercise its queenship! 
ki-ru-gu2 8(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 8th kirugu. 
me-gu10 mu-da-kur2-ra-am3| “My powers have been alienated from me.” 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its gišgigal. 
e u4-de3 u4-de3 kalam tesz2-a mi-ni-ib-ra| Alas, storm after storm swept the Land together: 
u4 gal an-na-ke4 u4 gu3 dub2-dub2-be2| the great storm of heaven, the ever-roaring storm, 
u4 gig-ga kalam-ma ba-e-zal-la re| the malicious storm which swept over the Land, 
u4 uru2 gul-gul-e u4 e2 gul-gul-e| the storm which destroyed cities, the storm which destroyed houses, 
u4 tur3 gul-gul-e u4 amasz tab-tab-be2| the storm which destroyed cow-pens, the storm which burned sheepfolds, 
garza ku3-ga szu bi2-ib2-la2-a re| which laid hands on the holy rites, 
GA2xGAR nig2 aratta{ki}-ka szu pe-el-la2 im-mi-ib-du11-ga re| , which defiled the weighty counsel, 
u4 kalam-ma nig2 du10 im-mi-ib-ku5-da re| the storm which cut off all that is good from the Land, 
u4 sag-ge6-ga a2 bi2-ib-la2-a re| the storm which pinioned the arms of the black-headed people. 
ki-ru-gu2 9(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 9th kirugu. 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its gišgigal. 
u4 ama nu-zu re u4 a-a nu-zu re| The storm which knows no mother, the storm which knows no father, 
u4 dam nu-zu re u4 dumu nu-zu re| the storm which knows no wife, the storm which knows no child, 
u4 nin9 nu-zu re u4 szesz nu-zu re| the storm which knows no sister, the storm which knows no brother, 
u4 uszur nu-zu re u4 ma-la nu-zu re| the storm which knows no neighbour, the storm which knows no female companion, 
u4 dam im-szub-ba u4 dumu im-szub-ba re| the storm which caused the wife to be abandoned, which caused the child to be abandoned, 
u4-de3 u4 kalam-ma u2-gu bi2-ib-de2-a re| the storm which caused the light in the Land to disappear, 
u4 hul gig du11-ga {d}en-lil2-la2-ta im-mi-in-zal-la re| the storm which swept through, ordered in hate by Enlil - 
a-a {d}nanna u4-bi uru2-zu-ta ki nam-ba-ga2-ga2| Father Nanna, may that storm swoop down no more on your city. 
ug3 sag-ge6-zu igi-zu nam-bi2-ib-du8| May your black-headed people see it no more. 
u4-bi im an-ta szeg3-ge26-gin7 ki-tusz-bi nam-ba-gur-ru| May that storm, like rain pouring down from heaven, never recur. 
nig2-zi-gal2 an ki sag-ge6 im-ma-an-dub2-ba re| May that storm, which struck down all the black-headed living beings of heaven and earth, 
u4-ba du3-a-bi he2-em-ma-gul-lu| be entirely destroyed. 
abul ge6 u3-na-gin7 {gesz}ig he2-bi2-in-kesz2-da| May the door be closed on it, like the great city-gate at night-time. 
u4-ba szudum-ma na-an-ni-ga2-ga2| May that storm not be given a place in the reckoning, 
nig2-ka9-bi e2 {d}en-lil2-la2-ta {gesz}gag-ta he2-em-ta-si-ig| may its record be hung from a nail outside the house of Enlil. 
ki-ru-gu2 1(u)-kam-ma-am3| 10th kirugu. 
u4 ul u4 kur2-ra u4-da egir-bi-sze3| Until distant days, other days, future days. 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its gišgigal. 
u4 ul kalam ki gar-ra-sze3| From distant days when the Land was founded, 
{d}nanna lu2 sun5-na giri3-zu mu-un-dab5-be2| O Nanna, the humble people who lay hold of your feet 
er2 e2 si-ga-bi mu-ra-an-de6 igi-zu-sze3 du12-a-bi| have brought to you their tears for the silent house, playing music before you. 
sag-ge6 ba-ra-szub-bu-usz-a-bi giri17 szu ha-ra-ab-tag-ge-ne| May the black-headed people, cast away from you, make obeisance to you. 
uru2 du6-du6-da ba-an-gar-ra-za i-si-isz hu-mu-ra-an-ga2-ga2| In your city reduced to ruin mounds may a lament be made to you. 
{d}nanna uru2{ki} ki-bi gi4-a-za pa e3 ha-ra-ab-ak-e| O Nanna, may your restored city be resplendent before you. 
mul-an ku3-gin7 nam-mu-un-ha-lam-e igi-zu he2-bi2-ib-dab5-be2| Like a bright heavenly star may it not be destroyed, may it pass before you. 
dingir lu2-u18-lu-ke4 kadra mu-ra-an-de6| The personal deity of a man brings you a greeting gift; 
lu2 siskur2-ra-ke4 a-ra-zu mu-ra-ab-be2| a supplicant utters prayers to you. 
{d}nanna E2xSAL kalam-ma-me-en| Nanna, you who have mercy on the Land, 
en {d}dili{im2}-babbar sza3-zu im-mi-ib-du11-ga re| Lord Ašimbabbar -- as concerns him who speaks your heart's desire, 
{d}nanna lu2-ulu3-bi nam-tag-ga-ni u3-mu-e-du8| Nanna, after you have absolved that man's sin, 
lu2 a-ra-zu im-me-a-bi sza3 ha-ba-na-hug-e| may your heart relent towards him who utters prayers to you. 
dingir lu2-ba-ke4 kadra mu-ra-an-de6| (3 mss. add 1 line:) The personal deity of this man brings you a present. 
lu2 siskur2-ra mu-un-gub-ba-bi-ir igi zi mu-un-szi-in-bar| He looks favourably on the man who stands there with his offering. 
{d}nanna igi du8-a bar-ra-zu sza3 szu nigin su3-ga-am3| Nanna, you whose penetrating gaze searches hearts, 
lu2-ulu3-bi u4 hul du3-a-ba he2-em-ma-an-szi-ku3-ge| may its people who suffered that evil storm be pure before you. 
sza3 kalam-ma gal2-la-zu he2-em-ma-an-szi-ku3-ge| May the hearts of your people who dwell in the Land be pure before you. 
{d}nanna uru2 ki-bi gi4-a-za me-tesz2 he2-i-i| Nanna, in your restored city may you be fittingly praised. 
ki-ru-gu2 1(u) 1(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 11th kirugu. 
u4 szu bala ak-de3 gesz-hur ha-lam-e-de3| To overturn the appointed times, to obliterate the divine plans, 
u4-de3 mar-uru5-gin7 tesz2-bi i3-gu7-e| the storms gather to strike like a flood. 
me ki-en-gi-ra szu bala ak-de3| To overturn the divine powers of Sumer, 
bala sa6-ga e2-ba gi4-gi4-de3| to lock up the favourable reign in its home, 
uru2 gul-gul-lu-de3 e2 gul-gul-lu-de3| to destroy the city, 
tur3 gul-gul-lu-de3 amasz tab-tab-be2-de3| to destroy the house, to destroy the cattle-pen, 
gu4-bi tur3-bi-a nu-gub-bu-de3| that the cattle should not stand in the pen, 
udu-bi amasz-bi-a nu-dagal-e-de3| that the sheep should not multiply in the fold, 
i7-bi a mun4-na tum3-u3-de3| that watercourses should carry brackish water, 
gan2-ne2 zi-de3 {u2}KI.KAL mu2-mu2-de3| that weeds should grow in the fertile fields, 
edin-e u2-a-nir mu2-mu2-de3| that mourning plants should grow in the open country, 
ama dumu-ni-ir ki nu-kin-kin-de3| that the mother should not seek out her child, 
ad-da a dam-gu10 nu-di-de3| that the father should not say “O my dear wife!", 
dam tur ur2-ra nu-hul2-le-de3| that the junior wife should take no joy in his embrace, 
dumu tur du10-ba nu-bulug3-ge26-e-de3| that the young child should not grow vigorous on his knee, 
UM.ME-e u5-a nu-di-de3| that the wet-nurse should not sing lullabies; 
nam-lugal-la ki-tusz-bi kur2-ru-de3| to change the location of kingship, 
esz-bar kin-e szu la2-e-de3| to defile the seeking of oracles, 
nam-lugal kalam-ma kar-kar-re-de3| to take kingship away from the Land, 
igi-bi ki-szar2-ra ga2-ga2-de3| to cast the eye of the storm on all the land, 
inim du11-ga an {d}en-lil2-la2-ta gesz-hur ha-lam-e-de3| to obliterate the divine plans by the order of An and Enlil; 
u4 an-ne2 kur-kur-ra sag-ki ba-da-an-gid2-da-ba| after An had frowned upon all the lands, 
{d}en-lil2-le igi-ni ki kur2-ra ba-an-gar-ra-a-ba| after Enlil had looked favourably on an enemy land, 
{d}nin-tu-re nig2-dim2-dim2-ma-ni za3 bi2-in-tag-ga-a-ba| after Nintur had scattered the creatures that she had created, 
{d}en-ki-ke4 {i7}idigna {i7}buranun-na asz2 bi2-in-bala-a-ba| after Enki had altered the course of the Tigris and Euphrates, 
{d}utu har-ra-an kaskal-e nam ba-an-ku5-da-a-ba| after Utu had cast his curse on the roads and highways; 
ki-en-gi-ra me-bi ha-lam-e-de3 gesz-hur-bi kur2-ru-de3| so as to obliterate the divine powers of Sumer, to change its preordained plans, 
uri5{ki}-ma me nam-lugal-la bala-bi su3-su3-u4-de3| to alienate the divine powers of the reign of kingship of Ur, 
dumu nun-na e2-kisz-nu-gal2-la-na szu pe-el-la2 di-de3| to humiliate the princely son in his house E-kiš-nu-gal, 
{d}nanna ug3 u8-gin7 lu-a-na igi-te-en-bi si-il-le-de3| to break up the unity of the people of Nanna, numerous as ewes; 
uri5{ki} esz3 nidba gal-gal-la nidba-bi kur2-ru-de3| to change the food offerings of Ur, the shrine of magnificent food offerings; 
ug3-bi ki-tusz-ba nu-tusz-u3-de3 ki-erim2-e szum2-mu-de3| that its people should no longer dwell in their quarters, that they should be given over to live in an inimical place; 
szimaszki{ki} elam{ki} lu2-kur2-ra ki-tusz-bi tusz-u3-de3| that Šimaški and Elam, the enemy, should dwell in their place; 
sipa-bi e2-gal-la ni2-te-na lu2-erim2-e dab5-be2-de3| that its shepherd, in his own palace, should be captured by the enemy, 
di-bi2-{d}suen kur elam{ki}-ma-sze3 gesz-bur2-ra tum2-u3-de3| that Ibbi-Suen should be taken to the land Elam in fetters, 
isz za-bu{ki} gaba a-ab-ba-ka-ta za3 an-sza4-an{ki}-na-sze3| that from Mount Zabu on the edge of the sea to the borders of Anšan, 
sim{muszen} e2-bi ba-ra-an-dal-a-gin7 iri-ni-sze3 nu-gur-re-de3| like a swallow that has flown from its house, he should never return to his city; 
{i7}idigna {i7}buranun-na gu2 tab 2(disz)-a-ba u2 hul mu2-mu2-de3| that on the two parallel banks of the Tigris and of the Euphrates bad weeds should grow, 
kaskal-la giri3 nu-ga2-ga2-de3 har-ra-an nu-kin-kin-de3| that no one should set out on the road, that no one should seek out the highway, 
uru2 a2-dam ki gar-gar-ra-ba du6-du6-ra szid-de3| that the city and its settled surroundings should be razed to ruin-mounds; 
ug3 sag-ge6 lu-lu-a-ba gesz-hasz-e ak-de3| that its numerous black-headed people should be slaughtered; 
gan2-ne2 zi-de3 {gesz}al nu-ru-gu2-de3 numun ki nu-tag-de3| that the hoe should not attack the fertile fields, that seed should not be planted in the ground, 
e-el-lu szer3 gu4 su8-su8-ba edin-na nu-di-de3| that the melody of the cowherds' songs should not resound in the open country, 
{e2}tur3-ra i3 gara2 nu-ak-de3 szurum ki nu-tag-e-de3| that butter and cheese should not be made in the cattle-pen, that dung should not be stacked on the ground, 
sipa-de3 gi-szukur-ra amasz ku3-ga szu nu-nigin2-nigin2-de3| that the shepherd should not enclose the sacred sheepfold with a fence, 
i-lu-lam-ma dun5-dun5 {dug}szakir3-ra amasz-a nu-di-de3| that the song of the churning should not resound in the sheepfold; 
edin-na masz2-ansze tur-re-de3 nig2-zi-gal2 til-le-de3| to decimate the animals of the open country, to finish off all living things, 
nig2-ur2-limmu2 {d}szakkan2-na-ke4 szurum ki nu-tag-ge-de3| that the four-legged creatures of Šakkan should lay no more dung on the ground, 
ambar-ra szu ki-in-dar di-de3 numun nu-tuku-tuku-de3| that the marshes should be so dry as to be full of cracks and have no new seed, 
gesz-gi gi sag hul mu2-mu2-de3 hab2-ba til-e-de3| that sickly-headed reeds should grow in the reedbeds and come to an end in a stinking morass, 
pu2-{gesz}kiri6 u2 gibil-la2 nu-me-a ni2-ba szu2-szu2-de3| that there should be no new growth in the orchards, that it should all collapse by itself 
uri5{ki} am gal u3-na gub-ba ni2-bi-ta nir-gal2| Ur the great charging wild bull, confident in its own strength, 
iri numun i-i nam-en nam-lugal-la ki sikil-la du3-a| the primeval city of lordship and kingship, built on sacred ground - 
gu4-gin7 saman ul4-la-bi szub-bu-de3 gu2 ki-sze3 la2-e-de3| - so as quickly to subdue it like a roped ox, to bow its neck to the ground; 
an {d}en-lil2 {d}en-ki {d}nin-hur-sag-ga2-ke4 nam-bi ha-ba-an-tar-re-esz| An, Enlil, Enki and Ninḫursaga have decided this as its fate. 
nam-tar-ra-bi nig2 nu-kur2-ru-dam a-ba szu mi-ni-ib2-bala-e| Its fate cannot be changed. Who can overturn it? 
inim du11-ga an {d}en-lil2-la2 1(disz)-kam sag a-ba-a mu-un-ga2-ga2| It is the command of An and Enlil. Who can oppose it? 
an-ne2 ki-en-gi ki-tusz-ba bi2-in-hu-luh ug3-e ni2 bi2-in-te| An frightened the very dwellings of Sumer, the people were afraid. 
{d}en-lil2-le u4 gig-ga mu-un-zal iri-a me bi2-ib-gar| Enlil blew an evil storm, silence lay upon the city. 
{d}nin-tu-re ama5 kalam-ma-ka {gesz}ig-szu-ur2 im-mi-in-de6| Nintur bolted the door of the storehouses of the Land. 
{d}en-ki-ke4 {i7}idigna {i7}buranun-na a im-ma-da-an-kesz2| Enki blocked the water in the Tigris and the Euphrates. 
{d}utu nig2-si-sa2 inim ge-na ka-ta ba-da-an-kar| Utu took away the pronouncement of equity and justice. 
{d}inanna-ke4 me3 szen-szen-na ki-bala-e ba-an-szum2| inanna handed over victory in strife and battle to a rebellious land. 
{d}nin-gir2-su-ke4 ki-en-gi ga-gin7 ur-e ba-an-de2| Ningirsu poured Sumer away like milk to the dogs. 
kalam-ma ga-ba-ra-hum im-ma-an-szub nig2 lu2 nu-zu-a| Turmoil descended upon the Land, something that no one had ever known, 
nig2 igi nu-gal2-la inim nu-gal2-la nig2 szu nu-te-ge26-dam| something unseen, which had no name, something that could not be fathomed. 
kur-kur-re ni2 te-a-bi-a szu suh3-a ba-ab-du11| The lands were confused in their fear. 
iri{ki} dingir-bi ba-da-gur sipa-bi ba-da-ha-lam| The god of the city turned away, its shepherd vanished. 
nam-lu2-ulu3 ni2 te-bi-a zi gig mu-un-pa-an-pa-an| The people, in their fear, breathed only with difficulty. 
u4-de3 szu-ne-ne ba-du3-du3 u4 nu-mu-un-ne-gur-re| The storm immobilised them, the storm did not let them return. 
u4 gi4-a mu-un-ne-tuku-am3 u4 dur2-bi-sze3 nu-gen| There was no return for them, the storm did not retreat 
{d}en-lil2 sipa sag-ge6-ga-ke4 a-na bi2-in-ak-a-bi| This is what Enlil, the shepherd of the black-headed people, did: 
{d}en-lil2-le e2 zi gul-gul-lu-de3 lu2 zi tur-re-de3| Enlil, to destroy the loyal households, to decimate the loyal men, 
dumu lu2 zi-da-ke4 dumu-sag-e igi hul dim2-me-de3| to put the evil eye on the sons of the loyal men, on the first-born, 
u4-ba {d}en-lil2-le gu-ti-um{ki} kur-ta im-ta-an-e11| Enlil then sent down Gutium from the mountains. 
DU-bi a-ma-ru {d}en-lil2-la2 gaba gi4 nu-tuku-am3| Their advance was as the flood of Enlil that cannot be withstood. 
tu15 gal edin-na edin-e im-si igi-sze3 mu-un-ne-gen| The great wind of the countryside filled the countryside, it advanced before them. 
edin nig2-dagal-la-ba sag3 ba-ab-du11 lu2 nu-mu-ni-in-dib-be2| The extensive countryside was destroyed, no one moved about there. 
u4 ge6-ge6-ga szika bar7-bar7-ra sa-sze3 ba-ab-de6| The dark time was roasted by hailstones and flames. 
u4 babbar-re izi-ge6-edin-na ba-da-an-tab-tab| The bright time was wiped out by a shadow. 
u4-mud-e giri17 i3-dub-dub sag i3-dab5-dab5| (2 mss. add 2 lines:) In the darkness, noses were heaped up, heads were smashed. 
u4 {gesz}gan2-ur3 an-ta e3-de3 iri {gesz}al-e ba-ab-ra-ah| The storm was a harrow coming from above, the city was struck by a hoe. 
u4-ba an ba-dub2 ki ba-sag3 igi u4-da ba-lib4| On that day, heaven rumbled, the earth trembled, the storm worked without respite. 
an ba-suh3-suh3 gissu ba-an-la2 kur-re mur mi-ni-ib-sza4| Heaven was darkened, it was covered by a shadow; the mountains roared. 
{d}utu an-ur2-ra i-in-nu2 sahar kur-ra zal-am3| Utu lay down at the horizon, dust passed over the mountains. 
{d}nanna an-pa-a i-in-nu2 ug3-e ni2 bi2-in-te| Nanna lay at the zenith, the people were afraid. 
iri{ki}-ba dingir-x ki-tusz ba-ab-be2-de3 bar-ta ba-da-gub| The city's god left his dwelling and stood aside. 
kur-kur-re iri{ki} lu2-bi nu-til-la i-im-sar-sar-re-ne| The foreigners in the city even chased away its dead. 
gesz mah ur2-bi-a mu-un-bala-e {gesz}tir-ra guru5 i| Large trees were uprooted, the forest growth was ripped out. 
pu2-{gesz}kiri6 gurun-ba mu-un-BU-BU {gesz}ligima i3-bu-re| The orchards were stripped of their fruit, they were cleaned of their offshoots. 
buru14 isin-bi-a mu-un-su-su {d}SZE.TIR i3-tur-re| The crop drowned while it was still on the stalk, 
{i7}buranun-na ad6 i3-la2-a {gesz}tukul-e sag gaz i3-ak-e| There were corpses floating in the Euphrates, weapons smashed heads. 
ad-da dam-a-ni-ta ba-da-gur dam-gu10 nu im-me| The father turned away from his wife saying “This is not my wife!” 
ama dumu-ni-ta ba-da-gur dumu-gu10 nu im-me| The mother turned away from her child saying “This is not my child!" 
e2 zi-da-ke4 e2-a-ni mu-un-szub e2-gu10 nu im-me| He who had a productive estate neglected his estate saying “This is not my estate!" 
nig2-gur11 tuku nig2-gur11-ra-ni-ta giri3 kur2 ba-ra-an-dab5| The rich man took an unfamiliar path away from his possessions. 
u4-ba nam-lugal kalam-ma-ka szu pe-el-la2 ba-ab-du11| In those days the kingship of the Land was defiled. 
aga men sag-ga2 gal2-la-bi tesz2-bi ba-ra-an-kur2| The tiara and crown that had been on the king's head were both spoiled. 
kur-kur-re du10-us2 dili dab5-ba-bi igi-te-en-bi ba-si-il| The lands that had followed the same path were split into disunity. 
uri5{ki} esz3 nidba gal-gal-la-ka nidba-bi ba-ab-kur2| The food offerings of Ur, the shrine of magnificent food offerings, were changed for the worse. 
{d}nanna ug3 u8-gin7 lu-a-na szu bala ba-da-ab-ak| Nanna traded away his people, numerous as ewes. 
lugal-bi e2-gal ni2-te-na zi im-ma-ni-in-gi4| Its king sat immobilised in his own palace. 
{d}i-bi2-{d}suen e2-gal ni2-te-na i-si-isz ba-ni-in-la2-la2| Ibbi-Suen was sitting in anguish in his own palace. 
e2-nam-ti-la sza3 hul2-la-ka-na er2 gig mu-un-sze8-sze8| In E-namtila, his place of delight, he wept bitterly. 
a-ma-ru ki al ak-e szu im-ur3-ur3-re| The flood dashing a hoe on the ground was levelling everything. 
u4 gal-gin7 ki-a mur mi-ni-ib-sza4 a-ba-a ba-ra-e3| Like a great storm it roared over the earth -- who could escape it? 
iri gul-gul-lu-de3 e2 gul-gul-lu-de3| To destroy the city, to destroy the house, 
lu2-lul lu2 zi-da an-ta nu2-u3-de3| so that traitors would lie on top of loyal men 
uri3 lu2-lul-e lu2 zi-ra ugu-a-na DU-sze3| and the blood of traitors flow upon loyal men. 
ki-ru-gu2 1(disz)-a-kam| 1st kirugu. 
u4-de3 mar-uru5-gin7 tesz2-bi i3-gu7-e| The storms gather to strike like a flood. 
gesz-gi4-gal2 ki-ru-gu2-da-kam| Ĝišgigal to the kirugu. 
e2 kisz{ki}-a hur-sag-kalam-ma-ka szu hul ba-e-du11| The house of Kiš, Ḫursag-kalama, was destroyed. 
{d}za-ba4-ba4 ki-tusz ki ag2-ga2-ni giri3 kur2 ba-ra-an-dab5| Zababa took an unfamiliar path away from his beloved dwelling. 
ama {d}ba-ba6 e2-iri-ku3-ga-na er2 gig mu-un-sze8-sze8| Mother Baba was lamenting bitterly in her E-Iri-kug. 
a iri gul-la e2 gul-la-gu10 gig-ga-bi im-me| Alas, the destroyed city, my destroyed house.” 
a iri gul-la e2 gul-la-gu10 gig-ga-bi im-me| “Alas, the destroyed city, my destroyed house.” 
ka-zal-lu{ki} iri ni2-ba lu-a szu suh3-a ba-ab-du11| Kazallu, the city of teeming multitudes, was cast into confusion. 
{d}nu-musz-da-ke4 iri ki-tusz ki ag2-ga2-ni giri3 kur2 ba-ra-an-dab5| Numušda took an unfamiliar path away from the city, his beloved dwelling. 
gidlam(MUNUS.USZ.DAM)-a-ni {d}nam-ra-at munus sa6-ga-a er2 in-sze8-sze8-e| His wife Namrat, the beautiful lady, was lamenting bitterly. 
a uru2 gul-la e2 gul-la-gu10 gig-ga-bi im-me| “Alas, the destroyed city, my destroyed house.” 
i7-bi sza3-su3-ga i3-gal2 a nu-un-de2| Its river bed was empty, no water flowed. 
i7 {d}en-ki-ke4 nam ku5-ra2-gin7 ka-bi-a ba-usz2| Like a river cursed by Enki its opening channel was dammed up. 
a-sza3-ga sze gu-nu nu-gal2 ug3-e nu-gu7-e| On the fields fine grains grew no more, people had nothing to eat. 
pu2-{gesz}kiri6-bi gir4-gin7 ba-hur-hur edin-bi sag2 ba-ab-di| The orchards were scorched like an oven, its open country was scattered. 
masz2-ansze nig2-ur2-limmu2 nig2-zi-gal2 nu-mu-un-bu-e| The four-legged wild animals did not run about. 
nig2-ur2-4(asz) {d}szakkan2-ke4 ni2 nu-mu-ni-ib-te-en-te-en| The four-legged creatures of Šakkan could find no rest. 
{d}lugal-mar2-da-ke4 iri-ni-ta bar-ta ba-da-gub| Lugal-Marda stepped outside his city. 
{d}nin-zu-an-na ki-tusz ki ag2-ga2-ni giri3 kur2 ba-ra-an-dab5| Ninzuana took an unfamiliar path away from her beloved dwelling. 
a iri gul-la e2 gul-la-gu10 gig-ga-bi im-me| “Alas, the destroyed city, my destroyed house.” 
i3-si-in{ki} esz3 kar-re nu-me-a a-e ba-e-dar| Isin, the shrine that was not a quay, was split by onrushing waters. 
{d}nin-isin2{+si}-in-na ama kalam-ma-ke4 er2 gig mu-un-sze8-sze8| Ninisina, the mother of the Land, wept bitter tears. 
a iri gul-la e2 gul-la-gu10 gig-ga-bi im-me| “Alas, the destroyed city, my destroyed house.” 
{d}en-lil2-le {d}ur-an-ki-ka {gesz}mitum2-a ba-an-sag3| Enlil smote Dur-an-ki with a mace. 
{d}en-lil2-le iri-ni esz3 nibru{ki}-a a-nir ba-ab-gar| Enlil made lamentation in his city, the shrine Nibru. 
ama {d}nin-lil2 nin ki-ur3-ra-ke4 er2 gig mu-un-sze8-sze8| Mother Ninlil, the lady of the Ki-ur shrine, wept bitter tears. 
a iri gul-la e2 gul-la-gu10 gig-ga-bi im-me| “Alas, the destroyed city, my destroyed house.” 
kesz3{ki} an-edin-na dili du3-a szu lil2-la2 ba-ab-du11| Keš, built all alone on the high open country, was haunted. 
adab{ki}-bu e2 i7-de3 la2-a re ki-bala-sze3 ba-ab-du11| Adab, the settlement which stretches out along the river, was treated as a rebellious land. 
musz kur-ra-ke4 ki-nu2 ba-ni-ib-gar ki-bala-sze3 ba-ab-du11| The snake of the mountains made his lair there, it became a rebellious land. 
gu-ti-um{ki} sza3 ba-ni-ib-bala-bala numun ba-ni-ib-i-i| The Gutians bred there, issued their seed. 
{d}nin-tu-re nig2-dim2-dim2-ma-ni-sze3 er2 gig mu-un-sze8-sze8| Nintur wept bitter tears over her creatures. 
a iri gul-la e2 gul-la-gu10 gig-ga-bi im-me| “Alas, the destroyed city, my destroyed house.” 
ki zabala{ki}-a gi-gun4-na ku3-ga szu lil2-la2 ba-ab-du11| In zabala the sacred Giguna was haunted. 
unu{ki}-ta {d}inanna ba-da-an-kar ki-erim2-e ba-ab-gen| inanna abandoned Uruk and went off to enemy territory. 
e2-an-na esz3 ge6-par4 ku3-ga erim2-e igi i-ni-in-bar| In the E-ana the enemy set eyes upon the sacred Ĝipar shrine. 
ge6-par4 ku3 nam-en-na-ba szu ba-e-la2-la2| The sacred Ĝipar of en priesthood was defiled. 
en-bi ge6-par4-ta ba-da-an-kar ki-erim2-e ba-ab-de6| Its en priest was snatched from the Ĝipar and carried off to enemy territory. 
a iri gul-la e2 gul-la-gu10 gig-ga-bi im-me| “Alas, the destroyed city, my destroyed house.” 
umma{ki} sig4-kur-sza3-ba-ke4 u4 gig-ga ba-e-dal| A violent storm blew over Umma and the Šeg-kuršaga. 
{d}szara2 e2-mah ki-tusz ki ag2-ga2-ni giri3 kur2 ba-ra-an-dab5| Šara took an unfamiliar path away from the E-maḫ, his beloved dwelling. 
{d}nin-mul-e iri{ki} hul-a-na er2 gig mu-un-sze8-sze8| Ninmul cried bitter tears over her destroyed city. 
iri{ki}-gu10 la-la-bi lu2 nu-un-gi4-a-gu10 gig-ga-bi im-me| “Oh my city, whose charms can no longer satisfy me," 
gir2-su{ki} iri{ki} ur-sag-ge26-e-ne-ke4 im gir2-e ba-ab-du11| Ĝirsu, the city of heroes, was afflicted with a lightning storm. 
{d}nin-gir2-su-ke4 e2-ninnu-ta giri3 kur2 ba-ra-an-dab5| Ningirsu took an unfamiliar path away from the E-ninnu. 
ama {d}ba-ba6 e2-iri-ku3-ga-na er2 gig mu-un-sze8-sze8| Mother Baba wept bitter tears in her E-Iri-kug. 
a iri gul-la e2 gul-la-gu10 gig-ga-bi im-me| “Alas, the destroyed city, my destroyed house.” 
u4-ba inim u4-dam al-du7-du7 sza3-bi a-ba-a mu-un-zu| On that day the word of Enlil was an attacking storm. Who could fathom it? 
{d}en-lil2 lu2 nam tar-tar-re-de3 a-na bi2-in-ak-a-ba| This is what Enlil, the one who determines destinies, did: 
{d}en-lil2-le elam{ki} lu2-kur2-ra kur-ta im-ta-an-e3| Enlil brought down the Elamites, the enemy, from the highlands. 
{d}nansze dumu-gi7 iri bar-ra mu-un-na-tusz-am3| Nanše, the noble daughter, was settled outside the city. 
{d}nin-mar-ki-ra esz3 gu2-ab-ba-ka izi im-ma-da-an-te| Fire approached Ninmarki in the shrine Gu-aba. 
ku3 {na4}za-gin3-bi ma2 gal-gal-e bala-sze3 i3-ak-e| Large boats were carrying off its silver and lapis lazuli. 
nin nig2-gur11-ra-ni hul-lu ti-la-am3 ku3 {d}nin-mar-ki-ke4| The lady, sacred Ninmarki, was despondent because of her perished goods. 
u4-ba u4 ka izi-gin7 bar7-ra-am3 im-ma-da-ab-tar-re| On that day he decreed a storm blazing like the mouth of a fire. 
ki lagasz{ki} elam{ki} szu-ni-a im-ma-szi-in-gi4| The province of Lagaš was handed over to Elam. 
u4-bi-a nin-e u4-da-a-ni sa2 nam-ga-mu-ni-ib-du11| And then the queen also reached the end of her time. 
{d}ba-ba6 lu2-ulu3-gin7 u4-da-a-ni sa2 nam-ga-mu-ni-ib-du11| Baba, as if she were human, also reached the end of her time: 
me-li-e-a u4-de3 szu-ni-a im-ma-szi-in-gi4| “Woe is me! Enlil has handed over the city to the storm. 
u4 uru2 gul-gul-e szu-ni-a im-ma-szi-in-gi4| He has handed it over to the storm that destroys cities. 
u4 e2 gul-gul-e szu-ni-a im-ma-szi-in-gi4| He has handed it over to the storm that destroys houses. 
{d}dumu-zi-abzu e2-bi ki-nu-nir-sza3-ba-ke4 ni2 im-ma-da-an-te| “Dumuzid-abzu was full of fear in the house of Kinirša. 
ki-nu-nir-sza3{ki} iri nam-dumu-gi7-ra-ka-ni kar-kar-re-de3 ba-ab-du11| Kinirša, the city to which she belongs, was ordered to be plundered. 
{d}nansze iri-ni nina{ki}-a kur-re ba-ab-gar| The city of Nanše, Nigin, was delivered to the foreigners. 
sirara3{ki} ki-tusz ki ag2-ga2-ni hul-gal2-e ba-an-szum2| Sirara, her beloved dwelling, was handed over to the evil ones. 
a iri gul-la e2 gul-la-gu10 gig-ga-bi im-me| “Alas, the destroyed city, my destroyed house.” 
ge6-par4 ku3 nam-en-na-ba szu ba-e-la2-la2| Its sacred Ĝipar of en priesthood was defiled. 
en-bi ge6-par4-ta ba-da-an-kar ki-erim2-e ba-ab-de6| Its en priest was snatched from the Ĝipar and carried off to enemy territory. 
gu2 i7-nun-na-{d}nanna-ka a2 dugud ba-szi-in-de6| Mighty strength was set against the banks of the Id-nuna-Nanna canal. 
masz-kan2-masz-kan2 e2-danna {d}nanna-ka tur3 dugud-gin7 ba-gul| The settlements of the E-danna of Nanna, like substantial cattle-pens, were destroyed. 
lu2-kar-ra-bi masz kar-ra-gin7 ur im-me-da| Their refugees, like stampeding goats, were chased (?) by dogs. 
ga-esz{ki} ga-gin7 ur-re ba-an-de2 i3-gul-gul-lu-ne| They destroyed Gaeš like milk poured out to dogs,

bara2 an-na-da gid2-da-bi a-nir ba-da-ab-sa2| A lament was raised at the dais that stretches out toward heaven. 
{gesz}gu-za an-na-bi nu-ub-gub sag me-te-a-asz li-bi2-ib-gal2| Its heavenly throne was not set up, was not fit to be crowned (?). 
{gesz}geszimmar-gin7 gu2-guru5 ba-ab-du11 tesz2-bi ba-ra-an-kad4| It was cut down as if it were a date palm and tied together. 
asz-szu{ki} e2 i7-de3 la2-a re a-e ba-da-ab-bu| Aššu, the settlement that stretches out along the river, was deprived of water. 
nig2-erim2 nu-dib {d}nanna-ka lu2-erim2-e ba-an-dib| At the place of Nanna where evil had never walked, the enemy walked. 
e2 ur5-re-am3 a-na-am3 ab-ak| How was the house treated thus?

eridu{ki} a gal-la diri-ga a nag-e ba-am3-u-gun3| Eridug, floating on great waters, was deprived (?) of drinking water. 
{gesz}taskarin-gin7 ba-sa6-ga-me-esz i3-sag3-ge-de3-en-de3-en| We have been struck down like beautiful boxwood trees. 
alan-gin7 kusz3-kusz3-a de2-a-me-esz i3-sag3-ge-de3-en-de3-en| We have been struck down like statues being cast in moulds. 
gu-ti-um{ki} lu2 ha-lam-ma-ke4 me-ze2-er-ze2-re-ne| The Gutians, the vandals, are wiping us out. 
a-a {d}en-ki-ra abzu eridu{ki}-sze3 szu-a ba-en-de3-en-gi4| We turned to Father Enki in the abzu of Eridug. 
u4-da gub sag sag3-ge-me-a a-na szu ba-ni-ti-en-de3-en| What do we receive trembling on duty during the day? 
ge6-da gub u3 nu-ku-me-a a-na u2-gu me-de2-de3-en-de3-en| What do we lose not sleeping on duty during the night? 
{d}en-ki-ke4 uru2-zu nam ha-ba-da-an-ku5 ki-erim2-e ha-ba-an-szum2| Enki, your city has been cursed, it has been given to an enemy land. 
me-en-de3-en eridu{ki}-ta gal2-la-da a-na-asz mu-e-de3-la2-e-ne| Why do they reckon us among those who have been displaced from Eridug? 
{gesz}geszimmar-gin7 szu nu-du11-ga-me-a a-na-asz mu-e-gul-gul-lu-ne| Why do they destroy us like palm trees which we have not tended?

{d}en-ki-ke4 igi-ni ki kur2-ra ba-an-gar-ra-ba| After Enki had cast his eyes on a foreign land,

uri5{ki}-ma lu2 u2-sze3 nu-gen lu2 a-sze3 nu-gen| In Ur no one went to fetch food, no one went to fetch water. 
u2-sze3 gen-bi u2-ta ba-gen hur nu-um-mi-ib-gur-ru| Those who went to fetch food, went away from the food and will not return. 
a-sze3 gen-bi a-ta ba-gen hur nu-um-mi-ib-gur-ru| Those who went to fetch water, went away from the water and will not return. 
ti-id-nu-um{ki}-e u4 szu2-usz {gesz}mitum2-a ur2-ra ba-ni-in-gar| The Tidnum daily strapped the mace to their loins. 
uri5{ki} am gal u3-na gub-ba-gin7 gu2 ki-sze3 ba-ab-gar| Ur, like a great charging wild bull, bowed its neck to the ground. 
{d}en-lil2-le lu2 nam tar-tar-re-de3 a-na bi2-in-ak-a-ba| This is what Enlil, who decides the fates, did: 
2(disz)-kam-ma-sze3 elam{ki} lu2-kur2-ra kur-ta ba-ra-e3| Again he sent down the Elamites, the enemy, from the mountains. 
kisiga{ki} {d}dumu-zi sag-gin7 ba-ra-e3 szu-ni ba-da-ab-du3| Dumuzid left Kisiga like a prisoner of war, his hands were fettered. 
nig2-gur11-ra-ni-ta ba-da-u5 kur-sze3 ba-gen| She rode away from her possessions, she went to the mountains. 
i-lu kur giri3 nu-gal2-la-ba gal-gal-bi mi-ni-ib2-be2| She loudly sang out a lament over those untravelled mountains: 
ga-sza-an-gen nig2-gur11-ga2 ga-ba-da-u5 ki-ba gi4-in de3-gen| “I am queen, but I shall have to ride away from my possessions, and now I shall be a slave in those parts.

a iri gul-la e2 gul-la-gu10 gig-ga-bi im-me| Alas, the destroyed city, my destroyed house.” 
nin-gu10 lu2-kur nu-me-a kur-re ba-ab-gen| My queen, though not the enemy, went to enemy land. 
ki-ru-gu2 2(disz)-kam-ma| 2nd kirugu. 
gesz-gi4-gal2 ki-ru-gu2-da-kam| Ĝišgigal to the kirugu. 
{d}en-lil2-le abul-la mah-ba {gesz}ig tu15-ma bi2-in-gub| Enlil threw open the door of the grand gate to the wind. 
uri5{ki}-ma lu2 u2-sze3 nu-gen lu2 a-sze3 nu-gen| In Ur no one went to fetch food, no one went to fetch water. 
ug3-bi a tul2-la2 de2-a-gin7 szu i3-nigin2-nigin2-ne| Its people rushed around like water being poured from a well. 
usu-bi ni2-bi-a nu-gal2 giri3-bi ba-ra-an-dab5| Their strength ebbed away, they could not even go on their way. 
{d}en-lil2-le sza3-gar lu2 nig2-hul iri-a ba-an-da-dab5| Enlil afflicted the city with an evil famine. 
nig2 iri gul-gul-e nig2 e2 gul-gul-e iri-a ba-an-da-dab5| He afflicted the city with that which destroys cities, that which destroys houses. 
nig2 igi-bi-sze3 {gesz}tukul-e la-ba-gub-bu-a iri-a ba-an-da-dab5| He afflicted the city with that which cannot be withstood with weapons. 
sza3 nu-si-si igi nigin2-bi iri-a ba-an-da-dab5| He afflicted the city with dissatisfaction and treachery. 
uri5{ki}-ma gi dili du3-a-gin7 sag sag3-ge nu-ga2-ga2| In Ur, which was like a solitary reed, there was not even fear. 
ug3-bi ku6 szu dab5-ba-gin7 zi-bi mi-ni-in-tum2-tum2-mu| Its people, like fish being grabbed in a pond, sought to escape. 
tur mah-bi i3-bara3-bara3-ge-esz lu2 nu-um-zi-zi-zi| Its young and old lay spread about, no one could rise. 
LUGAL.BI.GUB dub-la2-a u5-a nig2-gu7 la-ba-na-gal2| At the royal station (?) there was no food on top of the platform (?). 
lugal nig2 sa6-ga gu7-gu7-a szuku-re im-ma-an-dab5| The king who used to eat marvellous food grabbed at a mere ration. 
u4 im-szu2-szu2 igi im-la2-e sza3-ka-tab i3-zu-zu| As the day grew dark, the eye of the sun was eclipsing, the people experienced hunger. 
e2-lunga-na kasz nu-un-gal2 munu4-bi nu-um-gal2| There was no beer in the beer-hall, there was no more malt for it. 
e2-gal-la-na nig2-gu7 la-ba-na-gal2 tusz-u3-bi nu-ub-du7| There was no food for him in his palace, it was unsuitable to live in. 
ga2-nun mah-a-ni sze nu-um-si-si zi-bi la-ba-szi-in-tum2-tum2-mu| Grain did not fill his lofty storehouse, he could not save his life. 
guru7-du6 guru7-masz-e {d}nanna-ka {d}SZE.TIR nu-un-gal2| The grain-piles and granaries of Nanna held no grain. 
kin-sig unu2 gal dingir-re-e-ne-ke4 szu ba-e-la2-la2| The evening meal in the great dining hall of the gods was defiled. 
unu2 gal-bi kurun lal3 musz3 im-ma-ab-tum2| Wine and syrup ceased to flow in the great dining hall. 
gir2-PA-a gu4 udu gu7-ra u2-szim-e ba-da-nu2| The butcher's knife that used to slay oxen and sheep lay hungry. 
gir4 mah-ba gu4 udu nu-ak-e ir nu-mu-un-ur5-ur5-e| Its mighty oven no longer cooked oxen and sheep, it no longer emitted the aroma of roasting meat. 
e2 gu4-gin7 gu3 bi2-ib-du11-ga-a re si-ga-bi ba-du3| The house which used to bellow like a bull was silenced. 
{na4}kin2 {gesz}naga3 gesz-gan-na i3-dur2-dur2 lu2 nu-um-szi-gam-e| The mortar, pestle and grinding stone lay idle; no one bent down over them. 
kar-za-gin3-na {d}nanna-ka a-e ba-da-la2| The Shining Quay of Nanna was silted up. 
a {gesz}ma2-sag-ga2-ke4 gu3 nu-mu-un-gi4-gi4 asil3-la2 nu-mu-un-szub| The sound of water against the boat's prow ceased, there was no rejoicing. 
unu2-RI-banda3{da} {d}nanna-ka sahar ba-da-dub-dub| Dust piled up in the unuribanda of Nanna. 
{u2}ZI&ZI.LAGAB ba-da-mu2 {u2}ZI&ZI.LAGAB ba-da-mu2 gir re-e ba-an-mu2| The rushes grew, the rushes grew, the mourning reeds grew. 
ma2 ma2-gur8-ra kar-za-gin3-na musz3 im-ma-ab-tum2| Boats and barges ceased docking at the Shining Quay. 
i7 ma2-gur8-ra ba-ab-du7-a-za a2 nu-un-su3-su3-e| Nothing moved on your watercourse which was fit for barges. 
ezem ki garza-ka gesz-hur-bi ba-da-kur2| The plans of the festivals at the place of the divine rituals were altered. 
ma2 nesag-ga2 a-a ugu-na-ka nesag nu-mu-un-na-ab-tum3| The boat with first-fruit offerings of the father who begot Nanna no longer brought first-fruit offerings. 
ninda nidba-bi {d}en-lil2 nibru{ki}-sze3 nu-mu-da-an-ku4-ku4| Its food offerings could not be taken to Enlil in Nibru. 
i7-bi sza3-su3-ga i3-gal2 ma2-gur8 nu-mu-un-dib-be2| Its watercourse was empty, barges could not travel. 
gu2 tab 2(disz)-a-bi giri3 nu-gal2 u2 gid2-da ba-am3-mu2| There were no paths on either of its banks, long grass grew there. 
{e2}tur3 dagal-la {d}nanna-ka dub-ba-an-bi ba-si-il| The reed fence of the well-stocked cattle-pen of Nanna was split open. 
gi-sig {gesz}kiri6-ka szu ba-e-la2-la2 gu2-giri3 ba-an-gar-gar| The garden's fence was vioilated and breached. 
ab2-szilam-ma amar-bi ba-da-ab-dab5 ki-erim2-e ba-ab-de6| The cows and their young were captured and carried off to enemy territory. 
ab2 {u2}munzer-e edin ki nu-zu-bi giri3 kur2 ba-ra-an-dab5-be2-esz| The munzer-fed cows took an unfamiliar path in an open country that they did not know. 
{d}ga-a-a-u2 lu2 ab2 ki ag2-ga2 {gesz}tukul szurum-ma ba-szub| Gayau, who loves cows, dropped his weapon in the dung. 
{d}szu-ni-du10 i3 ga-ar3-ra du6-ul-du6-ul-e i3 ga-ar3-ra nu-du6-ul-du6-ul| Šuni-dug, who stores butter and cheese, did not store butter and cheese. 
i3-bi lu2 i3 nu-zu-ne i3-du9-du9-ne| Those who are unfamiliar with butter were churning the butter. 
ga-bi lu2 ga nu-zu-ne i3-im-musz3-musz3-u3-ne| Those who are unfamiliar with milk were curdling (?) the milk. 
{e2}tur3-ra {dug}szakir3-e dun5-dun5-e gu3 nun nu-mu-ni-ib-be2| The sound of the churning vat did not resound in the cattle-pen. 
ne-mur dugud-gin7 i3-ra-a re i-bi2-bi ba-gul| Like mighty coals that once burnt, its smoke is extinguished. 
{d}suen-e a-a-ni {d}en-lil2-ra er2 mu-un-na-sze8-sze8| Suen wept to his father Enlil: 
a-a ugu-gu10 iri{ki}-gu10 a-na-ra-du3 a-na-asz ba-e-da-gur-re-en| “O father who begot me, why have you turned away from my city which was built (?) for you? 
{d}en-lil2 uri5{ki}-gu10 a-na-ra-du3 a-na-asz ba-e-da-gur-re-en| O Enlil, why have you turned away from my Ur which was built (?) for you? 
ma2 nesag-e a-a ugu-na-sze3 nesag nu-mu-un-na-ab-tum3| The boat with first-fruit offerings no longer brings first-fruit offerings to the father who begot him. 
ninda nidba-zu {d}en-lil2 nibru{ki}-sze3 nu-mu-un-na-da-an-ku4-ku4| Your food offerings can no longer be brought to Enlil in Nibru. 
en iri bar-ra en iri sza3-ga lil2-e ha-ba-ab-lah5-e-esz| The en priests of the countryside and city have been carried off by phantoms. 
uri5{ki} iri{ki} {gesz}al-e ri-a-gin7 du6-du6-da ba-szid| Ur, like a city raked by a hoe, is to be counted as a ruin-mound. 
du6-ur2 ki ni2 dub2-bu {d}en-lil2-la2 esz3 lil2-la2 ba-ab-gar| The Du-ur, Enlil's resting-place, has become a haunted shrine. 
{d}en-lil2 iri-zu igi bar-ra e2-ri-a su3-ga| O Enlil, gaze upon your city, an empty wasteland. 
nibru{ki} iri-zu igi bar-ra e2-ri-a su3-ga| Gaze upon your city Nibru, an empty wasteland.” 
uri5{ki}-ma ur-bi ur2 bad3-da si-im-si-im nu-mu-un-ak-e| “The dogs of Ur no longer sniff at the base of the city wall. 
tul2 sag bulug-ga ganba-bi-a ki li-bi2-ib-de5-de5-ge| The man who used to drill large wells scratches the ground in the market place. 
a-a ugu-gu10 iri{ki}-gu10 dili-bi-ta a2-zu-sze3 nigin2-am3-szi-ib| My father who begot me, enclose in your embrace my city which is all alone. 
{d}en-lil2 uri5{ki}-gu10 dili-bi-ta a2-zu-sze3 nigin2-am3-szi-ib| Enlil, return to your embrace my Ur which is all alone. 
e2-kisz-nu-gal2-gu10 dili-bi-ta a2-zu-sze3 nigin2-am3-szi-ib| Enclose in your embrace my E-kiš-nu-gal which is all alone. 
uri5{ki}-ma numun ha-ra-ni-ib-e3 ug3 hu-mu-ra-ab-dagal-la| May you bring forth offspring in Ur, may you multiply its people. 
me ki-en-gi-ra ba-da-ha-lam-e ki-bi ha-ra-ab-gi4-gi4| May you restore the divine powers of Sumer that have been forgotten.” 
ki-ru-gu2 3(disz)-kam-ma| 3rd kirugu. 
a e2 zi e2 zi a lu2-bi lu2-bi| O good house, good house! O its people, its people! 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Ĝišgigal. 
{d}en-lil2-le dumu-ni {d}suen-ra mu-un-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4| Enlil then answered his son Suen: 
uru2 lil2-la2 sza3-bi a-nir-ra gi er2-ra ba-am3-mu2| “There is lamentation in the haunted city, reeds of mourning grow there. 
sza3-bi a-sze-ra gi er2-ra ba-am3-mu2| (1 ms. adds 1 line:) In its midst there is lamentation, reeds of mourning grow there. 
sza3-bi-a a-nir-ra u4 mi-ni-ib-zal-zal-e| In its midst the people pass their days in sighing. 
di-til-la inim pu-uh2-ru-um-ma-ka szu gi4-gi4 nu-gal2| The judgment uttered by the assembly cannot be reversed. 
inim du11-ga an {d}en-lil2-la2-ka szu bala-e nu-zu| The word of An and Enlil knows no overturning. 
uri5{ki}-ma nam-lugal ha-ba-szum2 bala da-ri2 la-ba-an-szum2| Ur was indeed given kingship but it was not given an eternal reign. 
u4 ul kalam ki gar-ra-ta za3 ug3 lu-a-sze3| From time immemorial, since the Land was founded, until people multiplied, 
bala nam-lugal-la sag-bi-sze3 e3-a a-ba-a igi im-mi-in-du8-a| who has ever seen a reign of kingship that would take precedence for ever? 
nam-lugal-bi bala-bi ba-gid2-e-de3 sza3 kusz2-u3-de3| The reign of its kingship had been long indeed but had to exhaust itself. 
{d}nanna-gu10 na-an-kusz2-kusz2-u3-de3 iri{ki}-zu e3-bar-ra-ab| O my Nanna, do not exert yourself in vain, abandon your city.” 
u4-ba lugal-gu10 dumu-gi7-ra ur5-ra-ni ba-an-usz2| Then my king, the noble son, became distraught. 
en {d}dili{im2}-babbar dumu-gi7-ra sza3 hul-lu im-ma-an-dim2| Lord Ašimbabbar, the noble son, grieved. 
{d}nanna lu2 iri{ki}-ni ki ag2-ga2 iri{ki}-ni ba-ra-e3| Nanna who loves his city left his city. 
{d}suen-e uri5{ki} ki ag2-ga2 giri3 kur2 ba-ra-an-dab5| Suen took an unfamiliar path away from his beloved Ur. 
{d}nin-gal-e gir5 iri{ki}-ni-ta ki kur2-sze3 du-u3-de3| In order to go as an exile from her city to foreign territory, 
tug2 ul4-ul4-la-bi ba-ra-an-mu4 iri{ki}-ta ba-ra-e3| Ningal quickly clothed herself and left the city. 
uri5{ki}-ma {d}a-nun-na-bi bar-ra ba-su8-ge-esz| The Anuna stepped outside of Ur. 
uri5{ki}-ma gesz-bi tu-ra-am3 gi-bi tu-ra-am3| The trees of Ur were sick, its reeds were sick. 
bad3-bi en-na nigin2-na-bi-da a-nir ba-da-sa2| Laments sounded all along its city wall. 
u4 szu2-usz-e {gesz}tukul-e igi-bi-sze3 sag i3-sag3-sag3-ge| Daily there was slaughter before it. 
uri5{ki}-ma {uruda}ha-zi-in gal-gal-e igi-bi-sze3 u3-sar i3-ak-e| Large axes were sharpened in front of Ur. 
gesz-gid2-da a2 me3-ke4 si bi2-ib-sa2-sa2-e-ne| The spears, the arms of battle, were prepared. 
{gesz}pan gal-gal {gesz}ilar {kusz}gurx(E.TUM){ur3}-ra tesz2 im-da-gu7-e| The large bows, throw-sticks and shields gathered together to strike. 
{gesz}ti zu2-ke4 muru9 szeg3-ga2-gin7 bar-ba mi-ni-in-si| The barbed arrows covered its outer side like a raining cloud. 
na4 gal-gal-e ni2-bi-a pu-u4-pa-ad im-mi-ib-za| Large stones fell toegether with great thuds. 
u4 szu2-usz iri{ki}-ta im-hul-e mu-un-da-an-gi4-gi4| (1 ms. adds 1 line:) Daily the evil wind returned in the city. 
uri5{ki} ne3-bi-ta nir-gal2 gab2-gaz-e ba-gub| Ur, confident in its own strength, stood ready for the murderers. 
ug3-bi lu2-erim2-e a2 bi2-ib2-gar {gesz}tukul-e la-ba-su8-ge-esz| Its people, oppressed by the enemy, could not withstand their weapons. 
iri{ki} {gesz}tukul-e sag nu-szum2-mu-a sza3-gar-e im-us2| In the city, those who had not been felled by weapons succumbed to hunger. 
sza3-gar-e iri{ki} a-gin7 ba-e-si ga2-la nu-um-ta-dag-ge| Hunger filled the city like water, it would not cease. 
sza3-gar-e igi-bi im-gam-me-e sa-bi im-lu-gu2-ne| This hunger contorted people's faces, twisted their muscles. 
ug3-bi a-nigin2-na ba-e-si zi HAR i-ak-e| Its people were as if drowning in a pond, they gasped for breath. 
lugal-bi e2-gal ni2-te-na-ka zi gig mu-un-pa-an-pa-an| Its king breathed heavily in his own palace. 
nam-lu2-ulu3-bi {gesz}tukul ba-e-szub {gesz}tukul ki bi2-ib2-tag| Its people dropped their weapons, their weapons hit the ground. 
szu-bi gu2-bi-sze3 ba-szi-ib-ri-ri er2 mu-un-sze8-sze8-ne| They struck their necks with their hands and cried. 
ni2-bi-a ad mi-ni-ib-gi4-gi4 inim im-szar2-szar2-e-ne| They sought counsel with each other, they searched for clarification: 
me-li-e-a du11-ga-me nam-gu10 tah-me nam-gu10| “Alas, what can we say about it? What more can we add to it? 
en3-sze3-am3 ka garasz2-a-ka i-im-til-le-de3-en-de3-en| How long until we are finished off by this catastrophe? 
uri5{ki}-ma sza3-bi nam-usz2-am3 bar-bi nam-usz2-am3| Inside Ur there is death, outside it there is death. 
sza3-bi-a nig2 sza3-gar-ra-ka i-im-til-le-de3-en-de3-en| Inside it we are to be finished off by famine. Outside it we are to be finished off by Elamite weapons. 
bar-bi-a {gesz}tukul elam{ki}-ma-ka ga-nam ba-e-til-le-en-de3-en| In Ur the enemy oppresses us, oh, we are finished.” 
uri5{ki}-ma lu2-erim2-e a2 bi2-ib-gar ga-nam ba-til-e-de3-en-de3-en| In Ur the enemy oppresses us, oh, we are finished.” 
zi-bi murgu-bi-sze3 i3-ak-e gu3 tesz2-a bi2-in-se3-ge5-esz| The people took refuge (?) behind the city walls. They were united in fear. 
e2-gal a ba-szub-ba szu ba-e-la2-la2 {gesz}si-gar-bi bi2-in-bu-bu-usz| The palace that was destroyed by onrushing water was defiled, its doorbolts were torn out. 
elam{ki}-e a mah e3-a-gin7 gidim im-ma-ni-ib2-gar| Elam, like a swelling flood wave, left (?) only the ghosts. 
uri5{ki}-ma {gesz}tukul-e {dug}sahar2-gin7 sag gaz i3-ak-e| In Ur weapons smashed heads like clay pots. 
lu2-kar-ra-bi du10 nu-um-zil(NUN)-e bad3 za3-ga bi2-in-dab5-be2-esz| Its refugees were unable to flee, they were trapped inside the walls. 
ku6 a-nigin2-na lu-ga-gin7 zi-bi in-tum3-tum3-mu-ne| (1 ms. adds 3 lines:) Like fish living in a pond, they tried to escape. 
e2-kisz-nu-gal2 {d}nanna-ka lu2-erim2-e ba-e-dab5| The enemy seized the E-kiš-nu-gal of Nanna. 
{uruda}alan uzugx(AN.ZAG)-ge si-a-bi gu2-guru5 ba-an-ne-esz| The statues that were in the shrine were cut down. 
{d}nin-i3-gara2 agrig mah-e URUxGAR-ma szu bi2-in-dag| The great stewardess Ninigara ran away from the storehouse. 
{gesz}gu-za-bi igi-bi-ta ba-e-szu2 sahar-ra ba-da-an-tusz| Its throne was cast down before it, she threw herself down into the dust. 
ab2 mah-bi si-musz3-bi ba-ra-an-dab5-be2-esz si-bi ba-ra-an-ku5| Its mighty cows with shining horns were captured, their horns were cut off. 
gu4 du7-du7-bi udu u2 gu7-a-bi {gesz}tukul-e ba-an-sag3-sag3| Its unblemished oxen and grass-fed sheep were slaughtered. 
{gesz}geszimmar-gin7 gu2-gur5-ru ba-ab-du11 tesz2-bi ba-ra-an-kad4| (1 ms. adds 1 line:) They were cut down as date palms and were tied together. 
{gesz}geszimmar uruda nig2 kal-ga a2 nam-ur-sag-ga2| The palm-trees, strong as mighty copper, the heroic strength, 
{u2}ZI&ZI.LAGAB-gin7 ba-bu {u2}ZI&ZI.LAGAB-gin7 ba-ze2 ur2-ba ti mi-ni-ib-bala| were torn out like rushes, were plucked like rushes, their trunks were turned sideways. 
sag sahar-ra ki ba-ni-ib-u2-us2 lu2 zi-zi la-ba-tuku| Their tops lay in the dust, there was no one to raise them. 
{gesz}ze2-na-bi gu2 ba-an-guru5-usz sag szu bi2-in-hu-hu-uz| The midribs of their palm fronds were cut off and their tops were burnt off.
