{gesz}a2-an zu2-lum-ma-bi pu2 du7-du7 ba-ra-an-BU-BU-de3-esz| Their date spadices that used to fall (?) on the well were torn out. 
gu2-un gal-gal-e mi-ni-in-gar-re-esz-a kur-re i3-il2-il2| The great tribute that they had collected was hauled off to the mountains. 
e2-e gesz-bur2 mah-bi ba-szub bad3-si-bi ba-gul| The house's great door ornament fell down, its parapet was destroyed. 
masz2-ansze zi-da gab2-bu-ba gu2-da la2-a-bi| The wild animals that were intertwined on its left and right 
ur-sag ur-sag-e gaz-a-gin7 igi-bi-ta ba-szu2| lay before it like heroes smitten by heroes. 
uszumgal ka du8-a pirig-ga2 ni2 guru3-gur3-ru-bi| Its gaping-mouthed dragons and its awe-inspiring lions 
am dab5-ba-gin7 saman-e bi2-in-szub-bu re ki-erim2-e ba-ab-de6| were pulled down with ropes like captured wild bulls and carried off to enemy territory. 
ki-tusz ku3 {d}nanna tir szim {gesz}erin-na-gin7 ir-si-im-bi ba-gul| The fragrance of the sacred seat of Nanna, formerly like a fragrant cedar grove, was destroyed. 
e2 u6 di-bi i3-du10-ga re u6 di-bi ba-gul| The glory of the house, whose glory was once so lovely, was extinguished. 
u4-gin7 kur-kur-ra im-si-a an-usan an-na-gin7 ba-e-du3| Like a storm that fills all the lands, it was built there like twilight in the heavens; 
{gesz}ig-bi mul-an-na x-bi du11-ga-ba| its doors adorned with the heavenly stars, 
{gesz}nu-kusz2-u3-bi-da lu2-kar-ra-gin7 er2 gig i3-sze8-sze8| The bolt, the holy lock and the great door were not fastened for it. 
{gesz}sag-kul {gesz}suhub4 ku3-ga {gesz}ig gal gu2 gid2-i nu-mu-na-ab-be2| The noise of the door being fastened had ceased; 
{gesz}ig gu2 gid2-da za-pa-ag2-bi ba-szub lu2 gu2 gid2-i la-ba-an-tuku| there was no one to fasten it. 
ki ku3-ba tigi2 szem5 {kusz}a2-la2-e gu3 nun nu-mu-ni-ib-be2| In its sacred place (?) the tigi, šem and ala instruments did not sound. 
dub-la2-mah ki nam tar-re-de3 ka-inim-ma nu-gal2| There was no eloquence in the Dubla-maḫ, the place where oaths used to be taken. 
{gesz}gu-za ki di ku5-ru-bi nu-mu-un-gub di si nu-um-sa2-e| The throne was not set up at its place of judgment, justice was not administered. 
{d}alamusz-e {gesz}gidri ba-da-an-szub szu-ni gu4-u4-gu4-u4| Alamuš threw down his sceptre, his hands trembling. 
a2-nu2-da ku3 {d}nanna-ka balag na-mu-un-tag-ge-ne| In the sacred bedchamber of Nanna musicians no longer played the balag drum. 
dub-szen ku3 lu2 igi nu-bar-re-dam erim2-e igi i-ni-in-bar| The sacred box that no one had set eyes upon was seen by the enemy. 
gesz-nu2 gi4-rin-na nu-um-gub u2 za-gin3 nu-mu-un-bara3| The divine bed was not set up, it was not spread with clean hay. 
{uruda}alan uzugx(AN.ZAG)-ge4 si-a-ba gu2-guru5 ba-an-ne-esz| The statues that were in the shrine were cut down. 
engiz ensi kiszib3-gal2-bi esz-da szu li-bi2-in-du7-usz| The cook, the dream interpreter, and the seal keeper did not perform the ceremonies properly. 
gu2 ki-sze3 gal2-la-ba ba-e-su8-su8-ge-esz kur2-re ba-ab-lah5-e-esz| They stood by submissively and were carried off by the foreigners. 
uz-ga ku3 szu-luh dadag-ga sza3-gada-la2-be2-e-ne| The priests of the holy uzga shrine and the sacred lustrations, the linen-clad priests, 
gesz-hur me ku3-ga ba-da-ha-lam-e iri kur2-sze3 ba-e-re7-esz| forsook the divine plans and sacred divine powers, they went off to a foreign city. 
{d}suen-e sza3 hul-la-ni a-a-ni-ir ba-szi-in-gen| In his grief Suen approached his father. 
igi a-a ugu-na {d}en-lil2-la2-sze3 du10 ki ba-ni-in-us2| He went down on his knee in front of Enlil, the father who begot him: 
a-a {d}en-lil2 lu2 a2 ag2-e du11-ga zi| Father Enlil, the one who advises with just words, 
di nig2 kur2-zu sza3| your inimical judgment 
sza3 zu-mu-ug-ga i-zi-gin7 hu-luh-ha-za igi zi bar-mu-un-szi-ib| look into your darkened heart, terrifying like waves. 
a-a {d}en-lil2 nam mu-e-tar-ra GA2xGAR ba-ra-an-du8-du8| O Father Enlil, the fate that you have decreed cannot be explained, 
siki-pa nam-en-na suh kesz2-da-ga2| as for my hairstyle (?) of lordship and the diadem with which I was crowned.” 
{d}en-lil2-le dumu-ni {d}suen-ra inim zi mu-un-na-ab-be2| Enlil then provided a favourable response to his son Suen: 
dumu-gu10 iri nam-he2 giri17-zal sza-ra-da-du3-a bala-zu ba-szi-ib-tuku| “My son, the city built for you in joy and prosperity was given to you as your reign. 
iri{ki} gul bad3 gal bad3-si-bi se3-ge5 u3 ur5-re bala an-ga-am3| Destroying the city, overthrowing its great wall and battlements: all this too is part of that reign. 
dur2-u3 re ki-tusz e2-temen-ni2-gur3-ru-za zi-de3-esz du3-du3-am3| As for dwelling in your home, the E-temen-ni-guru, that was properly built - 
uri5{ki} giri17-zal-la he2-en-du3 ug3 he2-en-szi-gam-e| - indeed Ur shall be rebuilt in splendour, the people shall bow down to you. 
ur2-bi-a nig2 he2-en-gal2 {d}SZE.TIR he2-eb2-da-tusz| There is to be bounty at its base, there is to be grain. 
pa-bi-a giri17-zal he2-en-gal2 {d}utu he2-en-da-hul2| There is to be splendour at its top, the sun shall rejoice there. 
{gesz}banszur-ba he2-gal2 {d}SZE.TIR-ka gu2-da he2-em-mi-ib-la2| Let an abundance of grain embrace its table. 
uri5{ki} iri an-ne2 nam tar-re ki-bi ha-ra-ab-gi4-gi4| May Ur, the city whose fate was pronounced by An, be restored for you.” 
{d}en-lil2-le gu3 zi de2-am3 gu2 an-sze3 he2-en-zi| Having pronounced his blessing, Enlil raised his head toward the heavens: 
{d}nanna-ra ma-da sig igi-nim-ma gu2 hu-mu-na-ab-diri| “May the land, south and highland, be organised for Nanna. 
{d}suen-ra kaskal kur-ra-ke4 si he2-en-na-sa2-e| May the roads of the mountains be set in order for Suen. 
muru9-gin7 ki us2-sa-a-gin7 szu mu-un-na-ga2-ga2| Like a cloud hugging the earth, they shall submit to him. 
inim du11-ga an {d}en-lil2-la2-kam szu zi he2-ga2-ga2| By order of An and Enlil it shall be conferred.” 
a-a {d}nanna iri{ki}-ni uri5{ki}-ma sag il2-la mu-un-gen| Father Nanna came into his city of Ur with head raised high. 
szul {d}suen e2-kisz-nu-gal2-la-sze3 im-ma-da-an-ku4-ku4| The youth Suen could enter again into the E-kiš-nu-gal. 
{d}nin-gal-e agrun ku3-ga-na ni2 mu-ni-ib-te-en-te-en| Ningal refreshed herself in her sacred living quarters. 
uri5{ki}-ma e2-kisz-nu-gal2-la-na im-ma-da-an-ku4-ku4| (1 ms. adds 1 line:) In Ur she could enter again into her E-kiš-nu-gal. 
ki-ru-gu2 4(disz)-kam-ma| 4th kirugu. 
iri{ki} lil2-la2-am3 sza3-bi a-sze-ra gi er2-ra ba-an-mu2| There is lamentation in the haunted city, mourning reeds grew there. 
sza3-bi a-sze-ra gi er2-ra ba-an-mu2| In its midst there is lamentation, mourning reeds grew there. 
ug3-bi a-sze-er-ra u4 mi-ni-ib-zal-zal-e| Its people spend their days in moaning. 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Ĝišgigal. 
u4 gig-ga u4 gaba-zu zi-ga-ab u4 e2-za gi4-bi| O bitter storm, retreat, O storm, storm return to your home. 
u4 uru2 gul-gul u4 gaba-zu zi-ga-ab u4 e2-za gi4-bi| O storm that destroys cities, retreat, O storm, storm return to your home. 
u4 e2 gul-gul u4 gaba-zu zi-ga-ab u4 e2-za gi4-bi| O storm that destroys houses, retreat, O storm, storm return to your home. 
u4 ki-en-gi-ra ba-e-zal-la kur-re he2-eb-zal| Indeed the storm that blew on Sumer, blew also on the foreign lands. 
u4 ma-da ba-e-zal-la kur-re he2-eb-zal| Indeed the storm that blew on the land, blew on the foreign lands. 
kur ti-id-nu-um{ki}-ma-ka he2-eb-zal kur-re he2-eb-zal| It has blown on Tidnum, it has blown on the foreign lands. 
kur gu-ti-um{ki}-ma-ka he2-eb-zal kur-re he2-eb-zal| It has blown on Gutium, it has blown on the foreign lands. 
kur an-sza4-an{ki}-na-ka he2-eb-zal kur-re he2-eb-zal| It has blown on Anšan, it has blown on the foreign lands. 
an-sza4-an{ki}-e im-hul dal-la-gin7 szusz3 he2-ni-ib-su-su| It levelled Anšan like a blowing evil wind. 
sza3-gar lu2 nig2-hul he2-en-da-dab5 ug3 he2-em-szi-ib-gam-e| Famine has overwhelmed the evildoer; those people will have to submit. 
me an-na gesz-hur ug3 ge-ne2 an-ne2 nam-kur2-re| May An not change the divine powers of heaven, the divine plans for treating the people with justice. 
di ku5 ka-asz bar-re ug3 si sa2-sa2-e an-ne2 nam-kur2-re| May An not change the decisions and judgments to lead the people properly. 
kaskal kalam-ma-ke4 giri3 ga2-ga2 an-ne2 nam-kur2-re| To travel on the roads of the Land: may An not change it. 
an-ne2 {d}en-lil2-bi nam-kur2-ru-ne an-ne2 nam-kur2-re| May An and Enlil not change it, may An not change it. 
{d}en-ki {d}nin-mah-bi nam-kur2-ru-ne an-ne2 nam-kur2-re| May Enki and Ninmaḫ not change it, may An not change it. 
{i7}idigna {i7}buranun-na a-bi tum3-de3 an-ne2 nam-kur2-re| That the Tigris and Euphrates should again carry water: may An not change it. 
szegx(IM.A) an-na ki-a sze gu-nu an-ne2 nam-kur2-re| That there should be rain in the skies and on the ground speckled barley: may An not change it. 
i7 a-bi-da a-sza3 sze-bi-da an-ne2 nam-kur2-re| That there should be watercourses with water and fields with grain: may An not change it. 
ambar-ambar-re ku6 muszen tum3 an-ne2 nam-kur2-re| That the marshes should support fish and fowl: may An not change it. 
gesz-gi gi sumun gi henbur mu2-mu2-de3 an-ne2 nam-kur2-re| That old reeds and fresh reeds should grow in the reedbeds: may An not change it. 
an-ne2 {d}en-lil2-bi nam-kur2-ru-ne| May An and Enlil not change it. 
{d}en-ki {d}nin-mah-bi nam-kur2-ru-ne| May Enki and Ninmaḫ not change it. 
pu2-{gesz}kiri6 lal3 gesztin u3-tu| That the orchards should bear syrup and grapes, 
an-edin-na {gesz}masz2-gur2 u3-tu| that the high plain should bear the mašgurum tree, 
e2-gal-la zi su3-u4-gal2 u3-tu| that there should be long life in the palace, 
a-ab-ba he2-gal2 nig2 u3-tu an-ne2 nam-kur2-re| that the sea should bring forth every abundance: may An not change it. 
ma-da ug3 lu-a sig igi-nim-ma an-ne2 nam-kur2-re| The land densely populated from south to uplands: may An not change it. 
an-ne2 {d}en-lil2-bi nam-kur2-re-ne an-ne2 nam-kur2-re| May An and Enlil not change it, may An not change it. 
{d}en-ki {d}nin-mah-bi nam-kur2-re-ne an-ne2 nam-kur2-re| May Enki and Ninmaḫ not change it, may An not change it. 
iri du3-du3-a ug3 szar2-szar2-ra| That cities should be rebuilt, that people should be numerous, 
an ki nigin2-na ug3 sag se3-ga| hat in the whole universe the people should be cared for; 
{d}nanna nam-lugal-zu du10-ga-am3 ki-za gi4-ni-ib| O Nanna, your kingship is sweet, return to your place. 
uri5{ki} bala du10 nam-he2 u4 he2-ni-ib-su3-u4-de3| May a good abundant reign be long-lasting in Ur. 
ug3-bi u2-sal-la he2-eb-nu2 e-ne su3-u4 he2-em-ak| Let its people lie down in safe pastures, let them reproduce. 
{d}nanna a iri-zu a e2-zu a nam-lu2-u18-lu-zu| O Nanna! O your city! O your house! O your people! 
ki-ru-gu2 5(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 5th kirugu. 
3(disz) sila3 kasz 2(disz) sila3 ninda| 3 sila3 beer, 2 sila3 bread, 
2(disz) gin2 i3 2(disz) gin2 naga| 2 shekels oil, 2 shekels alkali-plant, 
1(disz) sa szum2| 1 bundel onions: 
szu-ma-ma ka-us2-sa2| Šu-Mama, the ka’usa; 
3(disz) sila3 kasz 2(disz) sila3 ninda| 3 sila3 beer, 2 sila3 bread, 
2(disz) gin2 i3 2(disz) gin2 naga| 2 shekels oil, 2 shekels alkali-plant, 
1(disz) sa szum2| 1 bundel onions: 
ha-ba-ad gaba-ta| Habad, the gaba-ta; 
3(disz) sila3 kasz 2(disz) sila3 ninda| 3 sila3 beer, 2 sila3 bread, 
2(disz) gin2 i3 2(disz) gin2 naga| 2 shekels oil, 2 shekels alkali-plant, 
1(disz) sa szum2| 1 bundel onions: 
kur-bi-la-ak ka-us2-sa2| Kurbilak, the ka’usa; 
szunigin 1(ban2) la2 1(disz) sila3 kasz szunigin 6(disz) sila3 ninda| total: 1 ban2 less 1 sila3 beer, total: 6 sila3 bread, 
szunigin 6(disz) gin2 i3 szunigin 6(disz) gin2 naga| total: 1 ban2 less 1 sila3 beer, total: 6 shekels alkali-plant, 
szunigin 3(disz) sa szum2| total: 3 bundles onions; 
u4 2(u)-kam| 20th day, 
iti sze-sag11-ku5| month: “Harvest,” 
mu us2-sa bad3 mar-tu ba-du3| year after: “Martu-Wall was erected.” 
1(disz) gurusz  u4 5(disz)-sze3| 1 male laborer for 5 days, 
nibru{ki}-sze3| to Nippur 
3(disz) gurusz  u4 2(disz)-sze3| 3 male laborers for 2 days, 
nibru{ki}-sze3| to Nippur 
kiszib3 lu2-kal-la| under seal of Lukalla; 
mu {d}szu-{d}suen lugal| year: “Šu-Suen is king.”
lu2-kal-la| Lukalla, 
dub-sar| scribe, 
dumu ur-e11-e| son of Ur-E’e. 
1(disz) {munus}asz2-gar3 niga saga us2| 1 female kid, grain-fed, fine, second (quality), 
2(disz) udu| 2 sheep, 
1(disz) ud5| 1 nanny, 
4(disz) sila4| 4 lambs, 
ki szu-ma-ma-ta| from Šu-Mama 
{d}szul-gi-iri-mu| did Šulgi-irimu 
szu ba-ti| receive; 
iti ses-da-gu7| month: “Piglet-feast,” 
mu hu-uh2-nu-ri{ki} ba-hul| year: “Ḫuḫnuri was destroyed.” 
8(disz)| (total:) 8. 
tur3 me nun-e ba-du3-a-bi| After the cattle pen had been built for the foremost divine powers - 
lil2-e a-gin7 ib2-sag3 ki-bi me-na gi4-gi4| - how did it become a haunted place? When will it be restored? 
sze-eb na-ag2-tar-ra ba-mar-ra re| Where once the brick of fate had been laid - 
me-bi a-ba-a in-bir-re a-sze-er ba-da-tab| - who scattered its divine powers? The lamentation is reprised: 
szudum nibru{ki} esz3 {d}ur-an-ki-a| how did the storeroom of Nibru, the shrine Dur-an-ki, 
lil2-e a-gin7 ib2-sag3 ki-bi me-na gi4-gi4| become a haunted place? When will it be restored? 
ki-ur3 ki gal ba-du3-a-bi| After Ki-ur, the great place, had been built, 
sze-eb e2-kur-ra ba-du3-a-bi| after the brickwork of E-kur had been built 
ub-szu-ukken-na ba-du3-a-bi| after Ubšu-ukkena had been built, 
esz3 e2-gal-mah ba-du3-a-bi| after the shrine Egal-maḫ had been built - 
lil2-e a-gin7 ib2-sag3 ki-bi me-na gi4-gi4| - how did they become haunted? When will they be restored? 
uru2 zi sza3-su3-ga a-gin7 ba-an-du3| How did the true city become empty? 
gesz-hur kal-la-bi szu pe-el-la ba-ab-du11| Its precious designs have been defiled! 
uru2-a i3-zi-ig3-bi a-gin7 ba-an-szub| How were the city's festivals neglected? 
garza mah-bi szu suh3-a ba-ab-du11| Its magnificent rites have been thrown into disorder! 
nibru{ki} sza3-ba me hal-hal-a| In the heart of Nibru, where the divine powers were allotted 
ug3 sag-ge6-ga numun zi ib2-i-i-a| and the black-headed people prolificly multiplied, 
uru2 sza3-bi umusz ba-ra-pa3-da| the city's heart no longer revealed any sign of intelligence - 
{d}a-nun-na-ke4-ne na ba-an-de5-ge-esz-am3| - there where the Anuna used to give advice! 
ub-szu-ukken-na ki di gal ku5-ru| In Ubšu-ukkena, the place for making great judgments, 
esz-bar-e si sa2 ba-ra-an-zu-usz-am3| they no longer impart decisions or justice! 
dingir-be2-ne ki-tusz ba-ab-gar-ra| Where its gods had established their dwellings, 
szuku-u4-bi im-szub-ba bara2-bi im-ri-a| where their daily rations were offered, their daises erected, 
KI.LUGAL.GUB ku3 kin-sig7 unu2 gal-ba| where the sacred royal offering (?) and the evening meal in their great banquet hall 
din lal3 bala-bala-e nam-sze3 bi2-ib2-tar-ra| were destined for the pouring out of choice beer and syrup - 
nibru{ki} uru2 gissu dagal-la-bi-sze3| - Nibru, the city where, in its spreading shade, 
ug3 sag-ge6-ga ni2 im-szi-ib2-te-en-na| the black-headed people used to cool themselves - 
ki-tusz-ba gu2-zal-a-gin7 ba-ra-an-szub| - in their dwellings Enlil fell upon them as if they were criminals. 
ab2 sag2 du11-ga-gin7 e-ne sag2 ba-ra-an-du11| It was he who sent them scattering, like a scattered herd of cattle. 
uru2 sza3-bi er2 gig diri-ga| The inner city, whose bitter tears were overwhelming, 
en-na-me-sze3 dingir ga-sza-an-bi en3-bi nu-tar-re| How long until its lady, the goddess Ninlil, would ask after it? 
e2 gu-la za-pa-ag2 ib2-zu-a-bi| That great temple whose bustle of activity was famous, 
e2-ri-a su3-gin7 lu2 nu-un-ku4-ku4| as though it were empty wasteland, no one enters it. 
nibru{ki} iri{ki} bara2-bara2 gal-gal-e-ne szu im-ma-an-pesz11-esz-a-asz a-na-asz u2-gu i3-ni-in-de2-esz| As for all the great rulers who increased the wealth of the city of Nibru - why did they disappear? 
ug3 sag-ge6-ga u2 hi-a udu-gin7 bi2-ib2-gu7-a| Where the black-headed people ate rich grass like sheep, 
u4 en-sze3 i3-szub er2 a-nir sza3 sag3 ur5 usz2-a| For how long would Enlil neglect that Land? ears, lamentation, depression and despair! 
en-sze3 bar bi2-ib-tab2 sza3 nu-ub-szi-hug-e| How long would his spirit burn and his heart not be placated? 
{kusz}szem5 {kusz}a2-la2 mu-un-du12-a re| Why were those who once played the šem and ala drums 
i-lu gig-ga-a a-na-sze3 u4 mi-ni-ib2-zal| spending their time in bitter lamenting? 
balag di sig4-ba e-ne ba-dur2-ru-ne-esz| Why were the lamenters sitting in its brick buildings? 
kusz2-a gar-ra-bi er2-sze3 ba-ab-be2-ne| They were bewailing the hardship which beset them. 
lu2 dam szub-ba dumu szub-ba-ne| The men whose wives had fallen, whose children had fallen, 
a uru2 hul-a-me szer3-re-esz ba-ab-be2-ne| were singing “Oh our destroyed city!.” 
uru2-bi e3-a ki-tusz-bi kar-ra| Their city gone, their homes abandoned - 
sig4 uru2 ze2-ba-sze3 im-szi-szer3-szer3-e-ne-esz| - as those who were singing for the brick buildings of the good city, 
er2 du11-ga balag di-ne-ne-esz2| as the lamenters of wailing, 
a2-e3 lu2-e11-da umusz-bi nu-zu-gin7| like the foster-children of an ecstatic no longer knowing their own intelligence, 
ug3 ba-sag3 dim2-ma-bi ba-suh3| the people were smitten, their minds thrown into disorder. 
e2 zi-de3 er2 gig-ga-bi im-me| The true temple wails bitterly. 
ki-ru-gu2 1(disz)-a-kam| 1st kirugu 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its gišgigal 
e2 zi-de3 er2 a-sze-er ma-ra-ba| The true temple gave you only tears and lamentation - 
szer3 gig-ga im-me szu-luh zi ha-lam-ma-sze3| - it sings a bitter song of the proper cleansing-rites that are forgotten! 
sze-eb e2-kur-ra-ke4 er2 a-sze-er ma-ra-ba| The brickwork of E-kur gave you only tears and lamentation - 
szer3 gig-ga im-me szu-luh zi ha-lam-ma-sze3| - it sings a bitter song of the proper cleansing-rites that are forgotten! 
garza mah gesz-hur kal-kal szu hul du11-ga er2 gig i3-sze22-sze22| It weeps bitter tears over the splendid rites and most precious plans which are desecrated - 
me luh-luh-ha sikil szen-na-bi szu pel-la2-ke4-esz e2-e ur5 ib2-usz2| The temple despairs of its divine powers, utterly cleansed, pure, hallowed, which are now defiled! 
e2 zi-de3 ni2-bi sun5-sun5 gig-ga-a| The true temple, which it is bitter to enter on one's own, 
u4 mi-ni-ib2-zal-zal-e er2 im-gibil-gibil| passes the time renewing its tears. 
e2-a nig2 gar-ra nig2 diri-bi kiszib-bi ib2-du8-a-asz gun2 ki mu-ni-ib2-gal2| Because the sealings of the abundant materials stored in the temple have been broken open, they have placed the loads on the ground. 
nig2-gur11 URUxGAR sag se3-ga-ba szu gi4 ba-ab-du11-a-asz a-na ma-la2 im-me| Because the property in its well-tended storehouses has been sent back, it says “What will they weigh out for me now?"; 
lu2-kur2-ra sa6 hul nu-zu-ne nig2 du10 bi2-ib-ku5-ru-usz-a-asz i-lu gig im-me| because the enemies who do not know good from evil have cut off all good things, it sings a bitter dirge; 
nam-lu2-ulu3-bi masz2-ansze-gin7 sza3-ba mi-ni-ib-til-la-asz a ka-na-ag2-gu10 im-me| because they have finished off its populace there like animals, it cries “Oh my Land!.” 
ki-sikil gurusz di4-di4-la2-be2-ne zar-re-esz mi-ni-ib-sal-la-asz u8-a-bi im-me| Because they have piled up the young women, young men and their little children like heaps of grain, it cries “Woe!” for them. 
uri3-bi muru9 szeg3-ga2-gin7 ki-e bi2-ib-su3-a-asz er2-sze3 nu-gul-e| Because they have splashed their blood on the ground like a rain-storm, there is no restraint to its crying. 
e2-e ab2 amar-bi ku5-ra2-gin7 ni2-bi-sze3 mur gig-ga im-sza4 szex(SIG7)-szex(SIG7) i3-ga2-ga2| The temple, like a cow whose calf is cut off, groans bitterly to itself; 
balag di lu2 ad du10-ga-ke4-ne UM.ME{da} u5-a di-gin7 mu-bi er2-ra mi-ni-ib-bala-bala-e-ne| it is grief-stricken, and the sweet-voiced lamenters, like nursemaids singing a lullaby, respond tearfully with its name. 
uru2 u3-mu-un-bi sag ib2-ta-an-dub2-ba-asz| In anguish they bewail the fact that the city's lord has smashed heads there, 
i-bi2-ni ki kur2-ra ib2-ta-an-gar-ra ad-e-esz ba-an-sza4-asz| that he has looked away from it and toward a foreign land instead. 
e2 zi kur-kur-ra i-bi2-sze3 ba-gen-na| The true temple of all the countries, which had come before him - 
ug3 sag-ge6-ga us2 zi bi2-ib-dab5-ba| the black-headed people, who had taken a true path, 
a-na ib2-ak a-na im-ha-lam-ma-bi-sze3| what have they done regarding what have they forsaken, 
u3-mu-un-bi ib2-ta-ib2 sag-ki-a mu-un-DU| that their lord has become enraged with them and walks in anger? 
ki-ru-gu2 2(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 2nd kirugu 
me gal sza3-bi ba-ra-an-e3-a-asz gu3 gig-ga im-me| It voices bitter cries because he has removed the great divine powers from within it. 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its gišgigal. 
uru2 u3-mu-un-bi sza3 ba-da-an-dab-ba| The city's lord who became angry with it, 
en-sze3 la-ba-szi-gur-ru musz3-am3-bi nu-um-me| How long will he not turn to it, not say “Alas!” for it? 
sig4-bi a-na-sze3 giri3 ib2-ta-an-gar| Why did he cut off the road to its brickwork? 
tu{muszen} za-pa-ag2 ga2-ga2-bi ab-ta ib2-ta-an-dal| He made the noisy pigeons fly away from their windows. 
e2 ad zu sig4 tigi ag2 ze2-ba u4 mi-ni-ib-zal-zal-la ta-asz igi bi2-in-gi4| Why did he transform the appearance of the temple which knew voices, where they used to while away the days in sweet playing of tigi drums in the brick buildings? 
e2 sun5-na giri17 szu gal2-la re| The temple, once a place to offer salutations in humility, 
e2 ni2 nu-tuku-gin7 si-ga-bi ba-du3| is now as deathly silent as a temple which no one reveres! 
ag2 iszib-bi nu-ku3-ku3-ga-gin7| As though its purification priest's equipment were not utterly sacred, 
szu-luh-bi kur-kur-ra nu-ub-ta-sed6-a-gin7| as though its cleansing-rites did not bring calm in all countries, 
szu bi2-in-dag gaba-ni ib2-ta-an-zi| he has abandoned it, turned his breast away from it, 
ag2-gig ur5-ra-a a-sze-er-ra mu-un-du3| among dejection and lamentation he has made it a sacrilege. 
ta-sze egir na-ag2-bi i-bi2-ni-a la-ba-an-bara3| After its fate, how long till his face would be streaked with teardrops? 
ag2 sikil du3-a-gin7 ur5-re za3 bi2-in-tag| He rejected it thus as though it were a blasphemy! 
sig4-bi hul2-e a-na-asz ib2-ta-an-e3| Why has joy left its brickwork? 
ge6 an-bar7-ba sza3-ba er2 bi2-in-si| Night and day he has filled its heart with tears! 
a2-sze kur2 ag2-gig bi2-ib-ak-a| Even now, he has made it foreign and a sacrilege! 
u3-mu-un-bi im-hul-am3 szu-bi bi2-in-gi4-am3| Its lord, who has despoiled it like an evil wind, 
uru2-bi e2-bi in-gul-gul-am3| has destroyed that city and its temples! 
ur2-bi in-bu-ra-am3 al-e bi2-in-ra-am3| He has ripped out their foundations, struck them with the adze, 
dam dumu-bi sza3-ba mi-ni-in-ug5-ga-am3| killed wives and their children within it, 
uru2-bi uru2 szub-ba im-ma-ni-in-ku4-ra-am3| he has turned that city into a deserted city - 
ag2 ul-bi ki-bi bi2-in-gi4-am3| - when would he restore its ancient property? 
mu-un-gur11-bi tu15-e ba-ab-ir-ra-am3| Its possessions have been carried off by the wind! 
uru2 gal2-la-bi nu-gal2-la mi-ni-in-ku4-ra-am3| Enlil turned the city which used to be there into a city no longer! 
dim2-ma-bi giri3 ib2-ta-an-kur2-ra-am3| He made its mind wander! 
umusz-bi in-suh3-am3 lil2-e bi2-in-sag3-ga-am3| He threw its intelligence into disorder and made it haunted! 
u2-bi a-bi ib2-ta-an-kar-ra-am3| He took away its food and its water! 
ga zu kasz zu-a u4-bi mi-ni-ib-til-la-am3| He brought to an end its days of familiarity with milk and with beer! 
e2-e ag2-gig bi2-ib-ak-a| The temple which he has made a sacrilege utters bitter lamentations; 
a-sze-er gig im-me er2 bi2-ib-lu3-lu3| he has made its eyes blurred with tears. 
balag di lu2 i-lu ba-ab-be2-a| The lamenters who perform the dirges 
sza3 nu-ze2-ba-bi mu-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4| respond to it sorrowfully. 
u3-mu-un-bi me-bi ba-ra-an-e3-a| The city's lord who has removed its divine powers - 
a2-bi nu-mu-un-tag-ga-am3 en3-bi nu-tar-ra-am3| no one touches his arm, no one intercedes! 
ki-ru-gu2 3(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 3rd kirugu 
me gal-gal-la-ni a-gin7 ba-ra-an-dal| How did Enlil make all his greatest divine powers fly away! 
a2-bi la-ba-an-tag-ga-am3 en3-bi nu-tar-ra-am3| No one ever touches his arm! No one ever intercedes! 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its gišgigal 
mu-lu szer3-ra na-ag2-tar gig-ga-gu10-usz| To my dirge singer of bitter fates 
me-e ib2-szi-e11-de3-en er2 im-szi-sze22-sze22-en| I am going down and I shall weep tearfully to him. 
a2-sze balag di szer3 zu-ne| Even now the lamenters who are expert in song 
mur-ma-ra-gu10 ma-a-ar ma-ab-be2-ne-am3| make ululating wails over me! 
i3-ne-esz2 kusz2-a im-ma-diri-ga-gu10| Now my people who are overcome by hardship 
dili-dili-bi er2-ra ma-an-ga2-ga2-ne-am3| voice laments for me one by one! 
a2-sze sza3 su-mu-ug tab2-tab2-ba-gu10| Even now the places of refuge of my people whose hearts are burning in dark distress 
ki ku4-ra-bi ma-a-ar lu2 mu-da-an-zu-am3| have been made known to me! 
a-ra2 gig-ga sza3 bu-ra-gu10| My people whose hearts have been broken on the bitter way 
u5-a tur-ra-gu10 er2-ra ma-an-du12-am3| perform the lullabies of my young ones for me in tears! 
nin e2 du3-a ki-tusz-a-ne-ne| The well-built houses, ladies' dwellings, 
lul-e-esz ba-ab-gar-ra tu15-e ba-ab-tur-ra-am3| were falsely founded, and they have been eroded by the winds! 
lu2-erim2-e ka-na-ag2-gu10 ib2-til-la| Of how the foe has finished off my Land 
er2-ra ma-a-ar ma-an-ga2-ga2-ne-am3| They are making a lament! 
sza3 ag2-gig-ga ib2-diri-gu10 ad-bi-sze3 ba-ab-be2-ne ib2-sze17-de3-ne-am3| They are addressing the cries of my heart, overwhelmed with bitterness, in order to soothe it! 
er2-bi u3-mu-un-ga2 mu-un-ga2-ga2-dam| They are beginning their laments about my lord! 
E2xSAL sza3-ne-sza4 ma-ar ma-an-tuku-tuku-am3| He will have mercy and compassion on me - 
{d}mu-ul-lil2 a-a sag-ge6-ga-ke4| Enlil, father of the black-headed people, 
ki-gu10 gi4-gi4-gu10 a2-bi i3-ag2-ga2-a-ke4| he who will give the order to restore me! 
ki-ru-gu2 4(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 4th kirugu 
sza3-gu10 mud-a ba-ni-ge16-le-eg3-gen ba-bir-bir-en sug-ge4 ba-ab-gu7| My heart is dark, I am destroyed, I am in chaos, I have been devastated! 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its gišgigal 
sze-eb sag-a na-ag2-tar-zu gig-ga-am3 ib-szi-szer3-szer3-am3| In the foremost brick buildings they sing that your fate is bitter! 
a2-sze {d}mu-ul-lil2 a i-bi2-za szu ba-e-szi-in-ti-a| Even now, to Enlil who will accept your tears for you, 
za-e ni2-za er2 gig-ga szesz4-a ba-i-ri-ib-ak-esz| weeping bitter tears of your own accord, 
na-ag2-bi-sze3 u3-mu-un-zu-ur2 siskur e-ne du11-mu-na-ab| speak supplications to your lord himself concerning what he did to you, concerning that fate! 
u3-mu-un-gu10 en3-sze3 i-bi2 bar-mu-szi-ib u3-mu-un-gu10 e-ne du11-mu-na-ab| “My lord, how long? Look upon me with favour, my lord!" 
esz3-esz3-a ge6-ge6-ga-gu10 ki-tusz ku4-ma-ni-ib du11-mu-na-ab| Say “Re-enter for me your dwelling in my darkened shrines!" 
i-gi4-in-zu ur5-ra-ke4-esz sza-ne-sza4 E2xSAL ma-ra-tuku-tuku| Perhaps by this means I can make him have compassion and mercy for you. 
sza3-zu sza3 sag3 ib2-ta-be4-e sza3 zalag ma-ra-an-gar-ra-me| Depression has weakened your heart, but I am the one who has established good cheer for you. 
sag-zu zi-zi-i gesz-szub-ba-za ul-sze3 ma-ra-an-ga2-ga2| He will fix it forever as your lot that you shall lift your head high, 
ag2 kur2-re za-a-ar i-ri-ib-ak-e szu-bi bi2-ib-gi4-gi4-e| he will make good again the hostilities he is directing against you. 
ki-ru-gu2 5(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 5th kirugu 
iri{ki}-a szu bar-re nu-zu-a ur5-re bi2-ib-se3-ge| In the city which does not know freedom he struck them down thus. 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its gišgigal 
a2-sze u3-mu-un-zu gu2 szub-ba kur2 me-e-szi-in-ra-am3| Even now your lord has smitten the enemy fury for you! 
E2xSAL ma-ra-an-tuku-am3 na-ag2-zu in-tar-ra-am3| He has had mercy on you and decreed your fate! 
sig4-zu a-sze-er ib2-ta-an-e3-a ib2-si bi2-in-du11-ga-am3| He has said “Enough", so that he has removed lamentation from your brick buildings! 
ur5 sa6-ge sza3 hul2-la ma-ra-ni-in-ku4-ra-am3| In good mood and with a joyful heart he has entered in there again for you! 
{d}nin-urta maszkim kal-ga sag-ba bi2-in-tuku-am3| Ninurta, the mighty commissioner, has looked after things! 
szul u2-a-ni-sze3 ib2-szi-in-gub-ba-am3| He stood there before the hero, 
e2-kur esz3 kal-kal du3-du3-u3-dam a2 mu-un-da-ag2-am3| his provider Išme-Dagan, and issued the command to him to completely rebuild the E-kur, the most precious shrine! 
ag2 ul-bi ki-bi bi2-in-gi4-am3| He has restored its ancient property! 
gi-gun4-na-bi ki-bi gi4-gi4-bi u4-gin7 kar2-kar2-bi| to restore its ziggurat temple, to make it shine like the day, 
musz3-ba bara2 tum2-tum2-mu in-na-an-du11-ga-am3| to make fitting the dais upon its platform! 
garza kur2-re ib2-suh3-a szu hul bi2-ib2-du11-ga-am3| He has put back in their place the rites which the enemy disordered and desecrated, 
me ib2-bir-a-bi ki-bi-sze3 in-gar-ra-am3| along with the scattered divine powers! 
szu-luh erim2-e szu bi2-in-la2-a-ba| The cleansing-rites which the enemy had put a stop to, 
ku3-ge sikil-e-bi| so that they should sanctify and purify again, 
inim ku3 nu-kur2-ru-da-ni in-na-an-du11-ga-am3| he has given him his sacred unchangeable decision. 
{d}isz-me-{d}da-gan sipa ki ag2-ga2-ni-ir| He has told Išme-Dagan, his beloved shepherd, 
gu4 du7 masz2 du7 szar2-szar2-re-da in-na-an-du11-ga-am3| that faultless bulls and faultless bucks should be slaughtered! 
KI.LUGAL.GUB ku3 nam tar-re-da-ni giri17 szu mu-ni-gal2-la-am3| When decrees the fate of the sacred royal offering place (?), he will offer salutations 
siskur a-ra-zu-a u4 bi2-in-gub-ba-am3| and stand there daily in supplication and prayer. 
ki-ru-gu2 6(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 6th kirugu 
u4 en3-sze3 i3-kusz2-u3-de3-en| How long before you will rest at ease? 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its gišgigal 
sze-eb en3-sze3 er2-ra a-sze-er-ra i-bi2 mi-ni-ib-zi-zi-zi| How long will the brickwork strain its eyes upwards in tears and lamentations? 
a2-sze u3-mu-un-zu kur gal {d}mu-ul-lil2-le an ki-a diri-ga| Even now your lord, the Great Mountain Enlil, supreme in the universe, 
sze-eb-zu a-sze-er ib2-ta-an-e3 ur5-zu in-sa6-ga| has removed lamentation from your brick buildings and made favourable your humour! 
i3-ne-esz2 uru2 u3-mu-un-zu sza3-ne-sza4 E2xSAL ma-ra-an-tuku-a| Now, city, your lord who has had compassion and mercy for you, 
a-a {d}mu-ul-lil2 u3-mu-un kur-kur-ra-ke4 gur-ru-za bi2-in-du11-ga| Father Enlil, lord of all countries, who has commanded that you be restored, 
ama gal {d}nin-lil2-le a-ra-zu-a u3-gul mu-ni-in-gar-ra| and the great mother Ninlil, who entreated him in prayer there, 
nibru{ki} sag sag3-ge-bi gar-ra-ab sze-eb in-na-an-du11-ga-am3| and the brickwork itself which said to him “Steady the trembling of Nibru!" 
ama5-gu10 du3-ma-ab e2-gu10 si-ma-ab in-na-an-du11-ga-am3| and said to him “Rebuild my women's quarters for me! Re-establish my temples for me!” - 
sza3-ba-ni-a ad i-ni-in-gi4-esz-am3 e-ne-eg3-bi bi2-in-du11-ga| - he who mulled things over so that he came to a decision about them, 
{d}mu-ul-lil2 e-ne-eg3 zi du11-ga-ni in-de3-a-gen-na| Enlil, who found agreeable his command of true words, 
e2 zi ag2 ha-lam-ma ba-ab-ak sa6-ga-asz i-ni-in-ku4-ra| who beneficently entered the true temple which had suffered destruction - 
ag2 ur5-ra-ra e-ra-ni-ib-gi4-a e-ne ib2-ta-an-e11-de3| - he himself is removing what he turned upon you in distress. 
si-ga-bi mu-un-du3-un-na-gin7 hul2 u4 mi-ni-in-ku4-ra| Just as he silenced you, when he made joy enter again 
za-pa-ag2 din lal3 diri-sze3 bala-bala-e na-ag2-sze3 bi2-ib-tar-re| he decreed as your fate the sound of choice beer and syrup being poured out to overflowing. 
ib2-si u4 en3-sze3 er2 gul-la e-ne e-ra-an-du11-ga| “Enough! It is time to stifle the lament” he said to you himself. 
ag2 mu nu-tuku-gin7 ba-ti-le-na-asz na-ag2-zu in-tar-ra| Because you have been living in a state of neglect, Enlil who has decreed your fate 
uru2-gu10 sza3 ku3-gu10 mu-e-szi-hug za-a-ar ma-ra-an-gur-ra-am3| has said “My city, you have placated my sacred heart towards you.” He has returned to you! 
nibru{ki} sza3 ku3-gu10 mu-e-szi-hug za-a-ar ma-ra-an-gur-ra-am3| “Nibru, you have placated my sacred heart towards you.” He has returned to you! 
uru2 zi na-ag2 gal-zu in-tar-ra-am3 bala-zu in-su3-u4-dam| True city, he has decreed your great fate and made your reign long! 
nibru{ki} na-ag2 gal-zu in-tar-ra-am3 bala-zu in-su3-u4-dam| Nibru, he has decreed your great fate and made your reign long! 
e2-kur-ra u4-gin7 kar2-kar2-ka e-ne in-na-an-du11-ga-am3| Enlil himself has commanded Išme-Dagan that the E-kur should shine like the day! 
ki-ur3-ra u4 zi ba-an-e3-am3 u4 ma-ra-ni-in-ku4-ra-am3| Steady sunlight shines into the Ki-ur; he has brought daylight in there again for you! 
{d}nin-lil2-le ga2-gesz-szu2-a-ka na-ag2-zu in-tar-ra-am3| Ninlil has decreed your fate in the Ĝagiššua! 
{d}en-lil2 {d}nin-lil2-bi e2-kur-ra bara2 mu-ni-in-ri-esz-am3| Enlil and Ninlil together founded daises in the E-kur! 
sza3-bi-a u2 mi-ni-in-su3-su3-ge-esz-am3 din mi-ni-in-du10-ge-esz-am3| They dined there and enjoyed choice beer! 
sag-ge6 ki-tusz-ba ge-ne2-de3 ad-bi mu-un-gi4-esz-am3| They deliberated how to make the black-headed people secure in their dwellings! 
ug3 sug-za3-ge ba-ab-gu7-a-asz za-a-ar ma-ra-an-lah4-e-esz-am3| They have brought back to you the people who had been completely devastated! 
dumu ama-ni ba-da-an-gur-re-esz-am3 gu2 mu-un-gar-re-esz-am3| They have gathered back together the children whom they turned away from their mothers! 
nam-lu2-ulu3 ki-sag-gal2-la-ba mu-e-de3-re7-esz-am3| The populace goes with you in their strongholds! 
esz3 nibru{ki} kur gal {d}mu-ul-lil2-le za-a-ar ma-ra-an-gur-ra-am3| Shrine Nibru, the Great Mountain Enlil has returned to you! 
ki-ru-gu2 7(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 7th kirugu 
ur5-zu a-gin7 i3-tab sza3 sag3 a-gin7 i3-kusz2-u3-de3| How you suffer! How depression exhausts you! 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its gišgigal 
a2-sze me-ri-zu-a ki-en-gi ki-uri ki-bi gi4-gi4-da| Even now, they command Išme-Dagan that Sumer and Akkad should be restored at your feet, 
ug3 bir-a-bi gud3-bi-sze3 gur-ru-dam e-ne-esz im-mi-in-esz-am3| that their scattered people should be returned to their nests! 
eridu{ki} sza3-bi gesztu2 i-i umusz zi hal-ha-la-da| They have brought the news that the magnificent rites of Eridug would not be forgotten, 
garza mah-bi nu-ha-lam-me-da inim-bi im-de6-am3| its heart sending forth wisdom, so that good sense should be allotted! 
adab(U4.NUN) ki iri nin-bi nig2-zi-gal2 dim2-e u3-tu mu2-mu2-da| Adab, the city whose lady fashions living things, who promotes birthing, 
{d}a-nun-na en nam tar-re-da du3-u3-bi bi2-in-ne-esz-am3| The Anuna, the lords who decree fates, order that it should be rebuilt, 
uri2{ki} sza3-tum2-ma ki gar-ra me-bi me-ta suh| Ur founded in a pasture, its divine powers distinct from the rest, 
an-ne2 {d}en-lil2-le ki-bi gi4-gi4-da ad-bi bi2-in-gi4-esz-am3| An and Enlil have advised that it should be restored, 
larsa{ki} iri nun-bi nimgir an ki di-ku5 ug3 szar2-ra-ke4| The prince of the city Larsam, the herald of the universe, the judge of the numerous people, 
suhusz-bi ge-ne2-de3 us2 zi dab5-be2-da e-ne bi2-in-esz-am3| They command him to secure its foundations, to follow the proper path! 
unu{ki} kul-aba4{ki} iri ku3 gesz-kin-ti dingir-re-e-ne-ke4| Uruk-Kulaba, the sacred city, the handiwork of the gods, 
esz-bar kin-bi im-mi-in-esz-am3 ki-bi bi2-in-gi4-esz-am3| They have taken a decision concerning it and restored it. 
ki zabala{ki} iri nu-gig an-na-ke4 usu-ni mu-un-til-la| from the region of zabala, the city where the mistress of heaven concentrated her forces, 
lu2-erim2 lu2-kur2-ra-da kar-re-bi inim-bi im-de6-a| they have brought news of the removal of all foes and enemies. 
lagasz{ki} dim gal an-na esz3 gir2-su{ki} ul-ta gar-ra-ba| On Lagaš, the mooring-pole of heaven, and the shrine Ĝirsu, established long ago. 
an-ne2 {d}en-lil2-le igi sa6-ga-ne-ne im-szi-in-bar-re-esz-am3| An and Enlil have looked with their beneficent gaze 
e2-bi umma{ki}-a sig4-kur-sza3-ga hul-bi ba-ab-ak-a| From that temple in Umma, Šeg-kuršaga, which had been ill treated, 
ugu-bi-ta ti-id-nu-um nu-gar-ra ib2-ta-an-zi-ge4-esz-am3| they have removed the treacherous Tidnum. 
kisz{ki} za3 dab5 ki-en-gi ki-uri nam-nun-bi diri-ga| Kiš, at the edge of Sumer and Akkad, its dominion superlative, 
suhusz-bi ge-ne2-de3 bi2-in-esz-am3 dingir gal-gal-e-ne| It is the great gods who have commanded that its foundations should be secured, 
mar2-da{ki} iri i7-bi a zal-le a-sza3-ga sze gu-nu| Marda, the city in whose river water flows, in whose fields is fine grain - 
{d}a-nun-na-ke4-ne ib2-ta-an-kar-re-esz-a ib2-szi-in-gur-re-esz-am3| - the Anuna who took those things away from it returned them to it again! 
i3-si-in{ki} u2-a {d}a-nun-na-ke4-ne ul-ta ni2 il2-la-a| Isin, the provisioner of the Anuna, rising high since times of old - 
an {d}en-lil2 {d}en-ki {d}nin-mah-a bala-bi in-su3-u4-da-am3| - An, Enlil, Enki and Ninmaḫ have made its reign long! 
du11-ga-ba szu zi bi2-in-gar-re-esz-am3 he2-am3-bi bi2-in-esz-am3| By their command they have handed it over and expressed their approval! 
{d}nin-urta szul ur-sag kal-ga szu-ni ba-an-szum2-mu-usz-am3| They have entrusted it to Ninurta, the champion, the strong hero! 
{d}nin-isin2{si}-na dumu mah an-na szim-mu2 kalam-ma-ka| Ninisina, the exalted child of An, the incantation priest of the Land 
ki-tusz ku3 e2-gal-mah-ni-a ni2 dub2-bu in-na-an-ne-esz-am3| they have told to rest calmly in her sacred dwelling, Egal-maḫ! 
{d}da-mu kindagal2 {d}nu-nam-nir-ra a-zu zi-gal2-la-ka| Damu, the chief barber of Nunamnir, healer of the living, 
giri3 ama-na-sze3 a-a-na-sze3 kur gam-gam-e in-na-an-ne-esz-am3| they have told to make the foreign countries bow at the feet of his father and mother! 
ki-ru-gu2 8(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 8th kirugu 
an {d}en-lil2 {d}en-ki {d}nin-mah-bi a2-bi ha-ba-an-ag2-esz-am3| An, Enlil, Enki and Ninmaḫ have given their orders! 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its gišgigal 
i3-ne-esz2 a2-sze {d}en-lil2-le u4 zi kalam-ma bi2-in-gub-ba-am3| Now see! Enlil has fixed a good day in the land! 
u4 nibru{ki} gu2 an-sze3 zi-zi i3-ne-esz2 im-mi-in-du11-ga| He has even now ordered the day for Nibru to raise its neck to heaven! 
u4 zi e2-kur-ra sag mu2-mu2 e-ne im-mi-in-tuku-a| He himself has provided a good day for the E-kur to shine! 
u4 ki-ur3-ra dalla mah e3-a e-ne im-mi-in-zi-ga| He himself has raised up the day for the Ki-ur's magnificent manifestation! 
u4 ki-en-gi ki-uri dagal-e e-ne im-mi-in-gi4-a| He himself has restored the day for Sumer and Akkad to expand! 
u4 e2 du3-du3 ga2-nun nigin2-e e-ne ib2-ta-an-mar-ra| He himself has set aside the day for houses to be built and storerooms to be enclosed! 
u4 numun i-i nig2-zi-gal2 u3-tu e-ne ib2-ta-an-e3-a| He himself has brought out the day for seeds to sprout and living things to be born! 
u4 tur3 du3-du3 amasz ki ga2-ga2 e-ne ib2-ta-an-e3-a| He has brought out the day for building cattle pens and founding sheepfolds! 
u8-e sila4-a im-mi-ib-tu-u4-da tur3-e bi2-ib-si-a| he ewes which bore lambs have filled the pens! 
u8 amasz-bi im-mi-ib2-u3-tu sila4-bi tur3-e bi2-ib-si-si| Ewes have given birth in the folds, their lambs have filled the pens! 
ud5-de3 masz2-bi im-mi-ib-tu-u4-da amasz-a bi2-ib-si-a| The goats which bore kids have filled the folds! 
u8 sila4-bi im-da-ab-lu-a {e2}tur3 im-pesz11-am3| The ewes which flocked with their lambs have swelled the sheepfold! 
ud5-e masz2-bi im-da-ab-lu-a amasz dagal bi2-ib-tag-ga| The goats which flocked with their kids have caused the pens to be widened! 
u4 nig2 ha-lam-ma sa6-ga ku4-ku4 e-ne ib2-ta-an-gar-ra| He himself has set the day for turning destruction to the good! 
u4 nig2-si-sa2 kalam-ma ga2-ga2 a2-tah-a mi-ni-in-ku4-ra| He has brought in Išme-Dagan as assistance for the day for establishing justice in the land! 
ki-ru-gu2 9(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 9th kirugu 
u4 ki-en-gi ki-uri lu2-erim2-e szu hul bi2-in-du11-ga| Although Sumer and Akkad had been desecrated by the foe, 
u4-da-ta sza3 ba-szi-hug-ga2-am3 bar ba-szi-im-sze17-da-am3| afterwards hearts were appeased, spirits soothed! 
dingir gal-gal-e-ne sza3-ne-sza4 ur5-re ba-an-tuku-usz-am3| All the great gods thus had compassion! 
a2 kusz2-a igi bi2-in-du8-usz-am3 ib2-ta-an-e11-de3-esz-am3| They looked upon those sunk in exhaustion and brought them up out of it! 
iri du6-du6-da ba-gar-ra-za ki-bi-sze3 in-gar-re-esz-am3| They restored your city which had been razed to ruins! 
nig2 babbar-bi sag2 ba-ab-du11-ga-ba sug-ge4 ba-ab-gu7-a| Its shining property which had been scattered, which had been devastated, 
{d}en-lil2 lugal kur-kur-ra-ke4 ki-bi-sze3 in-gar-ra-am3| Enlil, king of all countries, restored it! 
nam-lu2-ulu3 gud3 us2-sa-ta ni2 im-szi-ib-te-na| There where the populace rested in the cool after building their nests, 
nibru{ki} kur me gal-gal-la-ka giri3 kur2 ba-ra-an-dab5-be2-esz-a| in Nibru, the mountain of the greatest divine powers, from where they had taken an unfamiliar path - 
{d}a-nun-na inim {d}en-lil2-la2-ta e2 bi2-in-szub-bu-usz-a| at Enlil's word the Anuna, those very lords who determine the fates, ordered that the temples which they had forsaken 
gil-sa ul-ta gar-gar-ra-ba tu15-e ba-ab-de6-a| and the jewels, put there long ago, which had been carried off by the wind 
ki-bi-sze3 ku4-ku4-da bi2-in-esz-am3 en nam tar-re-ne| should all be restored! 
sza3-bi-a u2 su3-su3 sza3 hul2-la sza3-ba mi-ni-in-gar-ra-am3| He has established there dining in joy within! 
{d}isz-me-{d}da-gan szita u4-da gub hul2 ni2-tuku-ni-ra| To Išme-Dagan, his joyous, reverent sacral officiant, 
u2-bi ku3-ge a-bi sikil-e in-na-an-du11-ga-am3| to sanctify its food, to purify its water Enlil has given the command to him. 
me szu pel2-la2-bi sikil-e in-na-an-du11-ga-am3| He has commanded him to purify its defiled divine powers! 
garza suh3-a bir-a-bi si bi2-in-sa2| He has put in order its disordered and scattered rites, 
ku3-ku3-ga szub-ba szu pel2-la2-a-ke4 ki-bi-sze3 in-gar-ra| he has put back in their place the most sacred things, neglected and defiled. 
szuku-u4 szub-ba esza zi3 dub-dub-bu na-ag2-sze3 bi2-ib-tar-re| He decrees as a fate the offering of daily rations and the grinding up of fine meal and flour. 
{gesz}banszur ninda lu ninda szar2-re-da sza3-ga-ni im-de6-a| He has decided to make bread plentiful on the table, to make loaves numerous! 
ki-ru-gu2 1(u)-kam-ma-am3| 10th kirugu 
u4 lu2-u3 lu2-ra inim kur2 nu-di dumu a-a-ni-ir ni2 te-ge26-e| A time when no one is to speak hostile words to another, when a son is to respect his father, 
u4 nig2-sun5-na kalam-ma ga2-ga2 tur-re mah dugud-da| a time to establish humility in the Land, for the inferior to be as important as the mighty, 
u4 szesz-banda3{da} szesz-gal-la-ni hu-luh-ha ni2 sun5-e| a time when the younger brother, fearing his big brother, is to show humility, 
u4 dumu gal-la dumu banda3{da} umun2 ak inim-ma-ni-sze3 tusz-u3| a time when the elder child is to treat the younger child reasonably and to pay heed to his words, 
u4 si-ga kal-ga sze29-esz2 nu-di nig2 sa6-ga gal gub-bu| a time to take neither weak nor strong away into captivity, but to serve with great acts of good, 
u4 kaskal suh3-a giri3 ga2-ga2 hul mu2-a bu-re| time to travel the disordered roadways, to extirpate evil growths, 
u4 lu2-u3 ki sza3-ga-ni-sze3 du-u3 gaba-ri-ni-sze3 in nu-dub2| {a time when anyone is to go where they will, to hurl no insults at one's fellow,} 
u4 lu2-u8 lu2-ra inim kur2 nu-di nig2-gig-ga nu-ak| {a time no one is to speak hostile words to another, to perform no sacrilege,} 
u4 kalam-ma nig2-gig-ga e3-a sza3-ba u4 ga2-ga2| a time to remove bitterness from the Land, to establish light therein, 
u4 nig2 ge6-ge6 kalam-ma zi-zi nig2-zi-gal2 hul2-le| a time when darkness is to be lifted in the Land, so that living things should rejoice. 
a-a {d}en-lil2 en du11-ga-ni nu-kur2-ru nun kur-kur-ra-ke4| Father Enlil, the lord whose command cannot be altered, prince of all countries, 
ug3 sag-ge6-ga bi2-in-gub-ba-am3 sa6-ge-ba bi2-in-du11-ga| has fixed it among the black-headed people, and commanded for their benefit. 
ki-ru-gu2 1(u) 1(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 11th kirugu 
i3-ne-esz2 a2-sze u4-da-ta {d}en-lil2 nun sza3-la2 su3-ga-am3| Now, see! After that time, Enlil, the prince who is full of pity, 
me erim2-e szu hul bi2-in-du11-ga si in-na-an-sa2-am3| He put in order again for him the divine powers which had been desecrated by the enemy! 
garza szu pel2-la2 mu-un-na-an-ku3-ku3-ga-am3| He sanctified again the defiled rites for him! 
gi-gun4-bi mu-na-an-sikil-am3 dalla mu-un-na-an-e3-am3| He purified its ziggurat temple and made it resplendent for him! 
sza3-ba he2-gal2 mi-ni-in-szar2-szar2-ra-am3 kurun lal3 bi2-ib-si-am3| Within he made abundance plentiful, he filled it with choice beer and syrup! 
u4 ne sza3 du10-ge bar hug-e ur5 sa6-ge mi-ni-in-gar-ra-am3| He established there at that time the pleasing of hearts, the appeasing of spirits, the ameliorating of moods! 
e-ne a-ra-zu-a mu-na-an-gub-ba-am3 giri17 szu mi-ni-gal2-la-am3| Išme-Dagan himself stood in prayer to Enlil and offered salutations! 
er2 gar-ra nam-szita du11-ga-ni nun kur-kur-ra-ke4| When he had begun the lament and spoken the supplication, 
i3-he-nun-na lal3 ku7-ku7-da-gin7 su-ni bi2-ib2-ak-am3| the prince of all countries treated his body with oil of abundance as if it were the sweetest syrup! 
szu12-da-ni gesz ba-an-tuku-am3 igi in-szi-in-bar-ra-am3| And his prayer was heard - Enlil looked upon him with favour, 
{d}isz-me-{d}da-gan-na inim-ma-ni su-a-na ba-du10-ga-am3| Išme-Dagan whose words bring Enlil pleasure! 
sag us2-a-ni sza3-ga du11-ga-ni in-de3-gen-na-am3| Enlil's constant attendant, with whose thoughts he agrees! 
sun5-na szita-ba ki la2-a-ne2-esz2 giri3-ba se3-ga-ne2-esz2| Because the humble one prostrated himself in his devotions and served there, 
siskur-ra u3-gul ga2-ga2-da-ne2-esz2 giri17 ki su-bu-da-ne2-esz2| because he will entreat him in supplication and will do obeisance, 
KI.LUGAL.GUB ti-le-da ni2 te-ge26-da-ne2-esz2 gur-gur-re-da-ne2-esz2| because he will complete and honour the royal offering and will return 
nig2-nam-ma-ni en-nu-ug3 ak-da-ne2-esz2 ga2-la nu-dag-ge-da-ne2-esz2| because he will keep watch over everything and will not be negligent, 
nam-nun-na mu su3-su3-ra2-ni e-ne-er in-na-an-du11-ga-am3| Enlil has promised to Išme-Dagan his dominion of extended years! 
lu2 nam-lugal-la sag-bi-sze3 e3-a e-ne-er in-na-an-du11-ga-am3| He promised him that he will be a man of pre-eminent kingship! 
lugal bala sa6-ga-ke4 e-ne-er in-na-an-du11-ga-am3| He promised him that he will be a king whose reign is good! 
ug3 ki-tusz ne-ha bi2-in-dur2-ru-na e-ne-er in-na-an-du11-ga-am3| He promised him that he shall have the people inhabit safe dwellings! 
ug3 szar2-ra nig2 bi2-in-du11-ga-a in-de3-a-gen-na-am3| Enlil found agreement in what he had said to the numerous people! 
ki-en-gi ki-uri a-na me-a u4 nam tar-ra-sze3| On the day for decreeing fates, every part of Sumer and Akkad, 
ug3 sag-ge6-ga u8-gin7 lu-a ug3 sag se3-ga-ba| mong the black-headed people flocking like sheep, among their well-tended people, 
nam-mah kur gal {d}nu-nam-nir-ra enkar an ki-ke4| will praise forever the majesty of the Great Mountain Nunamnir, enkar weapon of the universe! 
du-ri2-sze3 me-tesz2 am3-i-i-ne a-ra2 ni2-gal2-la-ni-im| It is his awe-inspiring way! 
ki-ru-gu2 12(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 12th kirugu 
{d}en-ki {d}nin-ki umusz mi-ni-in-gal2-e-esz 3(u)-a-kam| Enki and Ninki determined the consensus - 
{d}a-ru-ru {d}suen {d}en-ki-bi me-dim2-bi ba-an-ak-esz-a| When together Aruru, Suen and Enki had fashioned its limbs, 
am gal-gin7 gu3 mah im-mi-ib-du11 szix(KAxBALAG)-bi e-ne ba-e-si| Like a great wild bull which bellows mightily, that one filled the world with its roar. 
si gal-bi an-ne2 he2-em-us2-sa ni2-bi a-ba-a in-dub2| As its gigantic horns reached up to heaven, who trembled in his very core? 
sa-par4-gin7 kur-re he2-em-dub-ba a-ba-a ba-ni-in-gur| As it was piled up over the mountains like a battle-net, who turned away? 
unu{ki}-ge lu2 zi ni2 te-a-gin7 x x| Uruk, like a loyal citizen in terror, set up an alarm 
zi-ga szu-ba a-na-asz ba-ni-ib-dab5 igi zi a-na-asz| (and exclaimed) “Rise up!” Why did its hand seize Uruk? Why did the benevolent eye look away? 
e-ne ba-ab-te sahar-ra e-ne ba-an-tusz giri3 a-na-asz ba-da-ze2-er| That one drew nearer. That one settled upon the ground. Why would he withdraw? 
dim2-ma-bi szu bala a-ba-a bi2-in-ak umusz-bi a-ba-a bi2-in-kur2| Who distorted Uruk's good sense and deranged its good counsel? 
{d}udug sa6-ga-bi a-ba-a ib2-ta-an-dub2 {d}lamma-bi a-ba-a in-ga-an-ra| Who smashed its good udug deity? Who struck its good lamma deity too? 
ni2 me-lam2 sag-ga2 gal2-la-bi szu hul a-ba-a bi2-in-du11| Who desecrated the fearsome radiance which crowned it? 
er2-re a-nir-ra sza3 mu-ni-ib-kusz2-u3 iri ni2-ba mu-da-dub2| He consoled himself with tears and laments - the city trembled. 
szu pe-el szu ba-ab-ra sag ba-ab-tal2 iri ni2-ba ba-an-ta-ra| A defiled hand smote him and flattened his skull - the city collapsed. 
iri sag-ku3-gal2 kur-kur-ra re ha-lam gar-gin7 ba-du3| The proud city of all the lands became like one who spreads havoc. 
amasz {lu2}sipa zi-de3 du3-du3-a re ni2-bi-a ba-an-bu-bu| The faithful cowherds themselves overturned every single cattlepen. 
tur3 unu3 gal-e du3-a re ni2-bi-a ba-an-tab-tab| The chief shepherds themselves burned (?) every sheepfold. 
zar-gin7 ba-du3 zar-gin7 ba-sal ni2-bi-a ba-an-ur4| They built them up like grain heaps, they spread them out like grain piles, 
i3-ak-ak gi ki sumun-na-gin7 u3-tu-da nu-ga2-ga2| They did all that. Like reeds in a wasteland, life could not be revived. 
sag2 ba-ab-du11 iri-a nig2-hul-a KAxLUM mu-un-da-an-x x| They brought ruination. Evil things menaced (?) the city. 
sza3 ni2 te ug3-ba nig2-me-gar tug2-gin7 i-im-dul (x x)| A hush settled over the awed hearts of its people like a cloak. 
{d}udug sa6-ga-bi im-ta-an-e3-e-esz {d}lamma-bi ba-da-an-kar-re-esz| Its good udug deities went away, its lamma deities ran off. 
{d}lamma-bi edin-na bar-bi2-ib-da giri3 kur2 ba-ra-an-dab5-be2-esz| Its lamma deity (said) “Hide in the open country” and they took foreign paths. 
iri dingir-bi ba-da-gur sipa-bi ba-da-an-tak4| The city's patron god turned against it and its shepherd abandoned it. 
maszkim-bi lu2-erim2 nu-me-a ki kur2 im-ma-an-x| Its guardian spirit, though not an enemy, was exiled (?) to a foreign place. 
dingir gal-gal-bi ur5 in-ze2-esz bar-ta ba-su8-ge-esz| Thus all its most important gods evacuated Uruk, they kept away from it. 
iri silim du3-a gu7 nag-a {dug}saman-gin7 im-mi-in-szub| In the city built upon peace, food and drink were overturned like a saman vessel. 
sza3-tum3-ma dum-dam mu-ni-in-za ansze udu im-mi-in-e3| In the pasture lands a tumultuous noise arose, the asses and sheep were driven away. 
ki-ru-gu2 2(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 2nd kirugu. 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its gišgigal. 
{d}en-lil2-le husz gal-bi mu-un-tag gu3 ba-an-de2| Enlil struck out with great ferocity. He announced: 
a-ma-ru ki al ak-e gu3 im-ma-ab-zi| “A deluge dashing the hoe on the ground shall be invoked. 
siki lum-ma-bi {gesz}gan2-ur3-ra-am3 {mu}murgu-bi-sze3 izi-am3| Its overgrown hair shall be a harrow, its back shall be flames. 
sag-ki-bi u4 hul-du3-am3 ki an-na dul-lu-dam| Its countenance shall be a malevolent storm that enshrouds heaven and earth. 
gesz-nu11-bi nim gir2-re anzu{muszen}-gin7 igi su3-u4-bi bar-re-dam| The glint of its eyes shall be lightning that flashes far like the Anzud bird. 
gu3-bi mer-mer-ra-am3 izi bar7-a kur-re su3-su3-u3-dam| Its mouth shall rage -- a blazing fire that extends as far as the nether world. 
eme-bi ga-an-ze2-er-ra-am3 u3-dub2 szeg3-ge26 kalam-ma dar-re-dam| Its tongue shall be an inferno, raining embers, that sunders the Land. 
a2-bi anzu{muszen} mah du10 bad-re6 nig2-nam nu-e3-am3| Its arms shall be the majestic Anzud bird that nothing can escape when it spreads wide its talons.” 
ti-ti-bi nig2 za-ra ak-dam u4 zal-gin7 zal-le-dam| “Its ribs shall be crowbars that let light pass inside like the sun's rays. 
szab-ba-bi-a a2-sag3 uru2 gul-la nig2-kesz2-sze3 mu-un-la2| Knotted at both its hips shall be city-destroying slingstones. 
hasz2 gal-bi gir2 sur usz2 dul4-dul4-lu u3-mun bala-bala-e-dam| Its great haunches shall be dripping knives, covered with gore, that make blood flow. 
sa-sa-bi {uruda}szum-me szab-dam giri3-bi hu-ri2-in{muszen}-na-am3| Its muscles shall be saws that slash, its feet those of an eagle. 
{i7}idigna {i7}buranun ni2 mu-ni-ib-te kur-ra gu3 mi-ni-ib2-ra| It shall make the Tigris and Euphrates quaver, it shall make the mountains rumble. 
szix(KAxBALAG) gi4-bi-sze3 hur-sag i3-bu-re ug3 zar-re-esz i3-sal-e| At its reverberation the hills shall be uprooted, the people shall be pitched about like sheaves, 
ki-en-gi ki-uri su im-sag3-sag3-ge buru14-gin7 i3-su3-su3-u3| Sumer and Akkad shall shiver, they shall be flooded like a harvest crop. 
nu-zu-u3-ne im-szi-hul2-hul2-e-esz szeg5 im-szi-ib-tar-re-ne| The foolish shall rejoice, they shall exclaim (?): 
he2-em-du me3-a gesz-gesz-la2-sze3 iri igi he2-bi2-ib-du8-un-de3-en| “Let it come -- we shall be seeing war and battle in the city, 
URUxKAR2 im-gul-la-a-asz bad3 im-se3-ge5-a-asz iri silim i3-si-il-le-a-asz| how the sacred precinct (?) is destroyed, how the walls are battered down, how the city's peace is disrupted, 
numun zi sag lul-la sag zi-da szu bala mi-ni-ib-ak-a-a-asz| how among the loyal families honest men are transformed into traitors.”" 
lu2 zu-u3-ne gaba sag3 i3-ak-ne sag i3-sal-sal-e-ne| “But the sensible shall beat their breasts and droop (?) their heads. 
a2 ge6-ba ni2 er2 mu-ni-ib-te-esz igi lib i3-ak-ne| At midnight they shall be afraid and tearful, and suffer insomnia. 
ki-nu2 {tug2}nig2-bara3-bi u3 du10 li-bi-ku-ku-ne iri{ki} im-nigin2-nigin2-ne| In bed, under the covers, they shall be unable to sleep soundly, they shall wander about the city. 
e-ne-ne szu-ne-ne ba-du3-du3 sza3 dar i3-ak-ne| They shall be immobilised, their courage shall run out: 
a2-tah gub me3 silim-me-esz2 gaba-bi ha-ba-ab-zi-zi-i| “May our allies serving in times of war raise their forces for peace. 
inim {d}en-lil2-la2-ke4 he2-bi2-ib-gur-re murgu-bi-sze3 ha-ba-gub| May the word of Enlil be sent back, may it turn tail. 
x x {d}nu-nam-nir-ra-ka usz11-bi he2-bi2-ib-til-e| May the venom of Nunamnir's anger become exhausted. 
lu2 husz e2-kur-ra x mu-un-dab5-be2-esz-a igi-bi he2-em-szi-tum2| May those vicious men who have seized the E-kur be punished. 
nibru{ki}-sze3 igi-bi mu-ra-szi-ni-ib2-gal2-la szusz3 he2-em-mi-ib-su-su| May those who have set their sight upon Nibru be swept away.”" 
ki-ru-gu2 3(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 3rd kirugu. 
sza3-gu10 er2 im-si szex(SIG7)-szex(SIG7) i3-ga2-ga2| My heart is filled with sorrow, I am tear-stricken. 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its gišgigal. 
ki-en-gi a sza3-zu a bar-zu a nam-lu2-u18-lu-zu| Oh, Sumer! Alas -- your spirit! Alas -- your structure! Alas -- your people! 
inim an-na ki-bi-sze3 ga2-ga2-de3 URUxKAR2 i3-gul x x| The word of An, having been assigned its place, has destroyed the sacred precinct (?). 
sag erin2-na lu2-ta e3-a-me-esz gar3 hul-bi x| The troop leaders, the most outstanding of the men, were viciously hewn down. 
ki-en-gi ki-uri gu2-gur5-ru-usz {gesz}naga3-sze3 mu-un-ak-esz| They mutilated Sumer and Akkad, they pulverised it as with a pestle. 
masz-kan2 a2-dam-bi mu-un-gul-gul-lu-usz du6-du6-ra mi-ni-in-si-ig-esz| They destroyed its settlements and habitations, they razed them to ruin mounds. 
nam-lu2-ulu3-bi aga3-kar2 bi2-in-se3-ge5-esz tur mah-bi mu-un-til-le-esz| They massacred its populace, they finished off young and old alike. 
iri{ki} {d}a-nun-ke4-ne mu-un-gul-gul-lu-usz izi mu-ni-in-ri-ri-esz| They destroyed the city of the Anuna gods, they set it aflame. 
unu{ki}-ga igi tab-bi mu-un-gul-gul-lu-usz {gesz}isimu2{mu2}-bi mu-un-suh-u3-usz| hey put out both Uruk's eyes, they uprooted its young shoots. 
ki-a-nag {d}a-nun-ke4-ne-ke4 nigin2-nigin2 im-mi-in-dib-be2-esz| They wandered all through the libation places of the Anuna gods. 
kul-ab{ki} iri ul in-ga-me-a ki-lul-la bi2-in-sag3-sag3-ge-esz| And even Kulaba, which is the primeval city, they turned into a place of murder. 
ki-ru-gu2 4(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 4th kirugu. 
a ki-en-gi a nam-lu2-ulu3-bi| Alas - Sumer! Alas - its people! 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its gišgigal. 
zi-da gab2-bu ug3 nu-di a2-dam nu-du3-du3| To the right and left no people moved about, no habitations were built. 
masz-kan2-masz-kan2 ba-bir-bir unu{ki} dili-bi ba-du3| All the settlements were dispersed - Uruk stood all alone. 
{gesz}gu4-si-ASZ {kusz}gurx(E.TUM){ur3} ba-su8-ge-esz bad3-bi mu-un-si-il-si-il-le-esz| Battering rams and shields were set up, they rent its walls. 
za3-e3-ba gu2-giri3 mi-ni-in-gar-re-esz iri {gesz}al-e bi2-in-ra-ra-asz| They breached its buttresses, they hewed the city with axes. 
mu-un-se3-ge-esz mu-un-gul-lu-usz| They destroyed it, they demolished it. 
u3-mu-un nam-lu2-ulu3 ab2-gin7 mu-un-sur-sur-re-esz nig2 dim2 mu-un-ze-x-re-esz| They let the blood of the people flow like that of a sacrificial cow, they tore out everything that had been built. 
ki-ru-gu2 5(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 5th kirugu. 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi| Its gišgigal. 
nin nam-gal-la-ni kur-ra diri-ga| Lady inanna whose greatness is vaster than the mountains, 
an-gin7 dib {d}en-lil2-gin7 ni2 gur3-ru| hovering like An, vested with grandeur like Enlil, 
a-a-ni-gin7 ge6 an-szeg6-ga2-ba he2-du7| like her father, perfect by night and in the heat of the day, 
{d}utu-gin7 nam-szul-la za3 dib| like Utu, surpassing in vigour, 
ub-da limmu2-ba dili-ni mah| singularly exalted in all the four regions - 
ni2 dub2-ba e2-za hu-mu-hul2-le| let Išme-Dagan take pleasure in relaxing in your temple, 
e2-za mul-ma-al hu-mu-ri-ib-za| let him murmer to you in your temple, 
e2-an-na-za sag hu-mu-ri-in-il2| let him raise his head to you in your E-ana. 
{d}isz-me-{d}da-gan u2-a-zu ha-ra-da-gub| Let Išme-Dagan serve you as your steward. 
gu4 gal-gal-e si ha-ra-ni-ib-sa2| Let him prepare great bulls for you. 
nidba gal-gal-e gesz hu-mu-ra-ab-tag-ge| Let him dedicate great offerings to you. 
kasz i3-udu i3 hu-mu-ra-ab-szar2-e| Let him make the beer, fat and oil plentiful for you. 
lal3 gesztin bur-gin7 ha-ra-ab-de2-e| Let him make syrup and wine flow for you as from stone jars. 
{d}isz-me-{d}da-gan-e ki lugal gub-ba| Let Išme-Dagan, 
dumu {d}en-lil2-la2 giri17 szu ha-ra-ab-tag-ge| son of Enlil on the king's pedestal, bow in homage to you. 
ub3 a2-la2-e gu3 nun hu-mu-ra-ab-be2| May he make the ub and ala drums resound grandly for you. 
tigi a-ra-du10 za-am-za-am hu-mu-ra-ab-du12| May the tigi sound sweetly for you, and may the zamzam play for you. 
siskur a-ra-zu-zu sag-bi-sze3 ha-ra-e3| expressing your prayers and supplications before you. 
unu{ki} e2-ge6-par4-ra-za| all that there are, at your E-gipar in Uruk, 
lu2 sun5-na giri3-zu mu-un-dab5-ba| as a humble man who has grasped your feet, 
ni2-tuku nam-mah-zu mu-un-zu-a| as a reverent man who has experienced your exaltedness, 
nig2 ki-en-gi ki-uri a-na-ab-ak| As for everything that happened to Sumer and Akkad, 
unu{ki}-ga ki gig-ga igi-na bi2-du8-am3| which he has witnessed in Uruk, the aggrieved place, 
nar gal-zu szer3-ra hu-mu-ni-ib-tum2-tum2| may the most knowledgeable cantors perform songs there. 
u3-mu-un-e3-esz er2-bi {d}a-nun-na-ke4-ne| If the Anuna gods emerge tearfully, 
u4 an ki-in-du-a a-na gal2-la-ba| let them promise to us that as it was when heaven and earth came about, 
u4-bi nam-me-kur2-ru he2-me-ne-esz| nothing of that time shall be changed. 
an lu2-ba-ra igi zi u3-mu-un-szi-in-bar| If An looks kindly upon that man and at the well-built city, 
iri{ki} du3-a ki nam tar-re-da| the place of determining fate, 
lu2 iri-bi nam-ti nig2 du10-ge| “Man and city! Life and well-being!" 
gu3 zi-mu-na-ni-ib me-tesz2 he2-i-i| proclaim for him. Let praise ring out. 
zi-da gab2-bu-na he2-bi2-in-diri| Let him be made surpassing above all, to his right or left 
{d}lamma ga2-la nu-dag-ge sag-ga2-na tuku-bi2-ib| Tireless lamma deity, take hold of his head, 
nam-tar-ra-ni inim zi du11-ga-a-ba| pronounce his fate in charitable words - 
inim an-na {d}en-lil2-la2-sze3 su3-da-sze3 nu-kur2-ru| - by the command of An and Enlil it will remain unaltered for a long time. 
ki-ru-gu2 12(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 12th kirugu. 
u4 te-esz du11-ga tug2-gin7 ba-e-dul gada-gin7 ba-e-bur2| The roaring storm covered it like a cloak, was spread over it like a sheet. 
eridu{ki}-ga tug2-gin7 ba-e-dul gada-gin7 ba-e-bur2| It covered Eridu like a cloak, was spread over it like a sheet. 
eridu{ki}-ga u4 husz-e szix(KAxBALAG) mi-ni-ib-gi4-gi4| In Eridu, the furious storm resounded 
lugal-bi iri-ni iri kur2-gin7 bar-ta ba-ra-gub er2 gig mu-un-sze8-sze8| Its king stayed outside his city as if it were an alien city. He wept bitter tears. 
a-a {d}en-ki iri-ni iri kur2-gin7 bar-ta ba-ra-gub er2 gig mu-un-sze8-sze8| Father Enki stayed outside his city as if it were an alien city. He wept bitter tears. 
nam iri hul-a-na er2 gig mu-un-sze8-sze8| For the sake of his harmed city, he wept bitter tears. 
nin-bi muszen dal-a-gin7 iri-ni ba-ra-e3| Its lady, like a flying bird, left her city. 
ama e2-mah-a ku3 {d}dam-gal-nun-na iri-ni ba-ra-e3| The mother of E-maḫ, holy Damgalnuna, left her city. 
iri me ku3-ku3-ga me-bi szu ba-ab-bala| The divine powers of the city of holiest divine powers were overturned. 
garza(PA.AN) me gal-gal-la-kam me-bi ba-da-kur2| The divine powers of the rites of the greatest divine powers were altered. 
eridu{ki}-ga igi nigin2-nigin2-bi ba-kur2 szu suh3-a ba-ab-du11| In Eridu everything was reduced to ruin, was wrought with confusion. 
u4 hul du3-a iri-ta ba-ra-gen kalam i3-ur4-ur4-re| The evil-bearing storm went out from the city. It swept across the Land— 
u4 saga hul nu-gal2-la sa6-ga nu-zu hul nu-zu-e| —a storm which possessses neither kindness nor malice, does not distinguish between good and evil. 
su-bir4{ki}-e a-gin7 im-mi-ib2-gar szu im-ma-da-an-szub| Subir came down like rain. It struck hard. 
iri-a u4 zalag-ga e3-a u4 ba-da-ge6-ge6| In the city where bright daylight used to shine forth, the day darkened 
eridu{ki}-ga u4 zalag-ga e3-a u4 ba-da-ge6-ge6| In Eridu where bright daylight used to shine forth, the day darkened. 
{d}utu an-ur2-ra szu2-a-gin7 an-usan-sze3 ba-du3| As if the sun had set below the horizon, it turned into twilight. 
iri an-ne2 nam ba-an-ku5-ra2-gin7 ni2-bi-a ba-an-gul| As if An had cursed the city, alone he destroyed it. 
{d}en-lil2-le sag-ki gid2-da-gin7 eridu{ki} esz3 abzu gu2 ki-sze3 ba-ni-ib-gar| As if Enlil had frowned upon it, Eridu, the shrine Abzu, bowed low. 
ki-ru-gu2 1(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 1st kirugu. 
a uru2 gul-la e2 gul-la-ri gig-ga-bi im-me| It cried out bitterly: “O the destruction of the city! The destruction of the house!” 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its ĝešgiĝal. 
2(disz)-kam-ma-sze3 u4-de3 iri mu-un-gul-gul ad-bi gig-ga-am3| second time the storm destroyed the city—its song was plaintive. 
abul-la-bi {gesz}si-gar bi2-in-ku5 {gesz}ig-bi u4-de3 im-ma-gub| It cut the lock from its main gate. The storm dislodged its door. 
iri ki sikil-la zal-a-ni sahar-ra ur2 mi-ni-ib2-si| Throughout his city, the pure, radiant (?) place, the foundations were filled with dust. 
u6-nir esz3 an-ne2 us2-sa-bi sahar-tu11-e ba-an-gar| It cast down its ziggurat, the shrine which reaches up to heaven, into a heap of debris. 
gesz-bur2-ba me-te e2-a-ke4 ni2 il2-il2-a il2-bi ba-e-suh| The loftiness of its elevated door-ornament, befitting a house, was stripped down (?) 
ka2 u6-nir-gal-an-ki-ni2-husz-ri-a-bi| It cut down the gate, its Great-Ziggurat-of-Heaven-and-Earth-Covered-with-Terrible-Awesomeness, its shining door, 
{gesz}ig za-gin3-bi gu2-guru5 bi2-in-du11 {gesz}sag-kul-bi ba-du3| and it broke through its bolt. 
gesz-ka2-na-bi ba-ra-an-bu e2 igi ba-ab-kur2| It ripped out its doorframe. The house was defaced. 
ki-ru-gu2 2(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 2nd kirugu. 
eridu{ki} gul-la-ri gul-la-bi gig-ga-am3| The destruction of Eridu Its destruction was grievous. 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its ĝešgiĝal. 
ka2 igi pirig-ga2 ki nam tar-re-ba| At its lion-faced gate, the place where fates are determined, 
u3-mun-bi a bala-bala-e-da usz2-ni im-bala| Along with the fluids spilled from his guts, his blood spilled forth. 
ki-ru-gu2 3(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 3rd kirugu. 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its ĝešgiĝal. 
{gesz}{u2}kiszi17 kur-ra-ke4 zu2 ba-ni-ib2-kesz2| The area became entangled in wild thornbushes. 
{uruda}szen ku3 lu2 igi nu-bar-re-da| The holy kettles which no one may look at, 
szimaszki{ki} elam{ki} lu2 ha-lam-ma igi i-ni-in-bar| The Šimaškians and Elamites, the destroyers, looked at them. 
buru5{muszen}-gin7 a2-bur2-bi sar-sar-ra ba-e-re7-esz| .., they went like small birds shooed from their hiding places. 
ki-ru-gu2 4(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 4th kirugu. 
a-a {d}en-ki i-lu ni2-te-na gu3 gig im-me| Bitterly Father Enki uttered a lament for himself. 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its ĝešgiĝal. 
nam-bi-sze3 {d}en-ki lugal abzu-ke4| Because of this, Enki, king of the abzu, 
iri-ni iri kur2-gin7 bar-ta ba-da-gub gu2 ki-sze3 ba-an-la2| stayed outside his city as if it were an alien city. It bowed its neck down to the ground. 
nin-bi ab2 zi E2xSAL-a ku3 {d}dam-gal-nun-na| Eridu’s lady, holy Damgalnuna, the faithful cow, the compassionate one, 
gaba-ni i3-hur-re igi-ni i3-hur-re gu3 nir-ra im-me| clawed at her breast, clawed at her eyes. 
szu 2(disz)-a-na gir2 ba-da-ra szu bi2-in-du8 tesz2-bi i3-gu7-e| She uttered a frenzied cry. She held a dagger and a sword in her two hands—they clashed together. 
siki-ni {u2}ZI&ZI.LAGAB-bur-gin7 i3-ze2-e i-lu gig ga2-ga2| She tore out her hair like rushes, uttering a bitter lament: 
uru2 munus-zu nu-til-la a-la-zu nu-gi4-a-gu10 me-a er2-zu ba-gig| “You, my city whose woman does not dwell there, whose charms do not satisfy her—where is a lament uttered bitterly for you? 
uru2-ze2-eb{ki} uru2 munus-zu nu-til-la a-la-zu nu-gi4-a-gu10 me-a er2-zu ba-sze8| Eridu! You, my city whose woman does not dwell there, whose charms do not satisfy her—where are tears wept for you? 
u3-mu-un {d}mu-ul-lil2 lugal kur-kur-ra-ke4| Lord Enlil, king of the lands, 
ki-en-gi-ra i-bi2 hul he2-en-szi-bar giri3-bala-a he2-em-gul| looked maliciously at Sumer. He demolished it. 
ki-ur3 ki gal za3 he2-bi2-in-tag| He destroyed the Ki’ur, the great place. 
e2-kur za-gin3-na du3-a-ba {gesz}al-e he2-em-mi-in-ra| He razed with the pickaxe all of the shining E-kur. 
za3 he2-bi-in-tag szu li-bi2-in-dag| He destroyed it but did not abandon it— 
kin-sig unu2 gal-ni mu-ni he2-pa3-de3| —at the lunches, in his great dining hall, they call his name. 
{d}a-ru-ru nin9 {d}mu-ul-lil2-la2-ke4| Aruru, the sister of Enlil, 
iri-ni iri-sa12-rig7 za3 he2-bi2-in-tag| destroyed her city Iri-saĝ-rig. 
kesz3{ki} ki-SIG7.ALAN kalam-ma-ke4| In Keš, the creation place of the Land, 
GA2xMI ku3 u4 nu-zu-ba ug3-e igi he2-ni-in-bar| the people saw inside its holy sanctuary where daylight had been unknown. 
za3 he2-bi2-in-tag szu li-bi2-in-tag| She destroyed it but did not abandon it— 
kin-sig unu2 gal-ni mu-ni he2-pa3-de3| —at the lunches, in her great dining hall, they call her name. 
u3-mu-un {d}nanna u3-mu-un {d}dili{im2}-babbar| Lord Nanna, Lord Ašimbabbar, 
iri-ni uri2{ki}-ma za3 he2-bi2-in-tag| destroyed his city Urim. 
sza3-mar-ra-ka ka-na-ag2-bi he2-en-til| He decimated the Land with famine. 
e2-kisz-nu-gal2 ag2-gig-ga he2-bi2-ak sza3-bi he2-bi2-ra| He committed a sacrilege against the E-kiš-nu-ĝal. He struck at its heart. 
za3 he2-bi2-in-tag szu li-bi2-in-dag| He destroyed it but did not abandon it— 
kin-sig unu2 gal-ni mu-ni he2-pa3-de3| —at the lunches, in his great dining hall, they call his name. 
{d}ga-sza-an-an-na ga-sza-an an ki-ke4| inanna, the queen of heaven and earth, 
iri-ni unu{ki}-ga za3 he2-bi2-in-tag| destroyed her city Uruk. 
za3 he2-bi2-in-tag szu li-bi2-in-dag| she destroyed it but did not abandon it— 
kin-sig unu2 gal-ni mu-ni he2-pa3-de3| —at the lunches, in her great dining hall, they call her name. 
mu-u4-na-gu10 uru2-zu uru2-ze2-eb{ki}-gin7 gul-la a-ba-a igi mu-ni-in-du8| “My beloved, who has ever seen such a destruction as that of your city Eridu!” 
ki-ru-gu2 6(disz)-kam-ma-am3| 6th kirugu. 
gesz-gi4-gal2-bi-im| Its ĝešgiĝal. 
u3-mu-un dam-an-ki uru2-zu uru2-ze2-eb gul-la a-ba-a mu-ni-in-du8| “Lord Enki, who has ever seen such a destruction as that of your city Eridu? 
esz3 abzu e2-zu-gin7 hul-a a-ba-a igi mu-ni-in-du8| Who has ever seen such a misfortune as that of the shrine Abzu, your house?” 
ki-szu-tag-ga-ni lu2 nu-e11-de3| No one goes up to his offering terrace. 
kin-sig unu2 gal-ni mu-ni li-bi2-in-pa3-de3| At the lunches, in his great dining hall, they do not call his name. 
{d}en-ki lugal abzu-ke4| Enki, king of the abzu, 
sza3 ba-an-sag3 ur5-ra-ni ba-usz2 inim gidlam-na-sze3| felt distressed, felt anxious. At the words of his spouse, 
ni2-te-a-ni i-si-isz mi-ni-ib-la2 sza3-ka-tab-ba ba-an-nu2| he himself began to wail. He lay down and fasted. 
lugal-gu10 ur5 nam-ba-ug7-e sza3 nam-ba-sag3-ge| My king, you must not be distressed, you must not be anxious. 
a-a {d}en-ki ur5 nam-ba-ug7-e sza3 nam-ba-sag3-ge| Father Enki, you must not be distressed, you must not be anxious. 
dumu an-na sza3-zu ki-ur3-zu-sze3 iri-zu-sze3 {mu-usz-tug2}musztu-zu-sze3| Son of An, return your heart to your Ki-ur and your attention to your city. 
iri kur2-ra tusz-a gig-ga-am3 iri-zu-sze3 {mu-usz-tug2}musztu-zu-sze3| Living in an alien city is miserable—return your attention to your city. 
e2 kur2-ra tusz-a gig-ga-am3 e2-zu-sze3 {mu-usz-tug2}musztu-zu-sze3| Living in an alien house is miserable—return your attention to your house. 
iri lu2 ta nu-ub-da-sa2-a iri-zu-sze3 {mu-usz-tug2}musztu-zu| What can anyone compare with this city?—return your attention to your city. 
e2 lu2 ta nu-ub-da-sa2-a e2-zu {mu-usz-tug2}PI-zu| What can anyone compare with this house?—return your attention to your house. 
eridu{ki}-ga u4-bi ba-su3-su3 ge6-bi ba-til-til| Eridu’s day is long. Its night is over. 
asz-te-zu tusz-a hu-mu-ra-ab-be2| May your throne say to you “Sit down.” 
mu-nu2-zu nu2-a hu-mu-ra-ab-be2| May your bed say to you “Lie down.” 
e2-zu ni2 te-na-ab hu-mu-ra-ab-be2| May your house say to you “Be rested.” 
bara2 ku3-zu hul2-la-bi diri-bi tusz-a hu-mu-ra-ab-be2| May your holy dais also say joyfully to you “Sit down.”

{d}utu an-na nu-um-e3-e u4-de3 i-si-isz im-la2| Utu did not come forth in the sky, and the day was full of sorrow. 
ama dumu-ni-sze3 hul ti-la-e| The mother, miserable because of her son, 
ama lugal-la ku3 {d}nin-sumun2-na a sza3-gu10 im-me| the mother of the king, holy Ninsumun, was crying: “Oh my heart!.” 
nam ur-{d}namma mu-un-tar-ra-sze3| Because of the fate decreed for Ur-Namma, 
mu sipa zi ba-ra-ab-e3-a-sze3| because it made the trustworthy shepherd pass away, 
sila dagal ki-a-ne-di gal2-la-ba er2 gig i3-sze8-sze8| she was weeping bitterly in the broad square, which is otherwise a place of entertainment. 
i-lu sipa zi ba-dab5-ba-na u4 mi-ni-ib-zal-e| they passed their time in lamentation over the trustworthy shepherd who had been snatched away. 
a-esztub i7-da de2-a-bi ku3-gal2-bi ba-si| As the early flood was filling the canals, their canal-inspector was already silenced (?); 
sze gu-nu a-gar3-re mu2-a-bi zi kalam-ma ba-su| the mottled barley grown on the arable lands, the life of the land, was inundated. 
engar gan2 zi-de3 gub-x-ni mu-na-ab-tur-re| To the farmer, the fertile fields planted (?) by him yielded little. 
{d}en-ki-im-du lugal e pa5-ra-ke4 uri2{ki}-ta e pa5 ba-da-an-kar| Enkimdu, the lord of levees and ditches, took away the levees and ditches from Ur. 
edin-edin-e u2 sa6-ga nu-mu-un-mu2 u2-a-nir ba-an-mu2| The plains did not grow lush grass any more, they grew the grass of mourning.

sag-ku3-gal2 e2-gal-a-na i3-nu2| The proud one lay in his palace. 
ur-{d}namma lu2 erin2-e ki ag2-ga2 gu2 nu-mu-un-da-zi-ge| Ur-Namma, he who was beloved by the troops, could not raise his neck any more. 
tesz2 kalam-ma-ka ba-szub{ub} hur-sag-gin7 ba-gul| As he, who was the vigour of the Land, had fallen, the Land became demolished like a mountain; 
tir ha-szu-ur2-ra-gin7 im-ma-su3 me-dim2-bi ba-kur2| like a cypress forest it was stripped, its appearance changed. 
{gesz}taskarin-gin7 ki-tusz giri17-zal-la-na gin2 mu-ni-in-gar-re-esz| As if he were a boxwood tree, they put axes against him in his joyous dwelling place.

bad3 uri2{ki}-ma nu-mu-un-til-la-ni| That he could not complete the wall of Ur; 
e2-gal gibil na-mu-un-du3-a-ni nu-mu-un-hul2-hul2-la-ni| that he could no longer enjoy the new palace he had built; 
dam-a-ni ur2-ra-na a-la nu-mu-un-gi4-a-ni| that he could no longer bring pleasure to his wife with his embrace; 
dumu-ni du10-ba-na li-bi2-in-pesz-a-ni| that he could not bring up his sons on his knees; 
nin9 di4-di4 nu-mu-un-bulug3-bulug3-e-ne hi-li nu-mu-un-til-a-ni| that he would never see in their prime the beauty of their little sisters who had not yet grown up - 
ge26-e nig2 ne-e ba-ak-a-gu10| I, who have been treated like this, 
dingir-re-ne-er mu-ne-gub-bu-nam ki-ur3 mu-ne-gal2| served the gods well, set up chapels for them. 
{d}a-nun-na-ke4-ne he2-gal2-la pa mu-ne-e3-a| I have created evident abundance for the Anuna gods. 
gesz-nu2 u2 za-gin3 bara3-ga-ba gil-sa mu-ne-gar-ra-gu10| I have laid treasures on their beds strewn with fresh herbs. 
dingir ki-ga2 la-ba-e-gub sza3-gu10 la-ba-ni-ib-sed| Yet no god stood by me and soothed my heart. 
x-me-en nig2 geszkim sa6-ga-gu10 an-gin7 mu-ne-su3-u4| Because of them, anything that could have been a favourable portent for me was as far away from me as the heavens, 
ge6-da gub-ba u3 nu-ku-ga2-a u4 im-ma-ni-til| My days have been finished for serving them sleeplessly during the night! 
i3-ne-esz2 im an-ta szeg3-ge26-gin7| Now, just as the rain pouring down from heaven cannot turn back, 
me-li-e-a szeg12 uri2{ki}-ma-sze3 szu nu-um-ma-nigin2-nigin2| alas, nor can I turn back to brick-built Ur.” 
a2-sze gidlam(MUNUS.USZ.DAM)-gu10 nu-mu-un-su-am3| “Alas, my wife has become a widow (?)! 
i-lu a-nir nig2 gig-ga-a u4 mi-ni-ib-zal-zal-e| She spends the days in tears and bitter laments. 
i-lu a-nir nig2 gig-ga-a u4 mi-ni-ib-zal-zal-e| She spends the days in tears and bitter laments. 
udug sa6-ga-ni bar-ta ba-da-gub| Her kind protective god has left her; 
{d}lamma sa6-ga-ni sag-ga2-na li-bi2-in-ha-za| her kind protective goddess does not care for her any more. 
{d}nin-sumun2-na-ke4 a2 mah-a-ni sag-ga2-na li-bi2-in-ge-en| Ninsumun no longer rests her august arm firmly on her head. 
{d}nanna en {d}dili{im2}-babbar szu-ta nu-un-ri| Nanna, Lord Ašimbabbar, no longer leads (?) her by the hand. 
{gesz}ma2-gin7 tu15 sumur-ra ba-ra-ab-diri {gesz}dimgul nu-mu-na-kal| She is cast adrift like a boat in a raging storm; the mooring pole has not been strong enough for her. 
ansze-edin-na-gin7 pu2 hul ba-an-tum2-mu-da szu dugud lu2 mu-un-gar| Like a wild ass lured (?) into a perilous pit she has been treated heavy-handedly. 
pirig-gin7 a-RU-ub-ba ba-szub-ba en-nu lu2 mu-un-du3| Like a lion fallen into a pitfall, a guard has been set up for her. 
ur-gin7 {gesz}az-la2-e mu-un-dab5 me-a lu2 mu-un-gar| Like a dog kept in a cage, she is silenced. 
tigi a-da-ab gi-gid2 za-am-za-am-gu10 a-nir-ra mu-da-an-ku4| “My tigi, adab, flute and zamzam songs have been turned into laments because of me. 
gesz-gu3-di e2 nam-nar-ra-ka za3 e2-gar8-e i-ni-in-us2| The instruments of the house of cantorship have been propped against the wall. 
{gesz}gu-za hi-li-bi nu-mu-til-la-gu10| Instead of my throne whose beauty was endless, 
edin bar su3-ga-ka lu2 im-mi-in-nu2-u3-da| I have been made to lie down in the open, desolate steppe 
me-li-e-a dam-gu10 er2-ra dumu-gu10 a-nir-ra| My wife and my children are in tears and wailing 
lu2 nig2 du11-ga-ga2 i-lu balag di-gin7 he2-na-du12-usz| My people whom I used to command (?) sing like lamentation 
u4 ur5-gin7 im-ma-ab-ak-a-gu10| and dirge singers because of her (?) 
sag-kal {d}inanna nin me3-a di-ga2 nu-mu-un-ti| While I was so treated, foremost inanna, the warlike lady, was not present at my verdict. 
{d}en-lil2-le kur-kur-ra inim gal-gal-sze3 kig2-gi4-a bi2-in-gi4| Enlil had sent her as a messenger to all the foreign lands concerning very important matters.” 
ki-bi-ta igi-ni gar-ra-ni| When she had turned her gaze away from there, 
{d}inanna e2-kur za-gin3-sze3 sun5-na-bi mu-un-ku4| inanna humbly entered the shining E-kur, 
sipa zi e2-an-na-ta mu-un-e3 igi nu-mu-ni-in-du8| the trustworthy shepherd left E-ana, you cannot see him any more.” 
an i3-dub2-be2 ki i3-sag3-ge| made the heavens tremble, made the earth shake. 
{d}inanna-ke4 tur3 im-gul-e amasz im-tab-e| inanna destroyed cattle-pens, devastated sheepfolds, saying: 
an lugal dingir-re-e-ne-ke4 in-sze3 ga-mu-un-dub2| “I want to hurl insults at An, the king of the gods: 
{d}en-lil2-le sag mu-da-an-zi-ga inim-bi a-ba mu-un-kur2| Who can change the matter, if Enlil elevates someone? 
an lugal inim mah du11-ga-ni inim-bi a-ba mu-un-kur2| Who can change the import of the august words uttered by An, the king? 
gesz-hur kalam-ma he2-me-a-gub-ba sag ba-ra-ba-an-us2-sa| If there are divine ordinances imposed on the Land, but they are not observed, 
ki u4 e3 dingir-re-e-ne-sze3 nam-he2-gal2-bi nu-gal2| there will be no abundance at the gods's place of sunrise 
ge6-par3 ku3 esz3 e2-an-na-gu10 hur-sag-gin7 mu-un-gi4-esz| My holy gipar, the shrine E-ana, has been barred up {like (?) a mountain} 
sipa-gu10 hi-li-a-ni nu-usz-ma-an-ku4-ku4 ge26-e ba-ra-ku4-ku4-de3-en| If only my shepherd could enter before me in it in his prime - {I will not enter it otherwise!} 
kal-ga-gu10 u2-szim-gin7 edin-na nu-usz-ma-da-mu2-am3| If only my strong one could grow for me like greenery in the desert. 
ma2 i7-da-gin7 kar si-ga-na nu-usz-ma-da-gi-na si-ga-na| If only he could hold steady for me like a river boat at its calm mooring.” 
{d}inanna-ke4 i-lu-ni he2-kur-ku-ku| This is how inanna {gave vent (?) to a lament over him} 
gesz-gi a-ta im-ta-ab-e11-a-zu| the reedbeds which you have drained, 
nam ur-{d}namma mu-un-bala-e-esz-am3| That the fate of Ur-Namma had been overturned 
mu sipa zi ba-ra-ab-e3-a-ta| and that the trustworthy shepherd had been made to pass away, 
sila dagal ki-e-ne-de3 gal2-la-ba er2 gig mu-a-szi-szi| she was weeping bitterly in the broad square, which is otherwise a place of entertainment. 
i-lu sipa zi ba-an-dab5-be2-NE-esz-a u4 mi-ni-ib2-zal-zal-e| She spent the day in lamentation over the trustworthy shepherd who had been snatched away. 
nam-lu2-ulu3 lib ib2-til-la-am3 u3 du10 x x x x x-ku| Sweet sleep did not (?) come to the people whose happiness had come to an end. 
tesz2 kalam-ma ba-da-an-szub hur-sag-gin7 ba-gul| As he, who was the vigour of the Land, has fallen, the land became demolished like a mountain. 
{gesz}tir ha-szu-ur2 ba-da-an-sag3 a-ra2 kalam-ma ba-e-suh3| As he, a cypress forest, was felled, the state of the Land became confused. 
{gesz}erin kalam-ma-ke4 ba-da-bala a-ra2 kalam-ma ba-e-kur2| As he, the cedar tree of the Land, was uprooted, the state of the Land became altered. 
{gesz}taskarin-e ki-tusz giri17-zal-a-ni AGA mu-un-na-an-gar-re-esz| Axes (?) were set against him, a boxwood tree, in his joyous dwelling place. 
u4 du11-ga-ni-a sa2 mi-ni-ib-du alan-a-ni ba-ra-e3| His appointed time arrived, and he passed away in his prime. 
siskur2 nig2 du10-ge szu la-ba-an-tag szu gig ba-da-an-gid2| His (?) pleasing sacrifices were no longer accepted; they were treated as dirty (?).

x {d}en-x x x x x-am3 ur5 zi-zi la-ba-gal2-la| there was no more rising up. 
lugal garza kur-ra-ke4 sza3-ga-ni i3-zu| The king knew well the rites of the nether world, 
ur-{d}namma garza kur-ra-ke4 sza3-ga-ni i3-zu| Ur-Namma knew well the rites of the nether world: 
gu4 sig7 masz2 du-du udu niga im-ma-ab-lah4-e| so he brought magnificent bulls, faultless kids, and fattened sheep.
