e-ne-ne di kur-ra ku5-de3 ka-asz-bi IGI bar-re| he will pass the judgments of the nether world and render the decisions. 
u4 5(disz)-am3 u4 1(u)-am3 ba-zal-a-ta| After five days, 10 days had passed,

bad3 uri2{ki}-ma nu-mu-un-til-le-na| As he could not complete the wall of Ur;

{d}a-nun-na-ke4-ne he2-gal2 pa e3 ak-NE| I have created evident abundance for the Anuna gods. 
{d}en-lil2-le hur-sag gal-gal kig2-gi4-a bi2-gi| Enlil had sent her as a messenger to all the great mountains.”

an lugal dingir-re-e-ne in kur2 mu-un-ak-e| Antagonistically (?) she insulted An, the king of the gods: 
ug3-ga2 igi mi-ni-in-il2 sipa zi ur-{d}namma| looked around among the people. Ur-Namma the good shepherd, 
kur gal {d}en-lil2-le ug3 szar2-ra-ni-a im-ma-ni-in-pa3 x| The Great Mountain Enlil chose him from the multitude of people: 
sipa he2-a {d}nu-nam-nir-ra-ka ni2 husz mu-un-da-ri| “Let him be the shepherd of Nunamnir!” He made him emanate (?) fierce awesomeness. 
szeg12 e2-kur-ra-ke4 me am3-hur| The divine plans of brick-built E-kur were drawn up. 
kur gal {d}en-lil2-le e2-kur esz3 mah-a-na u4-gin7 kar2-kar2-da| The Great Mountain Enlil, to make them shine like the sun in the E-kur, his august shrine, 
sza3 inim-gal2 ku3 zi-de3 si-a-ni nam-de6| made up his mind, filled with pure and useful thoughts. 
sipa {d}ur-{d}namma-da e2-kur-ra sag an-sze3 il2-i-de3 a2-bi mu-u8-da-ag2| He instructed the shepherd Ur-Namma to make the E-kur rise high; 
lugal-e kalam-ma a2 he2-ni-in-mah ug3-ga2 sag he2-ni-in-il2| the king made him the mightiest in the Land, he made him the first among the people. 
di zu en gesztu2 dagal-la-kam {gesz}u3-szub-ba si am3-mi-in-sa2| the knowledgeable judge, the lord of great wisdom, prepared the brick mould. 
{d}en-lil2-le sipa dur-{d}namma-ra ki-bala erim2-gal2-la-ni| Enlil brought order in his rebellious and hostile lands for the shepherd Ur-Namma,

u6 di-bi-sze3 ug3 szar2-ra-ba szi-im-ma-gub| He made it to be wondered by the multitude of people. 
ka2 mah ka2 gal ka2 silim-ma hur-sag-galam-ma ka2 sze nu-ku5-da| The Lofty Gate, the Great Gate, the Gate of Peace, the Ḫursag-galama and the Gate of Perpetual Grain Supplies, 
su3-ra2-ag2 ku3-me-a sig7-igi-ba sze-er-ka-an mu-ni-in-du11| he made their glittering the eyebrow-shaped arches of by covering them with refined silver. 
anzu2{muszen}-de3 du10 am3-ma-ni-in-bad| The Anzud bird runs there 
hu-ri2-in umbin-ba lu2-erim2 dili mu-un-dab5| and an eagle seizes enemies in its claws (?). 
{gesz}ig-bi mah-am3 ul-la mi-ni-in-si| Its doors are lofty; he filled them with joy. 
e2 mah-am3 su zi am3-da-gal2| The temple is lofty, it is surrounded with fearsome radiance. 
dagal am3-tag ni2-bi gal szi-ri| It is spread wide, it awakes great awesomeness. 
hur-sag-galam-ma gi-gun4-na ki-tusz ku3 kur gal-la-ra| The Ḫursag-galama, the raised temple (?), the holy dwelling for the Great Mountain 
u18-ru mah-gin7 sza3-bi-a ki am3-ma-ni-in-us2| he made it stand like a great tower (?).

{d}en-lil2 {d}nin-lil2-bi du10 mi-ni-in-gal2-le-esz| Enlil and Ninlil relished it there. 
zi-kir szu-mi| In its great dining hall, the trustworthy hero chosen by Nunamnir 
ninda mah am3-mi-ni-du10 e2-kur hul2-la-am3| made them enjoy a magnificent meal: the E-kur was rejoicing. 
igi zi mu-un-szi-in-bar-re-esz sipa {d}ur-{d}namma-ra| They looked with approval at the shepherd Ur-Namma,

sag-ge6-ga-na a2 mi-ni-in-mah| making him the mightiest among his black-headed people. 
sa-gid2-da-am3| The sa-gida. 
{d}nu-nam-nir du11-ga esz-bar zi nig2 nu-kur2-ru ge26-me-en| “I am Nunamnir, whose firm commands and decisions are immutable! 
e2-kur mah-gu10 dalla mu-e-a-e3| You have made my lofty E-kur shine gloriously,

mu-zu an-za3-sze3 kur-ur2-sze3 he2-gal2| may your fame spread to heaven's borders, as far as the foot of the mountains!" 
kur gal a-a {d}en-lil2 du11-ga esz-bar zi nig2 nu-kur2-ru ge26-me-en| “I am the Great Mountain, Father Enlil, whose firm commands and decisions are immutable! 
e2-kur mah-gu10 dalla mu-e-a-e3| You have made my lofty E-kur shine gloriously, 
suh10 kar2-kar2-ka-da an-sze3 gu2 he2-ni-in-us2| you have raised it high with a brilliant crenellation.

lugal-gu10 udug2 mah kur erim2-gal2-la sag sahar-re-esz dub-bu ki-bala-a sza5-sza5| To my king the lofty mace which heaps up human heads like piles of dust in the hostile foreign countries and smashes the rebellious lands; 
sipa {d}ur-{d}namma-ke4 udug2 mah erim2-gal2-la sag sahar-re-esz dub-bu ki-bala-a sza5-sza5| to the shepherd Ur-Namma the lofty mace which heaps up human heads like piles of dust in the hostile foreign countries and smashes the rebellious lands, 
e-ne-er mu-na-an-szum2 en {d}nu-nam-nir-re| lord Nunamnir gave it to my king. 
kur am3-tu11-be2 giri3 saga11 am3-me| so now he beats down the foreign lands and tramples them underfoot. 
sipa {d}ur-{d}namma-ke4 mu-na-an-szum2 en {d}nu-nam-nir-re| Lord Nunamnir gave it to the shepherd Ur-Namma, 
kur am3-tu11-be2 giri3 saga11 am3-me| so now he beats down the foreign lands and tramples them underfoot. 
hul-gal2-la uru2 am3-mi-in-gul-gul| He destroys the cities of the wicked, 
nam-gu2 mah-am3 lil2 am3-mi-ni-in-su-ub| and with heavy oppression he turns (?) them into haunted places.

ar2-a-ni husz-am3 e2 ki-bala| He has a terrible fame in the houses of the rebellious lands, 
sipa {d}ur-{d}namma ar2-a-ni husz-am3 e2 ki-bala| The shepherd Ur-Namma has a terrible fame in the houses of the rebellious lands, 
bara2 nam-lugal-la-ke4 ki-a mu-ni-in-us2| He has made the royal dais stand firmly, 
uri2{ki}-ma pa e3 hu-mu-ni-ib2-ak| he has made Ur resplendent. 
sipa {d}ur-{d}namma-ke4 ni2 bi2-in-gur3-ru sag he2-ni-in-il2 lugal kalam-ma-kam| The shepherd Ur-Namma has made it exude awesomeness, and he, as king of the Land, has lifted his head high there. 
ki lugal-a-ni {d}en-lil2-la2-ka sag-e-esz he2-ni-rig7| All this was granted to him in the place of his king, Enlil: 
nam am3-tar-re szu zi am3-mi-in-gar| a fate was decreed and then it was duly fulfilled. 
giri17-zal uri2{ki}-ma {d}ur-{d}namma nam-he2-a| There is now joy and abundance in Ur because (?) of Ur-Namma. 
sa-gar-ra-am3| The sa-gara. 
tigi {d}en-lil2-la2-kam| A tigi of Enlil. 
iri me du10-du10-ga bara2 mah nam-lugal-la| City of the finest divine powers, lofty royal throne-dais! 
esz3 uri5{ki} gu2-gal ki-en-gi-ra ki ku3-ga du3-a| Shrine Urim, pre-eminent in Sumer, built in a pure place! 
iri bad3 gal ki gar-ra-zu abzu-ta mu2-a| City, your well-founded great wall has grown out of the abzu! 
iri an-gin7 sig7-ga hi-li gur3-ru ki gal-la gun3-gun3| City, beautiful as the sky, endowed with beauty, colourfully decorated in a great place! 
esz3 uri5{ki} ge6-par4 ki gar-ra ki-tusz an {d}en-lil2-la2| Shrine Urim, well-founded ĝipar, dwelling of An and Enlil! 
e2-gal mah-zu e2-kisz-nu-gal2 sza3-ga nam tar-ra| Your lofty palace is the E-kiš-nu-ĝal, in which the fates are determined! 
dub-la2-zu me-lem4 du8-du8-a kur-kur-ra diri-ga| Your pilasters heavy with radiance tower over all the countries! 
gi-gun4-na-bi dungu babbar-gin7 an-sza3-ga u6 di| Its terrace like a white cloud is a spectacle in the midst of heaven. 
{gesz}banszur sikil-la ki ag2 {d}suen-na| Suen's beloved pure table; 
e2-kisz-nu-gal2 {gesz}banszur sikil-la ki ag2 {d}suen-na| E-kiš-nu-ĝal, Suen's beloved pure table. 
lugal KI.LUGAL.GUB-la he2-du7-bi kisal mah-e si-a| The king, ornament of the royal offering place, occupies the august courtyard; 
ni2-te-a-ni mi2 zi i-ri in-ga-am3-me| praised himself exultantly: 
ur-{d}namma lugal uri5{ki}-ma nam du10 tar-ra-ba giri3 si mu-un-da-ab-sa2| Under Ur-Namma, king of Urim, for whom a favorable destiny was determined, the roads have been made passable. 
an-e ka ku3-ga-ni mu-un-ba szegx(IM.A) ma-u3-tu| An opens his holy mouth, and because of me rain is produced. 
ki-sze3 sza3-ga si ba-an-sa2 he2-gal2 ma-ra-de6| He directs it downward into the earth, and abundance is brought for me. 
{d}en-ki-ke4 mi2 zi mu-un-du11 a-esztub{ku6} {d}ezina2 sze gu-nu sag-e-esz mu-un-rig7| Enki treats me kindly, bestowing early floods, grain and dappled barley. 
{d}nin-tu-re ge26-e mu-un-dim2-dim2-en gaba-ri-gu10 nu-tuku| Nintur formed me; I am peerless. 
{d}utu ka-ga2 inim ba-ni-in-gal2| Utu endowed me with eloquence (?); 
di ku5-ru-gu10 ki-en-gi ki-uri gu3 tesz2-a bi2-in-se3| my judgments create concord in Sumer and Akkad. 
{d}nin-gublaga-ke4 a2 ma-an-szum2| Ningublaga has given me strength. 
me3-gu10 an ki szu2-a-bi lu2 la-ba-ra-e3| In the whole extent of heaven and earth, no one can escape from a battle with me. 
ur-{d}namma lugal uri5{ki}-ma {d}lamma iri-ga2-me-en| I am Ur-Namma, king of Urim, the protecting genius of my city. 
szer7-da mu-dub2 su mu-un-sag3-sag3| I strike against those guilty of capital offences, and make them tremble. 
di ku5-ru-gu10 ki-en-gi ki-uri us2 dili-a mi-ni-ib-dab5| My judgments make Sumer and Akkad follow a single path. 
ni2-zuh lu2 i-{d}utu-ka gu2-ba giri3 bi2-gub| I place my foot on the necks of thieves and criminals. 
erim2-du musz-gin7 szu gid2-gid2-da szu im-da-an-szu2-szu2| I clamp down on evildoers, who will be caught like snakes. 
nig2-si-sa2-e pa e3 bi2-ak nig2-erim2 sa2 bi2-du11| I make justice apparent; I defeat wickedness. 
{d}gibil6-gin7 sag-ki gid2-da-gu10 gu3 tesz2-a bi2-se3| As if I were fire, even my frowning is enough to create concord. 
nidba-bi e2-kisz-nu-gal2-la-na {d}nanna-ar mi-ni-in-hul2-le| Their food offerings make Nanna rejoice in E-kiš-nu-ĝal. 
a-gu10 sza3 ku3-ge ba-ri-a-ta| After my seed had been poured into the holy womb, 
{d}suen-e u6-e ki ag2-ni| Suen, loving its appearance (?), 
{d}nanna-ar hi-li-na ba-ni-in-ku4-re| made it partake of Nanna's attractiveness. 
{d}en-lil2-le {d}utu-gin7 kalam-ma e3-de3 mu du10 mu-un-sa4| Coming forth over the Land like Utu, Enlil called me by an auspicious name, 
{d}nin-tu tu-tu-a mu-un-gub-bu| and Nintur assisted at my birth. 
sza3 ama-gu10 {d}nin-sumun2-ka-ta| As I came forth from the womb of my mother Ninsumun, 
nam tar-ra sa6-ga ma-ta-e3| a favorable allotted destiny was determined for me. 
ur-{d}namma-me-en ma-da ki-en-gi ki-uri {d}lamma mu-un-da-an-tuku| In me, Ur-Namma, the lands of Sumer and Akkad have their protecting genius. 
kalam-ma ki ur5 sa6-ge-bi ge26-e-me-en zi-gu10 he2-u3-tu| I am a source of joy for the Land; my life indeed creates! 
edimx(EDIN)-ma ezen-gin7 du3-a-ba giri3 si mu-un-da-ab-sa2| In the desert, the roads are made up as for a festival, and are passable because of me. 
dumu ukur3-ra u2 il2-i-de3 gen-na ama-ni-ir mu-un-gi4-gi4| I have freed the sons of the poor from their duty of going to fetch firewood. 
{d}en-lil2-le u4 du10-du10-ga-na masz2-e bi2-in-pa3-de3-en| Enlil chose me by extispicy on a day very auspicious for him. 
ki-en-gi-ra gu3 zi mu-un-de2 e2-a in-da-an-zi-ge-en| He spoke fairly to Sumer, and caused me to arise (?) from my family (?) 
gesztu2 dagal igi-gal2-tuku-gu10-sze3| Because of my broad understanding and wisdom, 
ki-en-gi-ra ud5-sag-bi ge26-e-me-en| I am the cosmic bond of Sumer. 
ukken igi-gu10-sze3 si im-sa2| The people line up in front of me.

ge6-par4-ra {tug2}gada nam-mi-la2| I am clad in linen in the ĝipar. 
gesz-nu2 gi-rin-na ki-nu2 du10-ba mu-nu2| I lie down on the splendid bed in its delightful bedchamber. 
ug3-e u2 nir-gal2 bi2-ib2-gu7-en {d}en-ki-im-du-bi-me-en| I cause the people to eat splendid food; I am their Enkimdu (i.e. the god of irrigation and cultivation). 
sipa zi udu-ni diri gal2-la-me-en| I am the good shepherd whose sheep multiply greatly. 
nam-en-na-bi u3-me-ni-tag| Since I have been adorned (?) with their rulership, 
buru14 mah-gu10 ni2-bi il2-il2-i nig2-ku5 nu-ak-e| no one imposes taxes on my abundant crops which grow tall.

ki-en-gi i7-ba a szu bi2-ba gesz gu2-ba mu-zi| I release water into the canals of Sumer, making the trees grow tall on their banks.

gal2 da13-da13-bi {d}utu an-ur2-ta u4 mi-ni-in-gar-ra| Your gate is named by your god, the beautiful god; only when it is is open does Utu illuminate from the horizon. 
gi-sa2-zu ki nam tar-ra dingir-re-e-ne di si sa2 ku5-ru-de3| Your platform, the place where the fates are determined by the gods, 
{d}a-nun-na dingir an ki-ka ad mi-ni-in-gi-gi-ne| in order to make just decisions, is where the Anuna, the gods of heaven and earth, take counsel. 
sza3-ga-zu-ta gesz-hur ku3-ga-a hul-gal2 nu-mu-un-dab5-be2| In your interior the evildoer dare not lay hold of the holy statutes. 
e2 gi-gun4-na ninda-ba-bi ki-bala szusz3 su3-su3| House whose offerings of the temple terrace devastate the rebel lands. 
dub-la2-mah ki nam tar-re-za| At your Dubla-maḫ, the place where the fates are determined, 
dingir gal-gal-e-ne nam mi-ni-tar-re-ne| the great gods determine the fates. 
ki-en-gi ki-uri ug3 sag-ge6-ga| Suen chose Sumer and Akkad, the black-headed people, 
{d}ur-{d}namma {d}suen sza3-ge ba-ni-in-pa3| and Ur-Namma in his heart. 
me-e en u3-mu-un-ra mi2 zi-de3-esz| let me give praise to him 
{d}ur-{d}namma ga-an-i-i-de3| to Ur-namma, Let me give praise to him! 
{d}ur-{d}namma hi-li gur3-ru me-lem4 kalam-ma dul-la| Ur-Namma who is endowed with allure, the radiance covering the nation, 
{d}ur-{d}namma {d}dili{im2}-babbar sza3-ge ba-ni-in-pa3| in his heart Ašimbabbar has chosen Ur-Namma, 
{gesz}rab3-ba kur-kur-ra im-mi-in-gar| placing thereby a shackle on all the lands 
si-gar kal-ga im-mi-in-gib-ba lugal {d}suen-ra tum2-ma-am3| and blocking the way with a strong bolt. The king is worthy of Suen! 
nig2-erim2 igi-ni-sze3 nu-dab5-be2| Wickedness cannot pass unnoticed before his eyes. 
nig2-si-sa2 {d}ur-{d}namma nig2-gur11 sa2 bi2-in-du11| Ur-Namma has accomplished an achievement, justice! 
za-pa-ag2-ga2-ni-sze3 kur erim2-ma bi2-in-gar| He fills the wicked land with his battle-cry. 
ki-bala-bi mu-un-se3 {d}ur-{d}namma maszkim im-me| The rebellious land is overthrown, Ur-Namma acts (?) as the constable. 
lugal-e e2 {d}suen-na-ke4| She has determined a fate for the king and the temple of Suen, 
{i7}idigna {i7}buranun {d}ur-{d}namma-ke4 nam mu-ni-ib2-tar-re| for the Tigris and the Euphrates and for Ur-Namma. 
{d}utu an-ur2-ta e3-a-ba| As the sun rises from the horizon, 
nam-lu2-ulu3 hu-mu-szi-ib2-dagal-e-ne| may the population multiply! 
nin-bi nin nig2-gur11-e ki ag2| Its lady, the lady who loves possessions, 
ki ag2-ga2-na-ke4 {d}ur-{d}namma-ke4 nam mu-ni-ib-tar-re| who loves him, has determined a fate for Ur-Namma; 
{d}nin-gal nin-bi nin nig2-gur11-e ki ag2| Ningal, its lady, the lady who loves possessions, 
munus a nun-na-ke4 {d}ur-{d}namma-ke4 nam mu-ni-ib-tar-re| the woman of princely seed, has determined a fate for Ur-Namma. 
sipa {d}ur-{d}namma-ke4 il2 e2 {d}suen-na-sze3 su6 za-gin3 sud4-sud4| The shepherd Ur-Namma is elevated; n the house of Suen, he is the one adorned with a lapis lazuli beard. 
{d}nin-lil2-le u4-da u3-tu-da-gin7| Like Ninlil who gives birth in a storm, 
dumu {d}nin-sumun2-na-ke4 za-e hu-mu-ra-u3-tu| child of Ninsumun, she has given birth to you. 
szer3-nam-szub {d}nanna-kam| A šir-namšub of Nanna. 
a-esztub {d}ezina2 sze gu-nu sag-e-esz he2-mu-rig7| He bestowed on him (?) early floods, grain and speckled barley. 
{d}ur-{d}namma ug3-e nam-he2-a gu2 hu-mu-u8-di-ni-ib-mar-re| Ur-Namma, may the people flourish in prosperity under your rule. 
lugal gu4-de3 gan2 gar-am3-ma gan2 gar-zu du10-ga-am3| King, cultivate the fields with oxen, and your cultivated fields will be rich; 
{d}ur-{d}namma gan2 gar-am3-ma GAN2 gar-zu du10-ga-am3| Ur-Namma, cultivate the fields with them, and your cultivated fields will be rich. 
gan2 gar-ra-za gu4-de3 ba-sa6 gan2 gar-za du10-ga-am3| The oxen will make (?) your cultivated fields fertile; your cultivated fields will be rich. 
lugal-gu10 gan2 {d}en-lil2-la2-ka a2 szu ha-ba-e-ni-du7| My king, when you have finished with all the work on the fields of Enlil; 
ur-{d}namma gan2 {d}en-lil2-la2-ka a2 szu ha-ba-e-ni-du7| Ur-Namma, when you have finished with all the work on the fields of Enlil, 
ab-sin2 gub-ba-zu im an-na si he2-em-ma-ni-in-sa2| may the rains of heaven make the furrows that you laid out sprout abundantly. 
bala-bala-e {d}en-lil2-la2-kam| A balbale of Enlil. 
inim-ma-an-ni kur2-kur2-re bi2-in-diri| all the foreign countries are full (?) of his fame. 
inim sza3-ga-na-ke4 sa bi2-in-du11| He carries out his plans,

lugal mes babbar2 uri5{ki}-ma ki du10-ge mu2-a| King, white meš tree growing in a pleasant spot in Urim,

gal-isz u-szi-bu {gesz}gigir-mesz erin2-hi-a-mesz-te dagal-mesz-te ad-ki| after I nobly ascended the royal throne, I mustered my chariotry (and) extensive troops.

iri ha-ri-ra iri hal-ha-la-usz sza2 en-mesz-ni en-mesz hi-i-t,i2 al-lik| and to the cities Ḫarira (and) Ḫalgalaus which (were under the authority) of the guilty rulers I marched.

ru-a| dedicated. 
{d}li-pi2-esz18-dar hi-li sza3-ga-na-me-en| Lipit-Ištar, you are the appeal of her heart. 
szir3-nam-szub-{d}inanna-kam| It is an incantation-song of Inanna, 
1(gesz2) 1(u) 6(disz) mu-bi-im| 76 are its lines. 
lu2 {gesz}DAR.GAG ra igi bi2-duh a-na-gin7 i3-gal2| Did you see the man who struck (and dislodged(?)) the mast/mooring pole/loom peg(!?)? How is he (found) there? 
x-TUG2 ama-gu10 lu2 he2-en-na-ab-be2 ti bur12-ra-ni a| (He says?) “Now, someone should say to my mother(?) “his torn out (dislocated) rib (i.e., boat planking)(!?) (let the) water (pour in?)” 
{gesz}sag-du ninda pad-pad-ra2-ni a bi2-ib-gul-la-a| The (supporting) beam(!?) (crumbling) like breads crumbs, destroyed him(!?) with water(!?) 
lu2 urx(AMA)-ta szub-ba igi bi2-duh a-na-gin7 i3-gal2| Did you see the man who had fallen from the roof(!?) How is he (found) there? 
igi bi2-duh a-na-gin7 i3-gal2| Did you see the man who was overtaken by(?) the curse(?) of his mother and father? How is he (found) there? 
i3-gal2| Did you see the man who was (intent to) not respect the command of his mother and father? How is he (found) there? 
i3-gal2| Did you see the ghost that does not have someone (to provide) funerary offerings (for him)? I saw him. How is he treated? 
a-na-gin7| <Did you see>(?) the tiny stillborn babies, who do not know their own names? How are they (found) there? 
u4 re-a u4 su3-ra2 re-a| In those days, in those distant days, 
ge6 re-a ge6 ba9-ra2 re-a| in those nights, in those remote nights, 
mu re-a mu su3-ra2 re-a| in those years, in those distant years, 
u4 ul nig2-du7-e pa e3-a-ba| in days of yore, when the necessary things had been brought into manifest, existence 
u4 ul nig2-du7-e mi2 zi du11-ga-a-ba| in days of yore, when the necessary things had been for the first time properly cared for, 
esz3 kalam-ma-ka ninda szu2-a-ba| when bread had been tasted for the first time in the shrines of the Land, 
{im}szu-rin-na kalam-ma-ka nig2-tab ak-a-ba| when the ovens of the Land had been made to work, 
an ki-ta ba-da-ba9-ra2-a-ba| when the heavens had been separated from the earth, 
ki an-ta ba-da-sur-ra-a-ba| when the earth had been delimited from the heavens, 
mu nam-lu2-u18-lu ba-an-gar-ra-a-ba| when the fame of mankind had been established, 
u4 an-ne2 an ba-an-de6-a-ba| when An had taken the heavens for himself, 
{d}en-lil2-le ki ba-an-de6-a-ba| when Enlil had taken the earth for himself, 
{d}eresz-ki-gal-la-ra kur-ra sag rig7-bi-sze3 im-ma-ab-rig7-a-ba| when the nether world had been given to Ereškigal as a gift, 
ba-u5-a-ba ba-u5-a-ba| when he set sail, when he set sail, 
a-a kur-sze3 ba-u5-a-ba| when the father set sail for the nether world, 
{d}en-ki kur-sze3 ba-u5-a-ba| when Enki set sail for the nether world— 
lugal-ra tur-tur ba-an-da-ri| against the king a storm of small hailstones arose, 
{d}en-ki-ra gal-gal ba-an-da-ri| against Enki a storm of large hailstones arose, 
tur-tur-bi na4 szu-kam| The small ones were light hammers, 
gal-gal-bi na4 gi gu4-u4-da-kam| the large ones were like stones from catapults (?). 
ur2 {gesz}ma2 tur-re {d}en-ki-ka3-ke4| The keel of Enki’s little boat 
nig2-bun2-na du7-am3 mi-szu2-szu2| as if it were being butted by turtles was trembling, 
lugal-ra a {gesz}ma2-sag-ga2-ke4| against the king the waves at the bow of the boat 
ur-bar-ra-gin7 tesz2 mu-na-gu7-e| like wolves were eating together, 
{d}en-ki-ra a {gesz}ma2-egir-ra-ke4| against Enki the waves at the stern of the boat 
ur-mah-gin7 sag gesz im-ra-ra| like a lion were attacking. 
u4-bi-a gesz 1(disz)-am3 {gesz}ha-lu-ub2 1(disz)-am3 gesz 1(disz)-am3| At that time, there was a single tree, a single ḫalub tree, a single tree, 
gu2 i7 buranun-na ku3-ga-ka du3-a-bi| growing on the bank of the pure Euphrates, 
i7 buranun-na a na8-na8-da-bi| being watered by the Euphrates. 
a2 u18-lu ur2-ba mu-ni-in-bur12 pa-ba mu-ni-in-suh| The force of the south wind uprooted it and stripped its branches, 
i7 buranun-na a im-ma-ni-ib-ra| and the Euphrates picked it up and carried it away. 
munus-e inim an-na-ta ni2 te-a du| A woman, respectful of An’s words, was walking along; 
inim {d}en-lil2-la2-ta ni2 te-a du| respectful of Enlil’s words, was walking along, 
gesz szu-na mu-un-dab5 unu{ki}-sze3 ba-ni-in-ku4-re| and took the tree and into Unug, 
{gesz}kiri6 gi-rin {d}inanna-sze3 im-ma-ni-in-ku4-ku4-re| into Inanna’s luxuriant garden brought it. 
munus-e gesz szu-na li-bi2-in-du giri3-ni-ta bi2-in-du| The woman planted the tree not with her hands, but with her feet. 
munus-e gesz szu-na a li-bi2-in-du11 giri3-ni-ta bi2-in-du11| The woman planted the tree not with her hands, but with her feet planted it. 
me-na-am3 {gesz}gu-za gi-rin ba-ni-tusz-de3-en bi2-in-du11| “When will this be a luxuriant chair on which I can take a seat?” she said; 
me-na-am3 gesz-nu2 gi-rin ba-ni-nu2-de3-en bi2-in-du11| “When this will be a luxuriant bed on which I can lie down?” she said; 
mu 5(disz)-am3 mu 1(u)-am3 ba-e-zal-la re| 5 years, 10 years went by, 
gesz ba-gur4 kusz-bi nu-mu-un-da-dar| the tree grew massive; its bark, however, did not split. 
ur2-bi-a musz tu6 nu-zu-e gu4 im-ma-ni-ib-us2| At its roots, a snake immune to incantations made itself a nest. 
pa-bi-a muszen anzu4{muszen}-de3 amar im-ma-ni-ib-gar| In its branches, the Anzud bird settled its young. 
szab-bi-a ki-sikil lil2-la2-ke4 e2 im-ma-ni-ib-du3| In its trunk, the phantom maid built herself a dwelling, 
ki-sikil zu2 li9-li9 sza3 hul2-hul2| the maid who laughs with a joyful heart. 
ku3 {d}inanna-ke4 er2 e-ne ba-sze8-sze8| But silver Inanna cried! 
u4 zal-le-da an-ur2 zalag-ge-da| When dawn was breaking, when the horizon became bright, 
buru5 u4 zal-le szeg10 gi4-gi4-da| when the little birds, at the break of dawn, began to clamor, 
{d}utu agrun-ta e3-a-ni| when Utu had left his bedchamber, 
nin9-a-ni ku3 {d}inanna-ke4| his sister silver Inanna 
ur-sag szul {d}utu-ra| to the young warrior Utu: said 
szesz-gu10 u4 re-a na-ag2 ba-tar-ra-a-ba| “My brother, in those days when destiny was determined, 
u4 he2-ma-al-la ka-na-ag2-ga2 ba-e-zal-la re| when abundance overflowed in the Land, 
u4 an-ne2 an ba-an-ir-ra-a-ba| when An had taken the heavens for himself, 
{d}mu-ul-lil2-le ki ba-an-ir-ra-a-ba| when Enlil had taken the earth for himself, 
{d}ga-sza-an-ki-gal-la-ra kur-ra sag rig7-ga-sze3 im-ma-ab-rig7-ga-a-ba| when the nether world had been given to Ereškigala as a gift; 
ba-u5-a-ba ba-u5-a-ba| when he set sail, when he set sail, 
a-a kur-sze3 ba-u5-a-ba| when the father set sail for the nether world, 
{d}am-an-ki kur-sze3 ba-u5-a-ba| when Enki set sail for the nether world—

{d}am-an-ki-ra gal-gal ba-an-da-ri| against Enki a storm of large hailstones arose. 
tur-tur-bi na4 szu-a-kam| The small ones were light hammers, 
gal-gal-bi na4 gi gu4-u4-da-kam| the large ones were like stones from catapults (?). 
ur2 {gesz}ma2 tur-re {d}am-an-ki-ka3-ke4| The keel of Enki’s little boat was trembling

ur-bar-ra-gin7 tesz2 mu-un-na-gu7-e| like wolves together were eating, 
{d}am-an-ki-ra a {gesz}ma2-egir-ra-ke4| against Enki the waves at the stern of the boat were attacking Enki like a lion.” 
ur-mah-gin7 sag gesz im-ra-ra| like a lion were attacking.” 
u4-bi-a mu di-ta-am3 {gesz}ha-lu-ub2 di-ta gesz TUG2 di-ta-am3| “At that time, there was a single tree, a single ḫalub tree, a single tree (?),

szesz-a-ni ur-sag szul {d}utu inim-bi nu-mu-de3-gub| Her brother, the young warrior Utu, however, did not stand by her in the matter. 
u4 zal-le-da an-ur2 zalag-ge-de3| When dawn was breaking, when the horizon became bright,

ur-sag {d}gilgamesz2 gu3 mu-na-de2-e| to the warrior Gilgameš speaks:

u4 an-ne2 an ba-an-ir-ra-a-ba| when An had taken the heavens for himself,

{d}ga-sza-an-ki-gal-la-ra kur-ra sag rig7-ga-sze3 im-ma-ab-rig7-ga-a-ba| when the nether world had been given to Ereškigala as a gift;

gal-gal-bi na4 gi gu4-u4-da-kam| the large ones were like stones from catapults (?).

u4-bi-a mu di-ta-am3 {gesz}ha-lu-ub2 di-ta-am3 gesz TUG2 di-ta-am3| “At that time, there was a single tree, a single ḫalub tree, a single tree (?),

i7 buranun-na a na8-na8-da-bi| being watered by the Euphrates. 
a2 {tum9}u18-lu ur2-ba mu-ni-in-bur12 pa-ba mu-un-ni-in-suh| The force of the south wind uprooted it and stripped its branches, 
i7 buranun-na a im-ma-ni-ib-ra| and the Euphrates picked it up and carried it away. 
nu-nus-e e-ne-eg3 an-na-ta ni2 te-a du| I, a woman, respectful of An’s words, was walking along; 
e-ne-eg3 {d}mu-ul-lil2-la2-ta ni2 te-a du| respectful of Enlil’s words, was walking along,

{gesz}kiri6 gi-rin ga-sza-an-an-na-sze3 im-ma-ni-in-ku4-ku4-re| into Inanna’s luxuriant garden.” 
nu-nus-e mu szu-na li-bi2-du11 giri3-ni-ta bi2-in-du| “The woman planted the tree not with her hands, but with her feet. 
{d}ga-sza-an-na-ke4 mu szu-na a li-bi2-de2 giri3-ni-ta bi2-in-du| Inanna watered it using not her hands, but her feet. 
me-na-am3 {gesz}gu-za gi-rin ba-ni-tusz-u3-de3-en bi2-in-du11| “When will this be a luxuriant chair on which I can take a seat?” she said; 
me-na-am3 gesz-nu2 gi-rin ba-ni-nu2-de3-en bi2-in-du11| “When will this be a luxuriant bed on which I can lie down?” she said; 
mu 5(disz)-am3 mu 1(u)-am3 ba-e-zal-la re| 5 years, 10 years had gone by, 
mu ba-gur4 kusz-bi nu-mu-un-da-dar| the tree had grown massive; its bark, however, did not split. 
ur2-bi-a musz tu6 nu-zu-e gu4 im-ma-ni-ib-us2| At its roots, a snake immune to incantations made itself a nest. 
pa-bi-a muszen anzu4{muszen}-de3 amar-bi im-ma-ni-ib-gar| In its branches, the Anzu bird settled its young. 
szab-ba-bi-a ki-sikil lil2-la2-ke4 e2 im-ma-ni-in-du3| In its trunk, the phantom maid built herself a dwelling, 
ki-sikil zu2 li9-li9 sza3 hul2-hul2| the maid who laughs with a joyful heart. 
ku3 {d}inanna-ke4 er2 e-ne ba-sze8-sze8| I, silver Inanna, cried!” 
nin9-a-ni inim in-na-an-du11-ga| In the matter which his sister had told him about, 
szesz-a-ni ur-sag {d}gilgamesz2 inim-bi ba-de3-gub| her brother, the warrior Gilgamesh, stood by her. 
5(u)-am3 3(u) gin2 ba-szi-in-ak| 50 minas were to him as 30 shekels. 
{uru4}ha-zi-in-na-ni har-ra-an-na-ka-ni| His bronze axe used for expeditions, 
7(asz) gun2 7(disz) ma-na-ka-ni szu-ni-a ba-an-dab5| which weighs 7 talents and 7 minas, in his hand he took; 
ur2-bi-a musz tu6 nu-zu-e sag gesz ba-an-ra| He killed the snake immune to incantations living at its roots. 
pa-bi-a muszen anzu4{muszen}-de3 amar-bi szu ba-an-ti hur-sag-sze3 ba-an-ku4| The Anzu bird living in its branches took up its young and went into the mountains. 
szab-ba-bi-a ki-sikil lil2-la2-ke4 e2 im-ma-an-ni-in-zal| The phantom maid living in its trunk left (?) her dwelling 
e2-ri-e2-ri-sze3 ba-an-kar-kar-re| and sought refuge in the wilderness. 
gesz ur2-ba mu-ni-in-bur12 pa-ba mu-ni-in-suh| As for the tree, he uprooted it and stripped its branches, 
dumu iri-na mu-un-de3-re7-esz-am3| and the sons of his city, who went with him, 
pa-bi i3-ku5-ru-ne zu2 ba-kesz2-re-ne| cut up its branches and bundled them 
nin9-a-ni ku3 {d}inanna-ra {gesz}gu-za-ni-sze3 mu-na-ab-szum2-mu| He gave it to his sister silver Inanna for her chair. 
gesz-nu2-da-ni-sze3 mu-na-ab-szum2-mu| He gave it to her for her bed. 
e-ne ur2-bi {gesz}ellag-a-ni-sze3 ba-da-ab-dim2-e| As for himself, from its roots, he manufactured his ball (?) 
pa-bi {gesz}e-ke4-ma-ni-sze3 ba-ab-dim2-e| and, from its branches, he manufactured his mallet (?). 
{gesz}ellag al du11-du11-ge sila ur3-ra {gesz}ellag na-mu-un-e| He played with the ball (?) in the broad square, never wanting to stop playing it, 
ni2 silim du11-du11-ge sila ur3-ra ni2 silim na-mu-un-e| and he praised himself in the broad square, never wanting to stop praising himself. 
gurusz iri-na-ka {gesz}ellag al du11-du11-ga-ne| The young men of his city were playing with the ball (?). 
a gu2-gu10 a ib2-ba-gu10 a-nir im-ga2-ga2-ne| they lamented: “O my neck! O my hips!” 
ama tuku dumu-ni-ir ninda mu-na-ab-de6| For those that had a mother, bread for her son she brought; 
nin9 tuku szesz-a-ni-ir a mu-na-de2-e| for those that had a sister, she poured water for her brother. 
u2-sa11-an-e um-ma-te-a-ra| As the evening came, 
ki {gesz}ellag gar-ra-ka-ni gesz-hur in-hur-re| he marked the spot where the ball (?) had been placed, 
{gesz}ellag-a-ni igi-ni-a mu-ni-in-il2 e2-a-ni-sze3 mu-un-de6| and he picked up his ball (?) from in front of him and took it home. 
szu du3-du3-a nu-mu-un-su-a-ta| the widows’ accusation 
i-{d}utu ki-sikil tur-ra-ta| and the young girls’ complaint 
{gesz}ellag-a-ni u3 {gesz}e-ke4-ma-ni dur2 kur-ra-sze3 ba-da-an-szub| caused his ball (?) and his mallet (?) to fall down to the bottom of the nether world. 
szu-ni mu-ni-in-du11 sa2 nu-mu-un-da-du11| He tried with his hand but could not reach them, 
giri3-ni mu-ni-in-du11 sa2 nu-mu-un-da-du11| tried with his foot but could not reach them. 
abul ganzer igi kur-ra-ka dur2 im-ma-ni-in-gar| At the gate of Ganzer, in front of the nether world, he sat down. 
{d}gilgamesz2 er2 im-ma-an-pa3 szex(SIG7)-szex(SIG7) i3-ga2-ga2| Gilgamesh wept, crying bitterly: 
a {gesz}ellag-gu10 a {gesz}e-ke4-ma-gu10| “O my ball (?)! O my mallet (?)! 
{gesz}ellag la-la-bi nu-mu-un-gi4-a-gu10| My ball (?), I am still not satiated with its charms, 
eszemen di nu-mu-un-sug4-ga-gu10| the game with it has not yet palled for me! 
u4-ba {gesz}ellag-gu10 e2 nagar-ra-ka nu-usz-ma-da-gal2-am3| If only my ball (?) waited still in the carpenter’s house for me! 
dam nagar-ra ama ugu-gu10-gin7 nu-usz-ma-da-gal2-la-am3| I would treat the carpenter’s wife like my own mother— 
dumu nagar-ra nin9 banda3{da}-gu10-gin7 nu-usz-ma-da-gal2-la-am3| I would treat the carpenter’s child like my little sister! 
{gesz}ellag-gu10 kur-sze3 mu-da-szub a-ba-a ma-ra-ab-e11-de3| My ball (?) has fallen down to the nether world—who will retrieve it for me? 
{gesz}e-ke4-ma-gu10 ganzer-sze3 mu-da-szub a-ba-a ma-ra-ab-e11-de3| My mallet (?) has fallen down to Ganzer—who will retrieve it for me? 
ARAD-da-ni en-ki-du10-e inim mu-un-ni-ib-gi4-gi4| His servant Enkidu answered: 
lugal-gu10 er2 e-ne ba-sze8-sze8 sza3 hul a-na-asz mu-e-dim2| “My king, you weep; why does your heart worry? 
u4-da {gesz}ellag-zu kur-ta ge26-e ga-mu-ra-ab-e11-de3| Today I shall retrieve your ball (?) from the nether world, 
{gesz}e-ke4-ma-zu ganzer-ta ge26-e ga-mu-ra-ab-e11-de3| I shall retrieve your mallet (?) from Ganzer.” 
{d}gilgamesz2-e en-ki-du10-ra inim mu-un-na-ni-ib-gi4| Gilgamesh answered Enkidu: 
tukum-bi u4-da kur-sze3 mu-ni-in-e11-de3| “If today you are going to go down to the nether world, 
na ga-de5 na de5-gu10 he2-dab5| let me advise you! My instructions should be followed. 
inim ga-ra-ab-du11 inim-gu10-sze3 gesztu2-zu| Let me talk to you! Pay attention to my words!" 
tug2 dan2-dan2-na-zu na-an-mu4-mu4-un| “You should not put on your clean garments: 
gir5-gin7 {gesz}kim na-an-ni-ib-e3-esz| they would recognise immediately that you are alien. 
i3 du10-ga bur-ra na-an-sze22-sze22-en| You should not anoint yourself with fine oil from a bowl: 
ir-si-im-bi-sze3 nam-mu-e-nigin2-nigin2-ne-esz| they would surround you at its scent. 
{gesz}ilar kur-ra nam-mu-e-sag3-ge| You should not hurl throw-sticks in the nether world: 
lu2 {gesz}ilar ra-a nam-mu-e-nigin2-nigin2-ne-esz| those struck down by the throw-sticks would surround you. 
{gesz}ma-nu szu-za nam-ba-e-ga2-ga2-an| You should not not hold a cornel-wood stick in your hand: 
gidim ba-e-de3-ur4-re-esz| the spirits would feel insulted by you. 
{kusz}e-sir2 giri3-za nam-mu-e-si-ge| You should not put sandals on your feet. 
kur-ra gu3 nam-mu-un-ga2-ga2-an| You should not shout in the nether world. 
dam ki ag2-ga2-zu ne na-an-su-ub-be2-en| You should not kiss your beloved wife. 
dam hul gig-ga-zu nig2 nam-mu-ra-ra-an| You should not hit your wife even if you are annoyed with her. 
dumu ki-ag2-zu ne na-an-su-ub-be2-en| You should not kiss your beloved child. 
dumu hul gig-ga-zu nig2 nam-mu-ra-ra-an| You should not hit your son even if you are annoyed with him. 
i-{d}utu kur-ra ba-e-dab5-be2| The outcry aroused would detain you in the nether world.” 
i3-nu2-a-ra i3-nu2-a-ra| “She who lies there, she who lies there, 
ama {d}nin-a-zu i3-nu2-a-ra| Ninazu’s mother who lies there— 
mur ku3-ga-na tug2 nu-um-dul| her pure shoulders are not covered with a garment, 
gaba ku3-ga-na gada nu-um-bur2| and no linen is spread over her pure breast. 
szu-si-ni uru4 lub-gin7 an-da-gal2| She has fingers like a pickaxe, 
siki-ni ga-rasz{sar}-gin7 i3-guru5-guru5| she plucks her hair out like leeks.” 
en-ki-du10 inim lugal-la-na-asz szu nu-um-ma-gi7-i| Enkidu, however, did not heed not his master’s words. 
tug2 dan2-dan2-na-ni im-ma-an-mur10| He put on his clean garments 
gir5-gin7 {gesz}kim im-ma-an-ne-esz| and they recognised that he was alien. 
i3 du10-ga {na4}bur-ra im-ma-an-szesz4| He anointed himself with fine oil from a bowl 
ir-si-im-bi-sze3 im-ma-an-nigin2-nigin2-ne-esz| and they surrounded him at its scent. 
{gesz}ilar kur-ra im-ma-an-sag3-ge| He hurled throw-sticks in the nether world 
lu2 {gesz}ilar ra-a im-ma-an-nigin2-nigin2-ne-esz| and those struck down by the throw-sticks surrounded him. 
{gesz}ma-nu szu-na im-ma-ni-in-gar| He held a cornel-wood stick in his hand 
gidim ba-an-da-ur4-re-esz| and the spirits felt insulted by him. 
{kusz}e-sir2 giri3-na im-ma-ni-in-si| He put sandals on his feet. 
kur-ra tuku4-tuku4 im-ma-ni-in-gar| He caused irritation in the nether world. 
dam ki ag2-ga2-ni ne im-ma-an-su-ub| He kissed his beloved wife 
dam hul gig-ga-ni nig2 im-ma-ni-in-ra| and hit his wife when he was annoyed with her. 
dumu ki-ag2-ga2-ni ne im-ma-an-su-ub| He kissed his beloved child 
dumu hul gig-ga-ni nig2 im-ma-ni-in-ra| and hit his son when he was annoyed with him. 
i-{d}utu kur-ra im-ma-an-dab5| He aroused an outcry and was detained in the nether world. 
ur-sag {d}gilgamesz2 dumu {d}nin-sumun2-na-ke4| The warrior Gilgamesh, son of Ninsumun, 
e2-kur-re e2 {d}en-lil2-la2-sze3 giri3-ni dili mu-un-gub| directed his steps on his own to E-kur, the temple of Enlil. 
igi {d}en-lil2-la2-sze3 er2 im-ma-sze8-sze8| He cried before Enlil: 
a-a {d}en-lil2 {gesz}ellag-gu10 kur-sze3 mu-da-an-szub {gesz}e-ke4-ma-gu10 ganzer-sze3 mu-da-an-szub| “Father Enlil, my ball (?) fell down into the nether world, my mallet (?) fell down into Ganzer. 
en-ki-du10 e11-de3 i3-gi4 kur-re im-ma-an-dab5| Enkidu went down to retrieve them but the nether world has seized him. 
nam-tar nu-un-dab5 a2-sag3 nu-un-dab5 kur-re im-ma-an-dab5| Namtar did not seize him, the Asag did not seize him; but the nether world has seized him. 
{d}udug {d}nergal sag szu nu-du7 nu-mu-un-dab5 kur-re im-ma-an-dab5| The udug demon of Nergal, who spares nobody, did not seize him, but the nether world has seized him. 
ki nam-nita-a-ke4 me3-a nu-un-szub kur-re im-ma-an-dab5| He did not fall in battle on the field of manhood, but the nether world has seized him.” 
a-a {d}en-lil2 inim-bi nu-mu-de3-gub eridu{ki}-sze3 ba-gen| Father Enlil did not stand by him in the matter, so he went to Eridu. 
eridu{ki} e2 {d}en-ki-ka3-sze3 giri3-ni dili mu-un-gub| In Eridu he directed his steps on his own to the temple of Enki. 
igi {d}en-ki-ka3-sze3 er2 im-ma-sze8-sze8| He cried before Enki: 
a-a {d}en-ki {gesz}ellag-gu10 kur-sze3 mu-da-an-szub {gesz}e-ke4-ma-gu10 ganzer-sze3 mu-da-an-szub| “Father Enki, my ball (?) fell down into the nether world, my mallet (?) fell down into Ganzer. 
en-ki-du10 e11-de3 i3-gi4-en kur-re im-ma-an-dab5| Enkidu went down to retrieve them but the nether world has seized him. 
nam-tar nu-un-dab5 a2-sag3 nu-un-dab5 kur-re im-ma-an-dab5| Namtar did not seize him, the Asag did not seize him; but the nether world has seized him. 
{d}udug {d}nergal sag szu nu-du7 nu-mu-un-dab5 kur-re im-ma-an-dab5| The udug demon of Nergal, who spares nobody, did not seize him, but the nether world has seized him. 
ki nam-nita-a-ke4 me3-a nu-un-szub kur-re im-ma-an-dab5| He did not fall in battle on the field of manhood, but the nether world has seized him.” 
a-a {d}en-ki inim-bi ba-e-de3-gub| Father Enki stood by him in this matter. 
ur-sag szul {d}utu-ra dumu {d}nin-gal-e tu4-da gu3 mu-na-de2-e| He said to the young warrior Utu, the son born by Ningal: 
i3-ne-esz2 ab-lal3 kur-ra gal2 u3-bi2-in-tak4| “Open a window in the nether world immediately, 
szubur-a-ni kur-ta e11-de3-mu-na-ab| and then bring up his servant from the nether world!” 
ab-lal3 kur-ra gal2 im-ma-an-tak4| He opened a window in the nether world 
si-si-ig-ni-ta szubur-a-ni kur-ta mu-da-ra-ab-e11-de3| and brought up his servant with his breeze (?) from the nether world. 
gu2-ni gu2-da mu-ni-in-la2 ne mu-un-su-ub-be2| They hugged and kissed. 
en3 tar-re im-mi-in-kusz2-u3-ne| They wearied each other with questions: 
a2-ag2-ga2 kur-ra igi bi2-du8| “Did you see the order of the nether world? 
nu-usz-ma-ab-be2-en gu5-li-gu10 nu-usz-ma-be2-en| If only you would tell me, my friend, if only you would tell me!” 
tukum-bi a2-ag2-ga2 kur-ra mu-ra-ab-be2-en| “If I tell you the order of the nether world, 
za-e tusz-a er2 ge26-e ga-tusz ga-er2| si yourself down and weep! I shall sit down and weep! 
tug2 sumun-a-gin7 uh bi2-in-tag| worms infest it like an old garment (?); 
en-e u8 bi2-in-du11 sahar-ra ba-da-an-tusz| “Alas!” he said and sat down in the dust. 
lu2 dumu-ni 1(disz)-am3 igi bi2-du8-am3 igi bi2-du8-am3 a-na-gin7 an-ak| “Did you see him who had 1 son?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
{gesz}gag e2-gar8-a-na ab-du3-a gig-ga i-i| “He weeps bitterly at the wooden peg which was driven into his wall.” 
lu2 dumu-ni 2(disz)-am3 igi bi2-du8-am3 igi bi2-du8-am3 a-na-gin7 an-ak| “Did you see him who had 2 sons?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
szeg12 2(disz)-a al-tusz ninda al-gu7-e| “He sits on 2 bricks, eating bread.” 
lu2 dumu-ni 3(disz)-am3 igi bi2-du8-am3 igi bi2-du8-am3 a-na-gin7 an-ak| “Did you see him who had 3 sons?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
{kusz}ummu4 dag-si-ke4 a al-na8-na8| “He drinks water from a saddle waterskin.” 
lu2 dumu-ni 4(disz)-am3 igi bi2-du8-am3 igi bi2-du8-am3 a-na-gin7 an-ak| “Did you see him who had 4 sons?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
lu2 ansze 4(disz) la2-gin7 sza3-ga-ni al-hul2| “His heart rejoices like a man who has four asses to yoke.” 
lu2 dumu-ni 5(disz)-am3 igi bi2-du8-am3 igi bi2-du8-am3 a-na-gin7 an-ak| “Did you see him who had 5 sons?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
dub-sar sa6-ga-gin7 a2-ni gal2 bi2-in-tak4 e2-gal si sa2-bi ba-an-ku4-ku4| “Like a good scribe he is indefatigable, he enters the palace easily.” 
lu2 dumu-ni 6(disz)-am3 igi bi2-du8-am3 igi bi2-du8-am3 a-na-gin7 an-ak| “Did you see him who had 6 sons?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
lu2 {gesz}apin-la2-gin7 sza3-ga-ni al-hul2| “He is a cheerful as a ploughman.” 
lu2 dumu-ni 7(disz)-am3 igi bi2-du8-am3 igi bi2-du8-am3 a-na-gin7 an-ak| “Did you see him who had 7 sons?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
dub-us2 dingir-re-e-ne-ke4 {gesz}gu-za ib2-tusz di-da gesz ba-tuku| “As a companion of the gods, he sits on a throne and listens to judgments.” 
tiru-e igi bi2-du8-am3 igi bi2-du8-am3 a-na-gin7 an-ak| “Did you see the palace eunuch?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
pa a-la-la hur-ra-gin7 ub-du11-ga-a ab-us2| “Like a useless alala stick he is propped in a corner.” 
munus nu-u3-tu4 igi bi2-du8-am3 igi bi2-du8-am3 a-na-gin7 an-ak| “Did you see the woman who never gave birth?” “I saw her.” “How does she fare?” 
gurusz tur ur2 dam-na-ka tug2 nu-ub-si-ge igi bi2-du8-am3 igi bi2-du8-am3 a-na-gin7 an-ak| “Did you see the young man who never undressed his wife?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
esz2-szu-ak szu im-mi-du7-un esz2-szu-ak-ba er2 im-mi-in-sze8-sze8| “You finish a rope, and he weeps over the rope.” 
ki-sikil ur2 dam-na-ka tug2 nu-ub-si-ge igi bi2-du8-am3 igi bi2-du8-am3 a-na-gin7 an-ak| “Did you see the young woman who never undressed her husband?” “I saw her.” “How does she fare?” 
gi-szu-ak szu im-mi-du7-un gi-szu-ak er2 mi-in-sze8-sze8| “You finish a reed mat, and she weeps over the reed mat.” 
lu2 ibila nu-tuku igi bi2-du8-am3 igi bi2-du8-am3 a-na-gin7 an-ak| “Did you see him who had no heir?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
u2-ni al-bar a-ni al-bar u2 gi7 al-gu7-e a gi7 al-na8-na8| “His food is set apart, his water is set apart, he eats the food offered (?) to him, he drinks the water offered (?) to him.” 
lu2 ur-mah-e gu7-a igi bi2-du8-am3| “Did you see him who was eaten by a lion?” 
a szu-gu10 a giri3-gu10 gig-ga-bi im-me| “He cries bitterly “O my hands! O my legs!” 
lu2 ur3 szub-ba igi bi2-du8-am3| “Did you see him who fell down from the roof?” 
lu2 sahar-szub-ba igi bi2-du8-am3| “Did you see the leprous man?” 
gu4-gin7 al-dub2 uh im-da-gu7-e| “He twitches like an ox as the worms eat at him.” 
lu2 me3-a szub-ba igi bi2-in-du8-am3 igi bi2-du8-am3 a-na-gin7 an-ak| “Did you see him who fell in battle?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
ad ama-ni sag-du nu-mu-un-dab5 dam-a-ni er2 i3-sze8-sze8| “His father and mother are not there to hold his head, and his wife weeps.” 
gidim lu2 ninda sig10-ge5 nu-tuku igi bi2-du8-am3 igi bi2-du8-am3 a-na-gin7 an-ak| “Did you see the spirit of him who has no funerary offerings?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
lu2 {gesz}ma2-du3 ra igi bi2-du8-am3 a-na-gin7 an-ak| “Did you see him hit by a ship’s board? How does he fare?” 
a2-sze ama-gu10 lu2 he2-en-na-ab-be2| “Alas, my mother!” the man cries to her,

{gesz}banszur ku3-sig17 ku3-babbar lal3 i3-nun-ta e-ne im-di-e-ne| “They play at a table of gold and silver, laden with honey and ghee.” 
ki gesz-nu2 dingir-re-e-na al-nu2| “He lies on a bed of the gods.”

gu2 ki gar-ba-ni| Submit!  
umma{ki}| Umma,  
gul-gul-la-ba| about its complete destruction  
he2-zu| may you know! 
gu2 ki gar-ba-ni| Submit!  
nam-lugal an-ta e11-de3-a-ba| After kingship from heaven descended, 
eridu{ki} nam-lugal-la| in Eridu was kingship. 
eridu{ki} a2-lu-lim lugal| In Eridu, Alulim was king, 
mu 8(szar2) i3-ak| 28,800 years he ruled; 
a2-lal3-gar mu 1(szar'u) i3-ak| Alalgar, 36,000 years he ruled; 
2(disz) lugal| 2 kings, 
mu-bi 1(szar'u) 8(szar2) ib2-ak| the years: 64,800 they ruled; 
eridu{ki} ba-szub| Eridu fell, 
nam-lugal-bi bad3-tibira{ki}-sze3| and the kingship to Bad-tibira 
ba-de6| was carried off. 
bad3-tibira{ki} en-me-en-lu2-an-na| In Bad-tibira, En-men-lu-ana, 
mu 1(szar'u) 2(szar2) i3-ak| 43,200 years he ruled; 
en-me-en-gal-an-na| En-men-gal-ana, 
mu 8(szar2) i3-ak| 28,800 he ruled; 
{d}dumu-zi sipa mu 1(szar'u) i3-ak| Dumuzi, the shepherd, 36,000 years he ruled; 
3(disz) lugal| 3 kings, 
mu-bi 3(szar'u) ib2-ak| the years: 10,8000 they ruled; 
bad3-tibira{ki} ba-szub-be2-en| Bad-tibira, you fell, 
nam-lugal-bi la-ra-ag{ki}-sze3 ba-de6| and the kingship to Larag was carried off. 
la-ra-ag{ki} en-sipa-zi-an-na| In Larag, En-sipa-zi-ana, 
mu 8(szar2) i3-ak| 28,800 years he ruled. 
1(disz) lugal| 1 king, 
mu-bi 8(szar2) ib2-ak| the years: 28,800 he ruled. 
la-ra-ag{ki} ba-szub-be2-en| Larag, you fell, 
nam-lugal-bi zimbir{ki}-sze3 ba-de6| and the kingship to Sippar was carried off. 
zimbir{ki} en-me-en-dur2-an-na| In Sippar, En-men-dur-ana 
lugal-am3 mu 5(szar2) 5(gesz'u) i3-ak| was king, 21,000 years he ruled; 
1(disz) lugal| 1 king, 
mu-bi 5(szar2) 5(gesz'u) ib2-ak| the years: 21,000 he ruled; 
zimbir{ki} ba-szub-be2-en| Sippar, you fell, 
nam-lugal-bi szuruppak{ki}-sze3 ba-de6| and the kingship to Shuruppak was carried off. 
szuruppak{ki} ubur-du-du| In Shuruppak, Ubara-Tutu 
lugal-am3 mu 5(szar2) 1(gesz'u) i3-ak| was king, 18,600 years he ruled, 
1(disz) lugal| 1 king, 
mu-bi 5(szar2) 1(gesz'u) ib2-ak| the years: 18,600 he ruled. 
5(disz) iri{ki}-me-esz| 5 cities, 
8(disz) lugal| 8 kings, 
mu-bi 1(szargal){gal} 7(szar2) ib2-ak| the years: 241,200 they ruled. 
a-ma-ru ba-ur3-ra-ta| Then the flood swept over. 
egir a-ma-ru ba-ur3-ra-ta| After the flood had swept over, 
nam-lugal an-ta e11-de3-a-ba| and kingship from heaven had descended, 
kisz{ki} nam-lugal-la| in Kish was kingship.

ninda ba-ra-gibil-la2 kasz ba-ra-gibil-la2| There being no fresh bread, there being no fresh beer, 
lu2 kasx(DU){kas}-e szu tak4-ma-ab| have a courier send some to me! 
a-ma-ru-kam| It’s a flood! 
du11-ga-ni-ta {gesz}tukul-zu hul-a mu-ni-in-tag| “At his command your weapon struck me evilly. 
me szu-ga2 szu ba-ba-gu10-ne me-bi abzu-sze3 ba-an-gi4| As I let the divine powers go out of my hand, these divine powers returned to the abzu. 
gesz-hur szu-ga2 szu ba-ba-gu10-ne gesz-hur-bi abzu-sze3 ba-an-gi4| As I let the divine plan go out of my hand, this divine plan returned to the abzu. 
dub nam-tar-ra-bi abzu-sze3 ba-an-gi4 me ab-la2-e-en| This tablet of destinies returned to the abzu. I was stripped of the divine powers.” 
inim amar anzu{muszen}-sze3 {d}nin-urta lul-asz ba-an-si| Ninurta was stunned at these words of the Anzu-chick. 
{d}nin-men-na-ke4 a-nir im-ga2-ga2| Ninmena gave out a wail: 
ge26-e me-bi szu-gu10-usz li-bi2-ku4 nam-en-bi nu-ak-e| “And what about me? These divine powers have not fallen into my hand. 
ge26-e e-ne-gin7 esz3-e abzu-a nu-mu-un-til| I shall not exercise their authority. I shall not live (?) like him in the shrine, in the abzu.” 
a-a {d}en-ki inim mu-un-du11-du11-ga-a abzu-a ba-da-an-zu| Father Enki in the abzu knew what had been said. 
ur-sag {d}nin-urta amar anzu{muszen}-de3 szu-ni bi2-in-ti| The Anzu-chick took the hero Ninurta by his hand 
ki {d}en-ki-ka3-sze3 abzu-sze3 im-ma-da-te| and drew near with him to Enki’s place, the abzu. 
{d}u4-ta-u18-lu amar anzu{muszen}-de3 abzu-sze3 ba-an-gi4| The Anzu-chick returned Uta-ulu to the abzu. 
en-e ur-sag-ra ba-szi-hul2| The lord was delighted with the hero, 
a-a {d}en-ki ur-sag {d}nin-urta-ra ba-szi-hul2| Father Enki was delighted with the hero Ninurta. 
en {d}nu-dim2-mud-e mi2 zi mu-un-i-i-de3| Lord Nudimmud honored him duly: 
ur-sag-e dingir szesz-zu-ne-a dingir na-me ur5-gin7 nu-mu-un-ak-e| “Hero, no god among your brother gods could have acted so. 
muszen {gesz}tukul kal-ga-zu bi2-dab5-ba-sze3| As for the bird which your mighty weapon captured, 
u4 me-da u4 ul-le2-sze3 gu2-bi giri3-zu ba-gub-be2-en| from now to eternity you will keep your foot placed on its neck. 
dingir gal-gal-e-ne a2 nam-ur-sag-ga2-zu me-tesz2 he2-i-i-ne| May the great gods give your heroic strength its due. 
a-a-zu {d}en-lil2-le nig2-du11-zu he2-ak| May your father Enlil do whatever you command. 
{d}nin-men-na-ke4 kin-se3-ga-zu na-an-dim2-e| May Ninmena not fashion your equal (?). 
za-e-gin7 ni2 na-ab-tuku dingir na-me igi-zu-sze3 szu si sa2 na-an-sa2-e| May no one be as revered as you and no god extend an upraised hand before you. 
iti-da esz3-e abzu-a igi-du8-a e2-zu sag he2-us2| Monthly may your house (?) regularly receive tributes in the shrine, in the abzu. 
an za3 gal-la mu-zu he2-pa3-de3| May An (?) proclaim your name in the seat of honor.” 
ur-sag nam-tar-ra-bi sza3-bi nu-hul2| The hero secretly was not happy with these promises. 
ki-gub-ba-ni a-ge6 i-im-ku10-ku10-ge i-sig7-sig7-ge| Where he stood, he darkened and yellowed like (?) a flood-storm (?). 
sza3-bi nig2 gal-gal i-im-bala-bala sza3-bi i3-kur2-kur2| He contemplated great deeds and inwardly he was rebellious. 
ur-sag {d}nin-urta igi-bi ki-szar2-ra ba-ni-in-gar| The hero Ninurta set his sights on the whole world. 
en gal {d}en-ki ki ni2-te-na-ke4 inim sza3-bi ba-x-zu| The great lord Enki intuitively grasped the substance of the plan. 
esz3-e abzu-a a-ge6 mud i-im-tuk4-tuk4-e| In the shrine, in the abzu he stirred up a dark flood-storm. 
sukkal {d}isimudx(PAB.NUN.ME.EZEN)-de3 e2-e giri3 mu-un-ru-gu2| By the house the minister Isimud opposed Ninurta. 
ur-sag {d}nin-urta e3-de3 nu-mu-un-sze-sze| The hero Ninurta refused to come out 
sukkal {d}isimudx(PAB.NUN.ME.EZEN)-de3-esz2 szu-ni ba-an-zi| and raised his hand against the minister Isimud. 
{d}en-ki-ke4 im abzu-a ba-al-gu7 ba-da-an-dim2| (Against Ninurta,) Enki fashioned a turtle from the clay of the abzu. 
ki sun5-na ka2 abzu-a ba-al-gu7 ba-da-an-gub| Against him he stationed the turtle at an opening, at the gate of the abzu. 
{d}en-ki-ke4 ki-lul-la-ke4 mu-un-na-ab-du11-du11| Enki talked to him near the place of the ambush 
ki-gub-ba ba-al-gi4-sze3 ba-da-an-tum3| and brought him to the place where the turtle was. 
ba-al-gu7 egir-ra-ni sa-bi ba-da-an-dab5| The turtle was able to grab Ninurta's tendon from behind. 
ur-sag {d}nin-urta giri3-bi ba-da-an-gi4| The hero Ninurta managed to turn back its feet. 
{d}en-ki nu-zu-gin7 a-na-am3 ne-e im-me| Enki, as if perplexed, said, “What is this?!” 
umbin-giri3-bi ki bi2-in-hur habrud hul ba-da-an-dun| He had the turtle scrape the ground with its claws, had it dig an evil pit. 
ur-sag {d}nin-urta sza3-bi ba-da-an-szub| The hero Ninurta fell into it with the turtle. 
ba-al-gu7 giri3 umbin-giri3-bi ba-an-sur-sur| The turtle kept on gnawing his feet with its claws (?). 
en gal {d}en-ki-ke4 gu3 mu-un-na-de2-e| The great lord Enki said to him: 
x-bil2-ga gal-gal di ge26-e bi2-ib2-ga2-ga2 ge26-e bi2-ib2-zi-de3| I cut down, I raise up. 
za-e ge26-ra a-gin7 igi-zu mu-gar-ra| You who set your sights on me like this— 
nam-kal-ga-zu me-sze3 ba-an-gen nam-ur-sag-zu me-a| Where has your strength fled? Where is your heroism? 
hur-sag gal-gal-e mu-ni-in-gul-gul e-ne-esz2 a-na-am3 mu-e11-de3| In the great mountains you caused destruction, but how will you get out now?” 
{d}nin-men-na-ke4 inim-bi ba-da-an-pa3| Ninmena learned of this situation. 
{u2}ug gu7-gu7-gu10-usz za-e a-ba-a mu-ra-ab-tum2| “My ug-plant-eater Enki, whom shall I send to you? 
dam-an-ki mu-bi nu-me-a u4-gu7-gu7-nu-de2-de2 mu-bi-im| That name is not Enki. That name is Ugugu-that-does-not-pour (?). 
nam-usz2 szu gar nu-tuku-a za-e a-ba-a mu-ra-ab-tum2| You who are death without mercy, whom shall I send to you?” 
u4 re-a nam ba-tar-ra-ba| In those remote days, when the fates were determined; 
mu he2-gal2 an u3-tu-da| in a year when An brought about abundance, 
ug3-e u2-szim-gin7 ki in-dar-ra-ba| and people broke through the earth like green plants -- 
en abzu lugal {d}en-ki-ke4| then the lord of the abzu, King Enki, 
{d}en-ki en nam tar-tar-re-de3| Enki, the lord who determines the fates, 
e2-a-ni ku3 {na4}za-gin3-na tesz2-bi ba-ni-in-du3| built up his temple entirely from silver and lapis lazuli. 
ku3 {na4}za-gin3-bi u4 kar2-kar2-a-ka| Its silver and lapis lazuli were the shining daylight. 
esz3-e abzu-a ul im-ma-ni-in-de6| Into the shrine of the abzu he brought joy. 
suh10 ku3 galam du11-ga abzu-ta e3-a| An artfully made bright crenellation rising out from the abzu 
en {d}nu-dim2-mud-ra mu-un-na-sug2-sug2-ge-esz| was erected for Lord Nudimmud. 
e2 ku3-ga i-ni-in-du3 {na4}za-gin3-na i-ni-in-gun3| He built the temple from precious metal, decorated it with lapis lazuli, 
gal-le-esz ku3-sig17-ga szu tag ba-ni-in-du11| and covered it abundantly with gold. 
eridu{ki}-ga e2 gu2-a bi2-in-du3| In Eridu, he built the house on the bank. 
szeg12-bi inim du11-du11 ad gi4-gi4| Its brickwork makes utterances and gives advice. 
gi-sal-la-bi gu4-gin7 mur im-sza4| Its eaves roar like a bull; 
e2 {d}en-ki-ke4 gu3 nun di-dam| the temple of Enki bellows. 
e2-e lugal-bi-ir ge6-a ar2 im-ma-ab-de6 du10-bi mu-un-ga2-ga2| During the night the temple praises its lord and offers its best for him. 
lugal {d}en-ki-ra sukkal {d}isimud-de3 mi2 du10-ge-esz im-me| Before Lord Enki, Isimud the minister praises the temple; 
e2-e im-ma-gen gu3 im-ma-de2-e| he goes to the temple and speaks to it. 
szeg12-e im-ma-gen gu3 im-ma-ab-szum2-mu| He goes to the brick building and addresses it: 
e2 ku3 {na4}za-gin3-na ki gar-ra| “Temple, built from precious metal and lapis lazuli; 
temen-bi abzu-a si-ga| whose foundation pegs are driven into the abzu; 
nun-e abzu-ta mi2 du11-ga| which has been cared for by the prince in the abzu! 
{i7}idigna {i7}buranun-na mah ni2 szu ti-a| Like the Tigris and the Euphrates, it is mighty and awe-inspiring (?). 
abzu {d}en-ki-ke4 ul-la bi2-in-tum2-mu| Joy has been brought into Enki's abzu. 
{gesz}sag-kul-zu gaba-szu-gar nu-tuku| Your lock has no rival. 
{gesz}si-gar-zu ur-mah ni2 gur3-ru| Your bolt is a fearsome lion. 
gesz-ur3-zu gu4 an-na suh10 ku3 galam du11-ga| Your roof beams are the bull of heaven, an artfully made bright headgear. 
{gi}kid-zu za-gin3-na gesz-ur3-sze3 gun3-a| Your reed-mats are like lapis lazuli, decorating the roof-beams. 
nir-gam-ma-zu gu4 si gur3-ru| Your vault is a wild bull raising its horns. 
ka2-zu ur-mah lu2 szu ti-a| Your door is a lion who seizes a man. 
kun4-zu ug lu2-ra e11-de3| Your stairway is a lion coming down on a man. 
abzu ki sikil me-te-gal2| Abzu, pure place which fulfils its purpose! 
e2-engur-ra lugal-zu giri3 im-ma-ri-in-gub| E-engura! Your lord has directed his steps towards you. 
{d}en-ki lugal abzu-ke4| Enki, lord of the abzu, 
temen-zu {na4}gug im-ma-da-an-sa2| has embellished your foundation pegs with cornelian. 
e2 {d}en-ki-ke4 lal3-har-ra ku3 kurum7 ak| The temple of Enki is provisioned with silver wax (?); 
gu4 lugal-bi-ir us2-a se3-ga| it is a bull obedient to its master, 
ni2-bi-sze3 mur sza4 tesz2-bi-sze3 ad gi4-gi4| roaring by itself and giving advice at the same time. 
e2-engur-ra {d}en-ki-ke4 gi dub-ba-an ku3 la2-am3| E-engura, which Enki has surrounded with a silver reed fence! 
sza3-zu-ta bara2 mah ki gar-ra| In your midst a lofty throne is erected, 
za3-du8-zu aszkud2 ku3 an-na| your door-jamb is the silver locking bar of heaven. 
abzu ki sikil ki nam tar-ra| Abzu, pure place, place where the fates are determined 
en gesztu2-ga lugal {d}en-ki| —the lord of wisdom, Lord Enki, 
{d}en-ki en nam tar-tar-re-de3| Enki, the lord deciding fates— 
{d}nu-dim2-mud en eridu{ki}-ga-ke4| Nudimmud, the lord of Eridu, 
sza3 szeg9-bar-ra lu2 igi nu-bar-re-dam| lets nobody look into its midst. 
abgal-zu siki bar-ra bi2-in-du8| Your abgal priests let their hair down their backs. 
eridu{ki} {d}en-ki-ke4 ki ag2-ga2-ni| Enki's beloved Eridu, 
e2-engur-ra sza3-bi he2-gal2 sug4-ga| E-engura whose inside is full of abundance! 
abzu zi kalam-ma ki ag2 {d}en-ki-ke4| Abzu, life of the Land, beloved of Enki! 
e2 za3-ga du3-a me galam-ma tum2-ma| Temple built on the edge, befitting the artful divine powers! 
eridu{ki} gissu-zu ab-sza3-ga la2-a| Eridu, your shadow extends over the midst of the sea! 
a-ab-ba zi-ga gaba-szu-gar nu-tuku| Eridu, your shadow extends over the midst of the sea! Rising sea without a rival; 
i7 mah ni2-gal2-la su kalam-ma zi-zi| mighty awe-inspiring river which terrifies the Land! 
e2-engur-ra uru2 mah ki us2-sa| E-engura, high citadel (?) standing firm on the earth! 
e2 da engur-ra pirig abzu sza3-ga| Temple at the edge of the engur, a lion in the midst of the abzu; 
e2 mah {d}en-ki-ke4 gesztu2 kalam-e szum2-mu| lofty temple of Enki, which bestows wisdom on the Land; 
akkil-zu i7 mah zi-ga-gin7| your cry, like that of a mighty rising river, 
lugal {d}en-ki-ra mu-un-na-tuku-am3| reaches (?) King Enki. 
e2 ku3-ga-ni-sze3 du10-bi mu-un-ga2-ga2| To his silver house its goodness he sets, 
{gesz}za3-mi2 {gesz}al-gar {gesz}balag al-gar-sur9-da| the lyre, the algar instrument, the balag drum 
{gesz}har-har {gesz}sa-bi2-tum {gesz}mi-ri2-tum e2 si-ga| the ḫarḫar, the sabitum, and the …… miritum instruments offer their best for his silver temple. 
sza3 ni2-ba-ka ad ha-ba-ni-ib-sza4| resounded by themselves. 
{gesz}al-gar ku3 {d}en-ki-ke4 ni2-ba mu-un-na-du12| The silver algar instrument of Enki played for him on his own 
nar 7(disz)-e ad he2-em-mi-ib-sza4| and seven tigi drums resounded. 
du11-ga {d}en-ki-ke4 szu nu-bala-e-de3| What Enki says is irrefutable; 
sukkal {d}isimud-de3 szeg12-e gu3 ba-an-szum2| This is what Isimud spoke to the brick building; 
e2-engur-ra-ke4 szir3 du10-ge-esz im-me| he praised the E-engura with sweet songs 
mu-un-du3-a-ba mu-un-du3-a-ba| As it has been built, as it has been built; 
eridu{ki} {d}en-ki-ke4 im-ma-an-il2-la-ba| as Enki has raised Eridu up, 
hur-sag galam kad5-dam a-e ba-dirig| it is an artfully built mountain which floats on the water. 
za3-ga-a-ni gesz-gi-a ba-an-KU| His shrine (?) spreads (?) out into the reedbeds; 
{gesz}kiri6 sig7-ga gurun il2-la-a-ba| In its green orchards laden with fruit 
muszen-e hasz4-bi mu-un-ga2-ga2| birds brood. 
suhur{ku6}-e u2-lal3-e e-ne mu-un-e| The suhur carp play among the honey-herbs, 
esztub{ku6}-e gi-zi di4-di4-la2 kun mu-un-na-su3-e| and the esztub carp dart among the small gizi reeds. 
{d}en-ki zi-ga-na ku6 i-zi-esz2 na-zi| When Enki rises, the fish rise before him like waves. 
abzu-e u6 am3-ma-gub| He has the abzu stand as a marvel, 
engur-ra hul2-la mu-ni-ib-de6| as he brings joy into the engur. 
a-ab-ba-gin7 ni2 mu-un-da-gal2| Like the sea, he is awe-inspiring; 
i7 mah-gin7 su zi mu-un-da-ri| like a mighty river, he instils fear. 
{i7}buranun-na u18-lu sumur mu-un-da-an-zi| The Euphrates rises before him as it does before the fierce south wind. 
{gesz}gi-musz-a-ni {d}nirah-a-ni| His punting pole is Nirah 
{gesz}gisal-a-ni gi tur-tur-a-ni| his oars are the small reeds. 
{d}en-ki u5-a-ni mu he2-gal2 sug4-ga| When Enki embarks, the year will be full of abundance. 
{gesz}ma2 ni2-bi nam-du8 esz2 ni2-bi nam-dab5| The ship departs of its own accord, with tow rope held (?) by itself. 
e2 eridu{ki}-ga-ke4 im-ma-kar-ra| As he leaves the temple of Eridu, 
i7-de3 lugal-bi-ir ad im-mi-ib-gi4-gi4| the river gurgles (?) to its lord: 
gu3-bi gu3 amar-ra gu3 ab2 du10-ga-ke4| its sound is a calf's mooing, the mooing of a good cow. 
{d}en-ki-ke4 gu4 im-ma-ab-gaz-e udu im-ma-ab-szar2-re| Enki had oxen slaughtered, and had sheep offered there lavishly. 
{kusz}a2-la2 nu-gal2-la ki-bi-sze3 sa2 im-du11| Where there were no ala drums, he installed some in their places; 
ub3 zabar nu-gal2-la ki-bi-sze3 im-mi-in-e3| where there were no bronze ub drums, he despatched some to their places. 
nibru{ki}-sze3 giri3-ni dili mu-un-gub| He directed his steps on his own to Nibru 
gi-gun4-na esz3-e nibru{ki}-a im-ma-da-an-ku4-ku4| and entered the temple terrace, the shrine of Nibru. 
{d}en-ki-ke4 kasz-kasz-e ba-te kurun2-kurun2-e ba-te| Enki reached for (?) the beer, he reached for (?) the liquor. 
kurun2 gal zabar-ra ba-ni-in-de2| He had liquor poured into big bronze containers, 
uluszin dili-am3 ba-ni-in-sur| and had emmer-wheat beer pressed out (?).

ka-bi lal3 zu2-lum-ma nig2 er9 ba-ni-in-ak| By adding date-syrup to its taste (?), he made it strong. 
{d}en-ki-ke4 esz3-e nibru{ki}-am3| In the shrine of Nibru, Enki 
a-a-ni {d}en-lil2-ra ninda mu-un-gu7-e| provided a meal for Enlil, his father.

kasz ba-du11 kurun2 ba-du10-ga-ta| After beer and liquor had been libated and enjoyed, 
{d}en-lil2 nibru{ki}-a hul2-la mu-ni-ib-de6| Enlil was made happy in Nibru.

ki du10-ga-am3 e2 im-ma-an-du3| He has built it in a pleasant place,

LAK397 du11-ga| Incantation
{d}nin-girimx(SZIM)-ma| of Ningirim,
nin szuruppak iri{ki} du10-ga 7(disz)-a| lady of sweet city Šuruppak, of the 7(?).
mu-gu10 mu| My lines are the lines
{d}asal-lu2-hi| of Asalluḫi,
dumu {d}en-ki-ka| son of Enki,
abzu nu-mu-da-bur2-re| in the Abzu, it cannot be undone(?).
enerux(AN.U){+ex(DAG)-nu-ru}| enuru:
musz-e kur-musz-ta KA nam-gi4| The snake from snake mountain indeed called.
me-TAR an ki-ka| The lizard of heaven and of earth
eme ba-ni-ak| licked.
dumu me-TAR an ki 7(disz)-a-ne-ne| The sons of the lizard, heaven and earth, are 7.
pu2 lil2-am3 i3-du3| The well like wind it made.
a lil2-am3 i3-in-de2| Water like wind he poured out.
gugx(A.ZI.ZI.A) lil2-am3 za3-bi ib2-dab6| Grass like wind its right encircled.
gugx(A.ZI.ZI.A)-bi ga-bu-ni| Its grass, his left
mu-ub-ze2| it tore out.

nam-mu-da-bur2-re| may they not be undone.

igi-za he2-en-sa6| (so that) in your eyes he indeed pleased.

dug nig2-dur2-buru3-e gu3 nun di-dam| You place the fermenting vat, which makes a pleasant sound,

na-ra-am-{d}suen| Narām-Sîn, 
sipa nig2-nam szar2-ra unu{ki}-ga| the shepherd who has increased everything in Uruk, 
lugal sza3 iri{ki}-na du10-du10| the king who always makes pleasant the heart of his city,

u4 an {d}inanna-ke4| When An and Inanna 
nam-lugal unu{ki}-ga ma-an-szum2-mu-usz-a| had given me the kingship of Uruk, 
u4-ba {gesz}tukul kal-ga-ga2-ta| then, with my mighty weapon

u4-ba bala nam-lugal-la-ga2| At that time, during the term of my kingship,

e2 an-gen7{en} usz8 ki gar-ra| The house like heaven, on a foundation placed; 
e2 dub-szen-gen7 gada mu-un-dul| The house like a tablet box, with a linen cloth one covered; 
e2 uz-gen7{en} ki-gal-la gub-ba| The house like a duck, on a pedestal stood; 
igi nu-gal2 ba-an-ku4| Blind ones entered it; 
igi i3-gal2 ba-an-e3| Ones that see came out; 
e2-dub-ba-am3| (Solution): it is the Edubba.

az-e iti asz3-kam ti-na nu-bala-e| The bear does not turn on its side (lit. rib(cage)) for six months 
AN u3-sa2 nu-mu-un-szum2-ma| “God/An has not given sleep 
ga2-gin7-nam he2-si-ig| So that like me, you(?) would be weak(?)” 
i-bi-lu a-da-lu| The riddle goes(?): 
tur-ra-me-en tur dumu sar-ra-me-en| (when) I am a youngster, I am the son of a garden. 
bulug3-me-en su dingir-ra-me-en| (when) I am a grown-up, I am the body of a god. 
szu-gi4-me-en a-zu kalam-me-en| (when) I am an elder, I am the physician of a land. 
ki-bur2-bi gada-am3| Solution: linen. 
nig2-tuku| Wealth 
nig2-al-di| to be demanded 
nig2-gig| is forbidden 
dingir-ra-kam| by the gods. 
nig2-tuku| Wealth 
nig2-al-di| to be demanded 
nig2-gig| is forbidden 
dingir-ra-kam| by the gods. 
nig2-tuku nig2-al-di| Wealth to be demanded 
nig2-gig dingir-ra-kam| is forbidden by the gods. 
du-du nam-ukur3-ra| By going about, poverty
a2 bi2-ib-gar| can be defeated.
lu2 lul-la abul in-ku4-ku4| When a liar enters the city gate
igi-be2 szu-si-am3| at his face is a finger,
egir-be2 szu-si-am3| behind his back is a finger.
lu2 dingir-ra-a-ni| A man, who his god 
nu-mu-un-kal-la| he does not honor, 
edin-na mu-un-szub| onto the plain fell. 
ad6-bi nu-ga2-ga2| His corpse one does not lay (to rest), 
ibila-a-ni alal-am3| his heir is the libation pipe, 
gidim-ma-a-ni a nu-na8| his ghost does not drink water. 
e2 gal2 tak4-a| An open house.
e2 sag gi4-a| A locked house.
igi bi2-in-du| He saw it,
u3 en-na sag ba-an-gi4| but even then it was closed.
ki-bur2-bi u2-hub2| Its answer: A deaf person.
{d}i-bi2-{d}suen| Ibbi-Suen, 
lugal kal-ga| strong king, 
lugal uri5{ki}-ma| king of Ur, 
lugal an-ub-da limmu2-ba| king of the four corners: 
dub-sar| scribe, 
ARAD2-zu| is your servant.

ugula azu nu-esz3 {d}5(u)-la2| foreman of the diviners, nešakku-official of Enlil, 
ARAD2 {d}marduk-sza-pi2-ik-numun| servant of Marduk-šāpik-zēri, 
lugal babila2{ki}-ke4| king of Babylon. 
inim-{d}szara2-ka| Inim-Šara 
ensi2-ke4| did the governor 
gu4-apin 1(disz)-am3| with 1 plough-ox, 
szu-ni ba-an-szum2| entrust, 
ga2-la bi2-in-dag| (but) he neglected it. 
mu 3(disz)-am3| For 3 years 
da-bi la-ba-ti| did he its side not approach; 
ensi2-ke4| the governor 
in-sag3| struck him. 
a-ra2 2(disz)-kam gu4-e| That a 2nd time an ox 
ga2-la nu-ub-dag-a| he will not neglect 
mu lugal-bi in-pa3| (did Inim-Šara) by the royal name swear; 
mu ma2 dara3 {d}en-ki-ka ba-ab-du8| year: “The Ibex barge of Enki was caulked.” 
inim-{d}szara2| Inim-Šara, 
dub-sar| scribe, 
dumu ur-{gesz}gigir| son of Ur-gigir. 
ab-ba-ge-na-ar| For Abbagena 
a-sza3 i3-szum2 erin2-e tab-ba-de3| the Išum field by the labor troop is to be smoothed out: 
ensi2-ke4 a2 in-da-na-an-ag2| the governor gave these instructions to him. 
erin2-e GAN2-dusu tab-ba-e-de3 szu bi2-ib2-dag| (Nevertheless,) the labor troop to smooth out the corvée field neglected. 
szuku-bi ba-ab-tab| They (instead) their (own) subsistence fields smoothed out. 
i7 i3-szum2-ma i3-ib2-de6-a| The canal that on the Išum (field) brings (water),  
u4 1(u) 4(disz)-am3 erin2-e a-sza3-bi-sze3 ba-ab-gid2| during 14 days the labor troop towards their fields diverted. 
ensi2-sze3 u3 da-da-ga-asz| (Abbagena) to the governor (Ayakalla) and Dadaga (to inform them) 
lu2 nu-mu-un-szi-in-gi4| sent nobody.  
a-sza3-bi a la-ba-ab-si| (Consequently,) their (Ayakalla and Dadaga’s) field with water was not filled. 
engar sza3-gu4-ka-ni| His (Abbagena’s) cultivators (and) ox-drivers 
sze gurx(SZE.KIN)-gurx(SZE.KIN)-de3 ba-an-na-szum2| to harvest the barley were given to him (Abbagena).  
da-da-ga gurum2-sze3 i3-gen| Dadaga for an inspection went there, 
erin2-bi 3(disz)-a diri-ga nu-gub-ba-am3| (and found out that) from the labor troop no more than 3 were in service. 
1(disz) ab-ba-ge-na| One Abbagena, 
1(disz) ur-{d}szul-pa-e3| one Ur-Šulpa’e (and) 
1(disz) a-a-kal-la| and one Ayakalla: 
sza3-bi 1(disz)-am3 sag-bi-sze3 nu-gub-ba-am3| not 1 of them as the person in charge was in service.  
inim ab-ba-ge-na-ka| In the statement of Abbagena, 
igi ensi2-ka-sze3 ba-an-ge-en6| before the governor it was confirmed. 
sza3 a-sza3 {gesz}ma-nu-ka| At the poplar field. 
iti nesag| Month “First fruits,” 
mu us2-sa ma2 {d}en-ki ba-ab-du8| year following: “The barge of Enki was caulked.” 
3(disz) masz2 e2-a-szar sipa da-da gala-ka| 3 goats of Ea-šar, shepherd of Dada, the lamenter, 
u2-gu ba-an-de2-am3| went lost. 
e2-a-szar-e lugal-{gesz}gigir-re ba-an-la-ah bi2-du11| Ea-šar “Lugal-gigire drove them off” declared. 
e2-a-szar egir-ba im-ma-an-gur| Ea-šar afterwards returned? (to the matter). 
1(disz) lu2-dingir-ra| One Lu-dingira 
u3 ur-{d}utu-ke4| and Ur-Utu 
3(disz) masz2 igi lugal-{gesz}gigir-re-ka gub-be2 igi bi2-in-du8-am3| “(Ea-šar) the 3 goats before Lugal-gigire standing saw; 
ARAD2 masz2 e-me-ta mu-la-ah in-na-an-esz| the servant (Lugal-gigire)  the goats from our dike drove” declared for him (Ea-šar). 
igi e2-gal-e-si-sze3| (Statements) before Egalesi, 
igi nin-dub-sar-sze3| before Nin-dubsar. 
masz2 e2 a-kal-la dumu {d}utu-saga-ka ba-an-su-un| “The goats into the house of Akalla, son of Utu-saga he (Lugal-gigire) brought” 
igi lu2-{d}inanna-ka-sze3| before Lu-Inanna, 
e2 a-kal-la-ke4 1(gesz2) ninda-am3 nu-ti-a gaba-ri-na mu-gub| “To the house of Akalla, within 60 ninda did (Ea-šar) not approach, he remained on his opposite side.” 
1(disz) a-li2 maszkim| One Ali, the commissioner,  
1(disz) ur-{d}suen nar| One Ur-Suen, the cantor,  
1(disz) tir-gu maszkim| One Tirgu, the commissioner, 
igi-ne-ne-sze3| before them.   
1(u) la2 1(disz) masz2 ziz2-da-asz| “10 less 1 goats as compensation  
ga-ra-ak in-na-du11| for you I will deliver” said; 
lugal-szu-nir-re a-ra2 2(disz)-kam sizkur2-bi bi2-du11| Lugal-šunire for the 2nd time(?) did the oral? rites. 
ka-ga ba-an-ge-en6| It was orally confirmed. 
igi lu2-dingir-ra dumu lugal-ba-ra-ab-e3-sze3| Before Lu-dingira, son of Lugal-barabe;

iti dal| month “Flight,” 
mu en eridu{ki} ba-hun| year: “The lord of Eridu was installed.” 
u4 n-am3 bi2-da ki udu-ka nu-tusz-am3| It was (the case) that during n days Bida at the place of the sheep did not stay. 
a-ra2 1(disz)-kam| For the 1st time. 
lugal-e2-mah-e en3-bi tar-re-dam| Lugal-emaḫe has to investigate this. 
sza3-ba u4 8(disz)-am3| That it was for 8 of those days (that he did not stay there) 
inim bi2-da-ka ba-an-ge-en8| in the statement of Bida it was confirmed. 
u4 1(disz)-am3 udu u2 nu-gu7-a ba-ge-en8| That it was for 1 day that the sheep with grass were not fed it was confirmed. 
igi kas4-sze3| Before Kas (as witness). 
u4 1(u) 5(disz)-am3 ki udu-ka asz nu-tusz-am3| (For the second time:) It was (the case) that during 15 days (Bida) at the place of the sheep did not stay. 
a-kal-la u3 lugal-e2-mah-e en3-bi tar-re-dam| Akalla and Lugal-emaḫe have to investigate this. 
sza3-ba u4 6(disz)-am3| That it was for 6 of those days (that he did not stay there) 
inim bi2-da-ka ba-an-ge-en8| in the statement of Bida it was confirmed, 
ka-i7-da-ka u4 1(disz)-am3 sze nu-gu7-a| That at Ka’ida for 1 day (the sheep) with barley were not fed 
lu2-kal-la in-ge-en8| Lukalla confirmed. 
inim bi2-da-ka ba-an-ge-en8| In the statement of Bida it was confirmed. 
n 2(disz) 1/2(disz) sila3 sze udu-a de6-a| (Concerning) n+2 1/2 liters of barley that for the sheep were brought, 
bi2-da nu-ub-dab5 bi2-in-du11| Bida “It was not taken!” declared. 
a-ra2 dab5-ba-asz in-ge-en8| Ara that (the barley) was taken has confirmed. 
nibru{ki}-a u4 2(disz)-am3| That at Nippur during 2 days 
udu u2 nu-gu7-a-asz a nu-nag-asz| the sheep were with grass not fed and water to drink were not given 
ur-{d}szul-pa-e3-ke4 in-ge-en8| Ur-Šulpa’e has confirmed. 
gurusz kikken2-da gub-ba kasz ma2-da ba-da-an-tusz| That with the male laborers who at the mill are serving (and) with the beer for the boats (Bida) was on duty 
kas4 in-ge-en8| Kas has confirmed. 
u3 nig2-du10-ga en3-bi tar-re-dam| and Niĝduga have to investigate this.

inim nu-um-ga2-ga2-a| wouldn't bring a claim,

edin-na masz2-ansze tur-re-de3 nig2-zi-gal2 til-le-de3| In order to diminish the herd, in order to finish the wild animals

ambar-re szu ki-in-dar di-de3 numun nu-tuku-tuku-de3| So that in the marshes (wet land) is turned into cracked land, so that they do not acquire seeds

uri2{ki} am gal u3-na gub-ba ni2-bi-ta nir-gal2| Urim, the great wild bull standing wildly, noble in and of itself 
iri numun nam-en nam-lugal-la ki sikil-la du3-a| The city where the seed of the en-ship and kingship is planted in a pure place 
gu4-gin7 saman ul4-la-bi szub-bu-de3 gu2 ki-sze3 la2-e-de3| In order to fell it quickly with a tethering rope like a bull, in order to bring its neck to the ground 
an {d}en-lil2 {d}en-ki {d}nin-hur-sag-ga2-ke4 nam-bi ba-an-tar-re-esz| An, Enlil, Enki and Ninhursag decreed its fate 
{d}nin-tur5-re ama5 kalam-ma-ke4 {gesz}ig-szu-ur2 im-mi-in-gub| Nintur set (open?) the bolt (in the street) at the women's quarters of the land 
{d}en-ki-ke4 {i7}idigna {i7}buranun-na a im-ma-da-an-kesz2| Enki bound up the water away from the Tigris and Euphrates 
{d}utu nig2-si-sa2 inim gin6-na ka-ta ba-da-an-kar| Utu took away justice and the true word from the mouth (of anyone that would speak it) 
{d}inanna-ke4 me3 szen-szen-na ki-bala-e ba-an-szum2| Inanna gave the battle and combat (to the enemy) in the rebel land 
{d}nin-gir2-su-ke4 ki-en-gi ga-gin7 ur-e ba-ni-in-de2| Ningirsu poured out Sumer like milk among the dogs 
kalam-ma ga-ba-ra-hum im-ma-an-szub nig2 lu2 nu-zu-a| Rebellion fell upon the land, it was something no one knew 
nig2 igi nu-gal2-la inim nu-gal2-la nig2 szu nu-te-ge26-dam| It was something unseen (before), and (for which) there was no word, something not to be accepted(?) 
kur-kur-re e2 ni2-ta-bi-a szu suh3-a ba-ab-du11| The lands were confused in their very own temples(!?) 
iri{ki}-ba dingir iri{ki}-bi-e-ne bar-ta ba-sugx(DU)-ge-esz| In the city, the gods of that city stood outside 
nam-lu2-lux(URU) e2 ni2-te-bi-a zi gig mu-un-pa-an-pa-an| Humanity breathed painfully in their very own homes(?) 
u4-de3 szu-ne-ne ba-du3-du3 u4 nu-mu-un-szi-ib2-gur-re| The storm bound their hands, the storm will not return them 
u4 gi4-a mu-un-na-tuku-am3 u4 dur2-bi-sze3 nu-um-DU| The storm acquired blocking(?) for them(?), it did not go(?) towards their (sturdy) bottom(?)

nam-ti he2-su3-u4-de3| If a man engenders the life of truth, he will prolong (his own) lifetime 
a-da-lam ni2 nu-te-ga2-asz| Now, fearless one 
ur5-gin7 nam-ma-ni-ib-gi4-gi4-in| Do not answer thusly 
szesz gal-gu10 en3 tar-ra-na-ma nam-sun7-na mu zu-bi| When(?) my “big brother” makes an inquiry (and says?), (it is?) a reputation(?) of arrogance 
si-ba lu2-tu15 en-na-bi-sze3-am3 nu-sun7-ne-en| Be silent, idiot, how long until you are not haughty? 
nig2-sig8 4(disz)-gin7 erin2 tesz2-a nu-ub-si-ge| Like a comb with only 4 teeth(!?) you(?) do not bring the workforce(?) together 
gi4-me-a-asz-zu is-hab2-ba-am3 za-e ku3-zu-me-en| Your colleagues (say) “he is a rogue, but you are wise” 
inim sikil-du3-a-bi ba-ra-an-du11| He should not have spoken insulting words to you

nam-tag-ga-ni ib-il2| So that his guilt is imposed (upon him)

al-zil2-zil2-le du14 ba-e-ak-ze2-en| It is good that you (pl.) quarrel

igi ugula-sze3 ba-an-gar-ra| Submitted before the overseer

e2-a inim nu-um-ga2-ga2-a| will not make a claim about the house,
mu lugal-bi in-pa3| he has sworn by the name of the king.
igi inim-{d}inanna dumu i-ti-i3-li2| Before Inim-nanna, son of Iti-ili;
igi {d}nanna-ma-an-szum2 dumu u4-du10-mu| before Nanna-manšum, son of Udumu;
igi e-te-el-pi4-{d}suen dumu ARAD2-e2-gu-la| before Etel-pī-sîn, son of Warad-egula;
igi ur-{d}szul-pa-e3 dumu lu2-{d}mar-tu| before Ur-šulpae, son of Lu-martu;
igi ARAD2-{d}en-lil2-la2 dumu ARAD2-e2-gu-la dub-sar| before Warad-enlila, son of Warad-egula, the scribe.
iti kin-{d}inanna| The month of Elūnum,
mu {d}en-lil2-ba-ni lugal-e| the year "Enlil-bani (is) king".
lu2-{d}en-lil2-la2| Lu-enlila
dumu ga-ra-nu-um|  son of Garanum
4(iku) GAN2 a-sza3 gug4-sze| A stubble field of 4 iku
sza3 a-sza3 {d}nin-unug| in the field of the god Nin-unug
us2-a-du a-gu-u2-a| adiacent to Agūa,
a-sza3 ip-qa2-tum dumu ur-du6-ku3-ga| the field of Ipqatum son of Ur-dukugga,
ki ip-qa2-tum dumu ur-du6-ku3-ga-ta| from Ipqatum, son of Ur-dukugga,
{disz}{d}da-mu-i-din-nam-ke4| Damu-i(d)dinam
nam-apin-la2-sze3| in tenancy
igi-3(disz)-gal2-sze3| for one-third (of the crop)
a2 mu-u2-a-sze3| as yearly rent
ib2-ta-an-e3| has rented.
igi dingir-ma-an-szum2| Before Dingir-manšum,
igi i-na-e2-kur-ra-bi| before Ina-ekurabi,
igi lu2-{d}nanna dub-sar| before Lu-nanna the scribe,
igi {d}en-lil2-gal-zu| before Enlil-galzu.
iti sig4-a| The month of Simānum
mu sa-am-su-i-lu-na lugal du11-ga an {d}en-lil2-bi-da bad3 uri2{ki} u3 unu{ki}-ga mu-un-gul-la| (of) the year (in which) king Samsu-iluna by the order of Anu and Enlil the wall of Ur and Uruk destroyed. 
{disz}ip-qu2-sza dumu dingir-ku3-sza| Ipquša, son of Ankuša,
{disz}e2-a-ta-a-a-ar dumu abzu-he2-gal2| Ea-tayar, son of Abzu-ḫegal,
nam-ibila-ni-sze3 ba-an-da-ri| has adopted as his heir.
u4 nam-ibila-ni-sze3 ba-an-da-ri-a| At the time when he adopted him as his heir,
4(asz) sze gur ur5-ra ip-qu2-sza ad-da-ni| Ipquša 4 kor of interest grain
{disz}e2-a-ta-a-a-ar in-su| has returned to Ea-tayar.
gibil-bi-sze3-am3 ip-qu2-sza ad-da ti-la-ke4| Recently, Ipquša, the living father,
{disz}e2-a-tu-ra-am dumu nita3-dam-ni| to Ea-turam, the son by his wife,
ha-la in-ne-en-ba| has distributed the inheritance.
1(u) 5(disz) gin2 e2 du3-a da e2 ip-qu2-e2-a dumu dingir-ku3-ta| A built-up house plot of 15 shekels, adjoining the house of Ipqu-ea son of Ankuta;

ha-la-ba e2-a-tu-ra-am| is the (inheritance) portion of Ea-turam.
1(u) 5(disz) gin2 e2 du3-a da e2 e2-a-tu-ra-am szesz-a-ni| A built-up house plot of 15 shekels, adjoining the house of Ea-turam his brother;

ha-la-ba e2-a-ta-a-a-ar szesz-a-ni| is the (inheritance) portion of Ea-tayar, his brother.

a2 mu-u8-a-sze3| annually;

a2 mu-u8-a-sze3| annually

{disz}ip-qu2-sza ad-da-ne-ne-ra| to Ipquša their father
in-na-ab-kal-la-ge-ne| will deliver promptly.
ibila lu2 nu-mu-na-ab-kal-la-ge| The heir who does not deliver it promptly,
nam-ibila-ni-ta ba-ra-e11-de3| forfeits his status as heir.
sze-ga-ne-ne-ta mu lugal-bi in-pa3-de3-esz| In mutual agreement, by the name of the king, they have sworn.

iti sze-sag11-ku5| The month of Addarum
mu i7 sa-am-su-i-lu-na he2-gal2-la2 mu-un-ba-al-la2| The year (in which Samsu-iluna the king) dug the canal “Samsu-iluna is abundance”.
1(disz) 1/2(disz) gin2 1(u) 8(disz) sze ku3-babbar| 1 1/2 shekels and 18 grains (= 288 grains) of silver,

u3 silim-ma-ni-sze3| and in good health

bi2-ib-du10-ge| will be satisfied.

e2 e2-gen7 lu2 lu2-u3| A house for a house, one to the other
in-szi-in(NI)-gar| has given.
mu e2 e2-e sa2 nu-ub-du11-ga-asz| Because one house doesn't reach the other (in value),
2/3(disz) gin2 ku3-babbar| (with) two third of a shekel of silver
{disz}da-mi-iq-tum-ke4| Damiqtum
be-le-su2-nu-ra in-na-an-bur2| has compensated Bēle(s)sunu.
u4 kur2-sze3 lu2 lu2-u3| (That) in future one against the other
inim nu-um-ga2-ga2| shall not make a complaint,
mu lugal-bi in-pa3-de3-esz| they have sworn by the name of the king.

e2 hu-mu-ru-um dumu ta-ri-bu-um| the house is of Ḫumurrum son of Tarībum;
1/3(disz) sar e2 du3-a| one built house plot of 1/3 SAR
da e2 hu-mu-ru-um| adjoining the house of Ḫumurrum,
e2 ib-bi-{d}utu dumu lu2-ur-sag-e-ne| the house is of Ibbi-šamaš son of Ku-ursaggene;
e2 e2-e-gen7-nam| one house is like the other house,
lu2 lu2-u3-ra in-szi-in-gar| one man to the other man has given.
u4 kur2-sze3 lu2 lu2-u3-ra| That in future one against the other
inim nu-ga2-ga2-a| wouldn't bring a claim
mu lugal-la tesz2-bi in-pa3-de3-esz| they have sworn together by the name of the king.
igi {d}da-gan-ma-an-szum2 dumu {d}en-lil2-lu2-ti| Before Dagan-manšum, son of Enlil-luti;
igi ri-ba-tum dumu ku3-{d}inanna| before Ribatum, son of Ku-inanna;
igi im-gur-{d}utu dumu la-a-lum| before Imgur-šamaš, son of Lālûm;
igi i-di-szum bur-gul| before Idišum, stone-cutter;
igi {d}nin-urta-ga-mil dub-sar| before Ninurta-gāmil, the scribe.
iti kin-{d}inanna| The month of Elūnum,
mu sa-am-su-i-lu-na lugal {d}utu {d}marduk-e-ne-bi-da-ra| the year in which Samsu-iluna the king, for Šamaš and Marduk (brought into Ebabbar in front of Šamaš and into Esagila in front of Marduk, images praying).

dumu ta-ri-bu-um| son of Tarībum

sib2-ta mu nam-szesz-gal| is the additional share for the status of elder brother.

mu lugal-bi in-pa3-de3-esz| they have sworn by the name of the king.

igi lugal-me-lam2-husz nar-gal| before lugal-melamḫuš, chief musician;
igi inim-{d}nin-urta nar-gal| before Inim-ninurta, chief musician;
igi dingir-nig2-ba-lu2-ti u3 i-din-{d}na-na-a-a i3-du8-me| before Diĝir-niĝ-baluti and I(d)din-na(n)nāya, doorkeepers;
igi husz-szu-tum dumu er3-ra-ga-mil| before Ḫuššutum, son of Erra-gāmil;
igi la-ma-sum2 dumu tum-ma-a-a| before Lama(s)sum, son of Tummaya;
igi {d}suen-e-ri-ba-am maszkim lukur-e-ne| before Sîn-erībam, inspector of the Nadītu’s;
igi i3-li2-ip-pa-al-sa3 tab-ba-ni| before Ilī-ippalsa(m), his colleague;
igi {d}en-lil2-gal-zu dumu ip-qu2-sza| before Enlil-galzu, son of Ipquša;
igi a-pil-{d}kab-ta dumu ku-bu-tum| before Apil-kabta, son of Kubtum;
igi {d}suen-ma-gir ku3-dim2| before Sîn-magir, silversmith;
igi i3-li2-ma dub-sar| before Ilī-ma, the scribe;
igi i3-li2-tu-ra-am bur-gul| before Ilī-turra, stone cutter.
iti szu-numun-a mu sa-am-su-i-lu-na lugal ama-ar-gi4 ki-en-gi ki-uri mi-ni-gar-ra| The month of Dumuzi, the year in which Samsu-iluna the king established the freedom of Sumer and Akkad.

a-li2-a-bi| Ali-abī

geme2 {d}iszkur| servant of Adad
