a-zu-gal| chief doctor
{disz}{d}nin-szubur-ta-a-a-ar-ke4| Ninšubur-tayar
{disz}pa-ti-ia-ra| Patiya
nam-dumu-ni-sze3 ba-da-an-ri-ke4| as his son has adopted;
e2 a-sza3 {gesz}kiri6 a-na-me-a-bi| the house, the field (and) the orchard, all of it,
{disz}{d}nin-szubur-ta-a-a-ar| Ninšubur-tayar
{disz}pa-ti-ia dumu-ni-ra| to Patiya his son
in-na-szum2 tukum-bi| has given. If
{disz}pa-ti-ia a-na {d}nin-szubur-ta-a-a-ar| Patiya to Ninšubur-tayar
ad-da-na-ta ad-da-mu nu-me-en| his father: "My father you aren't"
ba-na-an-du11 1/3(disz) ma-na ku3-babbar| says, 1/3 of mina of silver
i3-la2-e u3 tukum-bi| he will pay; and if
{d}nin-szubur-ta-a-a-ar| Ninšubur-tayar
{disz}pa-ti-ia dumu-ni-ra| to Patiya his son
dumu-mu nu-me-en ba-na-an-du11| says: "My son you aren't"
n ma-na ku3-babbar i3-la2-e| n minas of silver will pay (and)
ba-na-an-e11| he will forfeit.
{disz}pa-ti-ia a-na {d}nin-szubur-ta-a-a-ar| Patiya to Ninšubur-tayar
iti-da gar-ra mu-am3 1(asz) 1(barig) sze gur| every year a monthly supply of 1 kor (and) 1 pānu of barley,
n ma-na siki 6(disz) sila3 i3-gesz| n minas of wool and 6 qa of oil
in-na-ab-kal-ge| will provide.
igi a-pil-{d}utu dumu a-gu-u2-a| Before Apil-šamaš, son of Agū'a;
igi {d}nin-urta-ga-mil dumu dingir-szu-mu-ba-li2-it,| before Ninurta-gamil, son of Ilšu-muba(l)liṭ;
igi di-ku5-{d}iszkur bur-gul| before Diku-adad, stone-cutter;
igi i3-li2-u3-{d}utu dub-sar| before Ilī-u-šamaš, the scribe.
iti gu4-si-su2 u4 1(disz)-kam| The month of Ayyarum, the day 1 (of)
mu sa-am-su2-i-lu-na lugal-e gan2 ki-sur-ra{ki} sa-bu-um ka-si-il-la2 bi2-in-ku4| the year (in which) Samsu-iluna the king the region of Kisurra (and) Sabum brought to praise.
{d}nin-szubur-ta-a-a-ar| Ninšubur-tayar
u4 en gal ur-sag {d}nergal| When the great lord, hero Nergal,  
iri{ki}-ni masz-kan2-szabra{ki}| having made his city Maškan-šapir 
sza3 gu2-be2 gi4-a-na| in his heart 'overflowing its banks' 
zi-de3-esz mu-un-e3-a| truly appear,  
bad3-bi ki sikil-la| and its city wall on a pure place  
gal-bi du3-a-da| having built up greatly,  
ki-tusz-bi dagal-la-da| and about its extended residences 
inim nu-kam3-me-da-na| with his words that cannot be changed  
mah bi2-in-du11-ga-a| having spoken loftily,  
u4-ba {d}suen-i-din-na-am| then Sîn-iddinam,  
nita kal-ga| the mighty man, 
u2-a uri2{ki}-ma| the provider of Ur, 
lugal larsa{ki}-ma| the king of Larsa, 
lugal ki-en-gi ki-uri-ke4| and king of Sumer and Akkad, 
lu2 e2-babbar e2 {d}utu-ke4| the man by whom the Ebabbar, the temple of Utu, 
mu-un-du3-a| had been built, 
{i7}idigna i7 dagal-la| who the Tigris, the wide river, 
mu-un-ba-al-la-a| had excavated, 
nidba mah| who the exalted food offerings 
{d}a-nun-na-ke4-ne| of the Anuna gods 
szu gal bi2-in-du7-a-me-en| did greatly perfect – namely I, 
a-ra2 gal-gal| because all the great ways 
ki-be2 mu-da-kin-kin-ga2-asz| I searched out for that place 
erin2 dagal-la mu-tum3-tum3-bi| and because about bringing together vast troops 
zi-de3-esz mu-zu-a-mu-sze3| I truly was knowledgable, 
nam-bi-sze3 {d}nergal| because of this Nergal,  
dumu {d}en-lil2-la2-ke4| the son of Enlil, 
{gesz}al {gesz}dusu ga2-ra ha-ma-szum2-szum2| gave me mattocks and earth baskets
nam-bi ha-ma-tar-tar| and determines this fate for me. 
iri{ki}-ni masz-kan2-szabra{ki}| For his city Maškan-šapir,
ki ku3-ga bad3-bi sag il2| lifting the top of its wall on a sacred place, 
sza3 hul2-la-ni-ta| with his joyful heart 
a2-ag2-ba ha-ma-ni-in-til| he finished for me its instructions. 
u4-ba igi-4(disz)-gal2| Then, one-fourth 
ugnim kalam-ma-mu| of the armies of my country 
um-mi-zi| I having mobilized there, 
iti-da u4 3(u)-ka| for one month, for thirty days,
sig4-bi he2-em-mi-du8| I had them make its bricks. 
bad3 gal-bi| That great wall, 
{d}nergal kur erim2 ha-am-se3-se3-ke| May Nergal Level the Enemy Lands For Me  
mu-bi-im| being its name, 
u3-ma mu-bi| by that name in triumph 
gal-bi he2-em-mi-sa4| I called it grandly. 
u4 bad3 gal| When the great wall 
masz-kan2-szabra{ki} mu-du3-a| of Maškan-šapir I built, 
a2 lu2 1(disz)-e| a wage for one man of   
sze 4(ban2) gur-ta| 40 liters each of barley, 
ninda 2(disz) sila3-ta| 2 liters each of bread,  
kasz 2(disz) sila3-ta| 2 liters each of beer, 
i3 2(disz) gin2-ta-am3| 1 liter each of oil, 
u4 1(disz)-a ur5-gin7 szu ha-ba-an-ti| for one day so each received. 
u4 bala du10-ga mu sa6-sa6-ga-ga2-a| During my favorable reign of good years 
sze 3(asz) gur-ta| 3 bushels of barley,  
zu2-lum 1(u) gur-ta| 10 bushels of dates, 
siki 1(u) 5(disz) ma-na-ta| 15 pounds of wool, 
i3-gesz 2(ban2)-ta| 20 liters of sesame oil, 
i3-szah2 4(ban2)-ta| or 40 liters of lard, 
ganba sza3 uri2{ki} larsa{ki}| in the markets of Ur, Larsa, 
u3 ma-da-ga2-ka| and of my (whole) land  
ku3 1(disz) gin2-e| for 1 shekel of silver 
ur5-gin7 ha-ba-ra-sa10| thus could be bought. 
{d}suen-i-din-na-am| Sîn-iddinam, 
lugal nam-lugal-a-ni| the king whose kingship 
kur-ra diri-ga-me-en| surpasses that in (all) the lands,  
gu3-de2-a iri-na| the called one(?) of his city,
u4-ba masz-kan2-szabra{ki}| at that time, Maškan-šapir   
ki du10-ga| the good place, 
suhusz-bi he2-em-mi-ge-en| its fundations I made firm. 
diri lugal szu IGI-DU-| More than the kingly predecessors  
mu-ne-sze3| of mine, 
ki-tusz-bi he2-em-mi-dagal| I broadened its residential areas.  
sza3 iri{ki}-ba hu-mu-ba-al| I dug out into the heart of that city, 
ug3-ug3-bi| (and so) I let its population 
a du10 hu-mu-ne-nag| have fresh water to drink. 
ki-tusz ne-ha| Peaceful residences 
NIM IRI si he2-em-mi-sa4| I set out in orderly fashion in the upper city(?). 
u4-ba nig2-si-sa2| At that time, justice 
du11-ga hu-mu-ni-szum2-mu| I was promulgating by (my) commands, 
nig2-gi-na| and laws  
inim-ta hu-mu-ni-gar| I establshed by (my) words. 
sza3 {d}utu lugal-ga2-ke4| (Thus) the heart of my king Utu 
hu-mu-du10| I indeed gladdened. 
libir bi2-gal2-la| that silver which is the outstanding debt 
u3 {d}nanna-za3-en simug ku3 la2-bi| the smith who weighed its silver

1(ban2) ninda 2(disz) gin2 i3 2(disz) gin2 naga| 1 ban2 of bread, 2 shekels of oil, 2 shekels of potash,
3(disz) sa sum| 3 strings of onions:
i3-li2-KAL gaba-asz| Ili-dan, outbound journey.
szunigin 3(disz) kasz-dida gin| 1(ban2) Total: 3 (dug-vessels) of ordinary quality beer extract, 1 ban2 (each).
szunigin 1(ban2) la2 1(disz) sila3 kasz szunigin 3(ban2) ninda| Total: 1 ban2 minus 1 sila3 of beer. Total: 3 ban2 of bread.
szunigin 6(disz) gin2 i3 szunigin 6(disz) gin2 naga| Total: 6 shekels of oil. Total: 6 shekels of potash.
szunigin 1(u) la2 1(disz) sa sum| Total: 9 strings of onions.
u4 1(u) 3(disz)-kam iti szu-numun| 13th day. Month: “Sowing”.
mu us2-sa {d}szu-{d}suen lugal-e bad3 mar-tu mu-du3| Year after the year: “Šu-Suen, the king, built the Martu wall”.
3(gesz2) 2(u) gu2 esir2 had2| 200 talents of dry bitumen,
esir2 ma2 gul-la| bitumen of a dismantled boat,
ur-{d}bil3| (belonging to) Ur-Gilgameš(?);
1(gesz2) 1(u) gu2 esir2 gul-gul| 70 talents of crushed bitumen,
e2-szu-tum gu2 i7-da ensi2-ka-ta| from the storehouse on the bank of the Ensi canal.
giri3 ur-am3-ma| responsibility of Ur-ama
u3 szesz-kal-la szu-i| and Šeš-kala, the barber;
3(u) gu2 esir2 had2| 30 talents of dry bitumen,
5(ban2) sila3 i3 ku6| 50 sila3 of fish-oil,
2(asz) 2(barig) 3(ban2) esir2 e2-a| 2 gur 2 barig 3 ban2 of construction bitumen,
ki lugal-nir-gal2-ta| from Lugal-nirgal;
4(u) 2(disz) {gesz}u3 hi-a| 42 planks:
ma2 du8-a| that which caulks a boat.
iti diri| Month: “Extra”.
mu sza-asz-ru-um ba-hul| Year: “Šašrum was destroyed”.
1(esze3) gan2 tug2-gurx(SZE.KIN)| 1 esze3 (which is worked with) a breaking-plow 
1/2(iku) 1/4(iku) GAN2 gesz a-ra2 3(disz) 4(iku) 1/2(iku) GAN2-ta| (at) ¾ iku (per day, and) harrowed 3 times at 4½ iku per (day):
a2 erin2-na-bi u4 4(u) 8(disz)-kam| its laborers’ work is 48 days.
2(esze3) GAN2 gesz a-ra2 2(disz) 4(iku) 1/2(iku) GAN2-ta| 2 eše3 (which is) harrowed 2 times at 4½ iku per (day):
a2 erin2-na-bi u4 2(u) 4(disz)-kam| its laborers’ work is 24 days.
a-sza3 gi-apin-ku5-ra2| Field: Gi-apin-kudra
ugula lugal-ku3-zu| Overseer: Lugal-kuzu
kiszib3 nu-ur2-{d}iszkur| Seal: Nur-Adad.
mu bad3 mar-tu ba-TU| Year: “The Martu wall was built”.
nu-ur2-{d}iszkur| Nur-Adad,
dub-sar| scribe,
dumu a-hu-du10| son of Ahu-tab.
3(u) udu sa2-du11 {d}gu-la| 30 sheep, regular delivery of Gula,
sza3 uri5{ki}-ma| in Ur,
1(u) 4(disz) udu 1(u) n(disz) u8| 14 rams, 10+n ewes,
1(disz) masz2 n(disz) ud5| 1 billy goat, x [nanny goats],
ba-ug7 mu ur-gir15-ra-sze3| dead, for the dogs,
dingir-ba-ni sipa ur-ra-ke4| Ilum-b¯ani, the dog-handler,
szu ba-ti| received.
zi-ga| Expenditure
ki na-sa6| From Nasag.
iti ki-siki-{d}nin-a-zu min| Month: “Weaving of [Nin]azu, second”.
mu si-mu-ru-um{ki} lu-lu-bum2{ki} a-ra2 1(u) la2 1(disz)-kam-asz ba-hul| Year: “Simurrum (and) Lullubum, for the ninth time, were destroyed”
nam-u-min ip-qa2-tum| The 12-(team) of Ipqatum (Foldi)
